program_0.description: This program captures a highly biosynthetic / proliferative epithelial state, typical of intestinal transit-amplifying (TA) cells that are actively producing ribosomes and metabolic enzymes while having shut down the mucin/secretory gene set characteristic of differentiated goblet or surface mucous cells. Evidence: • Strong positive enrichment for ribosomal small and large-subunit genes (e.g. RPL3, RPLP0, RPS6, RPS18), translation factors (EEF1A1, EEF1B2, EEF1D), and mitochondrial electron-transport components (UQCRH, COX7C, NDUFA4) indicates high global protein-synthesis and energy demand typical of cycling/TA cells. • Additional proliferation-linked or housekeeping genes (TMSB10, PFN1, GAPDH, FTH1/FTL) further mark a metabolically active, undifferentiated epithelial population. • Genes that define mature secretory intestinal epithelium are negatively loaded: mucins (MUC1, MUC2, MUC13), trefoil factor TFF1, goblet markers ZG16, FCGBP, LYPD8, and CEACAM5. Their repression is expected in TA cells that have not yet adopted secretory lineage programs. • Negative loading of immune-presentation genes (B2M, HLA-E) and interferon-stimulated genes (IFI27, ISG15) is consistent with early epithelial progenitors, which express lower MHC class I and ISG levels than differentiated cells. Inconsistencies: • The module lacks classical intestinal stem-cell markers such as LGR5 or ASCL2, suggesting it reflects the immediate proliferative progeny (TA cells) rather than true stem cells. • The ribosome/translation signature is not unique to intestinal epithelium and can appear in any highly proliferative cell type; additional lineage markers outside this module would be needed for unambiguous tissue assignment.

program_1.description: The program represents a robust type I interferon–stimulated gene (ISG) response, characteristic of cells that have sensed viral infection or exogenous interferon and entered an antiviral state. Evidence: • Canonical ISGs: ISG15, IFIT1/2/3, IFI6/27/35/44/44L, MX1/2, OAS1/2/3, RSAD2 (Viperin), IFITM1/3, LY6E and CMPK2 are well-established targets of the STAT1/STAT2–IRF9 complex activated by IFN-α/β. • Antiviral effectors: MX1/2 (blocks viral replication), OAS1/2/3 (activates RNase L), RSAD2, IFITM1/3 (inhibits viral entry), and IFIT proteins (cap-snatch discrimination) collectively define an antiviral state. • Apoptotic/immune-modulatory ISGs: TNFSF10 (TRAIL), XAF1, EPSTI1, UBE2L6 and HERC6 are induced by interferon to promote immune signaling and controlled cell death during infection. • Membrane and signaling modulators such as PLSCR1 and LY6E further support an interferon-primed phenotype. Inconsistencies: • No notable conflicting genes; all listed genes align with a type I interferon response.

program_2.description: The gene set is most consistent with intestinal/colonic epithelial cells (or colorectal-like tumor cells) that are experiencing an interferon-driven activation state characterized by heightened MHC class I antigen-presentation and modest suppression of mitochondrial/house-keeping gene expression. Evidence: • Epithelial / intestinal identity – EPCAM, CEACAM5, CLDN4, CLDN7, MUC13, SDCBP2 and PRSS3 are classical markers of absorptive/glandular epithelium of the colon and are frequently up-regulated in colorectal adenocarcinoma. • Interferon / inflammatory activation – ISG20, IL32 and SAT1 are interferon-stimulated genes; concomitant strong up-regulation of HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C and HLA-E indicates an IFN-γ–induced MHC-I antigen-presentation program. • Stress / metabolic shift – Negative loading of mitochondrial transcripts (MT-ND1, MT-CO3, MT-CYB) and the housekeeping gene EEF1A1 suggests cells in this program down-regulate oxidative phosphorylation and global translation, a common feature of interferon-stimulated epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • Few clear contradictions; genes such as ASS1 and RHOC are broadly expressed stress/metabolic genes but do not conflict with an interferon-stimulated epithelial profile.

program_3.description: The gene set profiles a type I interferon–driven antiviral program operating in epithelial cells (e.g., airway/alveolar epithelium). The program is characterized by strong induction of classical interferon-stimulated genes together with epithelial-specific junction/secretory markers, while genes typical of professional antigen-presenting or myeloid cells are concurrently suppressed. Evidence: • Interferon response genes up-regulated: OASL, IRF7, USP18, TRIM22, RTP4, SLFN5, BST2 – hallmark ISGs induced by type I IFN signaling during viral infection. • Epithelial identity genes up-regulated: CLDN3 (tight-junction claudin), GPRC5A (airway/alveolar epithelial marker), LCN2 (secreted by epithelial cells), supporting a non-hematopoietic epithelial source. • Pro-inflammatory/autophagy components up-regulated: IL32 (cytokine), SQSTM1/p62 (stress-induced autophagy adaptor), consistent with an epithelial stress/antiviral state. • Antigen-presentation/myeloid genes down-regulated: CD74, HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1 (MHC-II complex) and LYZ (myeloid lysosomal enzyme), fitting the absence of professional APC features in epithelial cells and highlighting a shift away from MHC-II expression. Inconsistencies: • LCN2 and IL32 can also be produced by neutrophils or activated immune cells; however, their known expression in inflamed epithelium aligns with the overall epithelial interferon program. • No major genes directly contradict the epithelial interferon interpretation.

program_4.description: The gene set represents a generic G2/M-phase cell-cycle program that marks actively proliferating cells, independent of lineage. Evidence: • Canonical G2/M regulators – MKI67, TOP2A, PTTG1, CDKN3, CKS2, BIRC5, CENPF, CENPW – are maximally expressed during late S phase through mitosis. • Microtubule/mitotic spindle components – STMN1 and TUBA1B – support chromosome segregation and spindle dynamics in M phase. • Chromatin-associated proteins elevated during replication and mitosis – HMGB1, HMGB2, HMGN2 – facilitate DNA packaging and repair in dividing cells. • ARL6IP1, although less specific, is frequently co-up-regulated with proliferation signatures in single-cell data sets. Inconsistencies: • No strongly discordant genes are present; all listed genes are compatible with a proliferative G2/M state.

program_5.description: The gene set reflects a mature absorptive colon enterocyte (“colonocyte”) program specialized for electrolyte and fluid transport. Evidence: • Electrolyte/water transport machinery of colonocytes: SLC26A3 (Cl⁻/HCO₃⁻ exchanger DRA), SLC9A3 (NHE3), CA4 (carbonic anhydrase IV), CLCA4 (chloride channel accessory), and AQP8 (water channel). • Colon-restricted markers: CEACAM7 and PRAP1 are highly expressed in normal colonic epithelium and largely absent from other tissues. • Secreted intestinal peptide: GUCA2A (uroguanylin) is produced by mature intestinal epithelium, especially colon, to regulate luminal fluid via GC-C signaling. • Differentiated brush-border/absorptive features: ANPEP (CD13), CES2, and FABP1 encode apical peptidase, carboxylesterase, and lipid-binding protein typical of mature enterocytes. Inconsistencies: • FABP1 is also abundant in hepatocytes, and SLC26A2 is better known in cartilage; however, both have documented, albeit lower, expression in intestinal epithelium and do not conflict strongly with a colonocyte identity.

program_6.description: The gene set is most consistent with an intestinal epithelial “wound-associated / transitional” program seen in KRT8⁺ regenerative enterocytes that appear after injury and during epithelial restitution. These cells co-express markers of mature colon epithelium (KRT20, FABP1) together with stress- and progenitor-associated factors (ID1/ID3, LGALS3, S100A6), reflecting a transient, dedifferentiated state that bridges crypt progenitors and fully mature absorptive cells. Evidence: • Mature intestinal/colon epithelium: KRT20, FABP1, PHGR1 – classical markers of differentiated enterocytes and colon epithelial cells. • Epithelial identity: KRT8, MYL6 – cytoskeletal genes enriched in simple epithelia and specifically up-regulated in the KRT8⁺ “wound” population. • Regeneration / injury response: ID1, ID3 (progenitor and early response TFs induced by BMP/TGF-β signaling); LGALS3 and S100A6 – lectin and S100 protein up-regulated during epithelial stress and restitution. • Metabolic support for high energy demand during repair: CKB (creatine kinase) provides rapid ATP buffering in regenerating epithelia. • HRCT1 (also reported as LECT1) shows enriched expression in inflamed or regenerating gut epithelium. Inconsistencies: • Lack of classical crypt stem-cell markers (e.g., LGR5, OLFM4) indicates these cells are not true stem cells but rather a post-progenitor transitional population.

program_7.description: The program represents a classical “immediate-early” activation response, seen when diverse cell types experience acute stimulation (e.g., growth factors, mechanical stress, antigen or neuronal activation). It is marked by rapid, transient induction of AP-1 family transcription factors and other early response genes, indicating cells that were recently activated rather than a distinct lineage. Evidence: • AP-1 complex members FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB and partner ATF3 are canonical immediate-early genes induced within minutes of mitogenic, inflammatory, or neuronal signals. • EGR1 and IER2 are stimulus-dependent transcription factors that follow the same rapid, transcription-independent induction kinetics. • BTG2 is a well-known early response gene that couples activation to cell-cycle control. • ANKRD37 is up-regulated by hypoxia and other stress pathways, fitting with a generalized acute-stress program. Inconsistencies: • No obvious conflicting markers; all listed genes coherently belong to an immediate-early activation module.

program_8.description: This program represents a “metallothionein-high stress response” state, a transcriptional module seen across multiple cell types (e.g., macrophages, hepatocytes, epithelial cells) when they experience oxidative or heavy-metal stress and inflammatory cytokine signaling. Evidence: • Strong up-regulation of the entire inducible metallothionein family (MT1G, MT1E, MT1X, MT1F, MT1H, MT1M, MT2A)––classic markers of cellular defense against reactive oxygen species, zinc/copper overload, glucocorticoids, TNF-α, IL-1β, and other stressors. • Co-induction of multiple MT1 isoforms together with MT2A is typical of a coordinated metal-binding antioxidant response rather than of any single lineage-restricted program. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are coherent with a metallothionein-driven stress program.

program_9.description: The program is most consistent with mature absorptive enterocytes of the colonic/intestinal epithelium that exhibit an anti-inflammatory regulatory state. Evidence: • LGALS4 – canonical secreted lectin of differentiated intestinal epithelial cells and a standard marker of colonic enterocytes. • CA1 – cytosolic carbonic anhydrase highly enriched in colon epithelium, involved in epithelial bicarbonate handling. • FABP1 – liver/intestinal fatty-acid–binding protein characteristic of mature absorptive enterocytes. • ETHE1 – mitochondrial persulfide dioxygenase enriched in enterocytes, detoxifying microbiota-derived H₂S. • IL1R2 – decoy IL-1 receptor expressed by colonic epithelial cells to limit mucosal inflammation, indicating a regulatory/anti-inflammatory epithelial state. • Collectively, the co-expression of LGALS4, CA1, FABP1 and ETHE1 strongly points to terminally differentiated intestinal epithelium. Inconsistencies: • TMSB4X is a ubiquitous cytoskeletal regulator and not specific to enterocytes; • HRCT1 has limited characterization and unclear relevance to intestinal tissue; neither conflicts with the overall enterocyte interpretation.

program_10.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature, ion‐transporting intestinal/colonic epithelial (colonocyte) program, characterised by active chloride secretion and xenobiotic metabolism in fully differentiated absorptive cells. Evidence: • CFTR, CHP2 – key components of apical chloride-secreting machinery highly expressed in small- and large-intestinal epithelium; CFTR is a canonical colonocyte marker. • ADH1C, SELENBP1 – phase-I/selenium-binding detoxification enzymes enriched in differentiated enterocytes and colonocytes, reflecting metabolic functions of mature gut epithelium. • ADIRF – expressed in differentiated epithelial cells of the gut (also reported in colon organoids), fitting a non-proliferative, mature state. Inconsistencies: • ADH1C is classically hepatocyte-enriched and ADIRF is reported in adipocytes/airway epithelium, but both have documented expression in intestinal epithelium, so these genes are only mildly atypical rather than contradictory.

program_11.description: The program represents a generalized cellular heat-shock/stress response, characterized by strong up-regulation of molecular chaperones that protect proteins from misfolding and aggregation; it is not specific to any one cell lineage but rather reflects a transient stress-activated state. Evidence: • HSPA1A and HSPA1B (HSP70 family) – classical inducible heat-shock proteins rapidly transcribed upon thermal or proteotoxic stress. • HSP90AA1 (cytosolic HSP90) – stress-inducible chaperone stabilizing unfolded client proteins and coordinating refolding. • DNAJB1 (HSP40 co-chaperone) – partners with HSP70 to stimulate ATPase activity and protein refolding during stress. • HSPB1 (HSP27) – small heat-shock protein that prevents aggregation and participates in cytoprotection during oxidative or heat stress. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are canonical components of the heat-shock chaperone network.

program_12.description: This program reflects a sterol / cholesterol‐biosynthesis (mevalonate-pathway) transcriptional state, classically driven by SREBP2 and commonly up-regulated in rapidly proliferating cells that require new membrane synthesis (e.g., cycling epithelial, cancer, or activated immune cells). Evidence: • HMGCS1 – catalyzes condensation of acetyl-CoA and acetoacetyl-CoA, initiating the mevalonate pathway. • MVD & FDPS – successive enzymes producing isopentenyl- and farnesyl-diphosphate, core intermediates for cholesterol and prenylation. • SQLE – converts squalene to 2,3-oxidosqualene, the committed step toward sterol formation. • MSMO1 – performs C-14 demethylation in later cholesterol-biosynthetic steps. Collectively, these enzymes span early, middle, and late stages of the cholesterol pathway, matching a coordinated SREBP2-mediated lipid-biosynthesis program typical of proliferative states. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes belong to the same biochemical pathway and support the assigned program.

program_0.description: The gene set is most consistent with a CXCL12-high, CD34⁺, LEPR⁺ perivascular/adventitial fibroblast (mesenchymal stromal) program that builds extracellular matrix and produces niche/angiogenic factors, typical of the stromal cells that line blood vessels and support hematopoietic or epithelial compartments. Evidence: • Perivascular/adventitial fibroblast & mesenchymal-stromal identity – CD34, CXCL12, LEPR, RSPO3, ACKR4, ACE, RAMP2, ANGPTL1, PI16, PDGFR-associated ECM genes (DCN, FBN1, TNXB, MFAP5, FBLN1/2) and complement factors (C3, C1R) are signature markers of CXCL12-abundant reticular cells and vascular adventitial fibroblasts. • ECM-production/remodeling state – High decorin (DCN), tenascin (TNXB), fibulins (FBLN1/2), PRELP, PCOLCE2, TIMP3, ADAMTSL4, HTRA1, SFRP1/2 and WNT2B denote active secretion and organization of interstitial matrix. • Stem/progenitor or niche activity – IGFBP6, CILP, SFRP1/2, RSPO3 and WNT2B modulate Wnt/IGF signaling that maintains progenitor niches; CLEC3B, CLDN11 and GPC3 are enriched in stromal cells that foster vascular or hematopoietic niches. • Low CXCL14 and HAAO (negatively loaded) – CXCL14 is typically high in quiescent dermal fibroblasts but low in CXCL12⁺ vascular fibroblasts, supporting the assignment; HAAO down-regulation is likewise seen in activated stromal cells. Inconsistencies: • S100A4 (fibroblast activation) and PPL/KRT24 (epithelial structural proteins) are present but can be expressed at low levels in stromal cells and do not outweigh the dominant perivascular fibroblast signature. • GPNMB is more common in myeloid or osteogenic cells but is also reported in certain stromal fibroblasts.

program_1.description: This program reflects a “high translation / ribosome-biogenesis” state seen in rapidly growing, metabolically active but non-stressed cells. Nearly every positively loaded gene encodes a cytosolic ribosomal protein or a core translation factor, while mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation transcripts are inversely correlated, indicating that cells scoring high for this program allocate resources to cytoplasmic protein synthesis and display low mitochondrial RNA content typical of healthy, proliferative cells rather than stressed or dying ones. Evidence: • Ribosome/translation up-regulation ─ dense enrichment of cytosolic ribosomal protein genes (RPL10, RPS18, RPL13A, RPS6, RPL32, RPS14, RPL27A, RPLP0, etc.), together with EEF1A1 and RACK1, is the canonical signature of ribosome biogenesis and active mRNA translation. • Biosynthetic/activation co-factors ─ FAU (ubiquitin-like ribosomal fusion protein), TMSB4X (supports actin dynamics during growth), and MIF (chaperone/cytokine that stabilises p53 and supports cell survival) commonly rise in proliferating or recently activated cells. • Low mitochondrial transcript content ─ strong negative loadings for MT-ATP6, MT-CO2/3, MT-CYB, MT-ND1/3/4/5 and MT-ATP8 denote reduced proportion of mitochondrial RNA; this is characteristic of healthy, non-stressed cells and contrasts with the high mitochondrial read fraction often seen in apoptotic or energetically stressed cells. • JUND, a stress-responsive/AP-1 factor, is negatively loaded, further supporting a low-stress cellular context. Inconsistencies: • TMSB4X and MIF can also rise in immune activation or migration states, which are not specifically addressed by the rest of the gene set, but their presence does not conflict with a general high-translation program.

program_2.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated mural-cell program, typical of pericytes/arteriolar smooth-muscle cells engaged in angiogenesis and hypoxic stress. Evidence: • Canonical mural-cell markers – PDGFRB, RGS5, CSPG4 (NG2), NOTCH3, EDNRA, MCAM, COL4A1/2, COL18A1 – define pericytes and vascular smooth-muscle cells. • Notch signalling axis – NOTCH3 together with JAG1, HEY2, HEYL, HES4 – characterises arteriolar/pericyte maturation and remodelling. • Angiogenic/hypoxia response – NDUFA4L2, COX4I2, HIGD1B, ANGPT2, FOXS1, APOLD1, PLXDC1 – are induced in mural cells under low O₂ and during new-vessel sprouting. • Cell–cell/ECM interaction genes – ESAM, GJA4, GJC1 (connexins), COL4A1/2, COL18A1, EGFLAM, CDH6 – support a role in vessel wall stabilisation and communication with endothelial cells. • KATP-channel subunits (KCNJ8, ABCC9) and regulators of lipid uptake (CD36, LPL) are frequently enriched in contractile, metabolically active pericytes. Inconsistencies: • A few genes (e.g. LPL, CD36) are also expressed in macrophages/adipocytes, but these are known secondary features of metabolically active pericytes and do not outweigh the dominant mural-cell signature.

program_3.description: The program is characteristic of mural cells—vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and closely related pericytes—in a highly contractile state. Evidence: • Canonical contractile apparatus: ACTA2, MYH11, ACTG2, MYL9, MYL6, MYLK, TPM2, TAGLN, LMOD1, CNN1, DES and PPP1R14A collectively define mature, contractile smooth muscle. • Cytoskeletal / focal-adhesion support: FLNA, CAV1, CAV2, CAP2, SORBS2, NET1, ITGA7, CSRP1/2 and CRIP2 are enriched in VSMCs and enable force transmission to the extracellular matrix. • Vascular/pericyte markers and matrix interactors: SPARCL1, FRZB, NPNT, CRIM1, TINAGL1, C1QTNF1 and BCAM are typical of mural cells that line vessels and modulate endothelial contacts. • Signalling typical of mural cells: PTGIR (prostacyclin receptor), PLN (calcium handling), FOXS1 (mesenchymal lineage), TMEM38B (smooth-muscle TRIC channel) and PPP1R12B (myosin phosphatase targeting subunit) support a contractile phenotype. • Additional genes occasionally observed in smooth muscle sub-types (e.g., SNCG, OR51E1, NTRK2, LINGO1) are reported in gastrointestinal, airway or perivascular smooth muscle, consistent with tissue-specific mural cell programs. Inconsistencies: • Neuron-associated genes (NTRK2, LINGO1, SERPINI1) and the olfactory receptor OR51E1 are atypical for generic VSMCs, but their documented expression in specialized smooth-muscle populations suggests tissue-specific rather than contradictory signals.

program_4.description: The gene constellation is most consistent with an activated, perivascular PDGFRA-positive mesenchymal/fibroblast program—akin to tissue-resident mesenchymal stem or stromal cells (MSCs) that are responding to developmental (BMP/WNT/HH) and vascular cues and that often emerge as “activated fibroblasts” or niche-forming cells in wound repair and tumours. Evidence: • Core mesenchymal / fibroblast markers: PDGFRA, PDGFD, POSTN, TM4SF1, EMID1, COL4A5, COL4A6, IGFBP3, AGT, CEBPD, GADD45G. • Developmental morphogen signalling typical of stromal progenitors: BMP2/4/5, NBL1, WNT5B, PTCH1, KREMEN1, FOXF1, DLL1, SCUBE2. • Perivascular / coagulation and extracellular‐matrix-remodelling genes seen in niche fibroblasts: F3, F2R, PLAT, CXCL14, CXCR4, F3, POSTN. • Stem/progenitor or MSC-associated surface proteins: PROM1 (CD133), TM4SF1, PDGFRA, TMEM119, TSPAN33. • Chemokine/cytokine milieu shaping wound-repair or tumour stroma: TSLP, CXCL14, SEMA4D, IGFBP3, PTGDR2. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal or neural-crest associated genes (NSG1, TRPA1, SLITRK6, C1QL1) and microglial marker TMEM119 are atypical for fibroblasts, suggesting either minor contamination, shared developmental origin, or cross-program co-activation. • Immune-skewing factors such as PTGDR2 (CRTH2) and TSLP are more typical of epithelial/immune cells but can be expressed by activated stroma in inflammatory settings.

program_5.description: The gene set is most consistent with peripheral‐nerve Schwann cells that retain a myelinating signature yet have transitioned into an injury/repair–associated, antigen-presenting state. Evidence: • Classical Schwann-cell and myelin structural genes: MPZ, PMP22, LGI4, ERBB3, HAND2, GPM6B, S100B, CD9, PLP1, MATN2. • Repair/injury-induced Schwann-cell factors: METRN, SPP1, FSTL3, CLU, VWA1, CTNNAL1. • Antigen-presentation machinery up-regulated in repair Schwann cells: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DMA, CD74, ARHGAP15, CD59. • Additional glial/axon-interaction or adhesion genes typical of Schwann cells: NRXN1, NTM, ANK3, PRNP, RDX. Inconsistencies: • ALDH1A1 (more characteristic of certain astrocytes or fibroblasts) and SCN7A/FXYD1 (neuronal or cardiac enriched) are less typical for Schwann cells but can emerge at low levels in peripheral glia; overall they do not outweigh the dominant Schwann-cell/repair signature.

program_6.description: The gene set represents a robust NF-κB/TNF-α–induced “inflammatory-SASP” program typically seen in stressed or senescent stromal/epithelial cells (e.g., fibroblasts or keratinocytes). Cells carrying this program secrete neutrophil-attracting chemokines and matrix-remodeling enzymes while mounting oxidative-stress and metabolic-rewiring responses. Evidence: • Secreted neutrophil chemokines (CXCL1, CXCL3, CXCL5, CXCL6, CXCL8/IL8) – canonical SASP factors driven by NF-κB signaling. • Matrix remodeling/ECM genes (MMP1, MMP3, COL7A1, CHI3L1) – hallmarks of tissue-remodeling arm of the SASP. • Stress-response and antioxidant genes (FTH1, SOD2, MT2A) – up-regulated in senescent cells to cope with iron load and ROS. • Metabolic rewiring genes (SLC16A3/MCT4, NAMPT, SAT1, GK) – support glycolytic shift and NAD⁺ salvage observed in senescence. • Immediate-early/inflammatory regulators (IER3, IL24) – induced by TNF-α/IL-1 and reported components of the SASP secretome. Inconsistencies: • COL7A1 is most abundant in skin keratinocytes/basement membrane, suggesting the program may be enriched in cutaneous stromal/epithelial contexts rather than universally across all fibroblasts. • GK and CHI3L1 are not classic SASP “core” genes, though both can be secondary metabolic or inflammatory respondents.

program_7.description: The gene set is most consistent with an adventitial / perivascular fibroblast program that is specialized for extracellular-matrix remodeling and complement- and lipid-handling functions (often referred to as ADAMDEC1⁺/APOE⁺ “lipofibroblasts”). These fibroblasts are TCF21-driven, secrete elastic-fiber and microfibrillar components, and release complement factors and apolipoproteins, indicating a tissue-protective, immune-modulatory state rather than a highly proliferative one (PTMA is negatively loaded). Evidence: • Fibroblast lineage / transcriptional driver – TCF21, MFAP4, FBLN5, MATN2, LTBP4 (classic adventitial or interstitial fibroblast markers). • ECM-remodeling and elastic fiber assembly – FBLN5, MFAP4, MATN2, LTBP4, MFAP4, C1S (serine protease modulating ECM). • Complement & immune modulation – C1S, CFH, ADAMDEC1 (secreted protease enriched in ADAMDEC1⁺ fibroblasts), APOE. • Lipid transport / metabolism typical of lipofibroblasts – APOE, PLTP, ABCA6, ABCA8, PLPP3. • Low proliferation signature – PTMA negatively loaded, supporting a quiescent, secretory fibroblast state. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal-biased transcripts NOVA1 and MAPK10, and leukocyte-associated ADAM28 are atypical for fibroblasts and may reflect low-level ambient RNA or cross-cell contamination.

program_8.description: The gene ensemble is most consistent with a cardiomyocyte program that couples canonical cardiac/striated-muscle identity with a generalized oxidative- or stress-response state, pointing to ventricular/atrial myocytes undergoing metabolic or remodeling stress rather than a distinct non-muscle lineage. Evidence: • Cardiac/striated-muscle identity – LDB3 (Z-disc protein ZASP), RBPMS2 (cardiomyocyte RNA-binding marker), DMPK (myotonic-dystrophy kinase), KCNA5 (Kv1.5 potassium channel enriched in atrial myocytes), RRAD and AKAP1 (highly expressed in heart/skeletal muscle), plus muscle-associated transporter SLC7A2 together specify striated muscle, particularly cardiomyocytes. • Stress / remodeling signature – MT1M/MT1X/MT1E (metallothioneins), GADD45B, CDKN1A, TSC22D1, RCAN2 (calcineurin inhibitor) and MTHFD2 (mitochondrial one-carbon metabolism up-regulated in stressed or proliferating cells) collectively mark oxidative, DNA-damage or hypertrophic stress responses typical of remodeling cardiomyocytes. • Cytoskeletal reorganization – ARPC1A (ARP2/3 complex) aligns with actin remodeling seen during cardiomyocyte hypertrophy. Inconsistencies: • NRGN (neuronal calmodulin-binding protein) is primarily neuronal, not cardiac. • ARPC1A and SLC7A2 are broadly expressed and alone are not specific to muscle, though compatible with the stress/remodeling context.

program_9.description: The gene set represents an immediate-early activation / stress-response program that can emerge in diverse cell types shortly after exposure to cytokines, growth factors, mechanical dissociation, or antigen-receptor signaling; it is not lineage-specific but instead reflects a transient, stimulus-induced state marked by AP-1, NF-κB and interferon-responsive transcription factors. Evidence: • AP-1 components (FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB) – canonical immediate-early genes rapidly induced by MAPK signaling during cellular activation or stress. • Early growth-response and adaptive genes (EGR1, IER2, BTG2, ZFP36, PPP1R15A) – typical within minutes of stimulation, mediating transcriptional feedback and mRNA decay. • Cytokine/NF-κB pathway genes (SOCS3, NFKBIZ, IRF1) – induced by IL-6/TNF/IFN signaling, reinforcing that the program is stimulus-driven rather than lineage-defining. • ATF3 – stress-responsive transcription factor often co-expressed with FOS/JUN in activated or dissociated cells. Inconsistencies: No notable inconsistencies; all listed genes coherently fit an immediate-early activation signature.

program_10.description: The gene set reflects a canonical type I interferon–induced antiviral program that can be activated in many cell types (epithelial, immune, stromal) upon viral sensing; it is characterized by strong up-regulation of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) without cell-type-specific markers, indicating an acute interferon response state rather than a distinct lineage identity. Evidence: • Global ISGs: ISG15, IFI44L, IFI27, IFI6 – hallmark genes rapidly induced by IFN-α/β signaling. • Antiviral effectors: MX1, MX2 (dynamin-like GTPases blocking viral replication); OAS1, OAS3 (activate RNase L to degrade viral RNA); IFIT1, IFIT2, IFIT3 (bind uncapped/viral RNAs, inhibit translation). • Interferon-regulated GTPase: GBP4 – up-regulated downstream of STAT1/2 signaling in viral defense pathways. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are prototypical ISGs and support a uniform type I interferon response signature, with no conflicting lineage-specific transcripts.

program_11.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, chemokine-secreting fibroblast/stromal program (often described as inflammatory or senescence-associated fibroblasts) characterised by strong chemokine output and extracellular-matrix remodelling activity. Evidence: • Chemokine cluster (CCL2, CCL8, CCL11, CCL13) – classical products of activated fibroblasts that recruit monocytes, eosinophils and other immune cells; frequently reported in “inflammatory” or SASP-like fibroblast subsets. • ECM / matrix-modifying and adhesion genes (HAPLN1, TFPI2, EDIL3) – canonical fibroblast-derived structural or protease-regulating factors. • A2M and FABP5 – secreted protease inhibitor and lipid-handling protein, respectively, enriched in activated or stress-responsive mesenchymal cells. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal adhesion and regeneration genes STMN2 and CHL1 are atypical for fibroblasts; they may reflect low-level neuronal contamination, doublets or a minor sub-population with neural-crest lineage features.

program_12.description: The gene set is most consistent with a COL14A1⁺/IGF1⁺ extracellular-matrix-secreting fibroblast program typical of “adventitial” or “IGF1-high” stromal fibroblasts that reside around blood vessels and become prominent as trophic or cancer-associated fibroblasts. Evidence: • Matrix/structural fibroblast markers – COL14A1, SVEP1, ABI3BP, SRPX are canonical extracellular-matrix genes enriched in adventitial and vascular-associated fibroblasts. • Growth-factor output – IGF1 and its carrier IGFBP4 are hallmarks of IGF1-high fibroblasts that provide paracrine support to neighboring cells. • Guidance/angiocrine factors – SLIT3 and IGSF10 are secreted stromal proteins produced by perivascular fibroblasts to regulate vessel and axon guidance. • Additional stromal/CAF signatures – CP, PLA2G2A and DCLK1 are repeatedly detected in inflammatory or cancer-associated fibroblast subsets, aligning with a secretory fibroblast state. Inconsistencies: • DCLK1 is best known as an epithelial tuft-cell marker; its presence suggests a minor signal from tuft cells or cross-loading. • CP is classically hepatocyte-derived, though low-level expression in inflammatory fibroblasts has been reported.

program_13.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with an extracellular-matrix–producing, immune-modulatory fibroblast subset (often referred to as CTSK⁺/LUM⁺ “immune-interacting” or “antigen-presenting” fibroblasts) that is not in a contractile myofibroblast state. Evidence: • Fibroblast/ECM identity – LUM, OLFML3, SERPINF1 and CTSK are well-described markers of stromal fibroblasts that actively remodel matrix; CTSK⁺ fibroblasts have been reported in synovium, lung and periosteum. • Immune-modulatory secretome – RARRES2 (chemerin) and PTGDS (prostaglandin D synthase) encode chemo-attractants and lipid mediators released by inflammatory fibroblasts. • Antigen-processing/IgG-handling genes – FCGRT, NPC2 and TMEM176A are enriched in fibroblast populations that interact with, and present antigen to, immune cells. • Leukocyte-associated cytoskeletal gene LSP1 is frequently up-regulated in “immune-interacting” fibroblasts, supporting a stromal cell engaging with immune milieu. • Absence of the contractile marker TAGLN (negatively loaded) rules out a myofibroblast or smooth-muscle program, fitting a non-contractile fibroblast state. Inconsistencies: • LSP1 and FCGRT are classically leukocyte or endothelial genes; their presence could also arise from low-level immune cell contamination or reflect atypical expression in this fibroblast subset.

program_14.description: The gene set most closely matches an anti-inflammatory / tolerogenic program of mononuclear phagocytes (immature or tissue-resident dendritic cells / macrophages) that modulate T-cell activation and promote immune quiescence. Evidence: • ADAMDEC1 and ADAM28 – secreted ADAM-family metalloproteases highly enriched in intestinal and other tissue macrophages / immature DCs and induced by IL-10–dependent tolerogenic signals. • TMEM176A and TMEM176B – hallmark transmembrane inhibitors of antigen presentation that are up-regulated in tolerogenic or “quiescent” dendritic cells. • PTGER2 – PGE2 receptor EP2; its engagement on macrophages/DCs skews them toward an immunoregulatory phenotype. • HAAO – kynurenine-pathway enzyme expressed in macrophages; contributes to local tryptophan catabolism and immune suppression. • Collectively, these genes constitute a well-described tolerogenic DC/macrophage signature seen in gut lamina propria and other steady-state tissues. Inconsistencies: • STMN2 and ADGRL3 are classically neuronal genes; their presence is atypical for myeloid cells. • PITX1 and FGFR4 are developmental / epithelial factors not normally linked to phagocytes.

program_15.description: The gene set represents a mature intestinal epithelial program, characteristic of differentiated absorptive and secretory (goblet-like) cells of the small/large-bowel mucosa that participate in barrier formation and luminal immune defense. Evidence: • Intestinal/goblet lineage markers – TFF3, AGR2, LGALS4, PHGR1 and PIGR are classical genes of mature intestinal and goblet cells involved in mucus production and IgA transcytosis. • Epithelial identity – EPCAM, KRT8 and CEACAM5 mark simple epithelial sheets lining the gut lumen. • Enterocyte metabolic components – FABP1 (fatty-acid binding protein) and FXYD3 (ion-transport regulator) are enriched in absorptive enterocytes, supporting a differentiated intestinal epithelial state. Inconsistencies: • No strong contradictions; most genes coherently point to mature intestinal epithelium.

program_16.description: The gene set reflects an activated, extracellular-matrix–remodeling fibroblast state—classically termed myofibroblasts or “COL11A1/CTHRC1 cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs)”—characterized by robust collagen production, matrix-modifying enzymes, and pro-migratory signaling. Evidence: • Fibrillar collagens (COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1) – core products of fibroblasts undergoing matrix deposition. • Activation-specific collagens (COL11A1, COL10A1) – hallmark of profibrotic or tumor-associated fibroblasts, rarely expressed in quiescent fibroblasts. • CTHRC1 – secreted protein strongly induced in wound-healing and CAF populations; promotes collagen cross-linking and cell migration. • ADAM12 – metalloprotease up-regulated in myofibroblasts, facilitating matrix remodeling and invasion. • ARL4C – small GTPase induced by Wnt/TGF-β signaling, enhances motility of activated fibroblasts. • BHLHE41 – hypoxia/EMT-associated transcription factor enriched in fibroblasts within fibrotic or tumor microenvironments. Inconsistencies: • Minimal; BHLHE41 and ARL4C can also be expressed in certain immune or epithelial cells, but their co-expression with the collagen/ADAM12/CTHRC1 module overwhelmingly supports an activated fibroblast identity.

program_17.description: The program reflects an extracellular-matrix–producing, activated fibroblast / myofibroblast state characteristic of wound healing or fibrotic tissue remodeling. Evidence: • Fibrillar collagens COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1, COL5A1/2, COL6A3 and FACIT collagen COL12A1 – classical products of fibroblasts undergoing matrix deposition during fibrosis and scar formation. • FN1 (fibronectin) – major ECM glycoprotein secreted by activated fibroblasts and required for collagen fibrillogenesis. • POSTN (periostin) – hallmark of myofibroblasts, cancer-associated fibroblasts and fibrotic stroma; promotes collagen cross-linking and tissue stiffening. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes contradict a fibroblast/myofibroblast identity; absence of canonical contractile genes (e.g., ACTA2, TAGLN) means the program emphasizes matrix synthesis rather than cytoskeletal activation, but this is not inconsistent with an ECM-secreting fibroblast state.

program_18.description: This program most closely matches a contractile vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) state characterized by cytoskeletal organization, actomyosin contractility, and ion-channel activity that regulates vascular tone. Evidence: • Canonical contractile VSMC transcription factor – MYOCD (myocardin) is the master co-activator of SRF driving smooth-muscle–specific gene expression. • Structural/contractile apparatus – TPM1 (tropomyosin 1) and LPP (LIM domain cytoskeletal protein) stabilize actin filaments typical of differentiated smooth muscle; SLMAP associates with the sarcolemma in muscle cells. • Vascular tone regulators – KCNMB1 encodes the β1 subunit of large-conductance Ca²⁺-activated K⁺ channels highly enriched in arterial smooth muscle; AOC3 (VAP-1) is abundant on vascular smooth muscle and modulates amine-dependent vasoconstriction. • Adhesion/migration proteins typical of quiescent VSMC – SORBS1 links integrins to the actin cytoskeleton and is expressed in smooth muscle and perivascular fibroblast-like cells. • Stress-response enzyme compatible with metabolically active muscle – MSRB3 reduces oxidized methionine residues, supporting protein integrity during contractile activity. Inconsistencies: No strongly contradictory genes are present; MSRB3 and SORBS1 are more ubiquitous but are reported in smooth muscle, so their inclusion is not discordant with the overall VSMC contractile program.

program_19.description: The program represents a generic HIF-1α–driven hypoxia response characterized by a metabolic shift toward glycolysis, induction of autophagy/mitophagy, and secretion of pro-angiogenic or pro-survival factors; it is compatible with many cell types experiencing low oxygen rather than a lineage-restricted state. Evidence: • Glycolytic switch – ENO1 and GAPDH are classic glycolytic enzymes transcriptionally up-regulated by HIF-1α under hypoxia. • Canonical HIF-1α target genes – BNIP3 (hypoxia-induced mitophagy), DDIT4/REDD1 (inhibits mTOR during oxygen stress), HILPDA (lipid droplet protein induced in hypoxia), ANGPTL4 and STC1 (secreted factors promoting angiogenesis and survival) are all well-validated direct targets of HIF signaling. • Stress/secretory component – IL11 is induced by hypoxia in stromal and tumor cells and contributes to survival signaling, matching the broader stress-adaptation theme. Inconsistencies: • No marked inconsistencies; all listed genes fit a coherent hypoxia/HIF-1α response signature.

program_20.description: The gene set most closely matches an adipose-lineage stromal cell or early pre-adipocyte program characterized by initiation of lipid uptake/handling and secretion of IGF-modulating factors rather than a fully mature lipid-laden adipocyte. Evidence: • Lipid transport / uptake typical of adipocyte precursors – CD36 (fatty-acid translocase), STEAP4 (metalloreductase strongly induced during adipogenic differentiation and metabolic stress). • Adipose-stromal or pre-adipocyte secretome – IGFBP2 and IGFBP7 (classically produced by adipose progenitors to modulate IGF signaling and insulin sensitivity). • Mesenchymal / stromal identity – SMOC2 (matricellular protein enriched in mesenchymal stem cells and adipose stromal vascular fraction) and INPP4B (phosphatase that promotes PI3K–AKT signaling during adipocyte commitment). • Additional surface enzyme found in adipose stromal vascular cells – CPM (carboxypeptidase M, reported on adipose-derived mesenchymal cells and pre-adipocytes). Inconsistencies: • CPM is more frequently noted in monocyte-macrophage lineages; its presence suggests either stromal vascular heterogeneity or low-level macrophage contamination, but it is also documented in adipose progenitors, so conflict is limited.

program_21.description: The gene set represents a generic cell-cycle/proliferation program characteristic of cells in late S phase through G2/M, seen in any actively dividing population such as progenitors, cycling immune cells, or tumor cells rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • S-phase nucleotide biosynthesis/DNA replication – TYMS, TK1, PCLAF (PCNA-associated), CKS2 • G2/M chromosome and spindle regulation – PTTG1 (securin), CENPW (centromere component), STMN1 (microtubule destabilizer) • Concerted up-regulation of multiple canonical cell-cycle regulators without lineage-specific markers supports a proliferation state rather than a differentiated identity. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are canonically linked to cell-cycle progression.

program_22.description: The program best fits a hypoxia-responsive, contact-forming astrocyte state (e.g., perivascular or reactive astrocytes) characterized by glial-specific adhesion molecules and an active HIF2 (EPAS1) pathway. Evidence: • Astrocyte surface/adhesion genes – ATP1B2 (AMOG) and the glial isoform of NFASC support astrocyte-axon and astrocyte-vascular contacts. • EPAS1 (HIF-2α) marks cells experiencing or sensing low O₂; perivascular and reactive astrocytes up-regulate EPAS1 during hypoxia or inflammation. • TBX2 is a T-box transcription factor enriched in proliferative radial glia/astrocyte precursors and in reactive astrocytes, consistent with an activated state. • PLCE1 participates in PLC-ε signaling implicated in Ca²⁺/inositol phosphate pathways used by astrocytes for neurovascular coupling. • The overall combination of glial adhesion/ion-homeostasis genes (ATP1B2, NFASC), hypoxia response (EPAS1) and glial lineage TF (TBX2) coherently points to hypoxia-responsive astrocytes. Inconsistencies: • NFASC is also expressed in neurons, and EPAS1 is common in endothelial cells; absence of canonical astrocyte markers (e.g., GFAP, AQP4) reduces specificity.

program_23.description: The program most closely reflects mesenchymal stromal / fibroblast cells that have been exposed to an inflammatory (likely IFN-γ) milieu, leading to strong induction of MHC class I antigen-presentation genes alongside canonical fibroblast-secreted factors. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C and their light-chain partner B2M form the core MHC-I complex; all are sharply up-regulated by IFN-γ. • Stromal identity: IGFBP7 and FRZB are secreted proteins highly expressed by fibroblasts, synovial- and cartilage-like mesenchymal cells, and are not typical of hematopoietic or epithelial lineages. • Combination of the two sets (MHC-I + fibroblast markers) is characteristic of “antigen-presenting fibroblasts” described in inflamed tissues and tumors following cytokine exposure. Inconsistencies: • The program lacks other canonical interferon-stimulated genes (e.g., ISG15, IFITs); however, selective up-regulation of MHC-I genes by IFN-γ without the full ISG repertoire has been reported. • FRZB does not directly participate in antigen presentation, but its strong enrichment in mesenchymal cells is compatible with the proposed fibroblast context.

program_24.description: The gene set most strongly points to a “clear-cell, lipid-laden epithelial” program classically seen in renal clear-cell–like states (e.g. clear-cell renal epithelial cells/tumours or other epithelia that accumulate neutral lipids and are HIF-responsive). The program couples neutral-lipid droplet formation, iron sequestration and extracellular acid–base control, features that collectively give the cytoplasm a clear, vacuolated appearance. Evidence: • PLIN2 and G0S2 – key regulators of neutral-lipid droplet biogenesis and storage; both are highly up-regulated in clear-cell renal epithelium and other lipid-rich “clear” epithelia. • CA12 – membrane carbonic anhydrase strongly induced by HIF1α in clear-cell renal carcinoma and used diagnostically for this cell type; supports pH regulation in hypoxic, glycolytic cells. • FTL – ferritin light chain; clear-cell renal cells show pronounced iron sequestration and ferritin expression, reflecting altered iron metabolism. • NMB – neuromedin B, frequently co-expressed with CA12 and PLIN2 in clear-cell renal carcinoma and other clear-cell epithelia, providing an additional epithelial/secretory signal. Inconsistencies: • The set lacks classic adipocyte markers (e.g. PLIN1, FABP4, ADIPOQ), so a bona-fide adipocyte identity is less likely despite the lipid-storage genes. • NMB is also a neuroendocrine peptide; its presence is not strictly specific for renal epithelium, though it is reported in clear-cell tumours.

program_25.description: The gene set represents a classic Heat-Shock/Proteotoxic-Stress response program that can be transiently activated in virtually any cell type when protein-folding homeostasis is challenged. Evidence: • HSPA1A and HSPA1B – inducible HSP70 family chaperones transcriptionally driven by HSF1 during heat shock and other proteotoxic insults. • DNAJB1 and DNAJA4 – HSP40 (DnaJ) co-chaperones that cooperate with HSP70s to refold or target mis-folded proteins for degradation; both are hallmark HSF1 targets. • HSPH1 (HSP105/HSP110) – nucleotide-exchange factor for HSP70s, up-regulated during heat shock to enhance chaperone capacity. • All listed genes are positively loaded and function within the cytosolic chaperone network, collectively defining the canonical heat-shock transcriptional module. Inconsistencies: No obvious conflicting genes are present.

program_26.description: The program most closely matches an epithelial or endothelial cell population that has activated a wound-healing / TGF-β-driven epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT)–like response, characterized by enhanced migratory capacity and extracellular-matrix remodeling rather than lineage-specific immune or stromal signatures. Evidence: • SERPINE1 (PAI-1) – canonical TGF-β target and sentinel of EMT, fibrosis, and endothelial/epithelial injury responses. • EMP1 – enriched in epithelial cells undergoing partial EMT and in activated endothelial cells; promotes adhesion and motility. • ABL2 – non-receptor tyrosine kinase that drives actin remodeling and cell migration during EMT and vascular remodeling. • NFATC1 / NFATC2 – calcineurin-dependent transcription factors induced by Ca²⁺/TGF-β signaling in epithelial and endothelial cells undergoing EMT; coordinate with AP-1 to promote motility and matrix gene expression. Inconsistencies: • NFATC1 and NFATC2 are also key in activated T cells, yet the program lacks other T-cell markers (CD3D/E, LCK, IL2RA), arguing against a lymphoid identity.

program_27.description: The gene set most consistently points to a cell population in which the Wnt/β-catenin pathway is active and cytoskeletal remodeling is engaged—features typical of proliferative, stem-like epithelial/progenitor cells (e.g., intestinal crypt, basal epidermis or other cycling epithelia). Evidence: • CTNNB1 (β-catenin) – canonical effector of Wnt signaling; nuclear accumulation marks cycling progenitor cells. • CDC42SE1 – downstream effector of CDC42 that reorganizes actin; frequently co-induced with β-catenin during epithelial cell spreading and migration. • C1orf56 (FAM112B) – reported Wnt/β-catenin target and enriched in proliferative compartments of several epithelia. • HNRNPH1 – RNA-binding protein up-regulated in rapidly cycling cells to support heightened mRNA processing demands. • PHKG1 – glycogen-phosphorylase–activating subunit; Wnt-driven progenitors often up-shift glycogen metabolism to fuel proliferation. Inconsistencies: • PHKG1 is classically muscle-enriched; its presence could alternatively indicate a muscle lineage or reflect metabolic rewiring rather than lineage identity. • The module lacks several hallmark epithelial-progenitor transcripts (e.g., EPCAM, KRT17), so the assignment rests mainly on signaling/metabolic genes rather than definitive lineage markers.

program_0.description: The gene set represents a generic “high-translation” program characteristic of cells that are actively growing or preparing to divide, rather than a lineage-restricted identity; it is marked by coordinated up-regulation of almost every cytosolic ribosomal protein and translation-associated factor, and concurrent down-regulation of genes typical of quiescent, stromal, or high-OXPHOS states. Evidence: • Global up-regulation of cytosolic ribosomal proteins (RPL10, RPL13, RPL32, RPS6, RPS14, RPS18, RPS19, etc.) together with elongation/assembly factors (EEF1A1, NACA, BTF3, RACK1, UBA52, FAU) is the canonical signature of enhanced ribosome biogenesis and protein synthesis seen in cycling or recently activated cells across multiple lineages. • TPT1 and RPLP0/P1/P2 are well-known components of the translation machinery that rise with cell growth signals (e.g., MYC-driven programs). • Negative loading of MT-ND4 (mitochondrial electron-transport) suggests relative suppression of mitochondrial gene expression, a pattern often observed when glycolytic, fast-dividing cells dominate. • Negative loading of ITGA1 and IGFBP3—markers of quiescent mesenchymal/stromal cells—further supports a shift away from a resting or extracellular-matrix-producing phenotype toward a biosynthetically active one. Inconsistencies: • CCL14 (chemokine) and, to a lesser extent, DUSP23 are not directly linked to ribosome biogenesis and may reflect cell-type–specific signaling noise or low-level contamination.

program_1.description: The gene set reflects a mural-cell program characteristic of pericytes and vascular smooth-muscle–like cells that are actively producing extracellular matrix and responding to hypoxia/oxidative stress. Evidence: • Mural-cell identity – NOTCH3, PDGFRB, RGS5, EDNRA, KCNJ8, AXL and CYGB are canonical pericyte/vascular smooth-muscle markers. • Contractile apparatus – ACTA2, MYL9, CALD1, TPM2 and SYNPO2 encode core smooth-muscle cytoskeletal proteins. • Extracellular-matrix synthesis/remodeling – High levels of COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1, COL5A3, COL6A3, PCOLCE, DDR2, SDC2 and TGFBI indicate active collagen deposition and matrix organization. • Hypoxia/oxidative-stress response – NDUFA4L2, COX4I2, HIGD1B, FAM162B, CYGB, STEAP4 and SOD3 are up-regulated by low O₂ or reactive oxygen species, consistent with hypoxic vessel microenvironments. • Additional supportive genes – FRZB (WNT modulator in mural cells), GEM and ARHGEF17 (Rho GTPase signaling in contractile cells), CD44 and LGALS3BP (stromal/ECM interaction proteins). Inconsistencies: • Neural/epithelial-associated genes such as NFASC, ADCY3, ID4 and CDH6 are atypical for contractile mural cells, but their presence at lower loadings may reflect transcriptional noise or a subset of pericytes with neurovascular specialization.

program_2.description: The gene set reflects an interferon-γ–driven “antigen-presentation” program whereby non-hematopoietic stromal or endothelial cells up-regulate both MHC-I and MHC-II machinery and a broader set of interferon-stimulated genes, enabling them to function as facultative antigen-presenting cells during tissue inflammation. Evidence: • Robust MHC-I module (B2M, HLA-B, HLA-C, HLA-E) together with the full MHC-II complex (HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPB1) and the invariant chain CD74—hallmark of cells newly licensed for antigen presentation. • Interferon/innate‐response genes: BST2 (tetherin), TNFSF10 (TRAIL), TXNIP, JUN, JUNB, GADD45B all rise after IFN-γ or type-I IFN exposure, aligning with the induction of the HLA module. • Stromal/endothelial identity markers that commonly gain MHC-II under IFN-γ: ENPP2 (autotaxin, fibroblast/endothelial), PLAT (tPA, endothelial), RBP7 and JAM2 (vascular/endothelial adhesion), FABP5 (activated stromal/epithelial lipid handling). • Additional genes expressed in inflamed tissue stroma: IGFBP2, ITM2B, FAM107A, supporting a non-hematopoietic baseline that is being “licensed” by cytokine exposure. Inconsistencies: • SRGN (serglycin) and CD320 are more typical of hematopoietic lineage cells, and their presence may indicate a minor contaminating immune population or convergent IFN response across cell types.

program_3.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with a quiescent / stress-responsive microvascular endothelial cell state in which junctional and cytoprotective genes are up-regulated while many basement-membrane and other extracellular-matrix (ECM) genes are concomitantly repressed. Evidence: • Endothelial identity/junctions – CLDN5 (tight-junction component of capillary endothelium, especially blood-brain and lung), TMEM100 (arteriolar / capillary endothelium), LIFR (expressed in vascular endothelium), CLU (secreted by stressed endothelial cells). • Stress / quiescence markers – BTG2 (antiproliferative, quiescent endothelium), CEBPD and PERP (p53 / inflammatory stress response), MT1E and MT1X (oxidative-stress metallothioneins), KCTD12 (induced by cAMP/PKA signalling in stressed endothelium). • Suppressed ECM programme – strong negative loading of SPARC, COL4A1, COL4A2, COL15A1, HSPG2 and VWA1 indicates active down-regulation of basement-membrane and interstitial ECM genes typical of matrix-depositing or angiogenic endothelial/perivascular states; their repression fits a quiescent, non-remodelling endothelial phenotype. Inconsistencies: • ADIRF (adipocyte-associated) and FBLN2 (ECM glycoprotein) are positively loaded despite overall ECM repression. • RGCC (cell-cycle regulator) is negatively loaded, supporting quiescence, but its expression can also rise in injured endothelium, so its suppression could reflect a mixed signal.

program_4.description: The gene set is most consistent with an arterial/large-vessel endothelial cell program characterized by active elastic-fiber assembly and extracellular-matrix remodeling. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – ICAM2, TM4SF1, ID1 and the gap-junction gene GJA5 (connexin-40) are canonical endothelial markers. • Arterial specification – GJA5 and SEMA3G are selectively enriched in arterial endothelial cells relative to venous beds. • Elastic-fiber / ECM synthesis – ELN (elastin), FBLN5, LTBP4, PCSK5, SERPINE2 and SULF1 cooperate in elastic-fiber formation, TGF-β sequestration and matrix remodeling, a hallmark of elastic arteries. • Additional vascular/perivascular support – TSPAN2, KCTD12, CLIC3 and SRP14 are expressed in vascular smooth-muscle or perivascular cells and are often co-expressed with arterial EC genes during vessel wall maturation. Inconsistencies: • LTC4S and SRGN are typically leukocyte-associated; PLLP is more common in oligodendrocytes; their presence may reflect minor contaminating transcripts or multifunctional expression in some endothelial subsets.

program_5.description: The gene set best fits a program active in fenestrated / capillary endothelial cells that are metabolically primed for lipid uptake-handling and ongoing angiogenic–Notch signalling. Evidence: • Core endothelial / fenestration markers – PLVAP (diaphragmed fenestrae), CA4 (lung/renal capillary ECs), RBP7 and VAMP5 (microvascular EC-enriched), CD320 and TMEM88 (Wnt-modulating EC proteins). • Lipid transport & metabolism – CD36, FABP5 and MGLL coordinate fatty-acid uptake and hydrolysis; IGFBP6 and RBP7 add lipid-soluble growth-factor/retinol transport capacity. • Capillary specialisation – SLC14A1 (urea transporter of renal & medullary ECs), NKX2-3 (gut/venous EC transcription factor) reinforce a microvascular identity. • Angiogenic / Notch tone – HES1 (canonical Notch target), ATOH8 and LNX1 (Notch modulators) indicate active vascular remodelling; PLAT (tPA) marks endothelium engaged in fibrinolysis. • Metabolic remodelling – PASK (energy-sensing kinase) aligns with the heightened lipid-handling profile. Inconsistencies: • GSN is a ubiquitous actin-binding protein and not EC-specific, but its presence is compatible with cytoskeletal remodelling during angiogenesis. • No other strong contradictions; the majority of genes coherently support a fenestrated/microvascular endothelial program.

program_6.description: The gene set represents a generic cell-cycle program characteristic of actively proliferating cells caught in late G2 and mitosis (G2/M phase), rather than a lineage-specific signature. Evidence: • Canonical proliferation markers: MKI67, TOP2A, TYMS, TK1, UBE2C, BIRC5 all peak during G2–M and are routinely used to mark dividing cells across tissues. • Mitotic spindle and chromosome segregation genes: NUSAP1, STMN1, TUBA1B (microtubule dynamics), CENPF, CENPW, ZWINT, MAD2L1 (kinetochore and spindle-checkpoint components), PTTG1 (securin) underscore an M-phase state. • Cell-cycle regulators: CDK1 (master G2/M kinase) and UBE2T (ubiquitin ligase co-factor) drive mitotic entry and exit, further confirming a G2/M program. • DNA synthesis/repair factors: PCLAF (PCNA-associated), TYMS, TK1 support late S to G2 transition. Inconsistencies: None apparent; all listed genes coherently fit a G2/M cell-cycle program.

program_7.description: The program matches a lymphatic endothelial cell (LEC) transcriptional state. Core lymphatic regulators (PROX1, LYVE1, CCL21) and venous / endothelial genes (TFPI, MMRN1, DKK3, AKAP12) dominate, with additional polarity and quiescence-associated factors (PARD6G, NR2F1, ADD3). Together these genes point to differentiated, homeostatic LECs capable of chemokine secretion for immune cell trafficking. Evidence: • Lymphatic lineage determinants – PROX1 (master LEC TF), LYVE1 (hyaluronan receptor), CCL21 (chemokine secreted by LECs guiding CCR7⁺ dendritic/T cells). • Endothelial/venous identity – TFPI, MMRN1, DKK3, AKAP12, ADD3, TSPAN5 are well-described in blood and lymphatic endothelium. • Venous-lymphatic specification & quiescence – NR2F1 cooperates with NR2F2 in venous/lymph fate; MAF has been reported in tissue-resident LEC subsets; PARD6G links to cell-cell junction polarity typical of endothelial monolayers. • Stress-adaptation genes (NUPR1, PPP1R2) and ion-handling protein FXYD6 are variably induced in quiescent or mildly activated endothelial states but remain compatible with an LEC profile. Inconsistencies: • TFF3 is classically a mucosal epithelium secretory factor; its presence suggests either paracrine uptake or low-level ectopic expression. • FXYD6 is better known in neural tissue; its contribution to LEC biology is less established, though not incompatible. Overall, the small number and modest endothelial expression of these genes do not outweigh the strong, canonical lymphatic endothelial signal from the majority of markers.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with post-capillary/venous endothelial cells that are in an IL-1–driven, inflammatory activation state and beginning to acquire extracellular-matrix/mesenchymal features (early endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition, EndMT). Evidence: • Endothelial / venous identity: ACKR1 (venular endothelial hallmark), ADGRG6/GPR126 and LRRC1 (vascular endothelium–enriched), SELP (P-selectin on activated endothelium), C7 (complement component produced by endothelium). • Inflammatory activation: IL1R1 (IL-1 receptor), ACKR1 and SELP (leukocyte recruitment), chemokines CCL14 and CCL23 (monocyte-attracting). • Early EndMT / matrix remodeling: POSTN (periostin), TLL1 (metalloprotease), and ECM-associated LRRC1 indicate acquisition of mesenchymal/ECM-secreting traits by endothelial cells. • Secretory/vesicle trafficking support: RAB3C, CPE, NPC2 facilitate the high secretory output expected in inflamed endothelial cells. Inconsistencies: • POSTN and TLL1 are classically fibroblast genes (though inducible during EndMT). • CPE and ZNF385D are better known in neuroendocrine/neuronal contexts and may represent background expression or admixture.

program_9.description: The program most closely matches a mature intestinal secretory epithelial (goblet-cell–biased) state, typical of colonic or distal small-intestinal epithelium that is actively producing and exporting mucins and antibacterial factors. Evidence: • Goblet/secretory cell core: MUC2 (major intestinal gel-forming mucin), FCGBP and AGR2 (MUC2 folding/packaging), PHGR1 and LGALS4 (goblet-cell-enriched secretory products), PIGR (transcytosis of IgA). • General intestinal epithelium: FXYD3 (ion transporter regulator enriched in colon epithelium), FABP1 (intestinal fatty-acid binding protein), KRT8 and KRT19 (simple epithelial keratins). • Secretory activity/defense: FCGBP, PIGR, LGALS4 together mark cells engaged in mucosal barrier protection typical of goblet cells. Inconsistencies: • FABP1 is more characteristic of absorptive enterocytes than goblet cells, suggesting some mixed enterocyte signature. • CKB (creatine kinase B) and C15orf48 are not specifically linked to goblet biology and may reflect generic metabolic/epithelial expression.

program_10.description: This program captures a “mito-high / stressed” cellular state often observed in dying or low-quality single-cell transcriptomes, characterized by disproportionate expression of mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation transcripts and a concurrent drop in cytosolic housekeeping mRNAs. Evidence: • Strong positive loadings for eight mitochondrially encoded OXPHOS genes (MT-ATP6, MT-CO2/3, MT-CYB, MT-ND3/4L/5/6) – hallmark of cells in which mitochondrial RNA dominates, usually because of membrane damage or apoptotic activation. • Negative loading for RPS20 indicates reduced cytosolic ribosomal gene expression, consistent with global translational shut-down during cellular stress or apoptosis. • Negative loading for TMSB4X (actin-binding, migration-associated) and FTH1 (iron-storage, oxidative-stress responsive) further supports loss of typical cytoplasmic programs in favor of a stress signature. Inconsistencies: No strongly cell-type–specific markers appear; the pattern is generic to stressed cells rather than any particular lineage.

program_11.description: The program represents a canonical type I/III interferon–induced antiviral state that can be engaged by many cell types upon viral sensing or exposure to exogenous IFN, rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • Core interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) – ISG15, IFI6, IFI27, IFI44L, LY6E – are rapidly and coordinately up-regulated after IFN-α/β or IFN-λ signaling. • Antiviral effector proteins – MX1 and MX2 (GTPases blocking viral transcription/replication) and RSAD2/Viperin (inhibits viral budding) – are hallmark products of an interferon response. • Translation-modulating IFIT family members (IFIT1, IFIT2, IFIT3) restrict viral mRNA translation and are classic read-outs of type I interferon activation. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes are strongly associated with interferon signaling and antiviral defense.

program_12.description: The gene set most closely matches arterial/Notch-activated endothelial cells, likely a subset undergoing proliferation or vascular remodeling. Evidence: • Arterial endothelial identity – EFNB2 (canonical arterial marker), GJA4/Connexin-37 (high in arterial endothelium), HEY1 and HES4 (Notch targets enriched in arterial ECs). • Active Notch signalling – simultaneous presence of EFNB2, HEY1, HES4 supports a Notch-high endothelial state. • Additional endothelial or vascular genes – PLPP1 (endothelial lipid-phosphate phosphatase), IGFBP3 (secreted by ECs and pericytes, induced by shear stress), SLC45A4 (reported in vascular beds). • Proliferation/remodeling signature – STMN1 (microtubule dynamics, cycling cells) and SAT1 (polyamine catabolism in dividing cells) indicate a subset of ECs in an activated/proliferative state rather than quiescence. Inconsistencies: • STMN1 and SAT1 are pan-proliferative markers, not endothelial-specific; their presence suggests mixed inclusion of generic cycling programs but does not contradict an endothelial identity. No genes directly oppose an endothelial interpretation.

program_13.description: The program represents a generic actin-cytoskeleton remodeling / motility state that can be adopted by many cell types (e.g., activated fibroblasts, mesenchymal-like tumor cells, or other cells preparing for migration or shape change). Evidence: • Core actin machinery – ACTB, PFN1, CFL1, TMSB10 all encode proteins that drive actin filament polymerization, depolymerization, and monomer sequestration, hallmarks of cytoskeletal reorganization. • Contractility – MYL6 (non-muscle myosin light chain) partners with actin to generate tension required for cell movement. • Calcium-binding adaptors – S100A6 and S100A11 regulate actin dynamics and cell motility in a Ca²⁺-dependent manner. • Adhesion/migration modulator – LGALS1 (Galectin-1) promotes cell–matrix interactions and is frequently up-regulated during migratory or mesenchymal transitions. • All genes are positively loaded, indicating coordinated up-regulation of this motility module. Inconsistencies: None apparent; every listed gene participates in actin organization, contractility, or associated signaling.

program_14.description: The program represents an NF-κB–driven inflammatory activation state of vascular endothelial cells, characterized by up-regulation of adhesion molecules and chemokines that recruit and tether leukocytes to the vessel wall. Evidence: • Endothelial adhesion molecules – SELE (E-selectin), VCAM1, and ICAM1 are canonical markers induced in endothelial cells by TNF-α/IL-1 to initiate leukocyte rolling and firm adhesion. • NF-κB activation – NFKBIA (IκBα) is rapidly transcribed following NF-κB signaling, marking cells experiencing inflammatory cytokine stimulation. • Leukocyte-recruiting chemokines – CXCL2, CXCL3 (GRO family) and CCL2 (MCP-1) are secreted by activated endothelium to attract neutrophils and monocytes, fitting a coordinated endothelial inflammatory response. • Coordinately induced auxiliary gene – C2CD4B is reported to rise in endothelial cells upon inflammatory stimuli, aligning with the same pathway. Inconsistencies: • The listed genes are largely endothelial-specific or broadly inducible; no strong contradictions are present in this program.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with a vascular endothelial program, particularly an angiogenic/tip-like endothelial cell state characterized by high VEGF responsiveness, Notch signaling and chemokine secretion. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – FLT1 (VEGFR1), NOTCH4, ACE and PODXL are classical blood-vascular endothelial markers; FLT1 and NOTCH4 are largely restricted to endothelial cells in most tissues. • Angiogenic/tip cell features – FLT1 and PODXL are up-regulated in sprouting “tip” endothelial cells; NOTCH4 modulates tip/stalk decisions; CXCL12 is a pro-angiogenic chemokine that guides vascular sprouting. • Additional endothelial enrichment – ADGRF5 (GPR116) and ACE are both enriched in microvascular endothelial cells; CXCL12 secretion by endothelial cells supports perivascular cell recruitment. Inconsistencies: • A2M is classically liver-derived, and ADGRF5 is also reported in alveolar epithelium, but both can be expressed or taken up by endothelial cells under inflammatory or remodeling conditions, so their presence is only a mild inconsistency rather than contradictory to an endothelial program.

program_16.description: The gene set represents a canonical Immediate-Early Gene (IEG) activation program, characteristic of cells that have very recently received an acute mitogenic, inflammatory, or stress stimulus (e.g., serum or MAPK/ERK activation) rather than a lineage-restricted signature; it marks a transient “just-activated” cellular state that can be super-imposed on many cell types. Evidence: • Core IEG/AP-1 transcription factors: FOS, EGR1, EGR2, IER2 are classic rapid-response genes induced within minutes of MAPK/ERK or NF-κB signaling. • Feedback regulators of MAPK signaling: DUSP1 (dual-specificity phosphatase that dephosphorylates ERK/JNK) fits the early response wave that attenuates the initial stimulus. • Post-transcriptional brake: ZFP36 (tristetraprolin) destabilizes cytokine/IEG mRNAs, another hallmark of the acute activation module. • Stress/activation-associated Kruppel-like factor: KLF4 is quickly up-regulated by oxidative or inflammatory signals and cooperates with AP-1 factors during early activation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are well-known members of the broad IEG/acute activation program.

program_17.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mucosal / lymphoid high-endothelial–venous cell state—i.e. MADCAM1⁺, NR2F2⁺ endothelial cells that mediate lymphocyte homing in gut-associated and secondary lymphoid tissues—characterised by lipid-mediator signalling and a non-fenestrated (PLVAP-low) phenotype. Evidence: • MADCAM1 (strongly positive) – canonical adhesion molecule of high endothelial venules (HEVs) in gut and lymph nodes, required for α4β7⁺ lymphocyte recruitment. • NR2F2/COUP-TFII (positive) – transcription factor specifying venous rather than arterial endothelial identity; enriched in HEVs. • PLA1A, PTGDS, PTAFR (positive) – lipid-metabolism / eicosanoid genes up-regulated in activated endothelial cells to support leukocyte extravasation and inflammation. • NNMT (positive) – metabolic enzyme frequently induced in activated endothelial cells during inflammatory signalling. • PLVAP (negatively loaded) – marker of fenestrated endothelial cells; its down-regulation fits the non-fenestrated, high-endothelial phenotype. Inconsistencies: • NNMT and PTGDS can also be expressed by perivascular fibroblasts/pericytes, so a minor stromal contribution to the program cannot be fully excluded.

program_18.description: The program is most consistent with an adipose-tissue–resident lipid-handling stromal/vascular cell population (FABP4⁺/RBP7⁺ “metabolic” endothelial cells or closely related perivascular adipocyte progenitors) that combines fatty-acid/retinol metabolism with extracellular-matrix regulation and CXCL12 chemokine secretion. Evidence: • Lipid-handling/adipocyte-enriched genes: FABP4, AQP7 and RBP7 are classical markers of white-adipose cells and of the specialized FABP4⁺ microvascular endothelial subset found in adipose tissue. • Adipose-restricted transcript: BTNL9 shows highest expression in white adipose tissue and in FABP4⁺ endothelial cells. • ECM/angiogenic regulators typical of stromal or endothelial cells: TIMP3 (metalloproteinase inhibitor in capillary ECs and perivascular fibroblasts) and AIF1L (expressed in endothelial and adipocyte lineages). • Chemokine secretion signature: CXCL12 is produced by perivascular stromal cells and FABP4⁺ endothelial cells, supporting a niche-forming, pro-angiogenic state. Inconsistencies: • Classic mature adipocyte markers (ADIPOQ, PLIN1, PPARG) are absent, arguing that the cells are not fully differentiated adipocytes but rather a vascular/stromal subset linked to adipose tissue. • Endothelial pan-markers (PECAM1, CLDN5) are not in the list, leaving open whether the program belongs to endothelial cells or closely associated stromal progenitors.

program_19.description: The program represents a classical MHC class II antigen-presentation state characteristic of professional antigen-presenting cells—most commonly B cells, dendritic cells, and monocyte-derived macrophages—undergoing or poised for immune activation. Evidence: • Strong enrichment for core MHC-II α/β chains (HLA-DPA1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DQB1) and for the peptide-loading chaperones (HLA-DMA, HLA-DMB), a signature set universally induced in professional APCs after IFN-γ stimulation or during maturation. • Presence of TSPAN7, a tetraspanin reported to be elevated in immature and maturing dendritic cells and activated B cells, supporting an APC identity rather than a non-immune lineage. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes or discordant markers are present, so no clear inconsistencies with the assigned APC activation program could be identified.

program_20.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature CNS neuron program—particularly excitatory cortical/hippocampal neurons—displaying active neurite outgrowth and synaptic remodeling. Evidence: • Neurite / dendritic-spine regulators – GPM6A (promotes neurite extension), CTTNBP2 (controls dendritic-spine morphogenesis), STXBP6/Amisyn (interacts with Syntaxin-1A during regulated vesicle exocytosis). • Synaptic/neuronal activity modulators – ERRFI1 (EGFR-responsive gene expressed in neurons, up-regulated by neuronal activity). • Neuron-secreted extracellular/vascular support factors – TFPI (produced by neurons and astrocytes to limit tissue-factor signaling in brain), EFEMP1/Fibulin-3 (secreted by retinal and cortical neurons, contributes to perineuronal extracellular matrix). Inconsistencies: • TFPI and EFEMP1 are better known in endothelial or mesenchymal cells; however, both have documented neuronal expression, so their presence is not strongly discordant with a neuronal program.

program_21.description: The program reflects an activated, pro-angiogenic endothelial cell state—akin to vascular “tip” or remodeling endothelial cells that secrete angiogenic factors and interact with immune cells during inflammation or tumor neovascularization. Evidence: • Endothelial identity/angiogenesis – ESM1 (endocan, canonical tip-cell marker), ANGPT2 and ANGPTL2 (angiopoietin family members released by remodeling endothelium), ADM (adrenomedullin, hypoxia-induced vasoactive/angiogenic peptide). • Extracellular matrix remodeling – LAMA4, a laminin α chain enriched in vascular basement membranes undergoing sprouting. • Endothelial–immune crosstalk – TNFRSF4 (OX40 receptor) has been reported on inflamed/tumor endothelium facilitating T-cell adhesion, consistent with an activated vascular phenotype. Inconsistencies: • TNFRSF4 is more classically a T-cell activation receptor; if expression is high it could indicate T-cell contamination, but its reported endothelial expression under inflammatory conditions limits this concern.

program_22.description: The program most closely reflects an inflammatory, cytokine-activated endothelial cell state that mobilizes and recruits myeloid cells (neutrophils/monocytes) through E-selectin–mediated adhesion and G-CSF production, while simultaneously modulating lipid handling (endothelial lipase) and lysosomal turnover. Evidence: • SELE (E-selectin) – canonical marker of TNF-α/IL-1β–activated endothelial cells that mediate leukocyte rolling. • LIPG – “endothelial lipase,” highly enriched in vascular endothelium and up-regulated by inflammatory cues. • CSF3 – G-CSF, produced by activated endothelial cells to stimulate granulopoiesis and neutrophil release. • LAMP3 – inducible in endothelial cells under hypoxia/IFN-γ and in inflamed vessels, consistent with activation. • CSF2RB – shared β chain of GM-CSF/IL-3/IL-5 receptor; endothelial expression reported during inflammation, enabling responsiveness to myeloid-derived cytokines. • Absence of negatively loaded genes supports a coherent, single activation program. Inconsistencies: • LAMP3 is better known as a mature dendritic-cell marker, though its inducible endothelial expression mitigates this conflict. • CSF2RB is predominantly hematopoietic; its inclusion suggests either low-level endothelial expression or minor myeloid contamination.

program_23.description: The program is most consistent with an activated fibroblast / myofibroblast state typical of wound healing or tumor-associated fibroblasts, characterized by extracellular-matrix production and secretion of pro-angiogenic factors. Evidence: • ECM remodeling genes (COL12A1, PXDN) – hallmark collagens and cross-linking enzymes produced by fibroblasts/myofibroblasts. • Pro-angiogenic secreted factors (PGF, APLN) – fibroblasts in healing or cancer stroma release these ligands to stimulate endothelial sprouting. • Biosynthetic/proliferative enzyme (ODC1) – polyamine synthesis up-regulated in rapidly expanding, activated fibroblasts. Inconsistencies: • APLN is also expressed by endothelial cells and pericytes, introducing minor overlap with vascular cells, but its co-occurrence with dominant fibroblast ECM genes supports a fibroblast origin.

program_0.description: The program is most consistent with mast cells in a highly biosynthetic (granule-replenishing) state—ribosome biogenesis and cytoskeletal remodeling genes are strongly up-regulated, while mitochondrial respiratory‐chain transcripts are relatively suppressed. Evidence: • TPSAB1 – canonical mast-cell tryptase; virtually restricted to mast cells/basophils. • Broad enrichment of cytosolic ribosomal proteins (RPL3, RPL7, RPL13A, RPS6, RPS14, RPS19, etc.) – hallmark of increased global translation needed for synthesis of secretory granule proteins after degranulation. • TMSB4X – actin-binding protein induced during cytoskeletal reorganization that accompanies mast-cell activation and vesicle trafficking. • Coordinated depletion of mitochondrial OXPHOS genes (MT-CO1/2/3, MT-ND3/4/5, MT-ATP6, MT-CYB) – suggests a metabolic shift away from oxidative phosphorylation that has been reported after mast-cell activation. Inconsistencies: • Most RPL/RPS genes and TMSB4X are ubiquitous housekeeping/activation markers and are not mast-cell specific; their presence alone could reflect a generic high-translation state. • Down-regulation of JUND (AP-1 component) is atypical for some mast-cell activation contexts where AP-1 can be induced.

program_1.description: The gene set represents a generic “ribosomal/translation” program, marking cells with elevated cytosolic ribosome content and therefore high global protein-synthesis activity, a state commonly seen in proliferating or recently activated cells across many lineages rather than a lineage-specific cell type. Evidence: • Strong coordinated up-regulation of multiple small- and large-subunit ribosomal protein genes (RPS12, RPS8, RPS23; RPL10, RPL11, RPL13, RPL19, RPL37A, RPLP1) is the canonical signature of increased ribosome biogenesis and translational capacity, which accompanies cell growth, cycling, and activation. • Absence of lineage-restricted markers supports the interpretation that the program reflects a metabolic/state feature (high translation) rather than a specific differentiated cell identity. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes consistently encode core ribosomal proteins.
