program_2.description: The gene set reflects a generic “ribosome/translation-high” program, marking cells that are actively synthesizing protein—a state frequently seen in proliferating, metabolically active, or recently activated cells rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • RPL32, RPL26, RPL35A, RPL35 – Large-subunit ribosomal proteins; increased transcription is a hallmark of ribosome biogenesis and high translational capacity. • RPS27, RPS25, RPS29, RPS15A – Small-subunit ribosomal proteins; likewise up-regulated during heightened protein synthesis. • Co-up-regulation of multiple RPL and RPS genes is a well-described signature of cell cycle entry, growth-factor stimulation, and other states that demand enhanced translation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are concordant with a ribosomal/translation program and do not point to an alternative, lineage-specific identity.

program_3.description: The gene set represents a strong Major Histocompatibility Complex class II (MHC-II) antigen-presentation program characteristic of professional antigen-presenting cells (e.g., dendritic cells, macrophages/monocytes, and B cells) in an MHC-II–high, immunologically active state. Evidence: • MHC-II α- and β-chains (HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQA1) – core components of the heterodimer that presents peptide antigens to CD4⁺ T cells. • CD74 – invariant chain that chaperones MHC-II molecules through the endosomal pathway, indicative of active antigen processing. • HLA-DMA – part of the HLA-DM heterodimer that edits peptides loaded onto MHC-II, further signifying an operational peptide-loading compartment. Inconsistencies: • None detected; all listed genes coherently support an MHC-II antigen-presentation state.

program_4.description: The gene set represents an immediate-early activation program most characteristic of recently T-cell–receptor–stimulated T cells (and other acutely activated lymphocytes), marked by rapid transcriptional responders and the canonical early activation surface marker CD69. Evidence: • CD69 – classical very-early surface marker induced within minutes of T-cell and NK-cell activation. • IER2, FOS, JUNB – AP-1/immediate-early transcription factors strongly and transiently up-regulated after TCR or cytokine stimulation. • NFKBIA – encodes IκBα, induced as part of the first wave of NF-κB activation in stimulated T cells. • BTG2 – early response gene induced by mitogenic or TCR signaling, linked to transient cell-cycle restraint during early activation. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes fit a coherent early activation/immediate-early response program rather than a lineage-specific signature.

program_5.description: The gene set represents a ubiquitous type I interferon–induced program characterized by up-regulation of class I antigen-presentation machinery (HLA-A, ‑B, ‑C, B2M) together with classical interferon-stimulated genes (IFI6, ISG15). This profile is seen in many nucleated cell types that have recently sensed IFN-α/β or viral danger signals rather than marking any single lineage. Evidence: • HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, B2M – core components of the MHC-I complex; transcription is strongly boosted by type I interferon, enhancing peptide presentation to CD8⁺ T cells. • IFI6, ISG15 – canonical interferon-stimulated genes involved in antiviral defense and frequently co-expressed with the above HLA genes during an IFN-α/β response. Inconsistencies: • No obvious contradictions; the entire list coherently fits a type I interferon response program.

program_6.description: This gene set represents a generic G2/M-phase cell-cycle program characteristic of actively dividing cells, independent of a specific lineage. Evidence: • TUBA1B & TUBB – α- and β-tubulins that rise during mitosis to build the mitotic spindle. • STMN1 – microtubule-destabilizing protein peaking in G2/M, required for spindle dynamics. • HMGB2 – chromatin-binding protein whose expression is highest in late S and G2/M, marking proliferating cells. • CKS1B – regulatory subunit that activates CDK1/2 and promotes p27 degradation; enriched in G2/M. • EXD3 – nuclease implicated in DNA/RNA processing and reported to increase in cycling cells. Inconsistencies: No appreciable contradictions; all detected genes align with a mitotic/proliferative state.

program_7.description: The program represents a classic, HSF1-driven heat-shock/proteotoxic stress state that can be induced in virtually any cell type when mis-folded proteins accumulate. Evidence: • HSPA1A and HSPA1B – inducible HSP70 chaperones that are among the earliest and strongest transcriptional targets of the heat-shock factor HSF1. • DNAJB1 and DNAJB4 – HSP40 co-chaperones that cooperate with HSP70s to refold or triage damaged proteins during thermal or oxidative stress. • HSPB1 (HSP27) – small heat-shock protein that prevents aggregation of unfolded proteins and is co-regulated with HSP70 genes during proteotoxic stress. • Absence of lineage-restricted markers and exclusive enrichment of stress-inducible chaperones further point to a cell-state program rather than a specific cell type. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are canonical components of the heat-shock response.

program_0.description: This program reflects a generic “biosynthetic/activation” state characterized by high ribosome biogenesis and glycolytic metabolism, typical of cells that have recently increased global protein synthesis (e.g., broadly activated or growth-stimulated immune and non-immune cells) rather than a specific lineage identity. Evidence: • Ribosome biogenesis / translation – very strong positive loading of >50 cytosolic ribosomal protein genes (RPLs and RPSs), together with EEF1A1 and RPLP0/P1/P2, is the canonical signature of heightened ribosome production and translational capacity. • Aerobic glycolysis – GAPDH, ENO1, TPI1, LDHA and AK4 are hallmark glycolytic enzymes up-regulated when cells boost ATP production to fuel biosynthesis. • RNA processing – HNRNPA1 enrichment supports increased mRNA metabolism that accompanies high translation rates. • Loss of quiescence factors – negative loading of ETS1 and JUND (transcription factors that maintain quiescence or lineage-specific programs in resting lymphoid and other cells) is consistent with a switch toward an activated, biosynthetic state. Inconsistencies: • Classic S/G2-M cell-cycle genes (MKI67, TOP2A, PCNA, MCMs) are absent, so the program marks increased protein synthesis/metabolic priming rather than full proliferative cycling. • No lineage-defining markers appear, confirming that the signature is generic and not tied to one cell type.

program_1.description: The program reflects a population of highly activated, tissue-resident/exhausted CD8⁺ cytotoxic T cells that have aberrantly induced MHC class II antigen-presentation machinery and secrete B-cell-recruiting and pro-inflammatory chemokines. Evidence: • Cytotoxic CD8 T-cell identity – CD8A, CD8B together with effector molecules GZMB, GZMH and IFNG. • Strong activation / inflammatory chemokine output – CXCL13 (B-cell and follicular homing), CCL3, CCL4. • Tissue-resident or chronically stimulated phenotype – VCAM1 and FABP5 are canonical markers of resident or exhausted CD8 T cells in inflamed tissues and tumors. • Induction of MHC class II pathway – HLA-DRA, DRB1, DPA1, DPB1, DQA1, DQB1 and the invariant chain CD74; expression of these genes in CD8 T cells is a known feature of chronically stimulated “MHC-II⁺ CD8” or “T resident/exhausted precursor” cells driven by CIITA. Inconsistencies: No major contradictions; although MHC-II expression is atypical for CD8⁺ T cells, it is documented in chronically activated tissue-resident/exhausted CD8 subsets, so it is compatible with this state.

program_2.description: The program reflects cells undergoing energetic stress or apoptosis, characterized by disproportionate accumulation of mitochondrial transcripts and concomitant loss of abundant cytoplasmic/ribosomal mRNAs—a signature widely used in single-cell studies to flag dying or low-quality cells rather than a distinct physiological cell type. Evidence: • Strong positive loadings for multiple mitochondrially encoded oxidative-phosphorylation genes (MT-CO1, MT-CO2, MT-CO3, MT-ATP6, MT-CYB, MT-ND1-6) are a canonical indicator of mitochondrial RNA enrichment observed when plasma-membrane integrity is compromised and cytoplasmic RNA decays. • Negative loadings for highly expressed housekeeping/cytoskeletal genes (ACTB), actin-binding regulators (TMSB4X, PFN1), and a core ribosomal protein (RPS17) are consistent with global cytoplasmic mRNA depletion that accompanies apoptosis or severe cellular stress. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes fit the expected pattern of mitochondrial over-representation and loss of cytoplasmic transcripts in stressed or dying cells.

program_3.description: The program reflects a canonical, cytotoxic natural killer (NK) cell state characterized by expression of multiple NK‐specific signaling adaptors, inhibitory/activating receptors and effector molecules, together with low expression of the broadly expressed calcium-binding protein S100A6. Evidence: • NK receptor/adaptor module: FCER1G, TYROBP (DAP12), KLRC1 (NKG2A), KIR2DL4, SH2D1B – classical components of conventional NK cell signaling. • Cytotoxic machinery: GZMA encodes Granzyme A, a hallmark of cytolytic NK and CD8⁺ T cells. • Lymphoid identity: CD247 (CD3ζ), CD7, LAT2, TXK and TMIGD2 (CD28H) are shared by NK and T cells but are all constitutively expressed in circulating NK cells. • Transcriptional regulators linked to NK maturation/activation: HOPX and CXXC5 are reported in mature cytotoxic lymphocytes. • Negative loading of S100A6 (widely expressed in many cell types but relatively low in NK cells) further distinguishes this program from non-NK populations. Inconsistencies: • HOPX and CXXC5 are also associated with tissue-resident or memory T cells, and their presence may indicate some overlap with cytotoxic T-cell programs. • The largely T-cell–associated adaptor CD247 could, in isolation, suggest T-cell identity, but it is also routinely expressed in NK cells and is outweighed by the strong NK receptor/adaptor signature.

program_4.description: The gene set represents a classic cytotoxic‐effector program most compatible with activated natural killer (NK) cells or cytotoxic CD8⁺ T lymphocytes in a degranulating state. Evidence: • Cytotoxic granule machinery – GZMA, PRF1, GNLY, CTSW and NKG7 encode granzymes, perforin, granulysin, cathepsin W and a granule membrane protein, respectively, hallmark components of NK/CD8⁺ T-cell–mediated target-cell killing. • NK-associated receptors – KLRD1 (CD94) and KLRC2 (NKG2C) are canonical NK‐cell (and some cytotoxic T-cell) lectin-like receptors that pair to form heterodimers recognizing HLA-E. • Chemotaxis/degranulation – CCL5 (RANTES) recruits additional cytotoxic lymphocytes, while CD63 is a tetraspanin up-regulated on the cell surface during granule exocytosis, marking active degranulation. • Negative loading of LTB – Lymphotoxin-β is higher in naïve/central-memory T cells; its relative depletion fits a terminally differentiated, cytotoxic effector state. Inconsistencies: • No strong contradictory transcripts are present; however, the absence of definitive T-cell markers (e.g., CD3D/E, CD8A/B) prevents unambiguous discrimination between NK cells and cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells.

program_5.description: The program represents a generic G2/M‐phase cell-cycle signature marking actively dividing cells (e.g., proliferative progenitors or cycling tumor cells), rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • Canonical G2/M regulators – CCNB1 (Cyclin B1), CKS2, UBE2C, PTTG1 and TROAP drive mitotic entry, APC/C regulation and spindle organization. • Nuclear transport & chromatin dynamics needed during mitosis – KPNA2 (importin-α), HMGB2 (chromatin architectural protein) and PIF1 (DNA helicase) are up-regulated in proliferating cells. • CALM2 (calmodulin) supports Ca²⁺-dependent checkpoints and spindle stability, fitting a mitotic context. Inconsistencies: • ARL6IP1 and CALM2 are broadly expressed housekeeping genes; their presence is not exclusively cell-cycle specific but does not contradict a proliferative program.

program_6.description: The gene set most strongly matches an activated/effector regulatory CD4⁺ T-cell (Treg) program—FOXP3⁺, CD25⁺ T cells that retain classical T-cell costimulatory molecules and a central/effector-memory homing profile (SELL⁺), consistent with Tregs responding to antigenic stimulation. Evidence: • Core Treg identity – FOXP3, IL2RA (CD25) are canonical transcriptional and surface markers required for Treg development and function. • Activated/effector state – TNFRSF4 (OX40) and PIM2 are up-regulated upon T-cell activation and are enriched in activated/effector Tregs. • CD4 T-cell lineage – CD4, CD28 confirm the CD4⁺ conventional T-cell lineage rather than CD8⁺ or NK cells. • Central/effector-memory homing – SELL (CD62L) and LTB are expressed in Tregs that traffic through lymphoid tissues and inflamed sites. • Migratory/effector Tregs – S100A4 is reported in tissue-migratory or effector Tregs. Inconsistencies: • CD79B is a B-cell receptor component and is atypical for T cells, suggesting minor contamination, doublets, or ambient RNA rather than a true feature of the Treg program.

program_7.description: The program represents an acute cellular stress/heat-shock response that can be elicited in many cell types (e.g., during tissue dissociation or other proteotoxic insults), characterised by induction of chaperones, immediate-early transcription factors and stress-responsive immune genes. Evidence: • Proteotoxic stress chaperones – HSPA1A, HSPA1B (HSP70 family) and DNAJB1 (HSP40 co-chaperone) are canonical heat-shock proteins up-regulated upon protein-folding stress. • Immediate-early stress transcription factor – JUN is rapidly induced by MAPK/JNK signaling after heat, oxidative or mechanical stress. • MAPK feedback regulator – DUSP2 is a stress-induced phosphatase that attenuates MAPK signaling, particularly in activated immune cells. • Stress-/cytokine-inducible antigen-presentation genes – HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C are up-regulated by interferons and cellular stress, reinforcing a broad stress/innate immune activation state. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes fit a generalized heat-shock / acute stress transcriptional program rather than a lineage-specific signature.

program_8.description: The program represents a broad type-I/III interferon–induced antiviral state that can be super-imposed on many immune and non-immune cell types. Evidence: • Canonical interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs): ISG15, IFI6, IFI44, IFI44L, ISG20, USP18 and MX1 are all classic targets of STAT1/STAT2/IRF9 signaling downstream of IFN-α/β or IFN-λ, marking an antiviral response. • LY6E is likewise strongly up-regulated by type-I IFN and restricts multiple viruses, further reinforcing an interferon-driven program. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes are provided; no contradictions with an interferon response were identified.

program_9.description: The gene set represents a generic “S-phase / DNA replication” program characteristic of actively cycling cells across multiple lineages rather than a lineage-specific cell type. Evidence: • Core DNA-replication machinery – PCNA, PCLAF (PCNA-associated factor), DUT, RRM2 and TYMS coordinate DNA polymerase processivity and deoxynucleotide biosynthesis, hallmark features of S-phase. • PTMA is a nuclear, chromatin-associated protein induced during proliferation and cell-cycle progression. • LGALS1 is negatively loaded; this lectin is frequently up-regulated in quiescent, stressed or immunomodulatory states, so its reduced expression is compatible with highly proliferative cells. Inconsistencies: No strong contradictions; all listed genes align with an S-phase proliferation program.

program_10.description: The program represents a generic G2/M‐phase cell-cycle signature marking cells that are actively undergoing mitosis, irrespective of lineage. Evidence: • ASPM, CENPF – spindle pole and kinetochore proteins that peak in late G2 and mitosis. • TOP2A – DNA topoisomerase required for chromosome decatenation; maximal in G2/M. • SMC4 – condensin complex subunit essential for mitotic chromosome condensation. • Coordinated high expression of these genes and relative repression of housekeeping genes (RPL41) and iron-storage gene FTL is characteristic of a dedicated G2/M module rather than a lineage-specific phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Down-regulation of ribosomal protein RPL41 and ferritin light chain FTL is not typically a hallmark of proliferating cells, which often maintain or increase biosynthetic capacity; however, their negative loading does not conflict with the designation of a cell-cycle program.

program_11.description: The program reflects an acute, early activation state of lymphocytes—most consistently T cells—characterized by a burst of immediate-early transcription factors and the canonical surface activation marker CD69. Evidence: • CD69 (positive) – prototypical very-early surface marker up-regulated within minutes of T-cell receptor or NK-cell activation. • FOS, FOSB, ATF3, EGR1 (positive) – classic MAPK-driven immediate-early transcription factors induced during TCR signaling; together form the AP-1/IEG module that initiates downstream effector programs in activated T cells. • TNFAIP3 (A20) (positive) – NF-κB–inducible negative feedback regulator rapidly expressed after antigen or cytokine stimulation in T cells, limiting excessive activation. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided and no positive genes conflict with a lymphocyte early-activation program.

program_12.description: The program is most consistent with a glucocorticoid-induced, anti-inflammatory / quiescent state in lymphocytes (B and T cells) characterized by dampened MAPK signaling, reduced proliferation, and altered chemokine responsiveness that favors retention in CXCL12-rich niches. Evidence: • TSC22D3 (GILZ) – canonical glucocorticoid‐responsive gene that mediates anti-inflammatory effects and T-cell quiescence. • DUSP1 – glucocorticoid- and stress-inducible MAPK phosphatase that terminates MAPK signaling and cytokine production. • BTG1 – antiproliferative factor enriched in resting B/T cells and often up-regulated after glucocorticoid exposure. • RGS1 – attenuates G-protein–coupled chemokine signaling (e.g., CXCR4/CXCR5), a feature seen in glucocorticoid-treated or tissue-resident lymphocytes. • CXCR4 – chemokine receptor whose surface retention is favored when RGS1 is high; supports homing to and retention within CXCL12-rich bone-marrow or lymphoid niches typical of resting lymphocytes. Inconsistencies: No clear contradictions; all listed genes fit an immediate early, glucocorticoid/stress response and quiescent lymphocyte profile.

program_13.description: The gene set represents a canonical heat-shock/proteotoxic-stress response program, reflecting cells that are experiencing elevated protein-folding demand or environmental stress rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. Evidence: • HSP90AA1 & HSP90AB1 – Inducible (AA1) and constitutive (AB1) Hsp90 chaperones; transcriptionally up-regulated by HSF1 during heat shock and other proteotoxic stresses to stabilize nascent or damaged proteins. • HSPD1 (Hsp60) & HSPE1 (Hsp10) – Mitochondrial chaperonin complex whose expression increases to refold mis-folded mitochondrial proteins under stress. • HSPH1 (Hsp105) – Large Hsp70 family co-chaperone induced by heat shock, supporting prevention of protein aggregation. • The concerted up-regulation of multiple major heat-shock protein families (Hsp90, Hsp70/105, Hsp60/10) is a hallmark of the heat-shock response governed by HSF1, consistent with a generalized proteostasis-stress state across diverse cell types. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes are provided, and no positively loaded genes contradict the stress-response interpretation.

program_14.description: The gene set best fits a broadly expressed “house-keeping / basal stress-response” transcriptional program that can be detected across many cell types rather than a signature of a single, well-defined lineage. The module combines components of RNA processing, cytoskeletal remodeling, energy-metabolism and low-level innate antiviral readiness, features that many cells up-regulate during routine growth or mild stress. Evidence: • RNA processing – HNRNPH1 (heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein, core splicing factor) is a canonical housekeeping gene. • Cytoskeleton / cell shape – CDC42SE1 is an effector of the Rho-GTPase CDC42, supporting actin remodeling required for general motility and membrane trafficking. • Energy metabolism – PHKG1 encodes the γ-subunit of phosphorylase kinase that activates glycogen breakdown, reflecting basal metabolic maintenance. • Innate antiviral / DNA–RNA editing – APOBEC3C is an IFN-inducible cytidine deaminase that provides low-level antiviral defense and is expressed in many hematopoietic and non-hematopoietic cells. • Ubiquitous expression – C1orf56 shows broad, low-level expression in diverse tissues, consistent with a non-lineage-restricted program. Inconsistencies: • No strong lineage-defining markers (e.g., muscle-specific structural genes, classic immune surface markers, neuronal genes) are present; thus the set does not convincingly pin down a single cell type. • APOBEC3C suggests innate immune activation, whereas PHKG1 is classically muscle-biased, underscoring the mixed, non-specific nature of the program.

program_0.description: This program captures a “high-translation/low-mitochondrial-respiration” state that is common in rapidly proliferating or recently activated cells of many lineages. Most cytosolic ribosomal protein genes and the elongation factor EEF1A1 are strongly up-regulated, indicating boosted ribosome biogenesis and protein synthesis, while the key oxidative-phosphorylation gene MT-CO1 is down-regulated, pointing to a relative suppression of mitochondrial respiration (a shift frequently observed in highly proliferative or metabolic-stress states). Evidence: • Cytosolic ribosome biogenesis / translation – Extensive up-regulation of small- and large-subunit ribosomal genes (e.g., RPS6, RPS18, RPL13, RPL10, RPL35A, RPS23) and the translation elongation factor EEF1A1 supports a global increase in protein-synthesis machinery. • Reduced mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation – MT-CO1, encoding a core subunit of cytochrome-c oxidase complex IV, is negatively loaded, consistent with lowered mitochondrial electron-transport activity often accompanying glycolytic or anabolic proliferative states. Inconsistencies: • No strong cell-cycle (MCM, PCNA, HIST) or lineage-specific markers accompany this module, so it is best interpreted as a generic metabolic/translation program rather than tied to a single differentiated cell type.

program_1.description: The gene set represents a ubiquitous heat-shock/proteotoxic stress program rather than a specific lineage; it reflects cells that have recently activated HSF1-driven chaperone expression together with early response transcription factors to counteract protein-misfolding and inflammatory stress. Evidence: • Canonical heat-shock chaperones – HSP90AA1, HSP90AB1, HSPA1A/B, HSPA8, HSPH1, HSPE1, HSPD1, HSPB1 – are classical targets of HSF1 and are rapidly induced upon thermal or proteotoxic stress to refold damaged proteins. • Co-chaperones DNAJB1 and DNAJA1 further support a protein-folding stress response. • Ubiquitin genes UBC and UBB rise with proteotoxic load to tag irreparably damaged proteins for proteasomal degradation. • Immediate-early stress/inflammatory response genes JUN, IER2, DUSP1, and NF-κB inhibitor NFKBIA are typically co-induced during acute cellular stress, linking protein damage to signaling pathways. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were supplied; no major contradictions to a heat-shock/proteotoxic stress state are evident.

program_2.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with cells undergoing a mitochondrial-stress / pre-apoptotic state rather than a specific lineage identity: they show strong up-regulation of mitochondrial-encoded oxidative-phosphorylation transcripts together with the stress-responsive transcription factor JUND, while core biosynthetic (ribosomal) and lineage (CD74) transcripts are concurrently suppressed. Evidence: • High expression of multiple mitochondrial genome genes (MT-ATP6, MT-CO2, MT-CO3, MT-CYB, MT-ND1/3/4/5) is a canonical single-cell signature of dying or metabolically stressed cells that have lost cytoplasmic mRNA but retain abundant, stable mitochondrial RNA. • JUND (AP-1 family) is rapidly induced by oxidative and genotoxic stress and is frequently reported in apoptotic or stress-response programs. • Depletion of ribosomal protein transcript RPS17 and the actin-binding transcript TMSB4X fits the global translation shutdown that accompanies cellular stress and early apoptosis. • Negative loading of CD74 (invariant chain of MHC-II) indicates loss of a lineage-specific, immune-activation program, consistent with a general shutdown rather than a differentiated functional state. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; however, JUND can also mark proliferative signaling, and mitochondrial gene enrichment can occur in highly oxidative, healthy cells—yet the simultaneous loss of ribosomal and lineage transcripts favors the stress/apoptotic interpretation.

program_3.description: The gene set reflects a generic “high-ribosome” program, indicative of cells with elevated ribosome biogenesis and translational capacity rather than a specific lineage; such a signature is commonly seen in rapidly proliferating or metabolically activated cells across many tissues. Evidence: • All positively loaded genes (RPS27, RPS28, RPS29; RPL34, RPL36, RPL37, RPL38, RPL39) encode structural constituents of the small (RPS) or large (RPL) ribosomal subunits, a canonical hallmark of boosted protein synthesis and ribosome assembly. • Concerted up-regulation of multiple RPS and RPL genes is a well-described transcriptomic indicator of heightened translation demands observed during cell-cycle entry, growth factor stimulation, immune activation, or early differentiation. Inconsistencies: • No apparent inconsistencies; the list is uniformly composed of ribosomal protein genes without lineage-specific markers.

program_4.description: The gene set represents an immediate-early/AP-1 activation program that is typically induced within minutes to hours after stimulation of immune cells, consistent with acutely activated dendritic cells or lymphocytes rather than a resting state. Evidence: • FOS, FOSB, ATF3 – canonical AP-1/immediate-early transcription factors induced by receptor or stress signaling in activated immune cells. • CD83 – surface marker sharply up-regulated upon activation of dendritic cells, B cells and T cells. • KLF6 – early-response zinc-finger transcription factor induced during immune activation and inflammatory signaling. • MCL1 (anti-apoptotic) and PMAIP1/NOXA (pro-apoptotic) – reciprocal BCL2-family genes co-induced during acute activation to balance survival versus apoptosis, a pattern documented in recently stimulated lymphocytes and antigen-presenting cells. Inconsistencies: • No genes are overtly contradictory; however, the list lacks additional dendritic-cell–specific markers (e.g., HLA-DRA, LILRA4) or T-cell markers (e.g., CD3E), so the program is best interpreted as a generic early activation signature rather than tied to a single immune lineage.

program_5.description: The program represents a robust type I interferon-stimulated (antiviral) transcriptional state that can be seen in many immune and non-immune cell types upon viral sensing or cytokine exposure. Evidence: • ISG15, IFI44L, ISG20 – canonical interferon-stimulated genes encoding antiviral effector proteins. • LY6E and BST2 (tetherin) – classic IFN-induced restriction factors that inhibit viral entry or release. • B2M – MHC class I component whose expression is up-regulated by type I IFN to enhance antigen presentation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are well-established interferon-responsive genes.

program_6.description: The program represents a strong MHC class II antigen-presentation signature, typical of professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells, macrophages/monocytes, and activated B cells, or of other cell types after IFN-γ–driven activation. Evidence: • HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1 – core α and β chains of the HLA-DR heterodimer, universally up-regulated in APCs. • HLA-DQA1, HLA-DQB1 – encode the α and β chains of the HLA-DQ heterodimer, likewise enriched in APCs. • HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1 – encode the α and β chains of the HLA-DP heterodimer, completing a full complement of MHC class II molecules typically co-expressed when cells are primed for antigen presentation. • Coordinated, high-level expression of multiple MHC class II loci is a hallmark of professional APC identity or IFN-γ–induced APC-like activation in non-hematopoietic cells. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; no negatively loaded genes were supplied.

program_0.description: The program represents a generic “high-translation” state characterized by coordinated up-regulation of cytosolic ribosomal protein genes and the elongation factor EEF1A1, indicative of cells engaged in intense protein synthesis such as proliferating or recently activated cells, while the concurrent down-regulation of the autophagy/ER-membrane gene VMP1 suggests suppression of catabolic processes that would otherwise compete with biosynthetic activity. Evidence: • Coordinated high expression of small and large ribosomal subunit genes (e.g., RPS6, RPS18, RPS27A, RPL5, RPL10, RPLP1) and the translation elongation factor EEF1A1 is a canonical signature of enhanced global translation and growth. • Presence of both RPL and RPS paralogs across nearly every ribosomal position (P, E, and exit sites) underscores a broad, not subtype-specific, activation of the ribosome biogenesis pathway. • Negative loading of VMP1, a gene required for autophagosome formation and ER–autophagosome contact, aligns with the notion that autophagy is repressed when anabolic protein synthesis is prioritized. Inconsistencies: No major gene sets conflict with a translation-high, proliferation-compatible state; the program lacks lineage-specific or stress-response markers that would argue against this interpretation.

program_1.description: This program captures a cellular stress/death state characterized by disproportionately high mitochondrial transcript abundance and a concomitant suppression of global protein-synthesis machinery, a signature commonly observed in apoptotic or severely stressed single-cell RNA-seq profiles rather than in any specific differentiated cell type. Evidence: • Enriched mitochondrial genome transcripts (MT-ATP6, MT-CO1/2/3, MT-CYB, MT-ND1/3/4/5) – hallmark of cells with compromised plasma membranes or mitochondrial dysfunction, leading to leakage and over-representation of mitochondrial RNA reads. • JUND – AP-1 family factor induced by oxidative and apoptotic stress, frequently up-regulated together with mitochondrial genes during cell injury. • Depletion of multiple ribosomal proteins (RPL31, RPL13A, RPL27A, RPL7, RPS17, RPS26) – indicates global translational shutdown typical of stress responses and pre-apoptotic states. • Reduced cytoskeletal/actin dynamics genes (ACTB, TMSB4X, PFN1) – consistent with cytoskeletal disassembly seen in dying or severely stressed cells. Inconsistencies: • None of the negatively loaded genes contradict the stress/death interpretation; however, high mitochondrial reads can also occur in highly oxidative healthy cells (e.g., cardiomyocytes), yet such cells usually maintain or elevate ribosomal gene expression, which is not the case here.

program_2.description: The gene set represents a highly activated cytotoxic lymphocyte program typical of CD8⁺ effector T cells/NK-like cytotoxic T cells that are executing a killing response and producing pro-inflammatory chemokines, rather than naïve or central-memory T cells. Evidence: • Cytotoxic machinery – GNLY, PRF1, GZMB, GZMA, GZMH, CTSW, NKG7 mark cells equipped for perforin/granzyme-mediated killing, characteristic of CD8⁺ effector T cells and NK cells. • Chemokine burst – CCL3, CCL4, CCL5 (RANTES) and IFNG indicate strong effector cytokine/chemokine secretion that recruits additional immune cells; these genes rise upon T-cell receptor or NK-cell activation. • NK/activated-T surface markers – KLRD1 (CD94) and CD63 are enriched on activated cytotoxic lymphocytes. • Adhesion/trafficking – VCAM1 is up-regulated on stimulated T cells, supporting migration to inflamed tissue. • Negative loading of IL7R and LTB – IL7R (CD127) and LTB are hallmarks of naïve or central-memory T cells; their repression is consistent with terminally differentiated effector cells. Inconsistencies: • VCAM1 is more classically endothelial but can be induced on activated T cells; its presence is not strictly cytotoxic-cell specific but does not contradict the effector program.

program_3.description: The gene set represents a mature, highly cytotoxic CD16⁺ natural killer (NK) cell program characterized by strong effector granule content and classic NK‐cell surface receptors, consistent with peripheral blood or tissue-migratory NK cells in an activated state. Evidence: • Cytotoxic granule / killing machinery – FGFBP2, PRF1, NKG7, CST7 all peak in activated NK and cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells but are especially enriched in CD16⁺ NK subsets. • NK-specific receptors and signaling – KLRF1, KLRD1 (CD94), FCGR3A (CD16), S1PR5 (egress receptor for mature NK cells), CD300A, and the adaptor TYROBP together define canonical NK-cell receptor signaling architecture. • Additional NK-associated or innate-lymphoid genes – SPON2, PLAC8 and CST7 are reported in innate cytotoxic lymphocytes, supporting an NK/innate cytotoxic identity. Inconsistencies: • IGFBP7 and SPON2 are more commonly secreted by stromal or myeloid cells; their co-loading may reflect microenvironmental signal contamination rather than intrinsic NK expression. • PLAC8 can be myeloid-enriched, and CMC1/C1orf21 are housekeeping or broadly expressed genes, offering limited phenotypic specificity.

program_4.description: This gene program represents a generic G2/M-phase cell-cycle module characteristic of actively proliferating cells, irrespective of specific lineage. Evidence: • CDK1, BIRC5, CEP55, ASPM, CENPW, ZWINT, CDCA5 – core regulators of mitotic entry, spindle/kinetochore formation, and cytokinesis. • ORC6, ASF1B, RRM2, RAD51AP1 – DNA replication licensing, histone assembly, dNTP synthesis and repair, all peaking in late S to G2 phase. • UBE2C, DTL – ubiquitin-mediated degradation of cell-cycle inhibitors, promoting G2/M progression. • MYBL2 – transcription factor driving expression of many G2/M genes. Inconsistencies: None evident; all listed genes align with a G2/M proliferation program.

program_5.description: The gene constellation most strongly fits an activated natural killer (NK) cell program, particularly the Fc-receptor/ITAM-based signalling arm that supports antibody-dependent cytotoxicity. Evidence: • NK‐specific receptors and adaptor chains – KIR2DL4, FCER1G (CD16 γ-chain), TYROBP (DAP12) and SH2D1B (EAT-2) are classical components of NK-cell activating and SLAM-family signalling pathways. • CD247 (CD3ζ) is the ITAM‐bearing signalling subunit shared by the TCR and by several NK activating receptors (e.g., NKp30/46, CD16). • GZMA encodes granzyme A, a canonical cytotoxic effector stored in NK-cell granules. • Src-family / cytoplasmic kinases FGR and FES participate in downstream signalling from Fc and NK receptors, and are frequently detected in mature, CD16+ NK populations. Inconsistencies: • Keratin gene KRT81, extracellular matrix gene COL23A1, and glycosyltransferase B3GNT7 are not typical of lymphoid cells and may reflect ambient RNA or rare doublets. • S100A13 is a broadly expressed stress-response gene with no specific NK association.

program_6.description: The gene set represents an acute, immediate-early activation program most characteristic of recently T-cell-receptor–stimulated T lymphocytes (and, more broadly, other immune cells responding to strong receptor or cytokine signaling). Evidence: • T-cell activation surface marker – CD69 is rapidly up-regulated within minutes of TCR engagement. • Canonical AP-1 immediate-early transcription factors – FOS, JUN, JUNB drive the first wave of transcription after MAPK/ERK signaling during T-cell activation. • Early response regulators – EGR1, BTG2, IER2, PPP1R15A are prototypical inducible genes seen within 0.5–2 h of stimulation in activated T cells. • Negative feedback phosphatases – DUSP1 and DUSP2 are induced to dampen MAPK signaling during early activation, fitting an immediate-early signature. • NF-κB pathway inhibitor – NFKBIA (IκBα) is transcriptionally induced shortly after NF-κB activation, consistent with an early activation burst. Inconsistencies: • No substantially discordant genes are present; all listed genes align with a rapid stimulus-response / early activation program.

program_7.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated tissue-resident cytotoxic lymphocyte program found in natural killer (NK) cells and NK-like tissue-resident memory (TRM) T cells. Evidence: • NK / cytotoxic lymphocyte receptors and signaling: KLRC1 (NKG2A) and KLRC2 (NKG2C) are hallmark inhibitory/activating receptors of NK cells; TYROBP (DAP12) and FCER1G encode adaptor chains that transmit activating signals in NK and TRM cells. • T/NK-associated tyrosine kinase: TXK (RLK) is preferentially expressed in activated T and NK cells. • Tissue residency: HOPX marks long-lived tissue-resident memory T cells and some tissue NK subsets. • Effector chemokines: XCL1 and XCL2 are secreted by activated NK and cytotoxic TRM cells to attract XCR1⁺ dendritic cells and amplify local immunity. • Negative loading of S100A4, a motility/mesenchymal marker, aligns with a sessile tissue-resident rather than migratory state. Inconsistencies: • B2M, a ubiquitously expressed MHC-I component, is negatively loaded; most NK and T cells usually express B2M, so its relative depletion is unexpected. • Classic cytotoxic granule genes (e.g., GZMB, PRF1, NKG7) are not present in the positive list, suggesting either a non-cytolytic activation state or incomplete capture of the full program.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated/effector regulatory T-cell (Treg) program, such as the FOXP3⁺ IL-2RA⁺ Tregs that expand after antigenic stimulation in inflamed tissues or tumors. Evidence: • FOXP3 and IL2RA (CD25) – canonical master regulator and high-affinity IL-2 receptor chain defining Tregs. • TNFRSF4 (OX40) – costimulatory receptor preferentially up-regulated on activated Tregs within inflamed tissues. • IL1R2 – decoy IL-1 receptor highly enriched in suppressive, activated Tregs. • BATF – transcription factor induced during T-cell activation and required for effector Treg differentiation. • SAT1, CUL9, BEX3, GNG8 – genes up-regulated in metabolically active or proliferating lymphocytes, compatible with an activated Treg state. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; BATF can also be expressed in other activated T-cell subsets, and GNG8/BEX3 lack Treg specificity, but their presence does not oppose the overall Treg signature.

program_9.description: The program primarily reflects an acute cellular stress/heat-shock response, most commonly seen in activated immune (e.g., T or NK) cells that are simultaneously producing effector cytokines such as IFN-γ. Evidence: • Canonical heat-shock/chaperone genes – HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSPA6 (HSP70 family), HSP90AA1 (HSP90), DNAJB1 (HSP40 co-chaperone) and HSPB1 (Hsp27) – are hallmarks of the conserved heat-shock/proteotoxic-stress pathway driven by HSF1. • RGS2 is an immediate-early, stress-inducible regulator of GPCR signaling that often accompanies heat-shock gene induction. • IFNG (interferon-γ) and CXCL13 (B-cell-attracting chemokine) show that the stressed cells are immunologically activated, consistent with IFN-γ-producing Th1/Tph or cytotoxic lymphocytes experiencing proteotoxic stress during strong stimulation. Inconsistencies: • IFNG and CXCL13 are not part of the classical heat-shock module; their presence indicates the program is occurring within activated immune cells rather than being a universal stress response across all cell types.

program_10.description: The program is characteristic of acutely activated inflammatory myeloid cells—principally neutrophils and inflammatory monocytes/macrophages—engaged in cytokine/chemokine release, alarmin production, and metabolic adaptation to oxidative stress. Evidence: • S100A8, S100A9 – canonical neutrophil/monocyte alarmins (calprotectin) abundantly expressed during acute inflammation. • CXCL8 (IL-8) – potent neutrophil-attracting chemokine produced by activated monocytes and neutrophils themselves. • IL1RN – IL-1 receptor antagonist secreted by stimulated monocytes/macrophages to modulate IL-1–driven inflammation. • G0S2, NAMPT, SOD2 – metabolic/oxidative-stress response genes up-regulated in activated myeloid cells to support high energetic and redox demands. • C15orf48 (NMES1) – transcriptional marker of pro-inflammatory macrophages and neutrophils in human tissues. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes cohere with an activated inflammatory myeloid phenotype.

program_11.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, non-cytotoxic CD4⁺ T-cell program—such as recently activated helper or regulatory T cells—that up-regulate costimulatory machinery (CD28, CD80) and IL-1 responsiveness while lacking classical cytotoxic/NK or professional antigen-presenting cell signatures. Evidence: • CD4 and CD28 together mark CD4⁺ helper/T-reg lineage cells that retain the canonical CD28 costimulatory receptor. • CD80, although classically APC-restricted, is inducible on strongly activated Tregs/effector CD4⁺ T cells, indicating an activated, immunoregulatory state rather than a resting T cell. • IL1R1 is up-regulated on activated/memory CD4⁺ T cells and especially on Tregs, conferring sensitivity to IL-1 family cytokines. • Negative loading of GZMK and HCST (genes associated with cytotoxic CD8⁺/NK programs) supports a non-cytotoxic, helper/regulatory phenotype. • Negative loading of HLA-DQB1 (MHC-II) argues against dendritic cells, B cells or macrophages as the dominant contributor, reinforcing a T-cell identity. Inconsistencies: • F5 (coagulation factor V) is atypical for T cells and is more commonly seen in hepatocytes or some macrophage subsets, suggesting either low-level promiscuous expression or ambient RNA contamination. • Constitutive CD80 expression is uncommon in resting T cells; its presence here presumes a highly activated T-cell subset and could alternatively derive from contaminating APC transcripts.

program_12.description: The gene set represents an antigen-presentation program characterized by strong induction of MHC class II machinery typical of professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs)—most plausibly activated B cells or dendritic cells—accompanied by CXCL13, a chemokine linked to follicular/germinal-center activity. Evidence: • HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQA1 – core MHC-II α/β chains required for peptide display on professional APCs. • CD74 – invariant chain that chaperones MHC-II complexes; its co-induction is a canonical hallmark of APC activation. • CXCL13 – chemoattractant for CXCR5⁺ B and T follicular helper cells; commonly produced by germinal-center B cells, follicular dendritic cells, and some activated dendritic cells, pointing to a follicular/lymph-node context. Inconsistencies: • CXCL13 is not universally expressed by all APCs; its presence favors follicular B or specialized dendritic cells rather than generic macrophages, but does not conflict with an overall MHC-II antigen-presentation program.

program_13.description: The gene set represents a robust type I/III interferon-stimulated (antiviral) response program that can be induced in many cell types (e.g., epithelial cells, monocytes, dendritic cells) upon viral sensing or exogenous IFN-α/β/λ exposure; it reflects an “acute interferon activation state” rather than a lineage-defining signature. Evidence: • Canonical ISGs: ISG15, IFI6, IFIT1, IFIT3, MX1, RSAD2 (viperin), and CMPK2 are textbook interferon-stimulated genes up-regulated within minutes to hours after IFN-α/β signaling, mediating antiviral restriction, RNA modification, and immune modulation. • Coordinated up-regulation of multiple IFIT family members (IFIT1, IFIT3) and MX1 is characteristic of a high-magnitude type I IFN response rather than basal immune tone. • CMPK2 and RSAD2 function in interferon-induced metabolic re-programming of mitochondria and lipid droplets, reinforcing that this program reflects an antiviral state. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are coherent with a type I/III interferon response.

program_14.description: The gene set strongly indicates a myeloid lineage program characteristic of tissue-resident phagocytes—most consistently homeostatic or mildly activated microglia/macrophages that secrete complement C1q and display classical phagocytic/iron-handling markers. Evidence: • Complement subunits C1QA, C1QB, C1QC – hallmark of microglia and other tissue macrophages that produce the C1q complex to tag synapses/pathogens for clearance. • AIF1 (IBA1) and CD68 – core markers of microglia/macrophage identity and active phagocytic function. • FTL (ferritin light chain) – iron-storage protein highly expressed in macrophages/microglia engaged in iron recycling and oxidative stress responses. Inconsistencies: • No obvious gene contradicts a microglial/macrophage identity; list lacks markers of alternative lineages.

program_15.description: The gene set reflects a generic “house-keeping / actin-cytoskeleton maintenance” program typical of relatively quiescent cells that are sustaining basal glycolysis and actin turnover while lacking acute AP-1 (FOS)–driven activation. Such a module is commonly observed across many epithelial, stromal, and immune populations when they are not recently stimulated. Evidence: • GAPDH – high glycolytic flux characteristic of basic metabolic maintenance. • CFL1, TMSB10, MYL6 – core actin-binding or contractile proteins required for steady-state actin filament turnover and cytoskeletal tension. • SH3BGRL3 – adaptor implicated in membrane/actin interactions, enriched together with the above cytoskeletal regulators. • FOS (negatively loaded) – FOS is an immediate-early transcription factor induced by stress, cytokines, or mitogens; its inverse association supports a low-activation or resting condition. Inconsistencies: • The list lacks lineage-restricted markers, so the program is not cell-type specific and may co-exist in multiple cell identities; no overt contradictions within the limited gene set.

program_16.description: The program is most consistent with a quiescent, circulating IL-7R^high naïve/central-memory T-cell state that has recently experienced glucocorticoid or other anti-inflammatory signaling. Evidence: • IL7R (CD127) – hallmark of naïve and central-memory T cells that rely on IL-7 for survival. • KLF2 and CXCR4 – transcription factor and chemokine receptor that drive lymph-node homing and are rapidly down-regulated after T-cell activation, marking resting, recirculating T cells. • TXNIP – metabolic brake enriched in quiescent lymphocytes, supporting a non-proliferative status. • TSC22D3 (GILZ) and ANXA1 – classical glucocorticoid-inducible, anti-inflammatory genes frequently co-expressed in resting T cells exposed to endogenous or exogenous steroids, reinforcing a tolerant/homeostatic phenotype. Inconsistencies: • ANXA1 can also be abundant in myeloid cells, but its co-occurrence with strong T-cell markers (IL7R, KLF2, CXCR4) supports a T-cell origin in this context.

program_17.description: The gene set represents a generic S-phase DNA-replication program, marking cells that are actively proliferating rather than defining a specific differentiated cell type. Evidence: • CDT1, MCM2 and MCM10 – replication-licensing and helicase components essential during G1/S transition and throughout S phase. • TYMS – catalyzes de novo dTMP synthesis, up-regulated when cells synthesize DNA. • FEN1 – processes Okazaki fragments during lagging-strand replication, peaking in S phase. • FAM111B – PCNA-interacting protein that promotes replisome activity and is transcriptionally induced in S-phase cells. • No negatively loaded genes counteracting proliferation signals, supporting a pure S-phase signature. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes coherently point to DNA replication/S-phase activity.

program_18.description: The program most closely matches an activated, tissue-infiltrating T helper 17 (Th17) cell state—often termed “pathogenic” Th17 cells—characterised by IL-23 responsiveness, IL-17 production and CCR6/CCL20-mediated trafficking, with additional extracellular-matrix–associated transcripts that are sometimes up-regulated in strongly activated Th17 cells within inflamed tissue. Evidence: • IL17A – signature effector cytokine of Th17 cells. • IL23R – receptor required for expansion/pathogenicity of Th17 cells; distinguishes Th17 from other T-helper subsets. • CCR6 and its ligand CCL20 – canonical chemokine pair guiding Th17 migration to mucosal and inflamed sites; CCR6 expression is a defining surface marker of Th17 cells. • ADAM12 and COL5A3 – extracellular-matrix/remodelling genes reported to be induced in highly activated or tissue-resident (“pathogenic”) Th17 cells in autoimmune settings (e.g., inflamed gut, synovium), consistent with a tissue-infiltrating effector state. Inconsistencies: • ADAM12 and COL5A3 are more typical of mesenchymal cells; their strong co-expression could indicate partial contamination/ambient RNA or a fibroblast doublet, but low-level expression is documented in activated Th17 cells and therefore does not clearly contradict the Th17 interpretation.

program_19.description: The gene set describes a canonical mature B-cell identity program characteristic of resting peripheral (naïve or memory) B lymphocytes that retain surface B-cell receptor (BCR) expression and are not yet committed to plasma-cell differentiation or proliferation. Evidence: • MS4A1 (CD20) and CD79A – hallmark surface/BCR-signaling components of mature B cells. • MEF2C – transcription factor sustaining B-cell lineage commitment and germinal-center/naïve B-cell survival. • TCF4 (E2-2) – supports B-cell development and is maintained in mature B cells prior to plasma-cell transition. • BASP1 – expressed in resting and memory B cells; modulates MEF2C activity, reinforcing a quiescent B-cell state. Inconsistencies: • None noted; all listed genes are consistent with a resting mature B-cell program.

program_0.description: The program represents a generic G2/M-phase mitotic proliferation signature, characteristic of cells actively progressing through chromosome segregation and cytokinesis rather than of any particular differentiated cell lineage. Evidence: • Core G2/M cyclins and kinase regulators (CCNA2, CCNB1, CDK1, PLK1, TTK) mark cells committed to mitosis. • Anaphase-promoting complex activators (CDC20, UBE2C) support metaphase–anaphase transition. • Chromosome passenger complex components (AURKB, BIRC5, CDCA8) and centromere proteins (CENPA, HJURP) ensure accurate chromosomal alignment and segregation. • Spindle assembly and kinesin motors (KIF2C, KIF18B, KIF14, KIF23, DLGAP5, NUSAP1, TPX2, NEK2, ASPM) highlight robust mitotic spindle activity. • Cytokinesis and mid-body factors (CEP55, KIF23, HMMR) indicate completion of cell division. • DNA topology and repair enzymes (TOP2A, PIF1) accompany high replication stress typical of dividing cells. Inconsistencies: No notable genes contradict a proliferative G2/M-phase state; the list lacks lineage-restricted markers, reinforcing the view that this program captures a universal mitotic process rather than a specific cell type.

program_1.description: The gene set most closely matches a neuronal / neuroendocrine secretory program, characteristic of mature, electrically excitable cells that package peptide hormones or neurotransmitters into secretory vesicles and are primed for rapid exocytosis. Evidence: • Synaptic‐vesicle assembly and release: STX1A (syntaxin-1A), UNC13A (Munc13-1) and LAT2 cooperate in vesicle docking/priming; CHGB is a canonical dense-core vesicle marker. • Electrical excitability: SCN2A (Nav1.2 sodium channel) and KCNK9 (two-pore K⁺ channel) support action-potential generation and resting membrane potential typical of neurons. • Neuroendocrine / secreted factors: FST, AZGP1, VSTM2A and TNFRSF11B encode secreted peptides commonly produced by neuroendocrine cells. • Neuro-associated transcription factors: SOX2, TCF4 and ST18 regulate neural lineage specification and maintenance. • EPHB6, RUNDC3A and STX1A participate in axon guidance or synapse organisation, reinforcing a neuronal identity. Inconsistencies: • Lymphoid signalling molecules (LCK, LAT2, CLEC2B, RGS13) are typical of T, B or NK cells rather than neurons. • MYBPC1 (skeletal muscle), AKR1C4 & AGMO (hepatic/lipid metabolism) and CRYBA2 (lens) are not expected in neurons, suggesting minor contamination or cross-loading of transcripts.

program_2.description: The program predominantly reflects an intracellular signal-transduction/activation state common to hematopoietic immune cells—especially myeloid and T-cell populations—marked by coordinated expression of Src-family kinases, SH2/adapter proteins, GPCR components and sphingolipid-mediated signaling molecules that facilitate receptor-triggered responses, cytoskeletal rearrangement and migration. Evidence: • Immune-receptor signaling scaffold – HCK (myeloid-restricted Src kinase), FYB1/ADAP (T-cell & myeloid adapter), SH2D6 (SH2-domain protein enriched in lymphoid tissues), PTPN7/HePTP (hematopoietic MAPK phosphatase). • Lipid-mediated activation – SPHK1 catalyzes sphingosine-1-phosphate production, a key chemoattractant for lymphoid trafficking. • GPCR/G-protein components that relay chemokine or neuropeptide cues – GNG13 (G-protein γ subunit), TACR2 (tachykinin receptor 2). • Cellular remodeling machinery – TUBA1A (α-tubulin) and EIF1B (translation initiation) rise during immune activation to support cytoskeletal dynamics and protein synthesis. Inconsistencies: • PRSS1 (pancreatic trypsin), UCN3 (pancreatic/neuronal hormone), RTBDN (retina-specific protein), COL18A1 (broad extracellular matrix collagen) and the sensory-neuron-biased GNG13 are not typically linked to hematopoietic cells and may represent background or low-level contamination from exocrine, endocrine, ocular or stromal sources.

program_3.description: The gene set is characteristic of intestinal/colonic goblet cells in an active secretory state, reflecting a program dedicated to mucus production and epithelial barrier defense. Evidence: • Core goblet-cell secreted proteins: FCGBP, TFF3, ITLN1, RETNLB, CLCA1, SPINK4, B3GNT6 – all highly enriched in colonic goblet cells and constituents/modulators of the mucous layer. • Goblet-cell transcriptional regulator: ATOH1 drives differentiation of secretory lineages, including goblet cells, in the intestinal epithelium. • Additional secretory epithelial markers: HEPACAM2, WFDC2, REP15 support a mucosal secretory identity. Inconsistencies: • TPSG1 (tryptase γ-1) is classically associated with mast cells rather than epithelial goblet cells and may reflect low-level contamination or sparse co-expression.

program_4.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature, metabolically active absorptive enterocyte/colonocyte program characterized by enhanced xenobiotic detoxification and oxidative-stress protection. Evidence: • Detoxification enzymes – ADH1C (alcohol dehydrogenase) and UGT2B17 (UDP-glucuronosyltransferase) are classically expressed in intestinal epithelium and liver to eliminate dietary and microbial compounds. • Oxidative-stress/heavy-metal response – A concerted up-regulation of MT1 family genes (MT1G, MT1M, MT1F, MT1H, MT1X) is typical of intestinal epithelial cells exposed to dietary metals and reactive oxygen species. • Energy/ketogenic metabolism – HMGCS2, a mitochondrial ketogenesis and β-oxidation enzyme, is highly expressed in differentiated enterocytes and colonocytes that rely on fatty-acid–derived ketone bodies. • Ion and pH regulation genes characteristic of gut epithelium – CHP2 (regulator of the brush-border Na+/H+ exchanger NHE3) and the cytosolic carbonic anhydrases CA1 and CA2 support acid-base handling and salt absorption in intestinal cells. • C15orf48 (NMES1) is an interferon-inducible gene enriched in gastrointestinal epithelium, further supporting an intestinal locale. Inconsistencies: • CA1/CA2 are also abundant in erythrocytes, and ADH1C is liver-enriched; however, all three have documented expression in gut epithelium, so their presence is not strongly discordant with an enterocyte/colonocyte identity.

program_5.description: The program represents a strong MHC-class II antigen-presentation/IFN-γ activation module typical of professional antigen-presenting cells (dendritic cells, macrophages and B cells) or other cells responding to interferon-γ. Evidence: • Classical MHC-II structural genes HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1, ‑DPA1, ‑DPB1, ‑DQA1, ‑DQB1 and the peptide-editing chaperones HLA-DMA/HLA-DMB constitute the core machinery required for presenting exogenous peptides to CD4⁺ T cells. • CD74 (invariant chain) escorts MHC-II molecules through the endosomal pathway, a hallmark of active antigen presentation. • UBD (FAT10) is an interferon-γ/TNF-α-inducible ubiquitin-like modifier enriched in activated antigen-presenting cells. • AIM2 is an interferon-inducible cytosolic DNA sensor that couples innate immune sensing with inflammasome activation, frequently co-expressed with IFN-γ–driven antigen-presentation genes. Inconsistencies: No obvious contradictions; the entire gene set coherently supports an IFN-γ–driven MHC-II antigen-presentation state, although the lack of lineage-specific markers prevents pinpointing the exact APC subtype.

program_6.description: The program is most consistent with an activated, tissue-resident memory lymphocyte state, particularly CD69⁺ T-cells that are retained in inflamed tissue and poised for rapid effector function. Evidence: • Tissue residency / retention – CD69 (canonical TRM marker that blocks S1PR1 egress), RGS1 and LSP1 (both promote retention within tissues), CXCR4 (guides positioning in CXCL12-rich niches). • Lymphocyte identity – CD52 (pan-lymphocyte surface protein), SRGN (granule proteoglycan in cytotoxic T and NK cells), GMFG (actin-remodelling protein in lymphocytes). • Activation / regulatory signals – CD69 (early activation), TSC22D3/GILZ (induced by glucocorticoids/IL-10 in activated T cells), ALOX5AP (leukotriene-pathway gene up-regulated after T-cell activation). Inconsistencies: • CD37 and LAPTM5 are more strongly associated with B cells or myeloid cells. • ALOX5AP and LAPTM5 are highly expressed in monocytes/macrophages, suggesting some myeloid contribution to the program.

program_7.description: The gene set is most compatible with a gastrointestinal secretory-lineage program that mixes features of intestinal goblet cells and pro-glucagon–producing enteroendocrine L cells, a state often seen in mucin-rich, remodeling epithelium of the small intestine or colon. Evidence: • Goblet-cell mucin machinery – MUC2 (major intestinal mucin) and TFF1 (trefoil factor that stabilises mucus) mark mucus-secreting goblet cells. • Enteroendocrine L-cell identity – GCG (pro-glucagon, precursor of GLP-1/2) together with TM4SF4 (strongly enriched in intestinal L cells) indicates an endocrine component. • Secretory/epithelial support genes – SERPINA1 (secreted antiprotease), HSPA2 (protein-folding chaperone), KCNMA1 (Ca²⁺-activated K⁺ channel important for stimulus–secretion coupling) and CRIP2 (zinc-binding transcriptional modulator) are all expressed in secretory epithelial cells. • Remodeling/WNT modulation – FRZB (secreted WNT antagonist) and FAP (extracellular-matrix protease induced during epithelial remodeling) fit with a reparative or metaplastic intestinal epithelium where stromal–epithelial crosstalk is active. Inconsistencies: • FAP is classically a fibroblast activation marker rather than an epithelial gene, suggesting stromal contamination or epithelial–mesenchymal transition signals in the program. • SERPINA1 is most abundant in hepatocytes; its presence may reflect a generic acute-phase/secretory response rather than strict intestinal identity.

program_8.description: The program represents a generic mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation module, typified by high expression of mitochondrially encoded electron-transport-chain transcripts and usually marking cells that are either highly respiring (e.g., energetically active muscle/neuronal cells) or, more commonly in single-cell RNA-seq data, cells undergoing metabolic or apoptotic stress that leads to leakage of mitochondrial RNA and a high percent-mito readout. Evidence: • Complex I subunits (MT-ND1, MT-ND2, MT-ND3, MT-ND4, MT-ND4L, MT-ND5) – signature of elevated NADH dehydrogenase activity. • Complex III subunit (MT-CYB) – points toward intact respiratory chain engagement. • Complex IV subunits (MT-CO1, MT-CO2, MT-CO3) – hallmark of oxidative phosphorylation. • Complex V subunit (MT-ATP6) – requirement for ATP synthase, consistent with a high OXPHOS state. Collectively these genes form the canonical “high-percent mitochondrial” signature used as a QC marker for stressed or dying cells and, when genuine, reflect elevated oxidative phosphorylation demand. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes are provided; no contradictions detected.

program_9.description: This gene set most strongly matches an immature/proliferative articular or growth-plate chondrocyte program characterized by active synthesis of cartilage extracellular matrix and responsiveness to growth and inflammatory signals. Evidence: • Cartilage matrix genes – COL2A1 and COL11A2 encode type II and XI collagens that are signature components of hyaline cartilage and are expressed at highest levels in proliferative/pre-hypertrophic chondrocytes. • Chondrocyte-enriched regulator – MIA (also called CD-RAP) is a well-validated marker of differentiated chondrocytes and accompanies COL2A1 expression during cartilage formation. • Growth factor support – IGF2 promotes proliferation and matrix production in fetal and growth-plate chondrocytes, fitting an immature, anabolic state. • Ancillary chondrocyte/osteochondral genes – CAPN6 is up-regulated in developing cartilage and osteoarthritic chondrocytes, compatible with a chondrocyte lineage context. • Innate immune sensor – TLR4 is inducible in articular chondrocytes and is often detected when these cells are exposed to inflammatory or damage-associated cues, suggesting an activated or stress-responsive chondrocyte state. Inconsistencies: • CLDN2 (tight-junction claudin, mainly epithelial) and SLC14A1 (urea transporter, erythroid/kidney) are not classical cartilage genes, though low-level or contaminating expression cannot be excluded. • TLR4 and CAPN6 are more typical of stressed or osteoarthritic chondrocytes than strictly healthy immature chondrocytes, indicating either mixed states or a subtle inflammatory overlay within the program.

program_10.description: The program represents cells in an “interferon-stimulated” antiviral state (often termed an IFN-high state) rather than a specific lineage; the concerted up-regulation of classical type I interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) indicates recent exposure to type I IFN or viral sensing. Evidence: • MX1, MX2 – dynamin-like GTPases induced by type I IFN that block viral transcription/replication. • ISG15 – ubiquitin-like modifier highly up-regulated by IFN-α/β, conjugates to viral and host proteins to restrict infection. • IFI44, IFI44L, IFI6 – canonical ISGs transcriptionally driven by STAT1/2–IRF9 signaling; IFI6 limits flavivirus replication. • IFIT1 – binds 5′-triphosphate viral RNA, suppressing translation; strongly induced by type I IFN. • RSAD2 (viperin) – ISG that inhibits multiple viruses by disrupting lipid rafts and viral budding. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are hallmark ISGs and coherently support an interferon-stimulated antiviral state.

program_11.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated/regenerative alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial program in the lung, characterized by maintenance of canonical AT2 identity (NKX2-1, SFTA3, SLC22A31) together with induction of secreted factors (CXCL14, EREG) that are typically up-regulated during epithelial injury repair or paracrine signaling. Evidence: • AT2 lineage/identity markers – NKX2-1 (master TF of distal lung epithelium) and surfactant-related gene SFTA3 support an alveolar epithelial origin. • Additional AT2-enriched transcripts – SLC22A31 is highly selective for AT2 cells in human single-cell atlases. • Injury/repair–associated secretory signals – CXCL14 and EREG are chemokine and EGFR-ligand transcripts induced in AT2 cells during inflammatory or regenerative states. • Cellular machinery compatible with secretory/lipid handling functions of AT2 cells – KIF25 (microtubule transport), ERP27 (ER chaperone), and CERS4 (ceramide synthesis) match the high secretory and lipid-processing load of surfactant-producing AT2 cells. Inconsistencies: • No obvious contradictory genes appear in the positively loaded list, and no negatively loaded genes were provided.

program_12.description: The program strongly matches the transcriptomic signature of BEST4⁺ / OTOP2⁺ “ionocyte-like” enterocytes found in human small intestine and colon epithelium, a rare absorptive cell type specialized for pH and electrolyte sensing/secretion rather than nutrient uptake. Evidence: • BEST4, CA4, CA7 and GUCA2B are canonical markers of BEST4⁺ intestinal ionocytes, reflecting bicarbonate handling (CA4/CA7) and secretion of the guanylin hormone uroguanylin (GUCA2B). • ITM2C and CPNE8 are repeatedly reported as enriched in colon epithelium and cluster with BEST4⁺ cells in single-cell atlases. • SPIB, while classically an M-cell transcription factor, is one of the few TFs recurrently detected in BEST4⁺ enterocytes, supporting this identity. Inconsistencies: • SPIB expression could also suggest M-cell identity; however, the absence of other M-cell genes (e.g., TNFRSF11A, CCL20, GP2) and the presence of multiple BEST4⁺ ionocyte markers argue the program is BEST4⁺ enterocyte rather than M cells.

program_13.description: The gene set denotes barrier epithelial cells (e.g., airway or intestinal epithelium) engaged in an acute, NF-κB / IL-17–driven antimicrobial-inflammatory response—characterized by secretion of neutrophil-recruiting chemokines, acute-phase proteins, and reactive-oxygen-species machinery. Evidence: • CXCL1 & CXCL3 – canonical NF-κB / IL-1 / IL-17 inducible chemokines that epithelial cells release to attract neutrophils. • CCL20 – epithelial chemokine attracting CCR6⁺ Th17 cells and dendritic cells during mucosal inflammation. • LCN2 (lipocalin-2) & SAA1 – acute-phase, antimicrobial proteins strongly up-regulated in inflamed airway, gut and renal epithelia. • PI3 (elafin) – serine-protease inhibitor produced by inflamed airway/skin epithelium, limiting neutrophil elastase activity. • DUOXA2 – maturation factor for DUOX2 hydrogen-peroxide–producing enzyme; highly expressed in intestinal and airway epithelia during cytokine-induced host-defense responses. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes align with an epithelial pro-inflammatory/innate-defense program.

program_14.description: The gene set most closely matches an activated fibroblast / mesenchymal stromal‐cell program engaged in wound-healing–type secretory activity (ECM production, lipid transport and coagulation modulation) under Notch signalling control. Evidence: • Extracellular-matrix production – FN1 is a canonical fibroblast/myofibroblast marker that rises during tissue remodelling and fibrosis. • Secretory, lipid-handling fibroblast subtype – APOD is enriched in “lipofibroblasts” and other secretory fibroblast states. • Coagulation-linked wound response – F5 transcripts are induced in inflammatory or injury-associated fibroblasts and synovial stromal cells, providing local coagulation factors. • Notch pathway modulation – MFNG (Manic fringe) glycosylates NOTCH receptors and is up-regulated during fibroblast activation and differentiation. Taken together, these positively loaded genes form a coherent fibroblast activation / wound-healing signature. Inconsistencies: • FAM9C and TCP11 are typically testis-restricted, germ-cell genes and are not characteristic of fibroblasts, suggesting low-level ectopic expression or technical contamination.

program_15.description: The gene set reflects activated, cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells (effector / effector-memory state) that secrete chemokines to recruit additional immune cells. Evidence: • T-cell identity: CD3D (T-cell receptor complex) and CD7 (pan-T marker) firmly place the program in the T-cell lineage, excluding CD3⁻ NK cells. • Cytotoxic machinery: GZMA (granzyme A) and HCST/DAP10 (adaptor for NKG2D signaling used by cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells) mark cytolytic competence. • Chemokine secretion: High CCL5 (RANTES) and CCL4 (MIP-1β) are hallmarks of activated effector-memory CD8⁺ T cells that attract CCR5-expressing leukocytes to inflammatory sites. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes are compatible with an activated cytotoxic T-cell program.

program_16.description: This program reflects an immediate-early gene (IEG) activation/stress-response state that can be transiently induced in virtually any cell type by acute stimuli such as growth factors, inflammation, mechanical dissociation or other stresses, rather than marking a specific lineage. Evidence: • JUN, FOSB, EGR1 – canonical AP-1/IEG transcription factors rapidly up-regulated within minutes of cell activation. • ATF3 – stress-inducible transcription factor cooperates with AP-1 family during early response. • DUSP1 – feedback phosphatase that attenuates MAPK signaling downstream of IEG induction. • BTG2 – classic early-response gene limiting cell-cycle entry after acute stimulation. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes or lineage-restricted markers are present, so no contradictions with the assigned “general stress/IEG” state are observed.

program_17.description: The gene set defines a canonical epithelial cell–cell adhesion program, marked by robust expression of adherens- and desmosome-associated proteins typical of differentiated, junction-rich epithelial cells (e.g., epidermal keratinocytes and simple mucosal epithelia) in a homeostatic state. Evidence: • CDH1 (E-cadherin) – central adherens-junction cadherin universally used to identify epithelial lineage. • DSG2 and DSP – desmoglein-2 and desmoplakin are core desmosomal components, enriched in stratified and simple epithelia with strong intercellular junctions. • SPTBN1 – spectrin β-chain anchors cadherin complexes to the cortical actin cytoskeleton, supporting epithelial junction integrity. • CANX and TMBIM6 – ER chaperones/stress-response proteins often up-regulated alongside high secretory load of junctional proteins in mature epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently support an epithelial adhesion/desmosome module.

program_18.description: The program is best explained by epithelial stem/progenitor cells that are experiencing strong canonical Wnt/β-catenin signalling and have switched on a characteristic negative-feedback module that tempers this pathway; this pattern is well described for intestinal crypt base columnar (LGR5⁺) stem cells and for other Wnt-high epithelial progenitors. Evidence: • NOTUM, NKD1, APCDD1 – three well-validated direct Wnt/β-catenin target genes that encode extracellular or membrane Wnt antagonists and are highly expressed in Wnt-high intestinal stem cells, hair-follicle matrix cells and pericentral hepatocytes as part of an auto-regulatory feedback loop. • ATOH8 – bHLH transcription factor transcriptionally induced by Wnt signalling in the intestinal epithelium and reported to restrain proliferation and promote differentiation, fitting a feedback-control programme. • PTCH1 – Hedgehog receptor whose expression is up-regulated in cells that receive Hedgehog cues; Hedgehog–Wnt cross-talk helps position Wnt-responsive stem cells in several epithelia, including the gut and skin, and PTCH1 frequently co-labels with Wnt feedback genes in these niches. Inconsistencies: • The list lacks classic proliferative stem-cell markers (e.g. LGR5, ASCL2, AXIN2); if those genes are absent from the wider dataset, the assignment to crypt stem cells would be less secure. • PTCH1 is a Hedgehog, not Wnt, component; its presence is compatible with niche stem cells but could also point to other Hedgehog-responsive cell types such as mesenchyme or neural progenitors.

program_19.description: The program reflects a core “simple” (non-stratified) epithelial structural identity, typical of luminal or ductal epithelial cells and many epithelial-derived carcinoma cells, characterized by high expression of KRT8/KRT19 and accompanying cytoskeleton- and membrane-associated genes. Evidence: • KRT8 and KRT19 – canonical intermediate filaments of simple/luminal epithelia (e.g., hepatobiliary ducts, pancreatic ducts, lung airway/luminal cells, many adenocarcinomas); absent from stratified epithelia that instead use KRT5/14. • ANXA2 – annexin enriched at the apical/lateral membrane of epithelial cells; supports membrane trafficking and tight-junction dynamics in luminal epithelia. • S100A6 – calcium-binding protein up-regulated in proliferative epithelial cells and epithelial cancers; cooperates with annexins and actin. • ACTB – β-actin, a ubiquitous cytoskeletal component, abundant in cells with active cytoskeletal remodeling such as epithelial sheets. Inconsistencies: • None apparent with the listed genes; all positively loaded genes align with a simple epithelial/luminal program.

program_0.description: The program represents a canonical G2/M-phase cell-cycle state characteristic of actively dividing cells—whether stem, progenitor, or tumor—rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. It reflects coordinated expression of mitotic spindle, kinetochore, chromosome-segregation and cytokinesis genes, together with universal proliferation markers. Evidence: • Universal proliferation markers – MKI67, BIRC5 (Survivin), FOXM1 confirm high mitotic activity. • G2/M cyclins and cell-cycle regulators – CCNA2, CCNB1, CCNB2, CDC20, CDKN3, PLK1, CDC25C drive transition through G2 and entry into mitosis. • Spindle assembly/kinetochore components – NUSAP1, CENPA/CENPF/CENPE/CENPW, NDC80, KIF11, KIF14, KIF15, KIF18A/B, KIF20A/B, KIF23, TACC3, HJURP support spindle formation and chromosome alignment. • Spindle-checkpoint and APC/C modulators – BUB1, BUB1B, MAD2L1, TTK, SGO1, SGO2 ensure proper chromosome segregation. • Cytokinesis and mid-body factors – ANLN, PRC1, RACGAP1, CEP55, CIT finalize cell division. • DNA topology/repair enzymes – TOP2A, PIF1, HMGB2 facilitate chromosomal condensation and stability during mitosis. Inconsistencies: None obvious; the entire gene set coherently maps to the mitotic (G2/M) cell-cycle program, with no negatively loaded genes provided.

program_1.description: The gene set is most consistent with the transcriptional program of chemosensory tuft/brush epithelial cells that are c-Kit-positive and poised for immunomodulatory activity, characterised by taste-signal transduction machinery and strong eicosanoid-biosynthetic capacity. Evidence: • Tuft-cell lineage regulators – POU2F3 and SPIB are the core transcription factors that specify mammalian tuft/brush cells. • Chemosensory/taste‐signalling module – TRPM5, TAS1R3, GNG13, PLCB2 and PAK3 encode the canonical taste-transduction cascade uniquely co-expressed by tuft cells. • Tuft-cell structural/marker genes – AVIL (villin-like), AOC1 (diamine oxidase), DKK3 and DEFB1 are established tuft/brush cell markers across airway and intestinal epithelia. • c-Kit expression – KIT transcripts mark the KIT+ tuft-cell subset described in airway and gut epithelium. • Eicosanoid synthesis for type-2 immune activation – PTGS1, ALOX5, ALOX5AP and HPGDS support prostaglandin- and leukotriene-production typical of activated tuft cells. • Immune-signalling adaptors – FYB1, VAV1, PLCG2, PIK3CG, SKAP2 and HCK mirror the “haematopoietic-like” signalling repertoire previously noted in tuft cells that enables rapid cytokine and lipid mediator release. Inconsistencies: • Classical myeloid markers (CD14, PSTPIP2, HCK) are unexpected in epithelial cells and could reflect low-level contamination or a shared signalling module rather than true lineage mixing. • IL17RB is more typical of type-2 immune cells (e.g., ILC2s); its presence may indicate paracrine responsiveness but is not a canonical tuft-cell marker.

program_2.description: This program represents a generic “high-translation” state characterized by up-regulated cytosolic ribosome biogenesis and protein synthesis machinery; it is not specific to one lineage but is commonly seen in proliferating or metabolically activated cells of many types. Evidence: • Cytosolic ribosomal protein genes: near-complete coverage of large- (RPL3, RPL5, RPL10A, RPL13, RPL19, RPL29, etc.) and small-subunit (RPS3, RPS6, RPS8, RPS18, RPS19, etc.) components indicates concerted ribosome production. • Translation elongation factors EEF1A1 and EEF1B2 further mark enhanced global protein synthesis. • Lack of lineage-restricted markers suggests a broad metabolic/housekeeping module rather than a cell-type-specific signature. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes participate in cytosolic translation and are concordant with a ribosome/translation program.

program_3.description: The gene set is most consistent with an ATOH1-driven intestinal secretory program characteristic of mature/late-differentiating colonic goblet cells that are actively producing and glycosylating mucins and releasing antimicrobial/repair peptides.
