Evidence: • Goblet-cell structural/secretory products – FCGBP, TFF3, CLCA1, ITLN1, RETNLB, SPINK4, BEST2, ST6GALNAC1, B3GNT6, GALNT8, REP15 all peak in colonic goblet cells and are required for mucin packaging, glycosylation and export. • Secretory-lineage transcriptional control – ATOH1 (master regulator of secretory fate) together with DLL1 (Notch ligand expressed by ATOH1⁺ progenitors) marks commitment to goblet/other secretory cells. • Colon-biased markers – BEST2, CAPN9 and KCNMA1 are preferentially enriched in distal‐gut goblet cells rather than small-intestinal counterparts. • Antimicrobial/regenerative peptides typical of goblet cells under stress or wound repair – REG1A, REG1B, REG3A, ITLN1, RETNLB, FRZB, FAP. • Additional secretory/vesicle trafficking and chaperone factors – REP15, HSPA2, CBFA2T3, CRIP2 support high secretory load expected in goblet cells. Inconsistencies: • TPSG1 (mast-cell tryptase), FAP (stromal fibroblast marker), and GCG (L-cell enteroendocrine hormone) are atypical for goblet cells, suggesting some cross-cell contamination or broader injury-response transcription. • CFI and NNMT are broadly expressed metabolic/immunity genes not specific to goblet cells.

program_4.description: The program is characteristic of T lymphocytes that have recently been activated yet retain an IL-7R–high, chemokine-secreting profile typical of central / tissue-resident memory T cells (CD69⁺ IL7R⁺ CCL4⁺/CCL5⁺). Evidence: • Core T-cell identity – CD2, CD3D, CD3E, CD7, CD52, PTPRC, CD48, CD53, CD37 confirm lymphoid, T-lineage origin. • Memory/IL-7 maintenance – High IL7R together with CXCR4 and IKZF1 fits naïve/central-memory or tissue-resident memory (Trm) T cells that rely on IL-7 signals for survival. • Early activation / tissue residency – CD69 and RGS1 are canonical early-activation and Trm markers; CD69 also antagonizes S1PR1 to retain cells in tissues. • Effector chemokine production – CCL4 and CCL5 are hallmark cytokines secreted by activated memory/effector T cells. • Granule and cytoskeletal remodeling genes (SRGN, LCP1, EVL, LSP1, CYTIP, ACAP1) support a state primed for migration and effector function. Inconsistencies: • VIM (vimentin) is more typical of mesenchymal cells but can be induced in highly activated T cells; its presence is therefore not strongly contradictory. • HCST (DNAM2) is more enriched in NK cells but is also expressed in activated cytotoxic T cells, so only mildly discordant.

program_5.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature absorptive colonic/intestinal epithelial (colonocyte) program characterized by active oxidative and xenobiotic-detoxifying metabolism. Evidence: • Intestinal/colonic epithelial markers – LGALS4, LGALS2, VSIG2, PIGR, C15orf48, NXPE4 and CHP2 are highly enriched in normal colon epithelium. • Bicarbonate/ion handling typical of colonocytes – CA1, CA2, SLC4A4. • Fatty-acid and butyrate-driven oxidative metabolism seen in colonocytes – HMGCS2 (ketogenesis from butyrate), FABP1. • Gluconeogenic / metabolic-detox genes that are physiologically up-regulated in colonocytes exposed to luminal nutrients – PCK1, GPT, ADH1C, UGT2B17, SULT1B1, MT1F/G/M. • Additional transporters associated with intestinal sulfate handling – SLC26A2. Inconsistencies: • SLC26A2 is classically described in chondrocytes, and ADH1C, GPT, UGT2B17 are better known in hepatocytes; however each has documented expression in normal intestinal epithelium, so no strong conflicts are apparent.

program_6.description: The program represents an interferon-γ–activated, antigen-presenting cell state typical of inflammatory dendritic cells/monocyte-derived macrophages: MHC class II machinery is strongly up-regulated together with classic IFN-γ-inducible immunomodulatory genes and T-cell-recruiting chemokines. Evidence: • High MHC-II antigen-presentation module: CD74 plus multiple HLA-D (DRA, DRB1/5, DPA1, DPB1, DQA1, DQB1, DMB) indicate professional antigen-presenting cells. • IFN-γ response genes: IDO1, UBD (FAT10), PSMB9 and B2M are well-known interferon-stimulated genes that enhance antigen processing or immune regulation. • T-cell-attracting chemokines: CXCL10 and CXCL11 are canonical IFN-γ–induced chemokines secreted by activated APCs to recruit CXCR3⁺ effector T cells. Inconsistencies: • TFF2 is usually expressed by mucosal epithelial/goblet cells; its presence is atypical for myeloid APCs and may reflect tissue-specific co-expression or ambient RNA contamination.

program_7.description: The gene set represents a robust type I interferon-stimulated (antiviral) transcriptional program that can be induced in many immune and non-immune cell types when they enter an antiviral/innate immune activation state. Evidence: • Canonical ISGs: ISG15, MX1, MX2, OAS2, OASL, IFI6, IFI27, IFI44, IFI44L, IFIT1/2/3 – classical targets of STAT1/STAT2–IRF9 signaling downstream of IFN-α/β. • Antiviral effector molecules: BST2 (tetherin) restricts viral particle release; RSAD2 (viperin) inhibits viral replication; CMPK2 supplies nucleotide precursors for ISG-driven restriction. • Interferon-induced modulators: EPSTI1 enhances antiviral responses; IFI family genes (IFI44, IFI6, IFI27) are hallmarks of IFN-responsive states. Inconsistencies: • None—every listed gene is a well-validated interferon-stimulated gene, coherently supporting an antiviral interferon response program.

program_8.description: The gene set reflects a generic proliferative program characteristic of cells in late-S to G2/M phases of the cell cycle rather than a specific lineage; it marks actively dividing cells preparing for DNA replication, cohesion, and mitosis. Evidence: • DNA synthesis & replication licensing – TYMS, TK1, RRM2, MCM10, ORC6, CDC45, ESCO2, ASF1B encode enzymes or cofactors required for nucleotide production, replication origin firing, and sister-chromatid cohesion, all peak in S phase. • G2/M control – CDK1 and its inhibitory kinase PKMYT1, together with CLSPN (checkpoint mediator), coordinate the G2 → M transition and DNA-damage checkpoint. • DNA repair/homologous recombination – BRCA1 and EXO1 are up-regulated to safeguard genome integrity during/after replication. • Chromatin remodeling in dividing cells – HELLS facilitates nucleosome reorganization during replication. • PCLAF (KIAA0101) associates with PCNA to enhance DNA polymerase processivity in proliferating cells. Inconsistencies: • No prominent genes conflict with a cycling/proliferative interpretation; the list uniformly supports a cell-cycle program.

program_9.description: The gene set represents a classic Immediate-Early Gene (IEG) activation program that marks cells that have received an acute stimulus (e.g., growth factor, antigen, mechanical or oxidative stress) and are mounting a rapid MAPK/ERK-driven transcriptional response; it is not restricted to a single lineage but rather reflects a transient “recently-activated” state across many cell types. Evidence: • Core IEG/AP-1 components (FOS, FOSB, JUNB, ATF3) – canonical markers induced within minutes of MAPK/ERK signaling. • Early growth-response transcription factors (EGR1, EGR4) and nuclear receptor NR4A1 – hallmarks of freshly stimulated T cells, neurons, fibroblasts, etc. • Stress-responsive regulators (DUSP1, ZFP36, BTG2, PPP1R15A) that dampen MAPK signaling, modulate mRNA stability, and resolve unfolded-protein or oxidative stress. • Pro-survival and cytoskeletal activation genes (MCL1, RHOB, IER2) commonly co-induced during acute stimulation. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded or lineage-specific genes contradict the interpretation; the list is uniformly characteristic of an IEG/stress-response program.

program_10.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated extracellular-matrix-producing fibroblast program, similar to the “VCAN⁺/THBS2⁺” stromal or alveolar fibroblast state that expands during tissue remodeling and fibrosis. Evidence: • ECM/remodeling core: VCAN, THBS2, COL6A1 and SPOCK2 are canonical matrix proteins highly enriched in activated or “myofibroblast-like” lung and other tissue fibroblasts. • Additional fibroblast/mesenchymal markers: FSCN1 (actin-bundling protein up-regulated in migratory fibroblasts), CRABP2 (retinoic-acid-responsive fibroblast gene), SLC7A2 (arginine transporter induced in inflammatory fibroblasts), and CFP (complement factor produced by stromal cells). • Co-expression of multiple secreted factors (VCAN, THBS2, SPOCK2, CFP, F5) fits a stromal cell engaged in wound-healing or pro-inflammatory signaling rather than a quiescent fibroblast or an epithelial lineage. Inconsistencies: • AQP5 is a classical alveolar type I epithelial and salivary gland water channel, rarely detected in fibroblasts. • PON3 and F5 are predominantly hepatocyte-derived plasma proteins and may reflect ambient RNA or low-level uptake. • ONECUT3 and HOMER2 are more typical of specialized epithelial/neuronal contexts than stromal cells.

program_11.description: The gene set is characteristic of the recently described BEST4⁺/OTOP2⁺ intestinal “ionocyte”/enterocyte subtype that lines the human small and large bowel and specializes in pH and electrolyte homeostasis rather than nutrient absorption. Evidence: • BEST4 and OTOP2 are the canonical co-markers that define this ion-transporting epithelial subtype in human colon and ileum. • CA4 and CA7 (carbonic anhydrases) support bicarbonate production/secretion, a key functional trait of these cells. • GUCA2A and GUCA2B (guanylin/uroguanylin) are hormones secreted by BEST4⁺ enterocytes to activate GC-C and regulate CFTR-dependent chloride and water transport. • UNC5C and MEIS1 have been repeatedly reported as enriched transcripts in BEST4⁺ cells in single-cell atlases, supporting the same cellular identity. • Low or absent markers of goblet (MUC2), Paneth (LYZ, DEFA5/6) or enteroendocrine (CHGA, NEUROD1) lineages further point to an absorptive/ion-regulatory epithelial state rather than other intestinal epithelial fates. Inconsistencies: • CEACAM3 is classically a neutrophil receptor, and SPIB is best known in M cells; their presence may reflect low-level background expression or a minor contaminating population but does not outweigh the strong, specific BEST4/OTOP2/CA/GUCA signature.

program_12.description: The gene set represents a mature, mucin-secreting goblet-cell program characteristic of intestinal or airway epithelium, reflecting both lineage-defining transcriptional machinery and effector genes required for mucin production and regulated secretion. Evidence: • Goblet-cell identity/differentiation – MUC2 (dominant secreted mucin of goblet cells), SPDEF (master transcription factor driving goblet-cell fate), LRRC26 (BK-channel regulator highly enriched in intestinal goblet cells). • Secretory machinery – RAB26 (small GTPase controlling secretory granule exocytosis), AQP3 (water channel supporting hydrated mucus), RAP1GAP (regulates RAP1-dependent vesicle trafficking). • Protective/anti-protease component of mucus – SERPINA1 (α1-antitrypsin, produced by mucosal goblet cells to protect luminal proteins). • Adhesion/remodeling elements consistent with epithelium – CDH11 (cadherin expressed in differentiated secretory epithelium), KIF19 (microtubule-based motor implicated in secretory vesicle positioning). Inconsistencies: • CDH11 is more commonly linked to mesenchymal cells, though low-level expression has been reported in differentiated epithelia. • KIF19 is better known for ciliary length control and is not a canonical goblet-cell marker, but kinesins frequently support secretory vesicle dynamics.

program_13.description: The program reflects a simple-epithelial (KRT8⁺/KRT19⁺) cell population that is engaged in cytoskeletal remodeling and stress-responsive metabolism, characterized by high expression of actin/annexin/S100 proteins and a concurrent down-regulation of mitochondrial respiratory transcripts—features commonly seen in proliferating or transformation-prone epithelial cells. Evidence: • Epithelial identity – strong enrichment for keratins typical of simple/luminal epithelia (KRT8, KRT19). • Cytoskeletal remodeling / motility – up-regulation of ACTB, TMSB4X (actin dynamics) and ANXA2 (membrane–actin linker), consistent with migratory or restructuring epithelia. • Stress / calcium signaling – S100A6 and ANXA2 are classic Ca²⁺-binding, stress-inducible proteins elevated during epithelial activation and regeneration. • Metabolic shift – positive loading of ASS1 (arginine biosynthesis) with simultaneous negative loading of mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation genes (MT-CO3, MT-CYB) points to reduced OXPHOS and a glycolytic or hypoxic-like metabolic program often accompanying rapid proliferation or oncogenic transformation. Inconsistencies: • No major conflicts; ACTB is ubiquitous but fits the cytoskeletal theme.

program_14.description: The gene set is most consistent with articular or growth-plate chondrocytes that are actively modulating Wnt signalling—a state typical of superficial-zone or early proliferative cartilage cells producing collagenous extracellular matrix while expressing multiple Wnt feedback inhibitors. Evidence: • Cartilage extracellular-matrix genes COL9A3 and COL11A2 are signature collagens of chondrocytes. • Wnt pathway feedback inhibitors/targets NOTUM, APCDD1 and NKD1 mark superficial-zone and proliferative chondrocytes where tight control of Wnt activity is required. • IGF2 supports chondrocyte proliferation and hypertrophic progression in the growth plate. • SLC14A1 and CAPN6 have documented expression in cartilage, aligning with chondrocyte metabolic and cytoskeletal functions. • TLR4 is expressed on chondrocytes and mediates their innate immune responses. Inconsistencies: • TLR4 is more commonly associated with immune cells; its presence may reflect inflammatory signalling rather than a core chondrocyte program. • SLC14A1 is best known as a urea transporter in erythrocytes/bladder epithelium, so its inclusion is peripheral to cartilage identity.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature colonic surface epithelial (colonocyte) program that supports barrier function and secretion of antimicrobial/adhesion molecules. Evidence: • LYPD8 – selectively secreted by differentiated colonocytes to coat flagellated bacteria and limit bacterial motility in the colonic lumen. • CEACAM7 – cell-adhesion molecule found on the apical surface of normal colonic epithelium and late-stage goblet/absorptive cells. • FXYD3 (MAT-8) – membrane protein highly expressed in gastric and colonic epithelial cells and up-regulated during epithelial maturation. • TSPAN1 – tetraspanin enriched in intestinal epithelial layers and up-regulated in differentiated colonocytes. • LGALS3 (Galectin-3) – lectin produced by epithelial cells that reinforces the mucosal barrier and binds luminal microbes; co-expressed with LYPD8 in colonic epithelium. • CKB – cytosolic creatine kinase isoform that supplies ATP for energy-intensive ion transport in absorptive epithelial cells. • HRCT1 and URAD – low-characterised genes but reported in gastrointestinal epithelium, further supporting an intestinal epithelial context. Inconsistencies: • LGALS3 is also abundant in macrophages, and FXYD3/TSPAN1 appear in several non-intestinal epithelia; however, the collective enrichment of colon-restricted genes (LYPD8, CEACAM7) outweighs this and points to a colonic epithelial program.

program_16.description: The gene set is most consistent with a small-intestinal secretory program typical of crypt-base secretory progenitors that share features of both Paneth cells and early enteroendocrine (EEC) cells. These cells co-express Paneth antimicrobial peptides (DEFA5/6) together with the endocrine prohormone-processing enzyme PCSK1 and other secreted proteases, reflecting a transitional state between the two mature secretory lineages. Evidence: • Paneth signature – DEFA5 and DEFA6 encode α-defensins that are highly selective for Paneth cells in the small-intestinal crypt. • Enteroendocrine specification – PCSK1 is a hallmark prohormone convertase of EECs and their immediate precursors. • General secretory/crypt factors – KLK12 (secreted serine protease), CXCL12 (chemokine produced by crypt niche cells), and CACNA2D2 (Ca²⁺ channel subunit expressed in secretory epithelia) support an active secretory program typical of crypt-base cells. • Cytoskeletal remodeling – CALD1 (caldesmon) is up-regulated during epithelial differentiation and migration from the crypt, consistent with a progenitor state. Inconsistencies: • SERPINA7 (thyroxine-binding globulin) is classically liver derived and is not typical of intestinal epithelium; its presence may reflect low-level background or ambient RNA. • CALD1 is more commonly associated with smooth muscle/fibroblasts; while it can appear in epithelial progenitors, its high expression would be atypical for mature Paneth or EECs.

program_17.description: The gene set reflects an activated cytotoxic T-lymphocyte program, most consistent with CD8⁺ effector T cells engaged in killing and cytokine/chemokine secretion. Evidence: • GZMA, GZMB, GNLY, NKG7 – canonical components of cytotoxic granules required for target-cell lysis, highly enriched in CD8⁺ T cells and NK cells. • CD3G – part of the T-cell receptor complex, pointing to T-cell rather than NK identity. • CCL3 and LTB – pro-inflammatory cytokines/chemokines released by activated effector T cells to recruit and modulate other immune cells. • ARHGDIB – leukocyte motility/activation gene expressed in activated lymphocytes, supporting an immune activation state. Inconsistencies: No substantial contradictions; all listed genes align with an activated cytotoxic T-cell signature, though ARHGDIB is also found in some myeloid cells.

program_18.description: The program reflects a high mitochondrial RNA signature characteristic of cells with elevated mitochondrial activity and/or compromised membrane integrity, commonly observed in stressed or pre-apoptotic (low-quality) cells rather than a specific differentiated cell type. Evidence: • All positively loaded genes (MT-CO1/2/3, MT-CYB, MT-ND1/2/4, MT-ATP6) are encoded by the mitochondrial genome and encode core subunits of complexes I, III, IV and V of the oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) chain, a classic indicator of abundant mitochondrial transcripts. • scRNA-seq datasets repeatedly show that dying or metabolically stressed cells leak mitochondrial mRNA, leading to disproportionate representation of these same genes; this “high-percent-mito” profile is therefore used as a QC flag for low-quality or apoptotic cells. • Absence of nuclear-encoded OXPHOS or cell-type-specific markers supports the interpretation that the signal is technical/physiological (cell stress) rather than lineage-defining. Inconsistencies: None; no negatively loaded genes are provided and the positive set is internally consistent with a generic mitochondrial expression program.

program_19.description: The gene set represents a canonical E2F-driven S-phase cell-cycle program characteristic of proliferating cells that are licensing and initiating DNA replication. Evidence: • E2F1 and CCNE2 form the core G1/S transcriptional axis that activates DNA‐replication genes. • CDC6, DTL (CDT2), and FAM111B encode replication-licensing or replisome components induced during S-phase. • UHRF1 couples DNA methylation maintenance with DNA synthesis and is up-regulated in cycling cells. • WDR76 is frequently co-expressed with replication and genome-maintenance genes in S-phase single-cell datasets. Inconsistencies: • No clear discordant genes; WDR76 is less well studied but is reported to track with proliferation, so fits the overall program.

program_20.description: The gene set represents a generic “metallothionein-high oxidative stress response” program that can be transiently activated in many cell types (immune, epithelial, stromal) when they experience heavy-metal exposure, reactive oxygen species, or inflammatory cytokines. Evidence: • Metallothionein core – MT1E, MT1X, MT1H, MT2A are classic metallothioneins whose transcription is driven by MTF-1 and NRF2 during Zn²⁺/Cd²⁺ overload or oxidative stress, providing metal sequestration and ROS buffering. • Mitochondrial respiration support – COX4I1 and COX7C (cytochrome-c-oxidase subunits) rise in parallel with stress-induced adjustments to the electron-transport chain and antioxidant defenses. • General translational capacity – RPS26 up-regulation is frequently seen in stress-adapted cells maintaining protein synthesis. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes are present; all listed genes fit a stress/metal response profile.

program_21.description: The gene set indicates a gastric secretory epithelial program characteristic of antral/foveolar-like mucous cells with features of a regenerative (REG4-high) secretory state. Evidence: • Gastric lineage genes – TFF1, CLDN18 and CTSE are canonical markers of gastric foveolar and antral gland epithelium. • Secretory/regenerative signature – REG4 is expressed in regenerating gastric and intestinal mucous cells; LYZ, while classic for Paneth cells, is also induced in gastric glands undergoing secretory metaplasia. • Epithelial identity – CLDN18 (tight-junction protein) and GABRP (epithelial γ-aminobutyric acid receptor subunit found in stomach epithelium) support an epithelial, non-immune origin. • Pro-survival/growth factor signalling – NTRK1 (TrkA) is up-regulated in a subset of gastric mucous cells and gastric metaplasia, fitting a regenerative/activated state. Inconsistencies: • LYZ is more typical of small-intestinal Paneth cells, although it can appear in gastric metaplastic epithelium. • NTRK1 and GABRP are not universal gastric markers and are variably expressed in other epithelial tissues, introducing some ambiguity about strict gastric specificity.

program_22.description: The program reflects a highly proliferative, cycling cell state—specifically cells in late-S to G2/M phases—characterized by coordinated activation of DNA replication, repair, and mitotic machinery. Evidence: • RAD51AP1 and NEIL3 – promote homologous recombination repair and base-excision repair during DNA synthesis, marking S-phase activity. • MYBL2 and E2F8 – transcription factors that up-regulate genes required for DNA replication and G2/M transition. • CDCA5 (Sororin) – ensures sister-chromatid cohesion, a hallmark of G2 progression. • SPC25 – subunit of the NDC80 kinetochore complex, essential for chromosome alignment in mitosis. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes consistently mark an S/G2–M cell-cycle program.

program_23.description: The gene set represents a cell-state program of heightened nuclear RNA processing/spliceosome activity rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The coordinated up-regulation of multiple serine/arginine-rich (SR) splicing regulators and exon-junction-complex components points to cells that are actively engaged in pre-mRNA splicing—commonly seen in proliferative or transcriptionally active cells. Evidence: • Core SR-rich splicing factors – PNISR, LUC7L3, RSRP1, ARGLU1 and PNN are all constituents of the spliceosome or nuclear speckles that promote exon definition and alternative splicing. • PNN and PNISR interact in the exon-junction complex, a hallmark of robust co-transcriptional splicing. • ARGLU1 serves as both a transcriptional co-activator and spliceosome adaptor, linking high transcriptional output with splicing demand. Inconsistencies: • CCDC14 is better known for centrosomal/ciliogenesis roles and has only indirect links to RNA splicing, so its presence is less clearly connected to the predominant splicing program.

program_24.description: The program is characteristic of mature, salt-absorbing colon epithelial cells (colonocytes) engaged in electrolyte and water transport. Evidence: • MS4A12 and SLC26A3 are highly selective markers of differentiated colonocytes, mediating Ca²⁺ influx and Cl⁻/HCO₃⁻ exchange, respectively. • AQP8 encodes a water channel abundantly expressed on the apical membrane of colonic absorptive cells, supporting fluid uptake. • HSD11B2 is co-expressed with SLC26A3 in distal colon epithelium, protecting mineralocorticoid signaling that drives Na⁺ absorption. • PHGR1 and PKIB are enriched in fully differentiated intestinal epithelial cells, further marking a mature absorptive state. Inconsistencies: • None identified (no negatively loaded genes and the positive set is internally consistent).

program_25.description: The gene set typifies CNS-resident microglia in an activated, complement- and lipid-handling state (often termed “disease-associated microglia”), characterized by robust innate-immune signaling and apolipoprotein-driven lipid metabolism. Evidence: • C1QA, C1QC – classical complement components highly enriched in microglia; up-regulated during phagocytic, synapse-pruning and neuroinflammatory responses. • TYROBP – adaptor for TREM2; indispensable for microglial activation, phagocytosis and complement induction. • FCER1G – immunoreceptor γ-chain shared by several myeloid receptors; supports ITAM signaling in activated microglia/macrophages. • APOE, APOC1 – apolipoproteins strongly induced in lipid-loaded or disease-associated microglia; coordinate cholesterol efflux and inflammatory gene programs. Inconsistencies: • None apparent—all listed genes fit an activated microglial/macrophage program.

program_26.description: The gene set is characteristic of antibody-secreting B cells, i.e. plasmablasts / early plasma cells undergoing high-rate immunoglobulin synthesis and ER expansion. Evidence: • JCHAIN – classic marker of IgM/IgA-producing plasmablasts and plasma cells. • MZB1 – ER‐resident chaperone up-regulated during plasma-cell differentiation to support immunoglobulin folding. • TNFRSF17 (BCMA) – receptor selectively expressed on plasmablasts and long-lived plasma cells; absent from naïve or germinal-center B cells. • DERL3 – component of ER-associated degradation pathway enriched in plasma cells coping with heavy secretory load. • CD79A – B-cell lineage marker retained in plasmablasts, although down-regulated in fully mature plasma cells. • POU2AF1 (OBF1) – B-cell transcriptional co-activator required for germinal-center reactions and plasma-cell differentiation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all provided genes align with an antibody-secreting plasmablast/plasma-cell program.

program_27.description: The gene set represents an acute, NF-κB–driven pro-inflammatory activation program, most commonly observed in innate immune cells such as activated monocytes/macrophages or dendritic cells following TNF or pathogen-associated stimulation. Evidence: • Canonical NF-κB target genes – NFKBIA (IκBα), TNFAIP3 (A20), TNF and CXCL8 – are rapidly induced upon NF-κB activation, defining a classic early inflammatory response. • Neutrophil-attracting chemokines CXCL2, CXCL3 and CXCL8 (IL-8) typify myeloid cell secretion aimed at recruiting granulocytes to sites of infection or tissue damage. • Autocrine/paracrine TNF (TNF) both triggers and sustains this NF-κB transcriptional module, reinforcing its identity as a TNF/NF-κB inflammatory state. Inconsistencies: No notable inconsistencies; all listed genes coherently fit an NF-κB-driven inflammatory program.

program_28.description: The gene set is most consistent with a neuroendocrine-like secretory program, as found in mature enteroendocrine or other peripheral neuroendocrine cells that store hormones in dense-core vesicles and rely on Ca²⁺-regulated exocytosis. Evidence: • Classical neuroendocrine regulators of dense-core vesicle secretion – SCG5 (Secretogranin V) and RAB3B – are central components of regulated hormone/peptide release. • The Ca²⁺-binding protein SCGN (Secretagogin) is a well-validated marker of pancreatic islet, enteroendocrine, and other neuroendocrine lineages where it modulates stimulus-secretion coupling. • INSM1, a zinc-finger transcription factor required for endocrine/neuroendocrine differentiation and routinely used to diagnose neuroendocrine tumors, supports an endocrine identity. • Coordinated up-regulation of the above genes without opposing (negatively loaded) markers indicates a coherent secretory/neuroendocrine state. Inconsistencies: • CRYBA2 (β-crystallin) and MS4A8 are more typical of lens fiber cells and intestinal tuft/chemosensory cells, respectively; their presence may reflect tissue-specific co-expression or low-level contamination rather than canonical neuroendocrine biology.

program_29.description: The gene constellation points to hormone-responsive, secretory-phase luminal (and early glandular) epithelial cells of the human endometrium—i.e., the “receptive” uterine epithelium that supports embryo implantation. Evidence: • ODAM, FOLR1, TM4SF20 – classical markers of the receptive endometrial luminal epithelium; strongly up-regulated during the implantation window. • SULT1E1 – estrogen-sulfating enzyme induced in progesterone-primed endometrium, contributing to local estrogen inactivation during the secretory phase. • CALB1 – calcium-binding protein whose expression in uterine/fallopian tube epithelium is estrogen-dependent and peaks in the peri-ovulatory/early secretory period. • ALDOB – fructose–bisphosphate aldolase enriched in secretory-phase endometrium where glycogen and fructose metabolism increase to support the pre-implantation embryo. Inconsistencies: • CALB1 is also expressed in certain neurons and distal renal tubule cells; ALDOB is a hepatocyte/enterocyte enzyme. Their presence is nonetheless documented in secretory endometrium, but they are not entirely specific to this tissue.

program_30.description: The gene set is most consistent with a proliferative epithelial (basal-like) program in which cells strengthen desmosomal adhesion (DSP) while activating a KLF5-driven transcriptional network that supports rapid growth and heightened RNA/innate-immune activity. Evidence: • DSP (Desmoplakin) – cornerstone of desmosomes, highly expressed in stratified and simple epithelia. • KLF5 – transcription factor that maintains proliferation of intestinal, airway and epidermal basal epithelial cells. • TM9SF3 – vesicle-trafficking membrane protein enriched in dividing epithelial and carcinoma cells. • HNRNPK and FAM120A – ubiquitous RNA-binding/processing proteins frequently up-regulated in highly biosynthetic, proliferating cells. • MAVS – mitochondrial antiviral‐signalling adaptor; its induction often accompanies KLF5-positive epithelial cells under stress or cytokine exposure, fitting a “proliferative-with-innate-alert” state. Inconsistencies: • Classical epithelial structural genes (e.g., keratins KRT5/14 or KRT8/18) are absent, so epithelial identity is inferred mainly from DSP. • MAVS is primarily an antiviral gene; its inclusion may reflect a concurrent stress response rather than the core epithelial proliferation program.

program_31.description: The gene set reflects a sterol/lipid-biosynthetic program, classically driven by SREBP (especially SREBP2) signaling, that is switched on in cells requiring extensive membrane production—e.g., rapidly proliferating epithelial or tumor cells, lipogenic hepatocytes, or metabolically activated immune cells. Evidence: • Core cholesterol pathway enzymes MSMO1, SQLE, HMGCS1 and FDFT1 mark a concerted mevalonate/sterol biosynthesis module under SREBP2 control. • INSIG1, itself an SREBP target and feedback inhibitor, reinforces that this is a regulated cholesterol-synthetic response rather than random expression. • SCD extends the program to fatty-acid desaturation, another SREBP-responsive step needed for membrane phospholipid remodeling during cell growth. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently belong to the same lipid/sterol biosynthetic pathway.

program_32.description: The gene set most closely matches an “inflamed mucosal epithelial” program, as seen in intestinal (and to a lesser extent airway) epithelial cells exposed to bacterial products or type-I/II interferons. Such cells up-regulate reactive-oxygen-species machinery (DUOX2/DUOXA2) together with secreted antimicrobial/anti-protease factors (LCN2, PI3) and other interferon-stimulated genes (APOL1), reflecting an epithelial host-defence state frequently reported in inflammatory bowel disease and other mucosal inflammations. Evidence: • DUOX2 + DUOXA2 – dual-oxidase system that generates H₂O₂ for luminal antimicrobial activity; highly enriched in inflamed intestinal and airway epithelium. • LCN2 – lipocalin-2, a siderophore-binding antimicrobial protein secreted by stressed gut/airway epithelial cells and neutrophils; strongly induced in IBD mucosa. • PI3 (elafin) – epithelial serine-protease inhibitor with antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory roles, up-regulated in mucosal epithelium during infection/inflammation. • APOL1 – interferon-inducible apolipoprotein expressed in several epithelial and endothelial contexts during innate immune activation. • Co-occurrence of the above genes in bulk and single-cell data sets defines “DUOX2-high” inflamed enterocytes described in Crohn’s/ulcerative colitis biopsy studies. Inconsistencies: • CHST4 is classically a high-endothelial-venule sulfotransferase rather than an epithelial gene, although low‐level or inflammation-induced epithelial expression has been reported; its presence is somewhat atypical for a pure epithelial program.

program_33.description: The gene set is most consistent with an alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial program, reflecting mature or mildly stress-responsive lung epithelial cells that secrete surfactant and express the lineage-defining transcription factor NKX2-1. Evidence: • NKX2-1 (TTF-1) – master regulator of lung epithelial specification and a canonical marker of AT2 cells. • SFTA3 and SLC22A31 – surfactant-associated genes highly enriched in AT2 cells and rarely expressed outside the distal lung epithelium. • CXCL14 – chemokine produced by airway/alveolar epithelium that recruits immune cells, fitting an epithelial context. • MEF2C – transcription factor implicated in lung development and AT2 maturation. • BNIP3 – hypoxia/mitophagy gene often up-regulated in metabolically active or stressed AT2 cells. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes are present; all listed genes are compatible with an AT2 epithelial state.

program_34.description: The gene set represents a canonical interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) program, reflecting cells—of virtually any lineage—exposed to type I/II interferon and mounting an antiviral/inflammatory response. Evidence: • STAT1 – master transcription factor activated by both type I and II interferons, drives ISG expression. • DDX60 – RNA helicase induced by IFN-α/β; promotes RIG-I–mediated viral RNA sensing. • PARP9 – forms PARP9-DTX3L complex that enhances STAT1 signaling and antiviral chromatin remodeling. • XAF1 – strongly up-regulated by IFN-γ/α; mediates pro-apoptotic, anti-viral effects downstream of STAT1. • SERPING1 – complement C1 inhibitor whose transcription increases after IFN exposure, linking ISG response to complement regulation. Inconsistencies: • No notable genes contradict the interferon response interpretation.

program_0.description: The program represents a generic, highly proliferative cell-cycle state (late S through G2/M and cytokinesis) that can be displayed by virtually any dividing cell type rather than a lineage-specific cell identity. Evidence: • Core mitotic regulators – CDK1, CCNB1/2, CCNA2, PLK1, AURKA/B, WEE1, PKMYT1, FOXM1, CDC20, BUB1/B1B, MAD2L1, TTK – mark entry into and control of G2/M phase and spindle-assembly checkpoint. • Chromosome condensation/segregation genes – NCAPG/NCAPG2/NCAPH, CENPA/F/M/PE/PK/PU, NDC80, SPC24/25, NUF2, KIF11, KIF2C, KIF14, KIF15, KIF18B, KIF20A, KIF23, KIF4A, HJURP – indicate active mitotic spindle formation and centromere function. • DNA replication/S-phase genes – TYMS, RRM2, TK1, CDT1, ORC6, RFC5, POLQ, FANCI, BLM, RECQL4, ASF1B, PCLAF – reflect ongoing DNA synthesis preceding mitosis. • Cytokinesis and mid-body components – ANLN, PRC1, CEP55, CIT, DIAPH3, TROAP – highlight completion of cell division. • Proliferation markers – MKI67, TOP2A, UBE2C, BIRC5 (Survivin), PCNA-associated PCLAF – are canonical indicators of cycling cells. • Transcriptional drivers of proliferation – MYBL2, E2F8, TCF19, ATAD2 – further reinforce a cell-cycle program. Inconsistencies: No major lineage-specific or quiescence genes are present; the gene set is coherently G2/M-biased with no evident contradictions.

program_1.description: The program reflects a generic “high-translation” state characterized by elevated ribosomal protein production and global protein-synthesis machinery, typical of metabolically active or proliferating cells independent of a specific lineage; concomitant suppression of the inflammatory chemokine CXCL1 suggests that cells engaged in this biosynthetic program are not simultaneously mounting a strong chemokine response. Evidence: • Extensive enrichment of small and large ribosomal subunit genes (e.g., RPS18, RPS6, RPL10, RPL13A, RPLP1, RPS3A, RPL35A) together with translation factors (EEF1A1, FAU, UBA52) is the canonical signature of increased translational capacity and ribosome biogenesis. • Absence of lineage-defining markers (e.g., CD3D for T cells, EPCAM for epithelia, COL1A1 for fibroblasts) supports a pan-cellular metabolic program rather than a cell-type-specific identity. • Negative loading of CXCL1, a chemokine induced during inflammatory signaling, is consistent with cells prioritizing biosynthesis over cytokine/chemokine secretion. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; the single negatively loaded gene (CXCL1) simply highlights an inverse relationship between translation and inflammatory signaling rather than contradicting the high-translation interpretation.

program_2.description: The program represents highly cytotoxic, chronically activated CD8⁺ T cells displaying multiple inhibitory-receptor and tissue-resident/exhaustion features, typical of tumour-infiltrating or chronically stimulated “exhausted”/TRM-like CD8⁺ T cells. Evidence: • T-cell identity: CD3D/E/G, CD2, CD247, LCK, ZAP70, TRAT1, ITK, GRAP2 confirm TCR-bearing lymphocytes. • CD8 lineage & cytotoxicity: CD8A, CD8B together with PRF1, GNLY, GZMB, GZMA, GZMH, GZMM, IFNG denote CD8⁺ cytotoxic effector function. • Chronic activation / exhaustion checkpoints: CTLA4, TIGIT, CD96, CXCL13, KLRD1, KLRB1 are commonly up-regulated in exhausted tumour-infiltrating lymphocytes. • Tissue-resident/memory traits: ITGA1 (CD49a), CXCR6, RORA, IKZF3, BCL11B, ETS1 are enriched in resident memory or persistence programs. • Signalling adaptors of sustained activation: SH2D1A, SH2D2A, SKAP1, RASGRP1 support ongoing TCR signalling characteristic of chronically stimulated cells. Inconsistencies: • Few markers such as CXCL13 and RORA are also expressed by peripheral-helper/Tfh CD4⁺ cells, but the strong CD8A/B and cytotoxic granule signature outweighs this. • CLEC2D and KLRB1 are more typical of innate-like T subsets (MAIT/NKT) yet are reported in exhausted CD8⁺ T cells in tumours.

program_3.description: The gene set strongly matches a mature, migratory dendritic-cell program (often termed “CCR7⁺ LAMP3⁺ mregDCs”) that have up-regulated chemokines and immunoregulatory molecules as they travel from peripheral tissues to lymph nodes and interact with T cells. Evidence: • Migration/lymph-node homing: CCR7, LAMP3, FSCN1, LAD1—classic markers of tissue-mature DCs that relocate to T-cell zones. • T-cell–attracting chemokines: CCL19, CCL17, CCL22—produced by migratory DCs to recruit naïve and regulatory T cells. • Antigen processing/presentation: HLA-DOB, CD200, BTLA, GCSAM, BIRC3—genes enriched in professional APCs and up-regulated on mature DCs. • Immunoregulatory/tolerogenic factors: IDO1, EBI3 (IL-27/IL-35 subunit), BCL2L14, TXN—typical of “regulatory” DCs that restrain excessive immunity. • Developmental/support genes for DC lineage: FLT3 (DC progenitor receptor), BIRC3, TREML1, MARCKSL1—all induced during DC maturation or survival. Inconsistencies: • Mesenchymal/other-lineage genes such as ADAM12 and LYPD3, and neuronal-associated genes (ACHE, GPR157, AUTS2) are not typical for dendritic cells and may reflect background expression or technical noise.

program_4.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated regulatory-T-cell (Treg) program, typical of lymphoid/follicular regulatory T cells (Tfr) that reside in germinal centres, although the presence of several B-cell and dendritic-cell transcripts suggests some transcriptional contamination or admixture in the factor. Evidence: • Core Treg/Tfr identity and activation: FOXP3 (lineage-defining), IL32, ICOS, TNFRSF18/GITR, TNFRSF4/OX40, TNFRSF25/DR3, HOPX, GPR174, GPR171, CAMK4 – all enriched in activated or follicular Tregs. • Effector/memory T-cell features: CCL5, CTSW, GZMK, KLRC2, FYN, LTB, TMIGD2, SLAMF1 – genes induced in activated or tissue-resident memory/follicular T cells. • Lymphoid localisation cues: SYNE2, ZNRF1 and LTB are up-regulated in lymph-node/tonsillar Tregs and Tfr cells. Inconsistencies: • B-cell lineage genes (MS4A1/CD20, CD79B, AFF3, BANK1, TNFRSF13C/BAFF-R, VPREB3, TLR10) and cDC2 markers (CD1C, FCER1A, CLEC10A, NDRG2) are not expected in pure Tregs, indicating either technical mixing, doublets or that the factor captures a broader lymphoid micro-environmental signal rather than a cell-intrinsic Treg programme.

program_5.description: The program reflects a robust NF-κB–driven, “M1-like” pro-inflammatory activation state of classical monocytes/macrophages, characterised by high expression of IL-1 family cytokines, multiple neutrophil-attracting CXC chemokines, CC chemokines that recruit other leukocytes, and auxiliary stress-response / anti-apoptotic genes typical of acutely TLR-stimulated myeloid cells. Evidence: • Canonical NF-κB target cytokines and chemokines (IL1B, IL1A, CXCL1, CXCL2, CXCL3, CXCL8, CCL3, CCL4, CCL20, IL1RN, TNFAIP6, TNIP3) – hallmark of TLR- or TNF-stimulated inflammatory monocytes/macrophages. • Myeloid granule/secretory genes (SRGN, PLAUR, F3) and surface marker CD44 consistent with monocyte/macrophage identity. • Metabolic / stress-response genes induced during classical (“M1”) activation (PTGS2/COX-2, NAMPT, SOD2, FTH1, IER3, BCL2A1, NFKBIA) support an oxidative, cytokine-producing phenotype. • Absence of lymphoid lineage markers and presence of broad chemokine spectrum point to cytokine-secreting myeloid rather than lymphoid activation. Inconsistencies: • SRGN and BCL2A1 are also expressed in neutrophils and cytotoxic lymphocytes, but both are well-documented in activated monocytes/macrophages and therefore not strongly contradictory.

program_6.description: The program reflects a ribosome- and translation-enriched state most compatible with metabolically active, homeostatic myeloid cells (e.g., resting monocytes/macrophages) that are not experiencing hypoxic or inflammatory stress. Evidence: • High translation machinery: Virtually all positively loaded genes (RPL31, RPS9, RPL5, RPL4, RPL38, RPL36, RPS28, RPLP0, RPL39, RACK1) encode 40S/60S ribosomal subunits or associated factors, a hallmark of vigorous protein synthesis. • Myeloid lean: PLAC8 and LGALS2 are preferentially expressed in monocytes, macrophages and neutrophils, pointing toward a myeloid lineage context for the ribosomal program. • Absence of stress/activation: Negatively loaded genes are classical hypoxia- or ER-stress/inflammatory-induced transcripts (HILPDA, ANGPTL4, ERO1A, AK4, INHBA, CCL4). Their suppression supports a non-activated, normoxic state. Inconsistencies: • Ribosomal genes are ubiquitous; without additional lineage markers, the program could in principle arise in other proliferative or protein-synthetic cell types. • Only two positively loaded genes (PLAC8, LGALS2) strongly point to myeloid identity, so the lineage inference, while plausible, is not definitive.

program_7.description: The gene set represents an S-phase cell-cycle program characteristic of actively proliferating cells, irrespective of lineage, marked by DNA replication licensing, helicase activity, and replication-fork progression. Evidence: • Replication licensing complex – MCM2, MCM4, MCM6, MCM7, MCM10 and CDC6 are core components that load and activate the replicative helicase at replication origins during S phase. • Replication fork assembly – CDC45 and the GINS complex subunit GINS2 cooperate with MCMs to form the CMG helicase that drives fork progression. • DNA synthesis machinery – PCNA clamps DNA polymerases; BRCA1 participates in fork protection and repair of replication-associated DNA damage. • S-phase transcriptional control – E2F1, E2F2 and CCNE2 are canonical E2F targets that initiate S-phase entry; DTL (Cdt2) mediates E2F-driven degradation of licensing inhibitors. • Epigenetic replication support – UHRF1 and HELLS couple DNA methylation and chromatin remodeling with ongoing replication. • Additional replication-associated factors – FAM111B (replication fork protease) and ZNF367 (E2F-regulated S-phase zinc-finger) further underscore an active DNA replication state. Inconsistencies: • No obvious discordant or lineage-specific markers are present; all listed genes align with a generic S-phase/proliferation program.

program_8.description: The program represents a robust type I/II interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) response that can be elicited in many immune and non-immune cells after viral sensing; it reflects an antiviral, pro-inflammatory cell state rather than a specific lineage identity. Evidence: • Canonical ISGs encoding antiviral effector proteins: ISG15, MX1, RSAD2, IFIT1/2, IFI6, IFI44/IFI44L, CMPK2, OAS2/3, OASL, USP18 – all rapidly up-regulated by IFN-α/β or IFN-γ signaling. • Chemokines induced by interferon for recruitment of CXCR3+ T cells/NK cells: CXCL10 and CXCL11. • Antimicrobial/epithelial defense gene DEFB1 is reported to be inducible by IFNs, fitting an overall innate defense program. Inconsistencies: • HESX1 is a homeobox transcription factor mainly linked to forebrain/pituitary development and is not typically interferon-responsive, making its presence atypical for a pure ISG module.

program_9.description: The program is characteristic of classical CD14⁺, FCN1⁺ inflammatory monocytes that have recently been activated by pro-inflammatory stimuli (e.g., LPS/IL-1/TNF); it reflects the well-described “S100A8/A9 inflammatory monocyte” state seen in blood and inflamed tissues. Evidence: • Core classical/inflammatory monocyte markers – S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, FCN1, VCAN, THBS1, SELL (CD62L) are all highly expressed in CD14⁺ monocytes but low/absent in non-myeloid cells. • Acute activation / immediate-early response genes – DUSP1, FOS, RGS2, NAMPT and APOBEC3A are induced within minutes-hours after TLR or cytokine stimulation, consistent with a recently activated state. • Innate immune effector or complement-related genes – CD55 (complement regulator) and THBS1 support a role in frontline inflammatory defense. • Survival and metabolic adaptation typical of activated monocytes – MCL1 (anti-apoptotic) and NAMPT (NAD⁺ salvage, supports high glycolytic flux) are up-regulated during inflammatory activation. • Additional monocyte-enriched transcripts – FOLR3 and RBP7 are reported in scRNA-seq datasets of blood monocytes/macrophages, reinforcing the lineage assignment. Inconsistencies: • RBP7 is more commonly noted in endothelial cells, and FOLR3 can appear in alternatively activated macrophages; however, both have documented expression in circulating monocytes, so they create only minor ambiguity.

program_10.description: The program most closely reflects mature, peripheral-blood neutrophils that are transcriptionally primed for inflammatory and interferon-mediated activation. Evidence: • Granulocyte identity – FCGR3B (CD16B), CSF3R (G-CSF receptor), AQP9, PI3 (elafin) and PLEK are all classic markers of terminal neutrophil differentiation. • Activation/priming signals – IFITM2 (type-I interferon response), LITAF (LPS-induced TNF regulator) and HCAR2 (GPR109A; anti-inflammatory receptor up-regulated in activated neutrophils/monocytes) indicate exposure to microbial or cytokine cues. • Additional neutrophil-enriched or generic myeloid genes – PPIF, IVNS1ABP, CDC42EP3 and MXD1 appear in published neutrophil transcriptomes, supporting a myeloid origin. • Absence of lymphoid, eosinophil or monocytic exclusives and the lack of negatively loaded genes further center the program on neutrophils. Inconsistencies: • HES4 and KATNBL1 are not commonly cited neutrophil markers but are low-level, ubiquitous regulators and do not contradict the overall neutrophil signature.

program_11.description: The program reflects a population of professional antigen-presenting, complement-producing macrophages (an MHC class II–high, tissue-resident macrophage state). Evidence: • Antigen presentation: Strong enrichment of class II molecules (HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1, ‑DQA1, ‑DQB1, ‑DPA1, ‑DPB1, ‑DMA, ‑DMB) together with the invariant chain CD74 is characteristic of MHC II-high macrophages and other professional APCs. • Complement genes: C1QA, C1QB, and C1QC are hallmarks of tissue-resident macrophages (e.g., microglia, Kupffer, alveolar) and are seldom co-expressed at high levels in B cells or dendritic cells. • Accessory myeloid factor: DNASE1L3, a secreted nuclease involved in apoptotic DNA clearance, is preferentially expressed in macrophages and monocyte-derived dendritic cells, supporting a phagocytic, debris-clearing phenotype. Inconsistencies: • The set lacks classical macrophage core markers such as LYZ, CSF1R, or MARCO, so the assignment relies mainly on MHC II and C1Q expression; however, no genes present contradict a macrophage identity.

program_12.description: The gene set represents a “high-mitochondrial” program—cells showing disproportionately abundant mitochondrial‐encoded oxidative-phosphorylation transcripts, a pattern classically associated with bioenergetic stress, incipient apoptosis, or other forms of cellular damage rather than a specific differentiated lineage. Evidence: • All positively loaded genes (MT-CO1, MT-CO2, MT-CO3; MT-ND1/2/3/4/4L/5; MT-CYB; MT-ATP6) are mitochondrial-encoded subunits of respiratory chain complexes I, III, IV and ATP synthase, marking elevated mitochondrial transcript representation. • Absence of nuclear-encoded OXPHOS genes or lineage-defining markers suggests the signal is transcriptome-wide enrichment of mitochondrial RNA, a hallmark of stressed or dying cells with compromised membranes that preferentially release/stabilize mitochondrial mRNAs in single-cell libraries. Inconsistencies: • None; all listed genes consistently point to an unspecific, high-mitochondrial/stress phenotype rather than a defined cell type.

program_13.description: The gene signature is most consistent with an activated, phagocytic, lipid-handling macrophage/microglial state (often referred to as “disease-associated” or “foamy” macrophages/microglia) characterized by up-regulated lysosomal proteases, lipid-binding apolipoproteins, and stress/interferon-responsive factors. Evidence: • Lysosomal proteases (CTSD, CTSB, CTSZ) and the sphingolipid-processing factor PSAP mark an expanded lysosome/phagosome compartment typical of highly phagocytic macrophages and disease-associated microglia. • Lipid-handling apolipoproteins APOE and APOC1, together with PLD3, are hallmark genes of foamy macrophages and disease-associated microglia that accumulate cholesterol-rich debris. • FTL (ferritin light chain) indicates iron sequestration commonly seen in activated or hemophagocytic macrophages/microglia. • NUPR1 (stress response) and IFI27 (type I interferon–inducible) reflect cellular stress and innate immune activation frequently accompanying the above state. Inconsistencies: • IFI27 is primarily an interferon-stimulated gene and is not part of the canonical lysosomal/apolipoprotein module, but its presence is compatible with an inflammatory activation context rather than contradictory.

program_14.description: The gene set reflects an HSF1-driven cytosolic heat-shock / proteotoxic-stress response that can be mounted by virtually any somatic cell rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The program is characterized by strong induction of ATP-dependent Hsp70/90 chaperones and their DNAJ/BAG co-factors, enabling refolding or autophagic disposal of misfolded proteins generated by acute heat, oxidative or chemical stress. Evidence: • Canonical inducible Hsp70 family members (HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSPA6) and the high-molecular-weight chaperone HSPH1 are hallmark transcriptional targets of HSF1 during heat shock. • HSP90AA1 and the small heat-shock protein HSPB1 (Hsp27) form part of the classical heat-shock chaperone network that stabilizes denatured proteins. • DNAJB1 and DNAJA4 are Hsp40 co-chaperones that deliver unfolded substrates to Hsp70s; both are rapidly up-regulated in heat-stressed cells. • BAG3 partners with Hsp70 to mediate chaperone-assisted selective autophagy, a later arm of the heat-shock/proteostasis program. • ZFAND2A (AIRAP) is an HSF1-responsive zinc-finger protein that enhances proteasomal degradation under proteotoxic stress. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes or lineage-specific markers contradict the assignment; all listed genes are coherent with a generalized heat-shock/proteotoxic-stress state.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with a LYVE1⁺ FOLR2⁺ STAB1⁺ tissue-resident, alternatively activated (M2-like) macrophage program associated with vascular homeostasis and wound-repair functions. Evidence: • Core macrophage / M2 markers: FOLR2, STAB1, DAB2, and F13A1 are well-validated transcripts enriched in M2-polarised and tissue-resident macrophages, including tumor-associated and perivascular “repair” macrophages. • LYVE1⁺ macrophage identity: LYVE1, together with FOLR2 and STAB1, defines capillary-associated resident macrophages found in lung, heart, adipose tissue, and tumors. • Iron-handling & coagulation: SLC40A1 (ferroportin) and F13A1 highlight iron export and clot-stabilising functions typical of homeostatic macrophages that recycle red blood cells and support tissue repair. • Pro-repair secretome: IGF1 and CXCL12 are classic macrophage-derived trophic factors that promote angiogenesis and fibroblast recruitment during healing. • Oxidative / lipid metabolism: PDK4 supports the fatty-acid–oxidative metabolism characteristic of alternatively activated macrophages adapting to tissue niches. Inconsistencies: • Minimal: CXCL12 and LYVE1 can also be produced by stromal or endothelial cells, but their co-expression with multiple macrophage-specific genes argues for a macrophage rather than stromal identity.

program_16.description: The gene set most closely matches an oxidative/metal-stress response program in activated myeloid cells (monocytes-macrophages), characterized by high metallothionein expression and ancillary inflammation-related genes. Evidence: • Metallothioneins (MT1G, MT1X, MT2A, MT1H, MT1E) – classic transcriptional response to heavy-metal load and reactive oxygen species, prominently induced in macrophages exposed to IFN-γ, LPS, or zinc/copper fluctuations. • SLAMF9 – cell-surface receptor restricted to monocytes, macrophages, and dendritic cells, reinforcing a myeloid context. • CSTB – cysteine protease inhibitor enriched in inflammatory macrophages and microglia, contributes to lysosomal protease control during activation. • LGALS1 – immunomodulatory galectin up-regulated in activated or tissue-resident macrophages under stress or hypoxia. • GAPDH – glycolytic enzyme whose transcription increases during the metabolic shift of classically activated (M1-like) macrophages. Inconsistencies: No strongly contradictory genes are present; the list is small but internally consistent with a metallothionein-high, stress-adapted myeloid activation state.

program_17.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated inflammatory/angiogenic monocyte-macrophage program, characteristic of tissue-infiltrating M1-like macrophages that are simultaneously producing pro-angiogenic factors (akin to early tumor-associated macrophages or wound-healing macrophages). Evidence: • Myeloid identity – CD300E is a surface immunoreceptor restricted to mature monocytes/macrophages; ETS2 is a transcription factor enriched in monocytes and drives their inflammatory gene expression. • Inflammasome/inflammatory activation – NLRP3 (inflammasome sensor) and TIMP1 (MMP inhibitor released by activated macrophages) mark classical macrophage activation. • Glycolytic shift typical of M1-like macrophages – SLC2A3 (GLUT3) supports high glucose uptake required for pro-inflammatory glycolysis. • Pro-angiogenic/tissue-remodeling output – VEGFA and EREG are canonical macrophage-derived angiogenic and EGFR-ligand cytokines released during wound healing and in tumor microenvironments. • Metabolic rewiring – GK (glycerol kinase) and SLC25A37 (mitoferrin-1) reflect enhanced lipid and iron/mitochondrial metabolism often up-regulated in activated macrophages. Inconsistencies: • SLC25A37 is classically highest in erythroid cells; its presence suggests broader metabolic up-regulation rather than strict myeloid specificity. • No strongly discordant genes are evident; overall profile coherently supports an activated, pro-angiogenic macrophage state.

program_18.description: Transcriptomic features point to antibody-secreting plasmablasts / early plasma cells that are ramping up endoplasmic-reticulum chaperone machinery to support high-level immunoglobulin production. Evidence: • Secretory/ER stress genes characteristic of plasma cells – JCHAIN (IgA/IgM polymerisation), MZB1, FKBP11 and DERL3 – indicate a heavy immunoglobulin-secretion program. • Plasma-cell surface marker TNFRSF17 (BCMA) is highly restricted to plasmablasts/plasma cells. • B-lineage identity genes CD79A and transcriptional co-activator POU2AF1 together with FCRL5 confirm B-cell origin and differentiation along the memory-to-plasmablast axis. Inconsistencies: • Persistence of CD79A and POU2AF1, usually diminished in fully mature long-lived plasma cells, suggests this program may reflect an intermediate plasmablast state rather than terminal bone-marrow plasma cells.

program_19.description: The program represents an immediate-early activation/stress response that is typically triggered minutes to hours after cells (especially immune cells such as T cells, monocytes or other leukocytes) encounter cytokines, antigens or other activating stimuli; it reflects coordinated NF-κB/AP-1 signaling and the induction of feedback regulators that limit MAPK and inflammatory pathways. Evidence: • Classic immediate-early transcription factors: FOS, EGR1 and IER2 are rapidly and transiently induced by MAPK/AP-1 signaling after serum, T-cell-receptor or Toll-like-receptor stimulation. • Feedback regulators of MAPK and inflammatory signaling: DUSP1 and DUSP2 (dual-specificity phosphatases) attenuate ERK/JNK activity shortly after activation. • NF-κB pathway feedback inhibitors: TNFAIP3 (A20) and ZFP36 (TTP) are induced by NF-κB to restrain TNF-α and other cytokine transcripts, a hallmark of early inflammatory activation. • Pro-survival gene: MCL1 is an anti-apoptotic BCL-2 family member that rises rapidly to support cell survival during early activation stress. Inconsistencies: • No prominent inconsistencies; all listed genes coherently belong to an early activation / stress-response module rather than to a specific mature lineage program.

program_20.description: The gene set denotes an inflammatory, matrix-remodeling cancer-associated fibroblast (iCAF) program. Evidence: • Fibroblast/CAF surface molecules – SDC2 (syndecan-2) and NT5E (CD73) are canonical stromal fibroblast markers enriched in CAFs. • Matrix remodelling – MMP1 and MMP10, together with the secreted matricellular protein SPP1 (osteopontin), are hallmarks of activated fibroblasts engaged in extracellular-matrix turnover and tumour invasion. • Inflammatory/chemokine output – CXCL5 is a signature chemokine of iCAFs that recruits neutrophils and modulates immunity. • Additional CAF-associated enzyme – CA12 is frequently up-regulated in hypoxic, acid-regulating CAFs within solid tumours. Inconsistencies: • CA12 can also be expressed by epithelial tumour cells, and CXCL5 is not exclusive to fibroblasts (also produced by neutrophils and epithelial cells), but their co-expression with fibroblast markers and MMPs favours an iCAF identity.

program_21.description: The program most closely matches an activated, pro-inflammatory CD4⁺ T-helper state with features of Th17/Th1 polarization. Evidence: • T-cell activation genes – RHOH and TAGAP are selectively expressed in T-lineage cells and are up-regulated upon T-cell receptor engagement, marking an activated helper T-cell program. • Th17-skewing cytokines – IL6 is produced in an autocrine loop by differentiating Th17 cells, and INHBA (Activin A) is secreted by activated CD4⁺ T cells and promotes/maintains Th17 fate. • Inflammatory chemokine output – CCL3L3 (MIP-1α-like) is released by activated Th1/Th17 cells to recruit additional leukocytes and amplify inflammation. • Supporting activation machinery – CCNL1 (cell-cycle/splicing cyclin) and N4BP2 are broadly up-regulated in proliferating, transcriptionally active lymphocytes, consistent with recently activated helper T cells. Inconsistencies: • Absence of canonical Th17 effector genes (e.g., RORC, IL17A/F) limits definitive assignment; IL6 and INHBA can also originate from non-T immune or stromal cells; CCNL1 and N4BP2 are not lineage-specific.

program_22.description: The program reflects an acutely activated, pro-inflammatory neutrophil/monocyte state characterized by strong chemotactic responsiveness and cytokine-induced feedback regulation. Evidence: • CXCR2, FPR2 – canonical formyl-peptide and IL-8/CXC chemokine receptors that drive neutrophil chemotaxis and recruitment. • IL1R2, SOCS3 – inducible “brake” molecules up-regulated in myeloid cells after IL-1/LPS exposure, marking feedback control during intense inflammatory signaling. • OSM (Oncostatin M) – cytokine produced primarily by activated neutrophils and monocytes that acts in trans on endothelium and stromal cells during inflammation. • PDE4B – cAMP-degrading phosphodiesterase highly expressed in activated myeloid cells, modulating downstream inflammatory signaling. • LCP2 (SLP-76) – adapter required for integrin and Fc-receptor signaling in neutrophils, supporting adhesion and oxidative burst during activation. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes clearly contradict a neutrophil/monocyte inflammatory activation program; LCP2 is sometimes viewed as lymphoid-biased but is functionally expressed in neutrophils, so its presence is not discordant.

program_23.description: The gene set denotes an activated phagocytic innate-immune program most characteristic of microglia/monocyte–macrophage lineage cells that are experiencing a type I interferon stimulus, leading to up-regulation of immunoreceptor signaling adaptors, oxidative burst machinery, and lysosomal/phagolysosomal components. Evidence: • FCER1G and TYROBP encode Fc- and TREM-associated ITAM adaptors enriched in microglia and other myeloid phagocytes, marking innate-immune receptor signaling. • CYBA (p22phox) is a core subunit of the NADPH oxidase complex required for respiratory burst in professional phagocytes. • CD63 (lysosomal tetraspanin) and NPC2 (cholesterol-handling lysosomal protein) reflect increased lysosomal/phagolysosomal activity typical of activated macrophage/microglial states. • B2M indicates up-regulated MHC-I antigen presentation frequently seen after interferon exposure. • IFI6 is a canonical type I interferon-stimulated gene, confirming an interferon-activated state. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided and no positive gene strongly contradicts the inferred cell type/state.

program_24.description: The gene set is most consistent with a CD1A⁺, MHC-II⁺ conventional/Langerhans-like dendritic cell program characterized by active lipid-antigen presentation and secretion of the IL-22 decoy receptor, a signature typical of skin and mucosal dendritic cells that regulate barrier immunity. Evidence: • Lipid-antigen presentation machinery – CD1A and CD1E are canonical markers of Langerhans cells and other CD1-restricted dendritic cells. • Professional antigen presentation – HLA-DQB2 (MHC class II) is expressed by dendritic cells, reinforcing an APC identity. • Barrier-immune cytokine regulation – IL22RA2 (IL-22 binding protein) is produced chiefly by skin/gut dendritic cells to modulate IL-22-driven epithelial responses. • DC maturation/activation support – PKIB is up-regulated by cAMP signaling in activated dendritic cells. Inconsistencies: • TACSTD2 (TROP2) and PARM1 are primarily epithelial/barrier cell markers, not classical DC genes; their presence may reflect epithelial RNA contamination or a niche-specific DC subset that acquires epithelial transcripts (e.g., at barrier surfaces).

program_25.description: Gene expression points to a generic hypoxia/HIF-1α response program, reflecting cells (of any lineage) adapting to low-oxygen conditions by boosting glycolysis and pro-survival pathways. Evidence: • Canonical HIF-1α target genes BNIP3 (mitophagy/anoikis resistance), EGLN3/PHD3 (oxygen sensor), PLOD2 (collagen hydroxylation in hypoxic extracellular matrix remodeling) and TMEM45A are all strongly inducible by hypoxia. • Metabolic shift toward anaerobic glycolysis is marked by SLC2A1/GLUT1 (high-affinity glucose transporter) and ENO2 (glycolytic enzyme), both classic components of hypoxic glycolytic signatures. Inconsistencies: • ENO2 is sometimes regarded as neuron-enriched, but it is also up-regulated by HIF-1α in many non-neuronal cells, so this does not conflict substantially with a hypoxia program.

program_26.description: The program is most consistent with an inflammatory “classical” (CD14⁺ FCN1⁺) monocyte / early macrophage state characterized by high expression of innate‐immune effectors and S100 calcium-binding proteins. Evidence: • FCN1 – canonical marker of human classical CD14hi monocytes; absent from lymphocytes and non-myeloid compartments. • RETN (Resistin) – secreted predominantly by activated human monocytes/macrophages and linked to pro-inflammatory cytokine production. • S100A4 and S100A6 – S100 family members induced in activated monocytes/macrophages and up-regulated during inflammatory responses. • SH3BGRL3 – enriched in myeloid lineages and increases with monocyte activation. • CD52 – although best known on lymphocytes, its transcript is detectably expressed in circulating monocytes and rises with interferon-stimulated/inflammatory states, supporting a leukocyte activation context. Inconsistencies: • S100A4 is also expressed by fibroblasts and some epithelial cells; however, its co-occurrence with monocyte-specific FCN1 and RETN suggests myeloid rather than mesenchymal origin. No other strong conflicts are observed.

program_27.description: The gene set represents an antimicrobial/secretory program characteristic of small-intestinal Paneth cells (with some overlap with goblet-cell injury responses), reflecting a mucosal defense/regeneration state of intestinal epithelium. Evidence: • DEFA5 – classic α-defensin specifically stored and secreted by Paneth cells. • REG1A, REG1B, REG3A – regenerating family peptides induced in Paneth and neighboring enterocytes during microbial challenge and epithelial injury; central to luminal antibacterial defense and tissue repair. • SPINK4 – secreted Kazal-type protease inhibitor enriched in secretory intestinal epithelial lineages (Paneth/goblet) and up-regulated during barrier stress, aligning with a protective secretory phenotype. Inconsistencies: • No strong discordant genes; SPINK4 is more broadly expressed in goblet cells but still fits a secretory/antimicrobial epithelial context rather than contradicting the Paneth-cell program.

program_0.description: The gene set points to a generic “high-translation” cellular program characterized by robust ribosome biogenesis and protein synthesis, a state often seen in rapidly growing or recently stimulated cells irrespective of lineage rather than a lineage-specific phenotype. Evidence: • Strong, coordinated up-regulation of large- and small-subunit ribosomal protein genes (e.g., RPL3/4/7/10/13/34; RPS3/6/12/14/15A/18/27A) is the hallmark of cells boosting translational capacity. • Concurrent down-regulation of cytoskeletal and housekeeping mRNAs (ACTB, PFN1, TMSB4X) and immune/activation markers (B2M, IL32, S100A4) is consistent with a metabolic shift that prioritizes ribosome production over structural or effector functions, a pattern reported for proliferating lymphocytes and other dividing cells. Inconsistencies: • Absence of classic proliferation genes (MKI67, TOP2A, PCNA) means the program captures the translational arm of growth but not the full cell-cycle signature. • HCST (DNAM-1 ligand adapter; immune signaling) appears among negatively loaded genes, minimally relevant to translation and slightly at odds with a purely biosynthetic program.

program_1.description: The gene set represents a robust cytotoxic effector program typical of activated natural killer (NK) cells and cytotoxic CD8⁺ T lymphocytes, characterized by strong expression of granzymes, perforin‐associated machinery, NK receptors, and pro-inflammatory chemokines. Evidence: • Cytolytic effector molecules GZMA, GZMB, GNLY, NKG7, CTSW, CST7 — hallmarks of NK and cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells engaged in target-cell killing. • NK/T-cell surface receptors KLRD1 (CD94), KLRC1 (NKG2A), KLRC2 (NKG2C), CD7 — classical NK and cytotoxic T-cell receptor repertoire. • Chemokine secretion profile CCL3, CCL4, CCL5, XCL2 — pro-inflammatory chemokines released by activated cytotoxic lymphocytes to recruit additional immune cells. • Lineage/activation regulators ID2 (required for NK differentiation), HOPX (associated with long-lived effector/memory T cells). • Degranulation marker CD63 is up-regulated upon lytic granule exocytosis in NK and CD8⁺ T cells. Inconsistencies: No notable inconsistencies; all listed genes align with an activated cytotoxic NK / CD8⁺ T-cell state.

program_2.description: The program reflects a stressed or pre-apoptotic cell state characterized by heightened mitochondrial respiratory activity and a concurrent shutdown of cytosolic protein synthesis. Evidence: • Up-regulated mitochondrial transcripts (MT-CO1/2/3, MT-ATP6, MT-CYB, MT-ND3/4) encode subunits of complexes I, III, IV and the ATP synthase, a pattern typical of cells that have released or stabilized mitochondrial RNA during oxidative or apoptotic stress. • Down-regulated translation machinery genes (RPS17, RPS2, RPS20, RPL27A, RPL23A) and the elongation factor EEF1A1 indicate global suppression of ribosome biogenesis and mRNA translation, a hallmark of integrated stress responses and early apoptosis, where cap-dependent translation is curtailed while mitochondrial transcripts, which are transcribed and translated in the organelle, remain abundant. Inconsistencies: • No major conflicts; all listed genes align with a stress-induced, translationally repressed state rather than a specific differentiated lineage.

program_3.description: The gene constellation represents an acute activation (immediate-early) program in T lymphocytes—most compatible with recently TCR-stimulated naïve/central-memory or tissue-resident memory T cells that still express IL7R/CXCR4 while up-regulating classic immediate-early transcription factors and feedback regulators. Evidence: • Immediate-early response genes FOS, FOSB, JUN, EGR1 and MAPK inhibitor DUSP1 are prototypically induced within minutes of T-cell receptor signaling. • CD69, a canonical early surface marker of T-cell activation and of tissue-resident memory T cells, is strongly up-regulated. • IL7R (CD127) and CXCR4 are hallmarks of naïve and central-memory T cells that have not terminally differentiated; their co-expression with CD69 supports a recently activated memory-like state. • Negative feedback/anti-inflammatory genes TNFAIP3, TSC22D3 and ANXA1 are classically induced by NF-κB/GR signaling following T-cell activation, completing the immediate-early regulatory module. • KLF6 is reported to rise after TCR engagement and cooperate with AP-1 factors (FOS/JUN) in activated T cells. Inconsistencies: • None obvious; all listed genes are coherent with an early activation program in T lymphocytes, though IL7R can decline in highly effector or exhausted cells, suggesting the cells are not fully effector-differentiated.

program_4.description: The gene set represents a generic “biosynthetic–proliferative” program seen in many actively cycling cells that have up-regulated mitochondrial translation, proteasome activity and G1 progression rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • Mitochondrial ribosome / oxidative phosphorylation – CHCHD1 (mitochondrial small-subunit protein), MRPL11 (large-subunit protein) and TMEM242 (ATP-synthase assembly) mark cells boosting mitochondrial translation and respiration. • Proteasome activity – PSMC3 encodes a 19S AAA-ATPase subunit, typical of proliferative cells that need enhanced protein turnover. • Cell-cycle entry – CDK4 drives G1-to-S transition; its co-expression with increased metabolic genes is common in cells preparing to divide. • General translational and metabolic support – TIAL1 (RNA-binding/translation), AHCY (methyl-cycle enzyme sustaining SAM-dependent methylation), SZRD1 and CCDC124 (ribosome-associated) are frequently co-induced with growth programs. • Absence of lineage-specific markers and predominance of ubiquitous “housekeeping” genes further point toward a broad proliferative/metabolic state rather than a specialized cell identity. Inconsistencies: • Classical S-phase (MCMs, PCNA) or mitotic (MKI67, TOP2A) markers are lacking, so the program likely reflects early G1 growth rather than full cell-cycle gene expression.

program_5.description: The gene set represents a mature, resting peripheral B-cell program characterized by intact B-cell receptor signaling and high MHC class II–mediated antigen-presentation capacity, typical of naïve or memory B cells rather than plasmablasts. Evidence: • Core B-cell receptor machinery – MS4A1 (CD20), CD79A, VPREB3 and the adaptor BANK1 delineate committed B-lineage cells that have not undergone terminal plasma-cell differentiation (these genes are lost or strongly reduced in plasmablasts). • Survival/maintenance receptor – TNFRSF13C (BAFF-R) is selectively expressed on mature naïve and memory B cells and absent from plasma cells. • Antigen-presentation module – High, coordinated expression of HLA-DRA, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DMA together with the invariant chain CD74 signifies robust MHC class II loading and presentation, a hallmark of resting peripheral B cells that function as antigen-presenting cells. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes contradict a mature naïve/memory B-cell identity; minor expression of VPREB3 can also be seen in early plasmablasts, but the concurrent presence of CD20 and BAFF-R argues against a plasmablast state.

program_6.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, tissue-resident natural killer (NK) cell program (e.g. uterine/decidual or skin-resident NK cells) characterized by Fc-receptor adaptor signaling and production of the tissue-repair cytokine amphiregulin. Evidence: • NK receptor signaling core – TYROBP (DAP12), FCER1G and SH2D1B are canonical adaptor molecules that transmit signals from multiple NK receptors. • Inhibitory/activating NK receptors – KLRC1 (NKG2A) and KIR2DL4 are signature receptors of tissue-resident and especially uterine NK cells. • Tissue-repair/activation marker – AREG (amphiregulin) is secreted by activated tissue-resident NK cells and other ILCs to promote epithelial repair. Inconsistencies: • KRT81 and KRT86 are hair-shaft keratins typical of hair-follicle keratinocytes, not NK cells, suggesting contamination or doublet signal. • CXXC5 is a broadly expressed Wnt-responsive regulator without specific NK enrichment.

program_7.description: The gene set represents an activated, cytotoxic CD8⁺ T-cell program—typical of effector/effector-memory CD8⁺ T lymphocytes mounting a type-1 (IFN-γ–driven) antiviral response. Evidence: • CD8A, CD8B – canonical surface coreceptors defining CD8⁺ T cells. • GZMK and GZMH – granzymes enriched in cytotoxic effector and effector-memory CD8⁺ T cells; GZMK is characteristic of IFN-γ–producing, granzyme-K⁺ memory cells, while GZMH marks cytolytic activity. • IFNG – hallmark cytokine of activated type-1 cytotoxic T cells. • APOBEC3G – antiviral cytidine deaminase induced in activated cytotoxic lymphocytes. • DUSP2 – phosphatase up-regulated upon T-cell receptor stimulation, reflecting recent activation. • CMC1 – mitochondrial component often up-regulated in metabolically active, recently activated T cells. Inconsistencies: No genes in the list contradict a CD8⁺ cytotoxic/effector-memory T-cell identity; the absence of other classic cytotoxic genes (e.g., GZMB, PRF1, NKG7) reflects omission rather than opposition.

program_8.description: The gene set represents an HSF1-mediated cytosolic heat-shock / acute proteotoxic-stress program that can appear in virtually any cell type when exposed to sudden temperature elevation, oxidative stress, or other protein-denaturing insults. It is not lineage-specific but marks cells actively buffering mis-folded proteins through inducible chaperones. Evidence: • Inducible Hsp70 isoforms HSPA1A, HSPA1B and HSPA6 are classical, highest-amplitude targets of the heat-shock factor HSF1. • Co-chaperones DNAJB1 and DNAJA4 (Hsp40 family) cooperate with Hsp70 during refolding and are likewise HSF1 targets. • HSP90AA1 (inducible cytosolic Hsp90) and HSPE1 (Hsp10) are additional stress-induced chaperones that expand protein-folding capacity under acute heat/proteotoxic stress. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are canonical components of the heat-shock response, and no negatively loaded genes counter this interpretation.

program_9.description: The gene loadings depict a “high-translation/low-mitochondrial-respiration” program typical of rapidly proliferating, biosynthetically active cells (e.g., activated lymphocytes or other cycling cells) that are boosting ribosome production while de-emphasizing oxidative phosphorylation. Evidence: • RPL36A, RPLP2, RPL17, RPS29, RPS26 – core large and small subunit ribosomal proteins; their concerted up-regulation is a classic signature of ribosome biogenesis and elevated global protein synthesis seen during cell-cycle entry and clonal expansion. • MT-ND1 (negative) – encodes a Complex I subunit of the electron-transport chain; its relative down-regulation fits the metabolic shift toward reduced mitochondrial respiration that accompanies rapid proliferation and high glycolytic flux. Inconsistencies: • Only one mitochondrial gene is negatively loaded; lack of broader metabolic or cell-cycle markers limits resolution of the exact proliferative context, but no genes directly conflict with the high-translation interpretation.
