program_10.description: The gene set most consistently fits a generalized “secretory/ER-Golgi trafficking” program, characteristic of cells that are ramping up protein/lipid export (e.g., activated secretory epithelia or immune cells) rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • ORMDL3↑ – ER-resident regulator of sphingolipid synthesis and unfolded-protein/secretory stress responses. • VTI1B↑ – late Golgi-to-endosome/lysosome SNARE essential for vesicle fusion in the secretory pathway. • AAMP↑ – Golgi/endosome-associated actin-binding protein that promotes vesicle movement and secretion; often up-regulated when secretory load is high. • GTF2A2↑ – basal transcription factor subunit; its elevation is commonly seen in global transcriptional up-scaling accompanying secretory activation. • ETFA↑ – mitochondrial electron-transfer flavoprotein subunit that supplies FADH₂ to oxidative phosphorylation, providing energy for ATP-demanding secretory processes. • VMA21↓ – ER chaperone for V-ATPase assembly; its suppression is frequently observed when cells divert membrane flux from lysosomal acidification toward exocytic trafficking. Inconsistencies: • AAMP is also enriched in endothelial cells, so its presence could alternatively indicate a vascular phenotype. • The list lacks several canonical ER-stress markers (e.g., HSPA5, DDIT3); thus the program may represent a mild or early secretory shift rather than a full unfolded-protein response.

program_11.description: The gene set reflects an activated/effector regulatory T-cell (Treg) program. Evidence: • FOXP3 – master transcription factor that specifies and maintains Treg lineage identity. • IL2RA (CD25) – constitutively high on Tregs, supporting FOXP3 expression via IL-2 signaling. • TNFRSF4 (OX40) and BATF – co-induced upon antigen/IL-2 stimulation in effector Tregs, marking their activated state and enhanced suppressive function. • LAIR2 – secreted inhibitory receptor enriched in human Tregs and linked to their suppressive capacity. • RTKN2 – FOXP3‐induced Rho-GTPase effector preferentially expressed in CD4⁺ T cells, reported as a Treg marker. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; each listed gene is compatible with a Treg identity, with BATF and TNFRSF4 also found in activated conventional T cells but commonly up-regulated in effector Tregs as well.

program_12.description: The gene set indicates a mature B-lymphocyte program characterized by high expression of class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC-II) molecules, consistent with antigen-presenting naïve or memory B cells rather than antibody-secreting plasmablasts. Evidence: • HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DQB1 – canonical MHC-II genes required for peptide presentation to CD4⁺ T cells; strongly expressed in professional antigen-presenting cells, especially resting/activated B cells. • CD19 – lineage-defining surface molecule for B cells that is retained in naïve and memory states but down-regulated during plasma cell differentiation, supporting a non-plasma, antigen-presenting B-cell identity. Inconsistencies: • No negatively associated genes were provided; no clear conflicts with the above interpretation.

program_13.description: The gene pattern is most compatible with a differentiated, metabolically active (oxidative/respiratory) cell state that is relatively non-proliferative, rather than pointing to a specific lineage. Up-regulation of mitochondrial respiration and detoxification enzymes, together with suppression of a core spliceosomal factor, fits many mature parenchymal cells (e.g., hepatocytes, renal tubule cells, cardiomyocytes) that rely on oxidative phosphorylation and show low cell-cycle activity. Evidence: • COX7A2L – scaffolding subunit that promotes respiratory-chain super-complex assembly; marker of cells relying on oxidative phosphorylation rather than glycolysis. • AKR7A2 – aldehyde/ketone detoxification enzyme enriched in mature metabolic tissues (liver, kidney), indicating differentiated metabolic function. • DCPS – 5′-mRNA cap–scavenging enzyme; its presence together with low spliceosome activity is typical of cells emphasizing mRNA turnover rather than active transcription/splicing. • Negative loading of PRPF38A – reduced expression of a core spliceosomal protein is characteristic of non-cycling or fully differentiated cells, contrasting with its high level in proliferating cells. Inconsistencies: • SNAPIN is best known for roles in synaptic vesicle trafficking; although it is broadly expressed, its inclusion provides only weak, lineage-specific evidence and does not strongly support the differentiated metabolic model.

program_14.description: The program represents a mature intestinal epithelial signature, spanning absorptive enterocytes and secretory/goblet cells of the small intestine/colon. Evidence: • GUCA2A & GUCA2B – encode guanylin and uroguanylin, peptides specifically produced by intestinal epithelial cells (mainly goblet and enteroendocrine lineages) to regulate fluid-electrolyte balance via GC-C signaling. • ZG16 – goblet-cell-enriched secretory lectin stored in mucin granules and released into the intestinal lumen. • PHGR1 – highly expressed in differentiated colonic and small-intestinal epithelial cells; used as a marker of intestinal epithelial differentiation. • FABP1 – fatty-acid-binding protein abundant in mature villus enterocytes, reflecting lipid absorption and metabolism in the gut epithelium. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes and no clear out-of-context markers; all listed genes are congruent with an intestinal epithelial program.

program_0.description: This program reflects a global “high-translation/low-oxidative-phosphorylation” state that can be seen in many rapidly growing or recently activated cells. It is characterized by coordinated up-regulation of virtually the entire cytosolic ribosomal protein repertoire and translation factors, coupled with relative suppression of mitochondrial electron-transport chain transcripts. Evidence: • Cytosolic protein synthesis machinery up: >70 genes encoding large- and small-subunit ribosomal proteins (e.g. RPL3, RPL10, RPS6, RPS18), translation factor EEF1A1, and scaffold RACK1 indicate enhanced ribosome biogenesis and active translation. • Actin-binding TMSB4X often co-varies with ribosomal genes in proliferating/activated cells that remodel their cytoskeleton during growth. • Mitochondrial OXPHOS down: negative loading of the core mtDNA-encoded ETC genes (MT-CO1/2/3, MT-ND1/3/4/5, MT-CYB, MT-ATP6) is typical of cells that shift energy production toward glycolysis or transiently dampen respiration during rapid biomass accumulation. • JUND, a stress-responsive/AP-1 transcription factor, is negatively loaded, consistent with cells not engaged in oxidative or inflammatory stress but instead prioritizing biomass production. Inconsistencies: • None of the positively loaded genes confers lineage specificity; thus the program alone cannot pinpoint a precise cell type but rather denotes a metabolic/functional state common to multiple lineages.

program_1.description: This program represents a generic “G2/M-phase mitotic cell-cycle” state that can be detected in any proliferating cell population, rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The uniformly high loading of canonical mitotic regulators, spindle assembly factors, and chromosome segregation genes indicates cells that are actively progressing through late G2, metaphase, anaphase, and cytokinesis. Evidence: • Core mitotic kinases – CDK1, AURKA, AURKB, PLK1, NEK2 activate and orchestrate G2/M transition, centrosome maturation, and spindle checkpoint. • Cyclins – CCNB1 and CCNB2 form the Cyclin-B–CDK1 complex essential for entry into mitosis. • Spindle and kinetochore components – CENPA, CENPE, CENPF, CENPE, BIRC5 (Survivin), HMMR, TPX2, DLGAP5, ASPM, CDCA8 (Chromosomal Passenger Complex) mediate spindle assembly, kinetochore attachment, and chromosome segregation. • Anaphase-promoting complex/cohesion regulators – CDC20 and UBE2C drive cyclin degradation and sister-chromatid separation. • DNA topology and condensation – TOP2A resolves chromosome catenation; HMGB2 assists chromatin organization. • Additional G2/M markers – GTSE1, CDKN3, CDCA3, DEPDC1 further mark proliferating cells. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are classical G2/M cell-cycle markers with no conflicting lineage-specific signatures.

program_2.description: The gene set represents an activated cytotoxic T-cell program characteristic of effector / effector-memory CD8⁺ T lymphocytes that co-express chemokines and NK-like cytotoxic machinery. Evidence: • Core T-cell identity – CD3D, CD3E, CD3G, CD2, CD7, LCP2 unequivocally mark T lymphocytes. • CD8⁺ lineage – CD8A together with CD3 complex indicates a CD8 T-cell subset. • Effector/cytotoxic molecules – GZMA, NKG7, CCL5, CCL4, KLRD1, CD96, PRDM1 (Blimp-1) denote activated, cytotoxic or NK-like effector T cells. • Memory/activation markers – IL7R, FYB1, TNFAIP3, GIMAP7 and RORA are enriched in effector-memory or tissue-resident memory T cells. • Transcriptional regulators of effector fate – ID2 and PRDM1 promote cytotoxic T-cell differentiation. Inconsistencies: • KLRB1 (CD161) and RORA are more typical of MAIT/Th17 cells but are also reported in tissue-resident memory CD8 T cells, so their presence is not strongly discordant.

program_3.description: Transcriptome pattern is most consistent with an immediate-early activation program in T lymphocytes (recently TCR- or cytokine-stimulated CD69⁺ T cells), marked by rapid induction of AP-1 family transcription factors, Nur77, chemokine/activation receptors and stress-responsive regulators, together with a relative drop in constitutive housekeeping/cytoskeletal transcripts. Evidence: • AP-1 immediate-early genes FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB and the MAPK-feedback phosphatase DUSP1 are classically up-regulated within minutes of T-cell activation. • NR4A2 (Nur77 family) is a direct TCR-signalling target and a sensitive marker of recent T-cell stimulation. • CD69 is one of the first surface markers induced after TCR engagement; CXCR4 is abundant in circulating T cells and its transcript often persists shortly after activation. • TSC22D3 (GILZ) is induced by glucocorticoid/TCR signalling in activated T cells and dampens downstream inflammatory responses. • Negative loading of ubiquitous cytoskeletal/housekeeping genes (ACTB, ACTG1, GAPDH, TMSB4X, SERF2) reflects the shift of transcriptional resources toward stimulus-responsive genes typical of an immediate-early response module. Inconsistencies: • KLF2 and CXCR4 are usually down-regulated in strongly activated effector T cells; their positive loading suggests a partial or early activation state (e.g., central memory or recently stimulated circulating T cells) rather than fully differentiated effectors.

program_4.description: The gene set represents a generic G2/M–phase cell-cycle program characteristic of actively dividing cells across multiple lineages rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • MKI67, STMN1 – canonical proliferation markers present during all active cell-cycle phases, peak in G2/M. • NUSAP1, KIF11, CKAP5, TUBB – spindle microtubule assembly/organization factors essential during mitosis. • CENPW, SPC25, NUF2, SGO2 – kinetochore and centromere cohesion components required for accurate chromosome segregation. • PBK (TOPK), PIF1 – mitosis-associated kinase and helicase up-regulated specifically in late S to M phase. • Cohesive absence of negatively loaded genes further supports a unidirectional proliferative signature. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; AAMDC is less well characterized but has been reported to correlate with high proliferation in several cancers, fitting the overall program.

program_5.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with a highly proliferative cell-cycle program (early S/G2 phase) in which chromatin-associated proteins are up-regulated while basal antigen-presentation machinery (MHC class I) is simultaneously repressed—an expression profile typical of rapidly dividing progenitor or tumor cells that transiently dampen immune visibility. Evidence: • Proliferation / S-phase chromatin genes up-regulated – STMN1 (microtubule dynamics during mitosis) – PCLAF/KIAA0101 (PCNA-binding factor, DNA replication) – HMGB2, HMGB1, HMGN2 (high-mobility group chromatin proteins enriched in cycling cells) • Antigen-presentation genes down-regulated – B2M, HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C (core MHC-I components commonly reduced in rapidly cycling or immune-evasive cells) Inconsistencies: • Absence of classic late-cell-cycle markers such as MKI67, TOP2A or cyclins may indicate this program captures a restricted chromatin/DNA-replication facet of proliferation rather than the full mitotic module.

program_6.description: The program represents a generic S-phase/DNA-replication signature characteristic of rapidly proliferating cells, irrespective of lineage. Evidence: • DNA replication licensing/elongation: MCM4 (MCM helicase), RFC2 and ATAD5 (PCNA clamp loader/unloader), FEN1 (Okazaki-fragment processing) all peak during S phase. • S-phase checkpoint control: CLSPN transduces ATR signals during replication stress, ensuring fork stability. • Chromosome segregation linkage: ZWINT localizes to kinetochores, up-regulated as cells progress from S into G2/M. • Cell-cycle transcriptional control: RBL1 (p107) modulates E2F-dependent genes at the G1/S boundary, typically expressed in cycling cells. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes coherently participate in DNA replication or its surveillance.

program_7.description: The program reflects a strong MHC-class II antigen-presentation module most consistent with CD23⁺ B cells (naïve or memory) that are primed for presenting antigen to T helper cells. Evidence: • HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQB1 – core MHC class II α/β chains required for peptide display, uniformly high in professional antigen-presenting cells. • CD74 – invariant chain that escorts MHC-II through the endosomal pathway; highly expressed in B cells and other APCs during active peptide loading. • FCER2 (CD23) – low-affinity IgE receptor largely restricted to mature B cells (naïve and memory) and rarely found on dendritic or myeloid cells, pointing specifically to the B-cell lineage rather than a generic APC program. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes coherently fit an MHC-II⁺, CD23⁺ B-cell antigen-presentation state.

program_8.description: The program represents a generic proliferative (S – G2/M phase) cell-cycle state common to many dividing cell types. Evidence: • S-phase licensing/replication genes: ORC6 and RFC3 are core components of the pre-replication complex and clamp loader, respectively, marking DNA synthesis. • G2/M cyclin and mitotic machinery: CCNA2 drives S-to-G2 transition and entry into mitosis; KIFC1 is a kinesin required for spindle/centrosome organization during mitosis. • Ancillary proliferation regulators: ARL3 (microtubule-associated small GTPase) and MAPK13 (p38δ MAPK, promotes proliferation in several contexts) are frequently up-regulated in actively dividing cells. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes and no clear lineage-specific markers; all listed genes fit a cell-cycle/proliferation program.

program_9.description: The program represents a canonical S-phase cell-cycle signature that appears whenever cells—irrespective of lineage—are actively replicating their DNA (e.g., proliferating progenitors, cycling immune cells, or tumor cells). Evidence: • Core DNA-synthesis enzymes – TYMS (thymidylate synthase), RRM2 (ribonucleotide reductase M2) and TK1 (thymidine kinase 1) supply deoxynucleotides specifically during S phase. • S-phase histone supply – ASF1B is a histone H3/H4 chaperone induced during DNA replication to package newly synthesized DNA. • S-phase transcriptional drivers – E2F1 is the archetypal transcription factor that activates genes required for DNA replication. • DNA-replication/repair helicase – BRIP1 (FANCJ) partners with BRCA1 at stalled forks, a hallmark of cells undergoing active replication. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded or lineage-specific markers are present; the gene set is uniformly consistent with a generic S-phase proliferation program.

program_10.description: The gene program is characteristic of myeloid cells—specifically resident CNS microglia or tissue macrophages in an immune-activated, phagocytic state. Evidence: • Microglial core/activation module: AIF1 (Iba1) and TYROBP are canonical components of the microglial “TYROBP network” that drives innate immune and phagocytic responses. • Fc-receptor signaling: FCER1G partners with TYROBP to transduce signals from TREM2 and other ITAM-containing receptors, a signature of activated microglia and macrophages. • Secreted cystatin and antimicrobial enzymes: CST3 (Cystatin C) and LYZ (lysozyme) are abundantly produced by microglia and macrophages and rise during phagocytosis and antimicrobial defense. • Iron handling/oxidative stress: FTL (ferritin light chain) is up-regulated in microglia/macrophages to sequester iron during inflammatory activation. Inconsistencies: None evident; all listed genes fit a myeloid, microglial/macrophage activation program.

program_11.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with a germinal-center (GC) B-cell program, reflecting B cells that have down-regulated the positioning receptor EBI2 (GPR183) to reside within the follicular GC and that express canonical GC regulators such as RGS13. Evidence: • Positive RGS13 – highly enriched in GC B cells where it limits CXCR4/CXCR5 signaling; rarely expressed in naïve or memory B cells. • Negative GPR183 (EBI2) – EBI2 is repressed by BCL6 in GC B cells but abundant in naïve and memory B cells; its negative loading matches the GC phenotype. • Negative S100A4 – this calcium-binding protein marks memory B cells; its depletion further separates GC from memory states. • Positive MARCKSL1 and HMGN1 – although more general, both are expressed in proliferating, activated lymphocytes and are reported in GC transcriptomes, supporting an activated intrafollicular state. Inconsistencies: • MARCKSL1 and HMGN1 are not strictly GC-restricted and are also found in other activated immune cells; however, they do not contradict the overall GC B-cell interpretation.

program_12.description: The gene set best fits germ cells that are in the meiotic division phase (primary spermatocytes or oocytes), i.e. a “meiotic-germ-cell program.” Evidence: • MND1 – classically restricted to meiotic prophase I where it partners with HOP2 to promote homologous recombination; highly enriched in spermatocytes and oocytes, rarely seen in somatic cycling cells. • HAUS8 – augmin-complex subunit required for spindle microtubule amplification; indispensable for both male and female meiotic spindle assembly, fitting a cell actively undergoing meiotic division. • TMEM106C and PISD – genes linked to membrane/mitochondrial remodeling that rise during germ-cell maturation and the metabolic re-wiring accompanying meiosis. • HBS1L – a ribosome-rescue GTPase whose transcripts are elevated in testis, consistent with the high translational demand of meiotic germ cells. Inconsistencies: • HBS1L is also expressed in erythroid progenitors and other dividing cells, so it is not uniquely germ-cell–specific. • TMEM106C and PISD are broadly expressed housekeeping genes, providing little specificity to the program.

program_13.description: The gene set represents a canonical heat-shock / proteotoxic stress response program that can be transiently induced in virtually any cell type rather than marking a specific lineage; cells expressing this program are in an acute cytoprotective state characterized by up-regulation of molecular chaperones to refold or prevent aggregation of damaged proteins. Evidence: • HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSPA6 – inducible members of the HSP70 family that are classically up-regulated within minutes of heat, oxidative, or chemical stress to bind unfolded proteins and assist refolding. • DNAJB1 – an HSP40 co-chaperone that stimulates ATPase activity of HSP70s and directs client proteins for refolding or degradation, a hallmark component of the heat-shock machinery. • HSP90AA1 – inducible cytosolic HSP90 isoform that stabilizes and refolds a broad range of signaling proteins during stress. Collectively, the synchronous induction of multiple HSP70, HSP40, and HSP90 genes is a well-established signature of the heat-shock transcription factor (HSF1) pathway and indicates a generalized stress response rather than lineage identity. Inconsistencies: None identified; all detected genes align with the heat-shock/proteotoxic stress program.

program_0.description: The program reflects a lineage-agnostic “ribosome/translation” state characterized by coordinated up-regulation of virtually every major cytosolic ribosomal protein gene together with core translation factors, pointing to cells undergoing heightened global protein synthesis—commonly observed during proliferation, activation, or other metabolically demanding conditions rather than defining a specific cell type. Evidence: • Cytosolic large-subunit (RPL) genes: RPL3, RPL5, RPL10, RPL13, RPL18, RPL23, RPL26, RPL35A, RPLP1/P2, etc. – concerted expression indicates ribosome biogenesis and abundance of the 60S subunit. • Cytosolic small-subunit (RPS) genes: RPS3, RPS6, RPS8, RPS14, RPS18, RPS19, RPS25, RPS28, RPS4X, etc. – matching elevation of 40S components. • Translation elongation factors EEF1A1 and EEF1B2 – mark active peptide elongation. • RACK1 (GNB2L1) – scaffolding protein that sits on the 40S subunit and regulates translation initiation. The coordinated up-regulation of virtually the entire ribosomal proteome together with elongation factors is a canonical signature of high translational throughput across diverse cell types. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes and no lineage-specific markers are present; the program is internally consistent but does not specify a particular cell lineage.

program_1.description: The program reflects a cytotoxic CD8⁺ T-cell activation state, characteristic of effector or tissue-resident/memory CTLs that have recently engaged antigen and are producing cytolytic molecules and chemokines. Evidence: • T-cell identity – TCR complex and signaling genes (CD3D/E/G, CD247, CD2, CD7, LCK, FYN, FYB1, TRAT1, LCP2, SH2D2A, BCL11B) are strongly positive. • Cytotoxic machinery – perforin and granzymes (PRF1, GZMB, GZMA, GZMM, GNLY, NKG7, CST7) plus HCST (DAP10) and CD96/KLRD1 indicate CTL/NK-like killing capacity. • CD8 lineage – CD8A and IL2RB (CD122) support a CD8⁺ rather than CD4⁺ program. • Effector chemokine secretion – high CCL5 and CCL4, along with IL32 and ALOX5AP, mark activated CTLs that recruit other immune cells. • Memory / tissue-resident flavor – IL7R, HOPX, ID2, KLRB1 and TMIGD2 are enriched in long-lived effector-memory or resident CTLs. • Absence of B-cell/plasma signatures – the B-cell/plasma marker JCHAIN is negatively loaded, reinforcing a T-cell identity. Inconsistencies: • IL7R is typically down-regulated in terminal effector CTLs, so its high loading suggests a less-differentiated effector-memory subset. • KLRB1 (CD161) is more common in Th17 or MAIT cells but can appear in tissue-resident CD8⁺ T cells; its presence may indicate some heterogeneity. • ALOX5AP is better known in myeloid cells, though it can be induced in activated T cells and thus is not wholly discordant.

program_2.description: The gene set represents a canonical G2/M cell-cycle program characteristic of actively dividing cells (e.g., cycling progenitors, activated immune cells, tumor cells) rather than a lineage-restricted phenotype. Evidence: • Core proliferation markers – MKI67, TOP2A, BIRC5, STMN1, PCLAF, TK1 and RRM2 are universally up-regulated in cycling cells. • G2/M regulators – CDK1, CDC20, UBE2C, CDCA3, CDKN3, MAD2L1 and PTTG1 coordinate mitotic entry, spindle checkpoint control and anaphase progression. • Chromosome segregation/centromere proteins – CENPA, CENPW, CENPN, CENPU, ZWINT and NUSAP1 mark centromere assembly and kinetochore function during mitosis. • Spindle and microtubule dynamics – AURKB, GTSE1, TUBA1B and SHCBP1 facilitate spindle formation and cytokinesis. • DNA replication/repair completion before mitosis – TYMS, UBE2T, HMGB2 support late S-phase DNA synthesis and repair, consistent with imminent mitosis. Inconsistencies: No appreciable lineage-specific markers or genes incompatible with a generic G2/M program are present.

program_3.description: The gene set points to a homeostatic, naïve-like lymphocyte program characterized by abundant ribosomal/translation machinery and a simultaneous paucity of stress- or activation-induced transcripts. Cells expressing this program appear transcriptionally prepared for protein synthesis yet remain in a quiescent, non-stressed state typical of circulating naïve T or B cells. Evidence: • Robust enrichment of core ribosomal constituents (RPL39, RPL36, RPL38, RPL24, RPL22, RPL4, RPS21, RPS11, RPS5, FAU, UBA52) plus the mitochondrial ATP/ADP exchanger SLC25A6 ⇒ high basal translational capacity. • Naïve-lymphocyte transcription factors KLF2 (controls trafficking and quiescence of naïve T cells) and ID3 (restrains differentiation in naïve T and B cells) are positively loaded ⇒ consistent with an undifferentiated, resting lymphoid state. • Negative loading of ER- or stress-response genes (HERPUD1, PRDX4, DDIT4, TSC22D3) and of the granule protein SRGN ⇒ cells are not experiencing unfolded-protein/oxidative stress and are not cytotoxic or glucocorticoid-stimulated, fitting a quiescent naïve profile. Inconsistencies: • Elevated ribosomal gene expression is often linked to proliferation; true naïve lymphocytes are usually low-cycling, so the strength of the ribosomal signature could also reflect a generalized “housekeeping/translation” program rather than a state unique to naïve lymphocytes.

program_4.description: The gene set defines a mature, antigen-presenting B-cell program typical of naïve or early memory B cells that have up-regulated MHC class II molecules in response to activation. Evidence: • B-cell identity: MS4A1 (CD20), CD22, TCL1A, VPREB3 – canonical markers of mature/naïve and early memory B cells. • Antigen-presentation machinery: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQB1, HLA-DMB – high expression of multiple MHC class II genes characteristic of professional antigen-presenting B cells. • Activation/immune signalling: CD83 and LTB are induced after B-cell receptor or CD40 stimulation; IRF8 supports B-cell activation and class-switch potential. • Accessory immune genes: LAPTM5 and LY86 (MD-1) are broadly enriched in B lineage and reinforce an immune activation profile. Inconsistencies: • IRF8 and LY86 are also expressed in myeloid/dendritic cells, but their co-occurrence with multiple B-cell-specific genes makes a non-B lineage interpretation unlikely.

program_5.description: The gene set is most consistent with a chromatin-remodeling/epigenetic-control program that is typically up-regulated in stem-like or dedifferentiated cells (including many cancer stem-cell populations), where extensive transcriptional plasticity, post-transcriptional silencing and niche-interaction signals are required. Evidence: • Epigenetic/chromatin complexes – TADA3 (SAGA HAT), BRD7 (SWI/SNF-PBAF), BRMS1 (mSIN3/HDAC), and SUZ12 (core PRC2) are all canonical regulators of histone modifications and chromatin structure that are highly expressed in pluripotent and cancer stem cells. • Post-transcriptional gene silencing – AGO3 is a key Argonaute family member driving miRNA/siRNA activity, another hallmark of stem-like states. • Signalling modules sustaining survival within a niche – ILK (integrin-linked kinase) and GNB1 (heterotrimeric G-protein β-subunit) sustain adhesion and growth-factor signalling frequently exploited by stem and tumour-initiating cells. • Stress/angiogenic support – ANG (angiogenin) is up-regulated in hypoxic or nutrient-limited environments and in cancer stem cells to promote vascular support. • General organelle and metabolic support – SAMM50 (mitochondrial import), HPS1 (lysosome-related organelle biogenesis) and GBE1 (glycogen branching enzyme) reflect heightened organelle turnover and flexible energy use typical of undifferentiated cells. Inconsistencies: • GBE1 (glycogen metabolism) is most abundant in hepatocytes and skeletal muscle, and HPS1 is classically linked to melanocytes/platelets; their presence suggests a partial housekeeping component rather than a stem-specific signature. • GDE1 (neuronal phosphodiesterase) and RNF114 (immune-related E3 ligase) are not strongly linked to stemness, indicating some gene-set heterogeneity.

program_6.description: The program most closely reflects an activated B-cell transitioning toward a plasmablast / early plasma-cell state that is mounting a strong unfolded-protein-response (UPR) and up-regulating antigen-presentation machinery, while relatively down-modulating core ribosomal transcripts. Evidence: • Plasma-cell/UPR module – XBP1 (master regulator of plasma‐cell differentiation and ER expansion), MZB1, SSR4 and DERL3 (ER‐resident chaperones/ERAD components induced during high-rate immunoglobulin secretion). • B-cell identity – CD79A (B-cell receptor component) and CD74 (MHC-II invariant chain) remain expressed, fitting an activated B cell that has not fully extinguished BCR genes (typical of plasmablasts). • Antigen presentation – HLA-B, HLA-C and B2M encode MHC-I heavy and light chains, consistent with activated immune cells. • Oxidative burst/generic leukocyte activation – CYBA (p22phox) rises in activated B cells and other leukocytes during immune stimulation. • Reduced ribosomal signature – negative loading of RPL34 and RPS27 suggests a relative decrease in ribosomal biogenesis, often observed when cells re-allocate transcriptional resources toward secretory/ER programs. Inconsistencies: • CYBA is more classically associated with phagocytes but is not incompatible with activated B cells; its prominence is mildly atypical. • Down-regulation of ribosomal proteins can be variable among plasmablasts, so the strong negative association of only two ribosomal genes may reflect dataset-specific normalization rather than a universal feature.

program_7.description: The program reflects a generic “immediate-early” activation/stress response that is rapidly induced in many cell types after mitogenic, inflammatory, or oxidative stimulation rather than marking a specific lineage. It captures AP-1/NF-κB–driven transcription and multiple negative-feedback regulators characteristic of the first 30–90 min after stimulation. Evidence: • AP-1 transcription factors JUN, JUNB, FOS, FOSB and co-factor IER2 – canonical early genes induced by MAPK/ERK signaling following growth-factor or TCR/BCR engagement. • EGR1 – prototypic immediate-early zinc-finger TF up-regulated within minutes of diverse stimuli. • NFKBIA (IκBα) – primary NF-κB target that provides rapid negative feedback to inflammatory signaling. • PPP1R15A (GADD34), ZFP36 (tristetraprolin), DUSP2 – stress-responsive phosphatase/RNA-destabilizing genes that dampen MAPK and cytokine signaling. • BTG2 – early-response antiproliferative gene induced by p53 and MAPK pathways. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are hallmarks of immediate-early activation.

program_8.description: The program reflects a strong mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation (OXPHOS) module, typical of cells with elevated respiratory activity or of stressed/apoptotic cells that exhibit a high fraction of mitochondrial transcripts in single-cell RNA-seq data, rather than pointing to a specific lineage. Evidence: • MT-CO1, MT-CO2, MT-CO3 – cytochrome-c oxidase subunits (Complex IV), hallmarks of active electron transport. • MT-ND1, MT-ND2, MT-ND3, MT-ND4 – NADH dehydrogenase subunits (Complex I), up-regulated when cells rely on oxidative metabolism. • MT-CYB – core component of Complex III. • MT-ATP6 – ATP synthase subunit essential for ATP production. → Coordinated elevation of multiple mitochondrial-encoded components across Complexes I, III, IV and V is the classic transcriptional signature of an OXPHOS program; in single-cell datasets this is often enriched in metabolically active cells (e.g., muscle, neurons) or in low-quality/dying cells that have lost cytoplasmic RNA but retain mitochondrial RNA. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; no negatively loaded genes were provided to contradict an OXPHOS/stress signature.

program_9.description: The gene set is most consistent with a proliferative, growth-factor-responsive monocyte/macrophage state (e.g. cycling tissue or tumor-associated macrophages) characterized by iron handling and GAS6–AXL signaling, rather than a B-lineage or plasma-cell identity. Evidence: • Macrophage/monocyte identity and function – GAS6: canonical M2/tissue macrophage ligand that promotes efferocytosis and survival via AXL/TYRO3. – FTL: ferritin light chain, highly expressed in iron-recycling macrophages. – PIM2 and PTP4A3: kinases up-regulated in myeloid cells, supporting survival, migration, and inflammatory signaling. • Proliferative/activated state – CCND2 (Cyclin-D2) and CDKN1A (p21) together mark cells transitioning through or regulating the G1 phase, typical of cycling macrophages seen during tissue remodeling or in tumors. • Exclusion of plasma/B-cell identity – JCHAIN, a hallmark of IgA/IgM-secreting plasmablasts, is negatively loaded, arguing against a plasma-cell program. Inconsistencies: • JSRP1 is a skeletal-muscle excitation–contraction gene and is not typical of myeloid cells; its positive loading is atypical for the proposed macrophage state.

program_10.description: The program reflects a myeloid lineage cell—most consistent with inflammatory monocytes / tissue-resident macrophages (including microglia) engaged in TYROBP-dependent Fc-receptor signaling and acute innate-immune activation. Evidence: • TYROBP, FCER1G, AIF1 – canonical adapter/signaling triad in microglia and macrophages, driving Fc-receptor and ITAM signaling. • LYZ – pan-myeloid lysozyme, highly expressed in circulating and tissue monocytes/macrophages. • S100A9 – alarmin strongly induced in inflammatory monocytes and early neutrophil-like states. • CXCR4 – chemokine receptor that retains/traffics classical monocytes in marrow and inflamed tissues; also present in microglial precursors. • FTH1 – ferritin heavy chain; macrophages up-regulate iron-handling genes during immune activation. • PFN1 – actin-binding protein enriched in motile immune cells, supporting cytoskeletal remodeling during phagocytosis/migration. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes; PFN1 and FTH1 are broadly expressed but are compatible with the heightened metabolic and motility demands of activated myeloid cells.

program_11.description: The gene set represents a canonical heat-shock/stress response program, reflecting cells that are experiencing acute proteotoxic stress rather than marking a specific lineage; the coordinated induction of multiple cytosolic heat-shock proteins (HSP70, HSP90, HSP40, HSP27 families) is characteristic of cells mounting a protective response to misfolded proteins and elevated temperature. Evidence: • HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSPA6 – inducible members of the HSP70 family that are rapidly up-regulated after heat or other proteotoxic stress to refold denatured proteins. • HSP90AA1 – inducible cytosolic HSP90 isoform that stabilizes a wide array of client proteins under stress. • DNAJB1 – HSP40 co-chaperone that stimulates HSP70 ATPase activity during protein folding, typically co-induced with HSP70s in heat-shock conditions. • HSPB1 (HSP27) – small heat-shock protein acting as a molecular chaperone and anti-apoptotic factor during stress. • HSPE1 – mitochondrial co-chaperonin (HSP10) partnering with HSPD1 (GroEL/HSP60) and often induced in generalized stress programs. • HSPH1 (HSP105) – large HSP that cooperates with HSP70 to prevent protein aggregation during severe heat stress. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are classical components of the inducible heat-shock/proteotoxic stress response.

program_12.description: This gene set represents a robust endoplasmic-reticulum (ER) stress / unfolded-protein-response (UPR) program that is typically activated in highly secretory cells (e.g., plasma cells, pancreatic β-cells, goblet/club cells) or in any cell experiencing acute protein-folding load. Evidence: • HSP90B1 (GRP94), FKBP11, FKBP2 – canonical ER-resident chaperones or peptidyl-prolyl isomerases induced by UPR to assist protein folding. • SEC11C – catalytic subunit of the signal-peptidase complex; up-regulated when co-translational translocation through the ER is elevated. • MANF – ER-localized/secreted protein transcriptionally induced by ATF6/XBP1 during ER stress. • SDF2L1 – ER co-chaperone that binds BiP and is a well-validated UPR target gene. • CRELD2 – ER/secreted protein transcriptionally up-regulated by PERK–ATF4 and ATF6 arms of the UPR; marker of ER stress in secretory lineages. Inconsistencies: No obvious discordant genes; all listed genes are UPR/ER-stress related and mutually reinforce the interpretation.

program_13.description: The gene set most parsimoniously reflects a generic acute-stress/inflammatory activation state that can be adopted by many cell types: immediate-early MAPK feedback (DUSP1), proteostasis/ubiquitin turnover (UBC), membrane–autophagy remodeling (TMEM59) and secretion of the matrix modulator TIMP1 are up-regulated, while multiple ribosomal protein transcripts are concurrently down-regulated, consistent with the transient translational dampening that accompanies cellular stress responses. Evidence: • Stress / immediate-early genes increased – DUSP1 (rapid MAPK-induced phosphatase), UBC (poly-ubiquitin locus induced by many stresses). • Proteostasis & membrane remodeling – TMEM59 (autophagy and Golgi stress), UBC (protein quality control). • Injury / ECM response – TIMP1 is secreted after cytokine or damage signals to inhibit MMPs. • Coordinated decrease in translation machinery – negative loading of ribosomal genes RPL28, RPL27, RPS24 fits the well-described stress-associated global reduction in ribosome gene expression. Inconsistencies: • The small gene list lacks classic interferon (e.g., ISG15) or heat-shock (HSPs) markers, so the precise upstream stress stimulus cannot be pinpointed.

program_14.description: The gene set reflects a generic “proteostasis / biosynthetic up-shift” program typical of cells that have recently increased their metabolic and proliferative activity (e.g., cycling or freshly activated cells of many lineages rather than a lineage-restricted signature). Evidence: • Proteasome activity – PSMD13 encodes a 26S proteasome regulatory subunit, a hallmark of enhanced protein turnover. • RNA processing / ribosome biogenesis – MAGOH (exon-junction complex component) and ZNF622 (large-ribosomal-subunit assembly factor) are up-regulated when cells boost translation capacity. • Translational growth control – DRG1 is a GTP-binding protein induced during growth and required for efficient translation. • Metabolic support for protein synthesis – GMDS (GDP-mannose 4,6-dehydratase) supplies fucose for glycoprotein production; DDHD1 contributes phospholipid remodeling needed for expanding membranes. • Stress-/survival-linked nuclear factor – THYN1 is up-regulated in rapidly dividing thymocytes and other cells experiencing DNA replication stress, fitting a state of active turnover. Inconsistencies: • No classic cell-cycle markers (e.g., MKI67, TOP2A) are present, so the program may mark heightened biosynthesis rather than full cell-cycle entry. • THYN1 shows some lymphoid bias, whereas the remaining genes are broadly expressed housekeeping factors, indicating the program is not strictly lymphocyte-specific.

program_15.description: The gene set represents a mucin-secreting gastrointestinal epithelial program characteristic of mature intestinal goblet (and related gastric foveolar) cells, reflecting high production of secreted trefoil factors, mucin-folding chaperones and antimicrobial peptides. Evidence: • AGR2, SPINK4 – endoplasmic-reticulum chaperone and serine-protease inhibitor specifically enriched in mucin-producing goblet cells, supporting a secretory goblet phenotype. • TFF3, REG4 – canonical secreted products of intestinal goblet cells that promote mucosal repair; REG4 is a hallmark of colonic/ileal goblet subsets. • TFF1 – trefoil factor produced by gastric foveolar (mucous) cells, compatible with a broader mucin-secreting gastrointestinal lineage. • S100P, LCN2 – secreted calcium-binding protein and antimicrobial lipocalin induced in inflamed or metaplastic gastrointestinal epithelium, frequently co-expressed with goblet-cell programs. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes fit a secretory goblet/foveolar epithelial program.

program_16.description: The gene constellation represents a robust type I interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) program, characteristic of cells mounting an antiviral innate-immune response rather than a lineage-specific signature; it can be induced in diverse immune and non-immune cell types upon exposure to IFN-α/β or viral RNA. Evidence: • ISG15, IFI6, IFI35, IFIT1, MX1, USP18 – canonical ISGs transcriptionally up-regulated by IFN-α/β through the JAK-STAT/ISGF3 pathway; encode antiviral effectors (MX1, IFIT1), ubiquitin-like modifier (ISG15), and negative feedback regulator (USP18). • TNFSF10 (TRAIL) – also induced by type I IFN and promotes apoptosis of infected or transformed cells, fitting an antiviral, pro-apoptotic state. Inconsistencies: • None noted; all positively loaded genes coherently fit a type I interferon response program, and no negatively loaded genes were provided.

program_17.description: The gene composition most strongly supports a generic “house-keeping / biosynthetic” program that accompanies metabolically active cells rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The module is enriched for core spliceosomal (PPIH), transcriptional co-activator (TADA3, NFYC, PELP1), mTORC1-regulatory (NPRL3) and membrane-trafficking (SEC22C, GOPC) factors—genes that are broadly required for RNA processing, transcriptional control, and secretory‐pathway function in many proliferative or metabolically engaged cells. Evidence: • RNA processing / spliceosome: PPIH is a core component of the U4/U6-U5 tri-snRNP; TADA3 and NFYC participate in SAGA and NF-Y transcription complexes, respectively, pointing to generalized transcriptional activity. • Ribosome biogenesis & nuclear function: PELP1 associates with the nucleolus and ribosomal large-subunit maturation; NPRL3 (GATOR1) links amino-acid sensing to mTORC1 inhibition, a canonical regulator of global translation. • Secretory and vesicle trafficking: SEC22C (SNARE) and GOPC (Golgi-associated PDZ protein) highlight Golgi/ER–to-plasma-membrane transport typical of actively secreting cells. Inconsistencies: • No cell-type-specific markers appear, so the program lacks discriminatory genes that would tie it to a particular lineage; all listed genes fit a ubiquitous biosynthetic role, leaving no clear contradictions.

program_18.description: The program most closely reflects an NF-κB– and RUNX3-driven activation state of peripheral T lymphocytes (effector/memory CD4⁺ or CD8⁺ T cells) characterized by enhanced T-cell-receptor (TCR) signaling, inflammatory responsiveness to prostaglandin E₂, and readiness for proliferation and migration. Evidence: • GRAP2 (GADS) – TCR adaptor essential for LAT/SLP-76 signalosome formation during T-cell activation. • REL (c-Rel) – NF-κB family member induced after TCR engagement; drives IL-2 and other activation genes in both CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T cells. • RUNX3 – Transcription factor required for cytotoxic CD8⁺ lineage commitment and Th1-skewing; cooperates with NF-κB during effector differentiation. • PTGER4 – Prostaglandin E₂ receptor up-regulated on activated T cells, modulating cytokine production and survival in effector/memory subsets. • DEK – Chromatin factor elevated in proliferating immune cells, supporting rapid division following antigen encounter. • ARL4C – Small G-protein induced by TCR signaling that promotes actin remodeling and migration of activated T cells. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes directly conflicts with a T-cell activation program; some (DEK, PTGER4) are more broadly expressed but are documented to rise in activated lymphocytes, so they are not clearly discordant.

program_19.description: This gene set most consistently reflects a generic “house-keeping / transcription–RNA-processing” program seen in metabolically active, often proliferating, cells rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The enrichment of core spliceosome, transcription-elongation, and protein-quality-control factors suggests a state of globally elevated gene expression and mRNA handling. Evidence: • mRNA splicing / processing – SF3B2 (spliceosome 3B complex) is a core component of the spliceosome, typically up-regulated when overall pre-mRNA processing demand is high. • Transcription elongation – SUPT5H (SPT5) is a conserved elongation factor that rises with heightened transcriptional activity. • Proteostasis / stress-granule activity – USP10 (de-ubiquitinase localizing to stress granules) and SIGMAR1 (ER chaperone modulating unfolded-protein and Ca²⁺ stress responses) point to increased protein-quality-control capacity accompanying heavy transcription/translation. • Cell-division scaffold – NDEL1 supports centrosome and microtubule dynamics during mitosis, fitting a proliferative or highly active state. • Ubiquitin-ligase adaptor – KLHDC3 (Cullin-RING substrate receptor) is linked to translational regulation and proteostasis, again consistent with intensified macromolecular turnover. Inconsistencies: No genes in the list sharply contradict this general, non-lineage-specific high transcription / processing program.

program_20.description: The constellation of positively loaded genes best fits an NF-κB–centred activation program that emerges in recently antigen-stimulated lymphocytes (T or B cells), coupling CARD11–BCL10–MALT1 signalling to BRD4-driven transcriptional elongation and to metabolic/autophagic remodelling of mitochondria and lipids. Evidence: • MALT1 – protease/scaffold of the CBM complex that is specifically required for T- and B-cell-receptor–induced NF-κB activation. • BRD4 – binds RelA to maintain NF-κB target-gene transcription in activated lymphocytes and is highly expressed after receptor stimulation. • FBXW5 & OSBPL8 – regulators of ULK1/mTOR and cholesterol trafficking, respectively, which are up-regulated during the metabolic switch that follows lymphocyte activation. • SAMM50 – outer-mitochondrial-membrane component essential for mitophagy/mitochondrial remodelling accompanying immune-cell activation. • TNRC6A – GW182 family member that expands in P-bodies during T-cell activation, providing miRNA-mediated post-transcriptional control of the NF-κB transcriptome. Inconsistencies: • Absence of canonical lymphocyte markers (e.g., CD3D, CD79A) indicates the program captures a signalling/metabolic module rather than full lineage identity. • All listed genes are ubiquitously expressed; therefore similar expression could, in principle, reflect NF-κB and autophagy regulation in other activated cell types.

program_21.description: The gene set defines a program characteristic of differentiated intestinal epithelial absorptive cells (colonocytes/small-intestinal enterocytes) that regulate lipid handling and fluid–electrolyte balance in the gut lumen. Evidence: • GUCA2A and GUCA2B encode the paracrine hormones guanylin and uroguanylin, classical secretory products of mature enterocytes/colonocytes that stimulate CFTR-dependent chloride and water secretion. • FABP1 (liver-type fatty-acid-binding protein) is highly expressed in small-intestinal and colonic enterocytes where it traffics dietary long-chain fatty acids. • PHGR1 is an intestine-restricted marker up-regulated during epithelial differentiation and enriched in colonic absorptive cells. • FXYD3 (Mat-8) modulates Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase activity in gastrointestinal epithelia and is abundant in mature intestinal epithelium. Inconsistencies: • FABP1 is also expressed in hepatocytes, but the concurrent presence of multiple gut-specific genes (GUCA2A/B, PHGR1, FXYD3) points to an intestinal rather than hepatic program.

program_22.description: The gene set points to a neuro-endocrine “regulated secretion” program, characteristic of neurons and other dense-core vesicle–bearing secretory cells (e.g., pancreatic islet and other neuroendocrine lineages) that are primed for Ca²⁺-dependent vesicle docking and release. Evidence: • CADPS2 – key Ca²⁺-dependent activator of dense-core vesicle exocytosis in neurons and endocrine β-cells. • DUSP26 – phosphatase enriched in neuroendocrine tissues and developing neurons, modulates MAPK signaling linked to neurotransmitter/hormone release. • SLC22A17 – lipocalin-2/iron receptor highly expressed in microglia, neurons and endocrine cells, trafficked through secretory vesicles. • ST3GAL6 – Golgi sialyl-transferase that glycosylates secretory-pathway proteins, up-regulated in cells with heavy vesicle traffic (neurons, plasma cells, endocrine cells). • RRAGD – Rag GTPase activating mTORC1, supporting the high translational load of secretory programs. Inconsistencies: • Absence of classical neuroendocrine markers (e.g. SNAP25, CHGA, PCSK1) limits precise placement in a specific secretory lineage. • ST3GAL6 is also abundant in immune/plasma cells, raising the possibility of mixed or context-specific expression.

program_23.description: The program most closely reflects a generic “cellular stress-adaptation” state—cells boosting protein and metal homeostasis, lipid/cholesterol biosynthesis and autophagy, features typically seen during nutrient deprivation, ER/oxidative stress or rapid metabolic remodeling, rather than marking a specific lineage. Evidence: • SCOC — positive: promotes ULK1-dependent starvation-induced autophagy, a hallmark of nutrient or metabolic stress. • PSMC4 — positive: 26S proteasome ATPase; proteasome up-regulation is a common response to proteotoxic/oxidative stress. • TM7SF2 — positive: ER enzyme for cholesterol biosynthesis; SREBP-driven lipid synthesis is activated during ER stress or membrane remodeling. • SLC30A1 — positive: ZnT1 zinc exporter induced by metal/oxidative stress via MTF1, contributing to redox homeostasis. • Concerted up-regulation of autophagy (SCOC), proteasome (PSMC4), metal efflux (SLC30A1) and lipid synthesis (TM7SF2) collectively supports a coordinated stress-adaptation program. Inconsistencies: • PSMG4 — negative: a proteasome-assembly chaperone; its down-regulation while a core proteasome subunit (PSMC4) is up is internally discordant, possibly reflecting feedback once mature proteasomes are abundant.

program_0.description: The gene set reflects a generic “high-translation” program—strong induction of cytosolic ribosomal proteins and translational machinery typical of cells that are actively growing, cycling, or recently activated, accompanied by repression of the mature intestinal epithelial marker CEACAM7, pointing to an undifferentiated/proliferative rather than a terminally differentiated epithelial state. Evidence: • Bulk of positively loaded genes (RPL3/5/7/10/13/18A/26/32, RPS2/5/6/14/19/23, RPLP0/1/2, RPS27A, EEF1A1, RACK1) encode 40S/60S ribosomal proteins or translation elongation factors—canonical hallmarks of high protein-synthesis and ribosome-biogenesis programs observed in cycling, activated, or stress-responsive cells. • Negative loading of CEACAM7, a surface glycoprotein enriched in differentiated colon and rectal epithelial cells, is consistent with loss of mature epithelial identity during proliferation or early activation. Inconsistencies: • None of the positively loaded genes are lineage-restricted; the program therefore indicates a cell state (elevated translation) rather than a specific cell type, and must be interpreted in the context of other programs to pinpoint lineage.

program_1.description: The program strongly matches the transcriptional signature of the specialized BEST4⁺/OTOP2⁺ “ionocyte–like” absorptive epithelial cells that reside in human colon and distal small-intestinal crypts, characterized by pH sensing, guanylin/uroguanylin secretion and fructose absorption. Evidence: • Ion-channel & pH-regulation genes typical of BEST4⁺/OTOP2⁺ cells – BEST4, OTOP2, OTOP3, CA4, CA7. • Guanylin hormones that define this subset – GUCA2A (guanylin) and GUCA2B (uroguanylin). • Additional colon enterocyte/ionocyte markers – DMBT1, SLC2A5 (GLUT5), CEACAM3, HEPACAM2, ADCY5, PCSK1N. • Transcription factors linked to this lineage – PROX1 and SPIB (reported in colonic BEST4⁺ cells), HES4 (Notch target in absorptive lineage). • Secretory/defence proteins enriched in colonic surface epithelium – WFDC2, CTSE. • Carbon/metal homeostasis genes (MT1H) and structural/trafficking components (HID1, CCNYL1, FKBP1A) commonly co-expressed in this epithelial subset. Inconsistencies: • MSLN (mesothelin) and MYOM1 (myomesin-1) are more typical of mesothelial or muscle tissues, respectively, and are infrequently reported in intestinal ionocytes. • METTL21A and NEURL1 are ubiquitous/moderately expressed genes without specific links to BEST4⁺ cells, suggesting some nonspecific loading.

program_2.description: The gene set represents a canonical intestinal goblet-cell transcriptional program—i.e., differentiated secretory epithelial cells specialized for mucin production in the small intestine/colon. Evidence: • Core goblet cell mucins/glycoproteins: MUC2, FCGBP, ZG16, CLCA1, ITLN1, SPINK4, REG4, LRRC26—classically enriched in colonic goblet cells and responsible for forming/expanding the mucus layer. • Trefoil factors that accompany mucins: TFF3 and TFF1 are secreted peptides that stabilize mucus and promote epithelial restitution. • Secretory-lineage transcription factors: ATOH1 (master regulator of intestinal secretory fate) and SPDEF (drives goblet differentiation). • Additional goblet/secretory markers: REP15 (Rab effector in mucin granule trafficking), BEST2 (anion channel enriched in colonic goblet cells), TBX10 (reported in secretory intestinal lineages), and CDC42EP3 (actin remodeling during vesicle exocytosis). • Protective/antimicrobial or protease-related secretions typical of goblet cells: KLK1, SERPINA1, TPSG1 contribute to the antimicrobial/protease-inhibitory milieu found in mucus. Inconsistencies: • MB (myoglobin) – canonical muscle protein, rarely detected in epithelium. • DPYSL2, NPDC1 – neuronal/cytoskeletal regulators not usually prominent in gut epithelium. • TPSG1 – mast-cell tryptase, more typical of immune cells. These minority genes may reflect low-level background expression or ambient RNA rather than the core program.

program_3.description: The gene set represents a canonical type I/III interferon-stimulated antiviral response program, marking cells that have recently sensed viral nucleic acids or been exposed to interferon, irrespective of their lineage. Evidence: • Antiviral effector GTPases MX1, MX2 and dsRNA-binding enzyme OAS2 are classical ISGs induced by IFN-α/β. • IFIT family members (IFIT1, IFIT3) and IFI6/IFI44/IFI44L restrict viral translation or replication downstream of STAT1/STAT2 signaling. • Ubiquitin-like modifier ISG15, E3 ligases HERC6 and TRIM22, and tetherin BST2 mediate ISGylation or block virion release—hallmarks of interferon activation. • RSAD2 (viperin), XAF1, IFI16 and IFITM3 are well-validated interferon targets that inhibit multiple RNA and DNA viruses. • Absence of lineage-specific markers and the concerted up-regulation of >10 prototypical ISGs together point to a generalized interferon response state rather than a particular differentiated cell type. Inconsistencies: None noted—the entire positively loaded set is uniformly composed of interferon-stimulated genes, and no negatively loaded genes were provided.

program_4.description: The gene set points to intestinal absorptive epithelial cells (enterocytes) that are in a strongly inflamed, antimicrobial-defence state such as that seen in inflammatory bowel disease or pathogen challenge. Evidence: • Epithelial lineage / enterocyte identity – ALDOB (glycolytic enzyme highly enriched in small-intestinal and colonic enterocytes) and the apical amino-acid transporter SLC6A14. • Reactive oxygen / nitrogen defence – DUOX2 together with its maturation factor DUOXA2 generates H₂O₂ at the mucosal surface, while NOS2 supplies antimicrobial NO; both are classic IFN-γ/TNF-α–inducible genes in gut epithelium. • Antimicrobial and neutrophil-recruiting factors – LCN2 (lipocalin-2), PI3/elafin, CXCL1 and CXCL3 are secreted proteins that limit bacterial growth and attract neutrophils, typical of inflamed intestinal epithelium. • Stress-response / inflammatory signalling – ANXA1 (glucocorticoid-inducible), PDZK1IP1 (MAP17) and the ER oxidoreductase ERO1A rise in epithelial cells exposed to cytokines or hypoxia, reinforcing an injury-response profile. Inconsistencies: No prominent genes conflict with an inflamed intestinal epithelial program; all listed genes are compatible with this cell type and state.

program_5.description: The gene set represents a type I interferon–induced antiviral program acting in mucosal/secretory epithelial cells (e.g., airway or gastrointestinal epithelium). Evidence: • Antiviral interferon-stimulated genes: CMPK2, OAS3, IFIT2, USP18, HERC5, DHX58, SLFN5 and LY6E are canonical ISGs induced by type I IFNs and mediate viral RNA sensing, ISGylation, translation blockade or negative feedback of the pathway. • Epithelial lineage/context markers: MUC1 (membrane-bound mucin of respiratory and GI epithelium) and TFF1 (trefoil factor secreted by mucosal goblet and gastric epithelial cells) indicate the responding cells are differentiated secretory epithelium rather than immune cells. Inconsistencies: • No strongly conflicting genes are present; TFF1 and MUC1 are not themselves ISGs but are consistent with the epithelial identity of the interferon-responsive cells.

program_6.description: The program reflects a generic “high-mitochondrial/oxidative-phosphorylation” state rather than a lineage-specific identity, marking cells that are either highly metabolically active or experiencing mitochondrial stress or early apoptotic priming. Evidence: • MT-ND1, MT-ND2, MT-ND3, MT-ND4, MT-ND5 – core subunits of Complex I; their concerted up-regulation is a hallmark of increased electron-transport activity. • MT-CYB – Complex III subunit, rises together with Complex I genes during enhanced OXPHOS. • MT-CO1, MT-CO2, MT-CO3 – Complex IV subunits; elevation is typical when cells boost respiratory capacity. • MT-ATP6 – Complex V subunit; increased expression supports higher ATP synthesis. Collectively, the coordinated induction of all mitochondrially encoded ETC complexes is a classic single-cell RNA-seq signature of OXPHOS-high or mitochondrially stressed cells seen across diverse cell types (e.g., activated memory T cells, oxidative muscle fibers, or cells entering apoptosis). Inconsistencies: None – the gene set is uniformly composed of mitochondrial-encoded ETC components, fully consistent with an OXPHOS-enriched state.

program_7.description: This program represents an MHC-class-II antigen-presentation module typical of professional antigen-presenting cells—activated dendritic cells, macrophages, or B cells—engaged in immune stimulation. Evidence: • Core MHC-II transcripts (HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DRB5, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DQB1, HLA-DMA, HLA-DMB) – hallmark of professional antigen-presenting cells. • CD74 (invariant chain) – chaperone dedicated to MHC-II assembly and peptide loading, up-regulated in activated APCs. • LCN2 – acute-phase, pro-inflammatory secreted protein induced in macrophages/dendritic cells during activation, supporting an “activated” rather than resting APC state. Inconsistencies: • LCN2 is more classically linked to neutrophils; its presence is less typical for B cells and may indicate a macrophage/dendritic bias or mixed inflammatory signal.

program_8.description: The gene set represents a SREBP-driven cholesterol / mevalonate-biosynthetic programme, characteristic of metabolically active or proliferating cells (e.g. hepatocytes, cycling epithelial or tumor cells) that are synthesizing new membranes and sterols. Evidence: • HMGCS1, IDI1, FDPS – core enzymes of the mevalonate arm that generates isoprenoid precursors for cholesterol and protein prenylation. • SQLE, MSMO1, CYP51A1 – successive steps converting squalene to lanosterol and downstream sterol intermediates. • INSIG1 – sterol-sensor that couples ER cholesterol levels to SREBP activation; its up-regulation signals active feedback control of cholesterol synthesis. • All listed genes are canonical transcriptional targets of SREBF2, whose induction marks a high cholesterol-biosynthetic state needed during rapid membrane expansion or lipogenic differentiation. Inconsistencies: None – every positively loaded gene maps directly to the cholesterol/mevalonate pathway, reinforcing a coherent biosynthetic programme.

program_9.description: The gene set depicts a mature, absorptive intestinal (colon/small-intestinal) enterocyte program characterized by high oxidative phosphorylation and lipid-handling capacity, with minimal inflammatory signaling. Evidence: • Enterocyte/intestinal identity – LGALS4, FABP1 and CA1 are canonical markers of differentiated colon and small-intestinal epithelial cells. • Metabolic maturation – COX7C, COX4I1 and CHCHD10 encode mitochondrial respiratory chain components, consistent with the elevated oxidative metabolism of fully differentiated villus/crypt-top enterocytes. • Low inflammatory tone – the chemokine CCL20 is negatively loaded, fitting with the quiescent, non-inflamed state of healthy differentiated epithelium. Inconsistencies: • FABP1 is also abundant in hepatocytes, and CA1 in erythrocytes, but both are well-documented enterocyte genes; no other major contradictions are present.

program_10.description: The gene set represents a metallothionein-high stress‐response program, marking cells (of any lineage) that are undergoing metal ion detoxification and protection against oxidative or inflammatory stress rather than defining a specific lineage identity. Evidence: • MT2A, MT1A, MT1E, MT1F, MT1G, MT1M, MT1X – classic metallothionein family genes whose coordinated up-regulation is a well-established signature of zinc/copper sequestration, heavy-metal detoxification, and reactive-oxygen–induced stress across many cell types (e.g., hepatocytes, macrophages, epithelial and tumor cells). Inconsistencies: • None detected; all listed genes coherently fit the metallothionein stress-response program.

program_11.description: The gene set is most consistent with differentiated intestinal (largely colonic) absorptive epithelial cells that have activated an interferon- and inflammation-driven response program, a state commonly seen in inflamed gut mucosa. Evidence: • Epithelial/colonocyte identity – AQP8 (water channel highly enriched in mature colon enterocytes), HPGD (15-PGDH abundantly expressed in colonic epithelium for prostaglandin catabolism). • Interferon/inflammatory activation – IFI27 and PLAC8 are classic type-I interferon-stimulated genes; IL32 is an inducible pro-inflammatory cytokine produced by epithelial cells during mucosal inflammation. • Differentiated, non-proliferative state – Negative loading of TMSB10, a small actin-binding protein typically high in proliferating cells, aligns with terminally differentiated surface epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • IL32 is also produced by immune cells, and PLAC8 can be expressed in macrophages; their presence could, in other contexts, suggest immune rather than epithelial cells, but the simultaneous enrichment of AQP8 and HPGD (rare in leukocytes) favors an epithelial origin.

program_12.description: The gene set most closely matches a mucosal epithelial program characteristic of differentiated secretory/absorptive cells of the lower gastrointestinal tract (colon-small-intestine epithelium). Evidence: • MUC13 – membrane-bound mucin highly enriched in intestinal and colonic surface epithelium. • CLCA4 – chloride channel accessory protein marking colonic and small-intestinal epithelial (goblet/enterocyte) cells. • EMP1 and TM4SF1 – epithelial membrane proteins broadly expressed in intestinal epithelium and up-regulated during epithelial maturation and wound repair. • GPRC5A – retinoic-acid–inducible GPCR with strong expression in mucosal epithelia, including colon and other secretory linings, supporting an epithelial identity. Inconsistencies: • ZMYND15 is largely testis-specific; its presence may reflect low-level noise or a rare contaminating transcript. • TM4SF1 is also found in endothelial cells, though its co-expression with multiple mucosal epithelial markers argues the program is epithelial rather than vascular. • GPRC5A is abundant in airway epithelium as well, so the program could, in principle, also arise in other mucosal epithelia.

program_13.description: The program points to intestinal crypt stem / early regenerative epithelial cells that up-regulate antimicrobial and injury-response secreted factors during mucosal repair. Evidence: • OLFM4 – canonical marker of LGR5+ intestinal stem and transit-amplifying cells. • REG1A & REG1B – C-type lectins strongly induced in injured or regenerating gut epithelium and abundant in “REG-high” regenerative cell clusters seen by scRNA-seq in inflammatory bowel disease. • PLA2G2A – Paneth-cell–derived secreted phospholipase with antibacterial activity, typically co-expressed with REG genes in crypt-associated antimicrobial programs. • SPINK1 – antiprotease up-regulated in stressed/regenerating gastrointestinal epithelium, providing protection from luminal proteases during repair. • Co-occurrence of the above antimicrobial/secretory factors together with the stem marker OLFM4, and absence of mature enterocyte or goblet markers, matches published signatures of “regenerative/secretory progenitors” that arise in crypts after injury. Inconsistencies: • BACE2 is better known in pancreatic β-cells and neural tissue; while occasionally detected in gut epithelium, it is not a core crypt-stem or regenerative marker, so its presence is somewhat atypical for this program.

program_14.description: The program is most consistent with antibody-secreting plasmablasts/plasma cells that are experiencing an anti-inflammatory (glucocorticoid/IL-10–induced) response. Evidence: • JCHAIN – canonical and nearly exclusive marker of plasmablasts/plasma cells; required for polymeric IgA/IgM secretion. • RGS1 – highly expressed in germinal-center-derived B cells and plasmablasts, where it limits chemokine signaling during egress. • SRGN – secretory-granule proteoglycan enriched in many granule-containing immune cells and present in antibody-secreting plasma cells, consistent with high secretory activity. • TSC22D3 (GILZ) – glucocorticoid/IL-10–inducible anti-inflammatory gene frequently up-regulated in activated B-lineage cells, indicating an immunoregulatory milieu. • VIM – cytoskeletal protein up-regulated in motile, activated immune cells, including circulating plasmablasts. Inconsistencies: • SRGN is more classically associated with cytotoxic lymphocytes and mast cells; its presence suggests either shared granule biology or a minor contribution from other leukocytes. • VIM is a generic mesenchymal/activation marker and not specific to plasma cells. • TSC22D3 is broadly inducible across leukocytes, so its inclusion may reflect systemic glucocorticoid signaling rather than a plasma-cell–specific feature.

program_15.description: The program reflects a simple-epithelial, KRT8/KRT19-high state that is commonly seen in transitional or injury-induced progenitor-like epithelial cells (e.g., “KRT8⁺ transitional”/DATP cells described during lung, liver and kidney repair) and in many carcinoma cells that retain epithelial identity. Evidence: • KRT8 and KRT19 – hallmark intermediate-filament genes of simple (non-stratified) epithelia; strongly induced in injury-associated transitional epithelial cells and many epithelial tumours. • LGALS3 (Galectin-3) – enriched in regenerating or stressed epithelia and carcinoma cells; promotes cell–matrix interactions typical of repair states. • ANXA2 – calcium-dependent membrane/cytoskeletal protein up-regulated in wound-healing epithelium and in epithelial cancers undergoing partial EMT. • S100A6 – calcium-binding protein induced by cellular stress and proliferation in epithelial progenitors and tumour cells. Inconsistencies: • No strongly conflicting genes are present; all listed genes are compatible with a stress-responsive, progenitor-like epithelial program.

program_0.description: The gene set represents a generic, lineage-independent G2/M cell-cycle program characteristic of highly proliferating cells approaching or undergoing mitosis. Evidence: • Proliferation markers – MKI67, TOP2A, BIRC5 (Survivin), MYBL2 and PCLAF are classically up-regulated in dividing cells. • Cyclin–CDK machinery – CCNB1, CCNB2, CCNA2 together with CDK1 drive G2/M transition; CDKN3 and UBE2C regulate CDK activity and cyclin turnover. • Spindle assembly/kinetochore components – AURKB, KIF11, TPX2, NUSAP1, DLGAP5, CENPA/E/F/P/U/W/K, NUF2, ZWINT, BUB1, MAD2L1 ensure chromosome alignment and segregation. • DNA replication and repair genes expressed late in S phase and G2 – TYMS, RRM2, DHFR, BRCA1, CDC6, ATAD5, TK1, GTSE1 support DNA synthesis and checkpoint control. • Microtubule/cytokinesis factors – STMN1, ASPM, SHCBP1, ARHGAP11A facilitate spindle dynamics and cleavage-furrow formation. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies detected; all listed genes are commonly enriched in dividing cells during late S, G2, or M phase.

program_1.description: The gene set denotes an activated CCR6⁺ KLRB1⁺ IL7R-high effector-memory CD4⁺ T-cell state, typical of Th17/MAIT-like cells that have recently been stimulated and are producing chemokines and low-level cytotoxic molecules. Evidence: • Core T-cell identity: CD3D/E/G, CD2, CD7, BCL11B, LCK, FYN, PTPRC, LCP2 confirm a T-lymphocyte program. • Memory/long-lived phenotype: IL7R, ETS1, BTG1, SPOCK2, GIMAP4/7 support a resting–memory rather than naive state. • Th17/MAIT surface signature: co-expression of CCR6 and KLRB1 together with transcription factor MAF and cytokine IL32 is characteristic of human CCR6⁺ CD4⁺ memory subsets enriched for Th17 or MAIT-like cells. • Activation & immunoregulation: CTLA4, TNFAIP3, LTB, FYB1, EVL reflect recent T-cell receptor signalling. • Effector/chemokine output: CCL4, CCL5, ALOX5AP, GZMA, CST7 indicate acquisition of modest cytotoxic and chemo-attractant functions often seen in activated effector-memory CD4⁺ cells. Inconsistencies: • ADAM12 is more typical of stromal/mesenchymal cells and is unusual in T-cell programs, though low-level expression can arise from ambient RNA or rare doublets.

program_2.description: The program represents a generic “high ribosome/translation” state, characteristic of cells that are actively synthesising protein—such as proliferating or metabolically activated cells—rather than defining a particular lineage. Evidence: • Virtually every positively loaded gene (RPLP1, RPL13, RPS18, RPL10, RPL24, RPS27A, FAU, etc.) encodes a component of the 60 S (RPL*) or 40 S (RPS*) ribosomal subunit, a classic hallmark of increased ribosome biogenesis and elevated translational capacity. • Absence of lineage-restricted markers and the overwhelming enrichment for core ribosomal proteins support the interpretation that this program reflects a global biosynthetic state rather than a specific cell type. Inconsistencies: • None identifiable; all listed genes fit a ribosome/translation programme.

program_3.description: This program represents a generic “high-translation / ribosome-biogenesis” state, typical of actively cycling or recently activated cells that have down-regulated mature epithelial/stress signatures. Cells expressing this program show strong up-regulation of ribosomal protein genes and translational machinery (hallmarks of proliferation and biosynthetic demand) while simultaneously repressing keratins, trefoil factor, S100 family proteins and other markers of differentiated or stressed epithelial cells. Evidence: • High translation machinery (positively loaded): RPL5, RPL6, RPL3, RPL10A, RPL39, RPS2, RPS3A, RPS4X, RPS6, RPS7, RPS9, RPS13, EEF1A1 and TPT1 collectively mark ribosome assembly, elongation and global protein synthesis, a signature repeatedly linked to proliferating or growth-factor–stimulated cells. • Loss of epithelial / stress markers (negatively loaded): KRT8, KRT19 (intermediate filament proteins of differentiated epithelia), TFF3 (secretory/goblet cell factor), S100A6, S100A14 (calcium-binding epithelial stress proteins), TSPAN1 (surface protein enriched in mature epithelia) and HSPA1B (heat-shock chaperone) are reduced, indicating suppression of mature epithelial or stress-response programs as cells enter a proliferative, biosynthetic state. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes clearly contradict the high-translation, low-differentiation interpretation; however, S100A6 can sometimes rise in cycling cells, yet here it is negatively loaded, suggesting tissue-specific regulation rather than a strict inconsistency.

program_4.description: The program represents mature intestinal (particularly colonic) epithelial cells that are engaged in mucosal secretion and Ig-transport, i.e. a mixed enterocyte–goblet cell state with mild interferon-stimulated activation. Evidence: • Core intestinal epithelial markers – EPCAM, LGALS4, PHGR1, CEACAM5, FXYD3 identify differentiated colon epithelium. • Goblet/secretory products – FCGBP, FAM3D and PIGR (IgA transcytosis) signal a secretory component typical of goblet cells. • Barrier / mucosal immunity factors – PIGR, FCGBP, LGALS4 highlight functions in luminal antibody transport and mucus stabilization. • Interferon-responsive but epithelial-expressed genes – IFI27 and C15orf48 suggest the cells are experiencing low-grade antiviral or inflammatory signaling rather than belonging to immune lineages. Inconsistencies: • IFI27 and C15orf48 primarily denote interferon stimulation; their presence may reflect an activated epithelial state rather than a basal one.

program_5.description: The gene set represents a classic “immediate-early” activation / stress-response program, seen when virtually any cell type is acutely stimulated by growth factors, cytokines, mechanical stress, or heat shock; it reflects a transient, AP-1–driven state rather than a lineage-specific identity. Evidence: • AP-1 transcription factors JUN, JUNB, FOS, FOSB assemble rapidly after stimulation, defining canonical immediate-early responses. • Early response regulators EGR1, IER2 and phosphatase DUSP1 are prototypical serum-/stress-inducible genes that modulate MAPK signaling during acute activation. • Chaperone/stress proteins HSP90AA1 and HSPB1 rise within minutes of cellular stress, supporting protein folding during the response. • UBC (poly-ubiquitin precursor) is up-regulated to meet increased proteostasis demand under acute stress. Inconsistencies: No clear lineage-specific markers appear; all listed genes fit an immediate-early activation profile, so no major inconsistencies with the assigned program state are evident.

program_6.description: The program reflects a generic “metabolic/house-keeping” state seen in highly active, non-inflamed cells of many lineages—marked by elevated mitochondrial protein import and respiration, lipid/cholesterol metabolism, vesicle–lysosome trafficking, and RNA/protein quality control—while interferon/STAT signaling is concurrently suppressed. Evidence: • Mitochondrial activity – TOMM40 (protein import into mitochondria) and DLD (TCA cycle enzyme) point to increased mitochondrial respiration; ACAT2 supports mitochondrial/ER-linked cholesterol and acetyl-CoA metabolism. • Protein folding & quality control – FKBP4 (HSP90 cochaperone) and DCAF13 (CUL4 ubiquitin-ligase adaptor) indicate heightened proteostasis demands typical of metabolically active cells. • Endocytic/trafficking machinery – AP2M1 (clathrin adaptor) and BLOC1S2 (lysosome-related organelle biogenesis) denote robust vesicle trafficking and lysosomal turnover. • Gene expression machinery – BUD31 (spliceosome component) suggests increased RNA processing consistent with high biosynthetic output. • DNA repair – NTHL1 (base-excision repair) is up-regulated during high metabolic/cycling states to counteract oxidative DNA lesions. • Absence of inflammatory signaling – The sole negatively loaded gene, NMI, is an interferon/STAT co-activator; its repression supports a non-interferon, non-stress context. Inconsistencies: • The set lacks classic cell-cycle genes (e.g., MKI67, PCNA), so the program describes metabolic activation rather than overt proliferation. • BLOC1S2 can be enriched in pigment or platelet lineages, but other lineage-specific markers are missing, supporting a broadly shared metabolic rather than lineage-restricted program.

program_7.description: The program typifies antigen-presenting, inflammatory myeloid cells—most consistent with class II-high monocytes / macrophages that are primed for immune activation and antigen presentation. Evidence: • Strong MHC class II module (HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DPA1) → hallmark of professional antigen-presenting cells, especially activated monocytes/macrophages and dendritic cells. • Myeloid/monocyte enzymes and antimicrobial activity (LYZ) → characteristic of blood-borne and tissue macrophages. • Adapter molecule TYROBP (DAP12) and cytoplasmic protein AIF1 (IBA1) → enriched in activated macrophages and microglia, supporting an inflammatory macrophage identity. Inconsistencies: • No obvious inconsistencies; negatively loaded gene list is empty, and absence of classical dendritic-cell-specific transcripts (e.g., CD1C, ITGAX) favors macrophages over dendritic cells.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with a T-cell receptor (TCR) signalling / co-stimulation program found in conventional T lymphocytes that have recently been activated (ICOS⁺), but have not yet up-regulated late effector modules (e.g. cytotoxic or follicular-helper transcripts). Evidence: • Core T-cell identity: CD247 (TCR-ζ chain) and PRKCH (PKC-η, a TCR-proximal kinase) mark cells engaged in TCR signalling. • Early/acute co-stimulation: ICOS is induced within hours of activation on conventional CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T cells; CD96 is likewise up-regulated on activated cytotoxic and memory T cells. • Signal-tuning regulators typical of recently stimulated yet non-effector T cells: PIK3IP1 and PHLDA1 dampen PI3K/AKT activity and promote survival during early activation; RBMS1 and SCML4 are broadly expressed RNA-binding/epigenetic factors enriched in proliferating lymphocytes. Inconsistencies: • Canonical markers of specific effector subsets (e.g. GZMB/PRF1 for cytotoxic T cells, CXCR5/BCL6 for T-follicular helper cells, FOXP3/IL2RA for regulatory T cells) are absent, so the program does not pinpoint a single differentiated T-cell lineage but rather a general early-activation state.
