program_9.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic endoplasmic-reticulum stress / unfolded-protein-response (UPR) and oxidative-stress program, a state often observed in activated or highly secretory cells (e.g., macrophages, plasma cells, stressed epithelia) rather than defining a unique lineage. Evidence: • ER stress & ER-associated degradation – SSR4 (translocon subunit), DERL3 and HERPUD1 (ERAD adaptors), PRDX4 (ER-localized peroxide reductase) are canonical UPR targets. • Oxidative/ROS balance – PRDX4 (antioxidant), CYBA (p22phox component of NADPH oxidase), FTL (ferritin light chain, iron sequestration under oxidative load) point to redox stress. • Vesicle/lysosome trafficking associated with secretory or phagocytic activity – CD63 (lysosomal/exosomal tetraspanin). • Suppressed mitochondrial respiration – negative loading of MT-CO3 suggests relative down-regulation of oxidative phosphorylation, typical of cells shifting metabolism under ER/oxidative stress. Inconsistencies: • CYBA and CD63 are enriched in phagocytes but are not exclusive to them; other macrophage markers (e.g., LYZ, CD68) are missing, so the program cannot be assigned unequivocally to a macrophage lineage.

program_10.description: The program predominantly reflects a high‐mitochondrial‐RNA signature that is classically seen in single-cell data from stressed or dying cells undergoing loss of cytoplasmic RNA, rather than a specific differentiated cell type; it indicates a cell state characterized by disproportionate expression of mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation transcripts. Evidence: • Strong enrichment of mitochondrial genome–encoded OXPHOS genes (MT-CO1/2/3, MT-ND1/2/4, MT-CYB, MT-ATP6) is a well-established marker of cells with compromised integrity or apoptosis, where mitochondrial mRNAs remain while nuclear transcripts are depleted. • Absence of nuclear gene sets that normally cooperate with OXPHOS (e.g., NDUF family, COX4I1, ATP5F1) argues against a coordinated metabolic up-shift and supports a stress-related selective retention of mitochondrial transcripts. • Similar mitochondrial-heavy signatures are routinely filtered out during single-cell QC because they correlate with elevated ambient RNA, low total UMI counts, and apoptotic markers such as high annexin V staining in parallel assays. Inconsistencies: No major inconsistencies; the program is limited to mitochondrial transcripts with no conflicting lineage-specific or proliferative genes.

program_11.description: The gene set reflects a cytotoxic, terminally differentiated/effector-memory CD8⁺ T-cell state that co-expresses natural-killer–like molecules and granule components used for target-cell killing. Evidence: • Cytotoxic granule proteins – NKG7 and GZMK are hallmarks of cytotoxic lymphocytes and are highly expressed in effector and effector-memory CD8⁺ T cells. • T-cell identity – CD8B confirms a CD8⁺ T-cell lineage rather than a pure NK cell. • NK-associated receptor – KLRD1 (CD94) is commonly up-regulated in late-stage effector CD8⁺ T cells that acquire NK-like features. • Terminal effector transcription factor – ZEB2 drives differentiation of mature cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells and NK cells. • Activation/effector marker – ANXA1 is induced in activated T cells and supports the identification of an active effector state. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes were provided, and the positive gene list is internally consistent with a cytotoxic CD8⁺ effector T-cell program.

program_12.description: The gene pattern most closely matches a cytoskeleton- and adhesion-oriented program characteristic of highly motile, extravasation-competent leukocytes—particularly activated neutrophils/monocytes engaged in chemotaxis and integrin-mediated adhesion. Evidence: • LCP1 (L-plastin) – leukocyte-restricted actin-bundling protein up-regulated during integrin activation and transmigration. • RIPOR2 (FAM65B) – RhoA-interacting regulator that restrains/coordinates actin remodeling in migrating neutrophils and T cells; enriched in granulocytes. • COTL1 – coactosin-like actin-binding protein that cooperates with 5-lipoxygenase in neutrophil chemotactic lipid synthesis. • RASGRP2 (CalDAG-GEFI) – calcium/DAG-dependent GEF essential for rapid inside-out activation of β2-integrins in neutrophils and monocytes, enabling firm adhesion to endothelium. • FLNA – actin cross-linker that anchors activated integrins to the cytoskeleton, facilitating leukocyte spreading. • ARL4C – small GTPase that promotes actin-rich membrane protrusions in motile immune cells. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes strongly contradict a leukocyte motility/adhesion program; FLNA and ARL4C are more ubiquitous but are nevertheless integral to cytoskeletal dynamics.

program_13.description: The program most closely fits a resting / memory B-cell state that is transcriptionally primed for immune-modulatory signalling (e.g. via prostaglandin E2 and lysophosphatidylserine receptors). Evidence: • CD84 – SLAM-family receptor highly enriched on mature, memory and germinal-center B cells; less abundant on most non-B lineages. • GPR174 – GPCR with peak expression in naïve and transitional B cells and shown to regulate B-cell positioning in lymphoid follicles. • PTGER4 – Prostaglandin-E2 EP4 receptor expressed in peripheral B cells and required for Ig class-switch and survival, supporting an immunomodulatory B-cell phenotype. • LBH, IPCEF1, TNRC6C – broadly expressed genes but reported to have higher baseline transcripts in lymphoid cells, consistent with a quiescent B-cell transcriptional landscape rather than a non-immune cell type. Inconsistencies: • No strongly conflicting genes are present; several genes (IPCEF1, TNRC6C, LBH) are ubiquitous rather than B-cell-specific, so they add little lineage information but do not contradict a B-cell identity.

program_14.description: The gene module is most compatible with an activated, tissue-resident regulatory/effector T-cell state (GITR⁺/CD9⁺) that is producing matrix-remodelling factors, a profile often seen in mucosal or tumour microenvironments. Evidence: • TNFRSF18 (GITR) – signature surface receptor of activated T cells, especially FOXP3⁺ regulatory T cells. • CD9 – tetraspanin enriched on activated/regulatory and tissue-resident memory T cells; supports suppressive function and vesicle secretion. • TIMP1 – metalloproteinase inhibitor secreted by activated T cells to modulate extracellular matrix. • FHL1 and AMPD1 – although best known in muscle, both transcripts are documented to rise in highly metabolically active or tissue-adapted T cells, reflecting cytoskeletal and purine-metabolic remodelling during activation. • ZG16 – a secreted lectin detected in some mucosal immune cells and aligns with a mucosal, tissue-resident context suggested by the programme. Inconsistencies: • Strong muscle enrichment of AMPD1 and FHL1 and goblet-cell lectin ZG16 are not canonical T-cell markers, raising the possibility of ambient RNA contamination or a mixed cell-type signal within the programme.

program_15.description: The gene set most closely fits a program active in metabolically engaged hepatocytes—liver parenchymal cells displaying high fatty-acid handling, metal detoxification, and elevated protein synthesis/mitochondrial respiration. Evidence: • FABP1 – canonical cytosolic fatty-acid–binding protein highly enriched in hepatocytes (and to a lesser extent enterocytes); a staple liver marker. • MT1G – metallothionein isoform induced in hepatocytes for heavy-metal sequestration and redox control, frequently co-expressed with FABP1. • MT-ND2 together with ribosomal proteins RPS17, RPL13A, RPL31 – indicates increased oxidative phosphorylation and ribosome biogenesis, a hallmark of actively synthesizing hepatocytes producing serum proteins. Inconsistencies: • Absence of additional liver-specific transcripts (e.g., ALB, APOA1, CYP enzymes) means the program could alternatively correspond to another FABP1⁺ epithelium such as intestinal enterocytes, although no genes in the list directly conflict with a hepatocyte interpretation.

program_16.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generalized nutrient-sensing / metabolic-stress program in otherwise ubiquitous cells, in which mTORC1 activity is curbed and resources are redirected toward autophagy-coupled membrane trafficking and acetyl-CoA–driven biosynthesis. Evidence: • NPRL3 – core subunit of the GATOR1 complex that inhibits mTORC1 when amino acids are scarce, a canonical trigger for autophagy. • DYNC1LI1 – dynein light-intermediate chain needed for retrograde transport of autophagosomes and late endosomes toward lysosomes during starvation-induced autophagy. • ACLY – supplies cytosolic acetyl-CoA for lipid synthesis and histone acetylation; its up-regulation is a common compensatory response to metabolic stress. • PLEKHA3 – PI-binding adaptor that partners with ARF6 to remodel endosomal membranes, facilitating the vesicle flux required for autophagosome maturation. • SYNCRIP (hnRNP-Q) – RNA-binding protein that accumulates in stress granules and regulates translation of metabolic and autophagy-related mRNAs under nutrient deprivation. Inconsistencies: • Classic autophagy genes (e.g., ATG5, MAP1LC3B) and unfolded-protein or oxidative-stress markers are absent, so the program may reflect only a partial or early nutrient-stress response rather than full autophagic flux.

program_17.description: The program most parsimoniously reflects a metabolically active, but non-cycling (quiescent/differentiated) cell state characterized by up-regulation of mitochondrial TCA-cycle and adhesion/regulatory genes and concurrent suppression of DNA-replication/mitotic machinery. Evidence: • Positive: IDH3B – β-subunit of mitochondrial NAD-dependent isocitrate-dehydrogenase, a hallmark of oxidative TCA activity typical of differentiated, energy-demanding cells. • Positive: PNKD – cytosolic/mitochondrial protein enriched in mature, highly oxidative tissues (brain, muscle), further pointing to a differentiated, oxidative metabolic profile. • Positive: ILKAP – phosphatase that modulates integrin/ILK and Wnt signaling, more active in differentiated cells where it restrains proliferation. • Negative: RECQL – DNA helicase essential for replication and repair; its down-regulation is characteristic of quiescent or terminally differentiated cells. • Negative: ANAPC1 – core anaphase-promoting complex subunit, normally high during G2/M; low levels indicate exit from the cell-cycle. Inconsistencies: • The gene list lacks classical lineage markers, so the precise cell type (e.g., neuron vs. muscle) cannot be firmly assigned. • ILKAP can also participate in some proliferative signaling contexts, although its net effect here aligns with anti-proliferative status.

program_18.description: The gene set points to a hematopoietic-restricted, antigen-receptor–bearing lymphocyte program, most compatible with naive/early-activated T cells that retain broad immunoregulatory capacity. Evidence: • SASH3 – lymphocyte-specific adaptor that amplifies T-cell-receptor (TCR) and B-cell-receptor signaling. • PTPN22 – cytoplasmic phosphatase expressed almost exclusively in T and B cells; fine-tunes early TCR signaling thresholds. • SELPLG (PSGL-1) – surface ligand highly expressed on naive and central-memory T cells as well as other leukocytes; supports lymphocyte trafficking to secondary lymphoid organs. • CMTM6 – transmembrane protein that stabilises PD-L1 on T cells and other immune cells, marking cells engaged in immune-checkpoint regulation shortly after activation. • Collectively, the four genes above are all enriched in lymphocytes and participate in proximal TCR signaling or immune-checkpoint modulation, consistent with a poised/early-activated T-cell state. Inconsistencies: • ATP8B2 encodes a ubiquitous aminophospholipid flippase with no strong lymphocyte specificity; its presence may reflect general membrane-maintenance needs rather than the T-cell program per se.

program_0.description: The gene set represents a generic “high-translation/low-oxidative-phosphorylation” program characteristic of cells that are actively synthesising protein—such as proliferating or recently activated cells—rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The program is driven by coordinated up-regulation of nearly every cytoplasmic ribosomal protein gene and translation-elongation factors, coupled with relative repression of mitochondrial respiratory-chain transcripts, consistent with a metabolic shift away from oxidative phosphorylation and with undifferentiated or early-cycle epithelial cells. Evidence: • Strong positive loading of ribosomal-protein genes (RPL10, RPL13A, RPL32, RPS6, RPS19, RPS27A, etc.) and elongation factors (EEF1A1, EEF1B2) – hallmark of increased ribosome biogenesis and protein synthesis. • TMSB4X (actin-sequestering protein induced in early cell-cycle entry and wound-healing) and MT1G (metallothionein induced by oxidative or metal stress) often co-express with high-translation states. • Negative loading of multiple mitochondrial-encoded ETC genes (MT-CO1/2/3, MT-ATP6, MT-CYB, MT-ND1/3/4/5) indicates reduced oxidative-phosphorylation transcript representation, a common inverse module to the ribosomal program in proliferating cells. • Negative loading of differentiated intestinal markers (LGALS4, FABP1, PHGR1) suggests the program is strongest in less-differentiated or cycling epithelial cells rather than mature absorptive enterocytes. Inconsistencies: • A few negatively loaded stress-response / transcription-factor genes (JUND) and metal-binding genes (MT1E) could point to additional stress signalling intertwined with the metabolic shift, but they do not contradict a high-translation proliferative state.

program_1.description: The gene set represents a robust mitotic/G2-M cell-cycle program common to actively dividing cells of many lineages rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • Core proliferation marker: MKI67 is expressed throughout active cell division. • Cyclin–CDK machinery of G2/M: CCNA2, CCNB1, CCNB2 together with CDK1 drive entry into and progression through mitosis. • Spindle assembly & kinetochore function: TPX2, NUSAP1, TUBA1B, STMN1, ASPM, DLGAP5, CENPA/CENPE/CENPF, NUF2, PLK1, AURKA, AURKB ensure spindle formation and chromosome segregation. • Anaphase-promoting complex regulators: CDC20, UBE2C, UBE2S promote metaphase–anaphase transition; BIRC5 (Survivin) and CDCA8 are part of the chromosomal passenger complex. • DNA topology and checkpoint control: TOP2A (decatenation), GTSE1 (p53/mitotic checkpoint), CDKN3 (CDK phosphatase) underscore a late cell-cycle state. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes coherently participate in G2/M cell-cycle regulation.

program_2.description: The gene set represents an immediate-early activation program typical of recently stimulated lymphocytes—most compatibly T cells that have just received T-cell-receptor (TCR) or cytokine signals and are mounting an AP-1/NR4A-driven response. Evidence: • AP-1 immediate-early factors FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB and the MAPK-inducible phosphatase DUSP1 are classical hallmarks of acute receptor signaling. • NR4A2 and TSC22D3 (GILZ) are rapidly induced by TCR activation and glucocorticoid/cytokine signaling in T cells. • CD69 is one of the earliest surface markers up-regulated after T-cell activation. • KLF2 and CXCR4 are transcriptionally responsive to TCR signaling and guide lymphocyte trafficking, fitting a recently activated but still migratory T-cell state. • House-keeping genes GAPDH, ACTB, ACTG1 and SERF2 being negatively loaded suggests a transcriptome skewed toward stimulus-induced genes rather than baseline metabolism, consistent with an acute activation burst. Inconsistencies: • KLF2 and CXCR4 are often down-regulated in fully differentiated effector T cells; their positive loading implies either a very early activation stage or involvement of other cell types (e.g., naïve or central memory T cells) rather than fully committed effectors.

program_3.description: The gene set represents a conventional T-cell identity and mild activation/memory program, characteristic of IL7R⁺ CD3⁺ αβ T cells that include central/effector memory and KLRB1⁺ (Th17/MAIT-like) subsets. Evidence: • Core T-cell receptor complex – CD3E, CD3D, CD3G, CD2, CD7 specify αβ T-cell lineage. • Survival/memory marker – IL7R (CD127) is highly expressed in naïve and central-memory T cells. • Activation/adaptor genes – FYB1 (T-cell receptor signaling) and IL32 (inducible cytokine in activated T lymphocytes). • Tissue-resident/Th17 bias – KLRB1 (CD161) and the transcription factor RORA are hallmarks of Th17, MAIT, and tissue-resident memory T cells. • Effector chemokine and cytotoxic-associated receptors – CCL5 (RANTES) and CD96 point to an activated/effector memory phenotype. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes are supplied; no clear contradictions within the positive set.

program_4.description: The program reflects a highly proliferative, cell-cycle–active state (S/G2–phase) in which chromatin/DNA-replication factors are up-regulated while MHC class I antigen-presentation genes are concurrently repressed—a pattern commonly seen in cycling progenitors and many tumor cells. Evidence: • Up-regulated chromatin & cell-cycle genes – STMN1: microtubule regulator essential for mitotic spindle assembly and fast-cycling cells. – PCLAF: PCNA-binding protein driving DNA replication and S-phase progression. – HMGB1, HMGB2, HMGN1, HMGN2: high-mobility-group proteins that remodel chromatin and are characteristically enriched in proliferating cells. • Down-regulated antigen-presentation genes – B2M plus HLA-A, ‑B, ‑C: core components of the MHC-I complex; their coordinated suppression is frequently observed in rapidly dividing progenitors or immune-evasive tumor cells, and contrasts with the house-keeping expression seen in quiescent somatic cells. Inconsistencies: No strong contradictions; the gene sets are mutually coherent with a cycling, low-MHC-I state.

program_5.description: The gene set represents a generic S-phase/DNA-replication program that is activated in any rapidly cycling cell (e.g., transit-amplifying epithelial cells, proliferating immune cells, or dividing cancer cells) rather than marking a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • DNA replication licensing and fork progression – MCM4, CLSPN, ASF1B, FEN1, ATAD5, SAC3D1 all encode factors required for origin firing, histone supply, flap processing, checkpoint signaling, or PCNA unloading during S phase. • DNA repair/mismatch surveillance – MSH2 and CLSPN participate in mismatch repair and replication-stress checkpoints, underscoring an S-phase context. • Cell-cycle control – RBL1 (p107) is an E2F-regulated G1/S inhibitor released in cycling cells; its co-expression with the above genes typifies active cell-cycle progression. • Supporting proliferation-linked factors – AAAS (nuclear pore component linked to replication stress) and PGP (phosphoglycolate phosphatase, required after DNA damage) are commonly up-regulated in dividing cells coping with replication-associated DNA lesions. Inconsistencies: • None striking; all listed genes fit a replication/repair cell-cycle program, though PGP and AAAS are more peripheral and not exclusive to S phase.

program_6.description: The gene set represents a canonical S-phase cell-cycle program found in proliferating cells of diverse lineages, highlighting DNA replication licensing, nucleotide biosynthesis, and chromatin/chromosome assembly that occur as cells transition from late G1 into S phase. Evidence: • DNA replication licensing: CDT1, ORC6, MCM6 encode core origin-licensing factors; UHRF1 coordinates DNA methylation maintenance during replication. • Nucleotide biosynthesis for DNA synthesis: TYMS, TK1, and RRM2 supply deoxythymidine and deoxyribonucleotides required for nascent DNA strands. • Transcriptional activation of S-phase genes: E2F1 is the prototypical transcription factor driving S-phase entry and up-regulating many genes in this list. • Chromatin assembly/kinetochore preparation: CHAF1A mediates nucleosome assembly behind the replication fork; ZWINT participates in kinetochore formation and is typically induced from S through G2. Inconsistencies: • No notable contradictions; all listed genes are strongly linked to S-phase proliferation.

program_7.description: The program reflects a professional antigen-presenting–cell (APC) state characterized by high expression of the MHC class II antigen-presentation machinery, most compatible with activated B cells or other IL-4–responsive APCs that up-regulate FCER2/CD23. Evidence: • HLA-DRA, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQB1 and CD74 encode the core MHC II α/β chains and invariant chain, a canonical module of professional APCs. • FCER2 (CD23) is the low-affinity IgE receptor induced by IL-4 on mature/activated B cells and dendritic cells, marking an activated APC phenotype. • CD52 is a pan-lymphocyte surface protein found on B cells, T cells and some dendritic cells, supporting an immune-cell identity. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; however, the absence of classical B-cell receptor genes (e.g., MS4A1/CD20, CD19, CD79A/B) leaves open the possibility that the program occurs in non-B APCs such as dendritic cells or macrophages.

program_8.description: The gene set reflects a generic proliferative program characteristic of cells in late-S to G2/M phase, marked by active DNA replication, DNA damage repair, and centromere/kinetochore assembly—features common to rapidly dividing progenitors, activated immune cells and many cancer cells, rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • DNA replication/repair – LIG1 (Okazaki-fragment ligase), FANCI (Fanconi-anemia DNA inter-strand cross-link repair), MND1 (homologous recombination factor) all peak in S/G2. • Chromosome segregation – CENPW is a core centromere/kinetochore component expressed during G2/M. • General growth/translation support – EIF1AD (translation initiation-related) and MCUR1 (mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake supporting oxidative phosphorylation) are commonly up-regulated in metabolically active, cycling cells. Inconsistencies: • MCUR1 and EIF1AD are not strictly cell-cycle-restricted and can be expressed in non-proliferating cells, but their up-regulation is frequently observed in highly metabolically active cycling cells, so they are only mildly discordant.

program_9.description: The program represents a generic heat-shock / proteotoxic stress response that can be transiently activated in virtually any cell type rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • HSPA1A & HSPA1B (HSP70 family) – classical inducible heat-shock proteins up-regulated within minutes of thermal or proteotoxic stress to refold denatured proteins. • HSPA6 – stress-inducible HSP70 paralogue expressed only after strong heat shock. • DNAJB1 – HSP40 co-chaperone that stimulates HSP70 ATPase activity during protein refolding; typically co-induced with HSP70s under heat stress. • HSP90AA1 – inducible cytosolic HSP90 chaperone whose transcription is driven by HSF1 during heat shock, stabilizing client proteins and preventing aggregation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes coherently participate in the canonical heat-shock chaperone network.

program_0.description: This program reflects a high-ribosome/translation state typical of rapidly proliferating, undifferentiated epithelial progenitors. Cells scoring high for the program strongly up-regulate essentially every cytosolic ribosomal protein and translation factor, while concurrently repressing markers of mature intestinal/colon epithelium, interferon response genes and MHC class-I components—features consistent with crypt-like stem or transit-amplifying cells that have shed differentiated and immune-responsive functions in favor of biomass accumulation and growth. Evidence: • Strong positive loadings for virtually all small- and large-subunit ribosomal proteins (e.g. RPS3, RPS6, RPL10, RPLP0), elongation factors (EEF1A1, EEF1B2) and ribosome-associated chaperones (RACK1, NACA) indicate active ribosome biogenesis and global protein synthesis. • Negative loadings for canonical mature epithelial/goblet cell markers (EPCAM, KRT20, CEACAM5, CEACAM1, CLDN4, MUC13, ZG16, LYPD8) support loss of differentiation. • Down-regulation of interferon-stimulated and antigen-presentation genes (IFI27, ISG15, HLA-A, B2M) is characteristic of rapidly cycling progenitors that suppress immune signaling. • Reduced mitochondrial (MT-CO1) and secretory genes (PRSS3, PLAC8) further fit a state prioritizing cytosolic protein synthesis over specialized functions. Inconsistencies: • None of the loaded genes strongly oppose a high-translation, low-differentiation interpretation; the presence of generic cytoskeletal/remodeling genes like GSN (negative) is explainable by reduced motility functions in progenitors.

program_1.description: The gene set describes a polarized, junction-rich epithelial program, characteristic of mature, tightly adherent epithelial cells (e.g., intestinal or airway surface epithelium) that are maintaining barrier integrity rather than undergoing epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition. Evidence: • Cell–cell junction/adhesion: strongly positive loading for desmosomal components DSG2 and DSP, adherens-junction protein CDH1 (E-cadherin), tricellular tight-junction protein LSR, integrin ITGB1, cytoskeletal linkers ACTN4, SPTBN1, MYH9, TPM3, and scaffold IQGAP1. • Epithelial identity & regulation: SPINT2 (serine-protease inhibitor enriched in epithelial barriers), KLF5 (transcription factor driving epithelial proliferation/differentiation), CD164, APLP2, and ER/secretory-pathway genes (SEC16A, KDELR2, ERGIC1) that support high secretory traffic typical of surface epithelia. • Barrier/immune interface: IL13RA1 and IFNAR1 suggest epithelium capable of responding to cytokines at mucosal surfaces. • Negative loadings include DSTN (actin depolymerizing), TBCA, and OST4, consistent with reduced cytoskeletal disassembly and glycosylation turnover, further supporting a stable, differentiated epithelial state. Inconsistencies: • MBP (myelin basic protein) is usually oligodendrocyte-associated; its presence here is atypical and may reflect low-level or non-canonical expression. • TAPBP and other antigen-presentation genes (e.g., HLA-related) are not hallmarks of classic epithelial barrier cells but can be expressed broadly.

program_2.description: The gene set represents a universal G2/M‐phase cell-cycle program characteristic of actively dividing cells across many lineages; it marks cells that are in late G2, mitosis, and cytokinesis rather than any specific differentiated cell type. Evidence: • Core mitotic kinases and regulators—CDK1, CCNB1, CCNA2, PLK1, AURKB, TTK, PBK—drive G2/M transition and chromosome segregation. • Kinetochore and spindle assembly factors—CENPA, CENPE, CENPF, CENPW, NDC80, BUB1, BUB1B, MAD2L1, NUSAP1, KIF11, KIF18A/B, KIF20A, KIF23, KIF2C—are quintessential markers of mitosis. • Cytokinesis/cleavage-furrow components—ANLN, PRC1, CEP55, KIF14—indicate progression through anaphase to abscission. • DNA replication and repair genes that peak in late S/G2—TOP2A, PIF1, HMGB2, GTSE1, FAM72A/D—support a high-proliferation signature. • Proliferation survival marker BIRC5 (Survivin) and classic cycling marker MKI67 further confirm an actively dividing state. Inconsistencies: No notable lineage-specific or quiescence markers are present; all listed genes coherently support a generic mitotic program.

program_3.description: The gene set most closely matches epithelial tuft (a.k.a. solitary chemosensory) cells displaying their canonical chemosensory/type-2–immune activation program. Evidence: • Chemosensory/taste-transduction core – POU2F3 (lineage-defining TF), TRPM5, TAS1R3, GNG13, RGS13 and GRK5 are hallmarks of tuft cells that sense luminal cues via taste-receptor signalling. • Lipid-mediator synthesis – ALOX5, ALOX5AP, HPGDS and PTGS1 encode enzymes that enable tuft cells to generate leukotrienes and prostaglandins that drive type-2 immunity. • Type-2/IL-25 axis – IL17RB (receptor for tuft-cell–derived IL-25) together with PLCG2, PIK3CG, FYB1, VAV1, HCK and PSTPIP2 constitute immune-signalling adaptors widely reported in tuft-cell transcriptomes. • Structural/ancillary tuft markers – AVIL, BCAM, DKK3, ANXA13, KIT and GFI1B are repeatedly detected in airway and intestinal tuft cells. • Coordinated absence of typical ciliated, goblet or basal-cell genes supports a distinct tuft identity. Inconsistencies: • Hematopoietic-biased kinases (e.g., HCK, MATK) and adaptors (PTPN6) are more characteristic of immune cells, but low-level expression of these molecules is a known feature of tuft cells and therefore only a minor discrepancy.

program_4.description: The gene set is characteristic of conventional T lymphocytes displaying an activated, tissue-resident memory/early effector state enriched for cytotoxic functions (Trm/Tem). Evidence: • T-cell identity: strong expression of TCR complex and pan-T markers (CD2, CD3D/E/G, CD247, CD7, PTPRC, CD52, CD48, CD53, LCP2) confirms lymphoid, T-lineage origin. • Memory/activation features: IL7R, CD69, RGS1, KLRB1, CXCR4, ACAP1 and RUNX3 are canonical for tissue-resident or central/effector memory T cells; CD69 and RUNX3 are hallmarks of Trm cells. • Cytotoxic/effector molecules: GZMA, NKG7, CST7, CCL4, CCL5, KLRD1 and HCST indicate acquisition of cytolytic machinery and chemokine secretion typical of early cytotoxic CD4⁺ or CD8⁺ effectors. • Signaling/adaptor genes linked to activation and immune synapse formation (HCLS1, LCP1, EVL, FMNL1, RAC2, ARHGDIB, GMFG) support an activated functional state. Inconsistencies: • VIM (vimentin) is predominantly mesenchymal but is up-regulated in highly activated T cells; its presence is therefore not strongly discordant. • GYPC (erythroid marker) and LSP1/FMN​L1 (often myeloid-biased) are outliers and may reflect low-level contamination or ambient RNA rather than the core program.

program_5.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature, highly secretory intestinal/colonic goblet-cell program, reflecting cells that have completed ATOH1/SPDEF-driven secretory differentiation and are actively producing and exocytosing MUC2-rich mucus along with associated antimicrobial and barrier-stabilising proteins. Evidence: • Core goblet-cell mucins and mucus-associated proteins: MUC2, TFF3, FCGBP, ZG16, ITLN1, CLCA1, ST6GALNAC1, SPINK4, RETNLB. • Secretory-lineage transcriptional regulators: ATOH1 (master regulator of secretory fate), SPDEF (drives terminal goblet differentiation), CREB3L1 (ER stress response in heavy secretors). • Genes linked to mucin granule maturation/exocytosis: RAB27A, RAB26, LRRC26, KCNMA1, BEST2, CAPN9. • Additional intestinal goblet/secretory markers described in human colon scRNA-seq atlases: REP15, WFDC2, FMOD, FRZB, DLL1. Inconsistencies: • Prostate-associated secreted proteases and channels (KLK3, KLK15, ANO7, KIF19) and mast-cell protease TPSG1 are atypical for intestinal goblet cells. • Mesenchymal/stromal markers such as CDH11 and FMOD, and the muscle protein MB, are out of context but could reflect ambient RNA or low-level background expression.

program_6.description: The gene set is most consistent with mature intestinal (particularly colonic) goblet cells in an active secretory state, characterized by high production, packaging and exocytosis of the gel-forming mucin MUC2 and associated trefoil-factor rich mucus. Evidence: • Mucin core and mucus-stabilizing genes classically enriched in intestinal goblet cells: MUC2, FCGBP, ZG16, TFF3, TFF1, ITLN1, CAPN9. • Goblet-cell chloride/anion and fatty-acid–sensing genes found in the colon: BEST2, FFAR4. • Secretory vesicle trafficking machinery needed for rapid mucin release: RAB27A, RAB3B, REP15, SYTL2, SYTL5, CDC42EP3, GSN. • Transcriptional/lineage regulators linked to the secretory goblet lineage: TBX10, MINPP1, MLLT3. • Additional genes previously reported in colonic goblet-cell signatures: KLB, FFAR4, CAPN9, MFSD4A, FAM177B. Inconsistencies: • SCGB2A1 (mammaglobin) is typical of secretoglobin-producing airway or mammary epithelium. • BCAS1 (oligodendrocyte marker), TRPA1 (chemosensory/tuft cell channel) and MLLT3 (hematopoietic regulator) are not classic goblet genes but could reflect low-level expression or cross-loading in the dataset.

program_7.description: The program most closely fits a high-biosynthetic, endoplasmic-reticulum (ER) stress / unfolded-protein-response-like state that is often seen in rapidly proliferating or highly secretory epithelial or cancer cells rather than marking a specific lineage. Evidence: • ER folding and glycosylation machinery up-regulated: CANX (calnexin), SSR1 (signal-peptide receptor), STT3B (oligosaccharyl-transferase), SERP1 (stress-associated ER protein), PTGES3/p23 (HSP90 co-chaperone) point to intensified ER protein-folding workload. • mRNA processing / translation factors abundant: HNRNPK, HNRNPF, PCBP2, LSM7, EIF4G2 together indicate elevated transcription-to-translation flux typical of cells with high protein output. • Vesicle transport & trafficking: KIF5B (kinesin motor) and KPNB1 (importin-β) support increased protein movement between nucleus, ER and cytoplasm. • Metabolic and stress adaptation components: COX7A2L (OXPHOS assembly), CERS6 (ceramide synthesis), PAWR and TRIM2 (ubiquitin–proteasome axis) are commonly induced during ER or oxidative stress. • Proliferation / stem-like transcriptional regulators: KLF5, YY1, TBL1XR1, ARID1A, KDM3B enhance chromatin remodeling and growth-related transcription, matching the heightened biosynthetic demand. Inconsistencies: • Classical UPR transcription factors (e.g., ATF4, XBP1, DDIT3) are absent, so the program may reflect sustained high secretory capacity rather than an acute UPR. • The gene set lacks lineage-specific markers (e.g., EPCAM, CD45, PECAM1), so while compatible with secretory/proliferative epithelial cells, it is not uniquely cell-type defining.

program_8.description: The gene constellation points to a nucleus-centred “chromatin-remodelling / RNA-processing” program that is typically up-regulated in highly transcriptionally active, proliferation-competent cells such as stem-like or malignant cells rather than defining a specific differentiated lineage. Evidence: • Chromatin remodellers: SMARCC1 and ARID1B (SWI/SNF complex), BPTF (NURF), BAZ2B, ZMYM2 – hallmarks of open, dynamically remodelled chromatin in cycling or stem-like cells. • Core spliceosome / RNA-binding factors: PRPF8, SNRNP200, DDX18, HNRNPK, HNRNPU, PCBP2 – support intensive pre-mRNA processing that accompanies high transcriptional throughput. • Transcriptional regulators that favour growth or transformation: MDM4 (p53 inhibitor), MTDH (onco-gene), NFAT5, ZBTB20, ZKSCAN1, IRF2BP2 – frequently enriched in proliferating cancers or progenitors. • Biosynthetic / organelle support genes: OGT (O-GlcNAc nutrient sensor), CANX (ER chaperone), AKAP1 & LRPPRC (mitochondrial mRNA/anchor), ADD3 (cytoskeleton), CERS6 (lipid synthesis) – provide the metabolic and structural scaffolding typical of fast-growing cells. • Surface signalling modulators found in stem-like epithelial tumours: RNF43 (WNT pathway E3 ligase), CD46 (complement regulator/co-stimulator). Inconsistencies: • CD46 (widely expressed but classically immune modulator) and CERS6 (neuronal bias) are not exclusive to proliferative programmes, yet their housekeeping roles can still fit a generic high-activity state.

program_9.description: The gene set most strongly matches the transcriptional program of BEST4⁺/OTOP2⁺ colonic enterocytes (“intestinal ionocytes”)—a specialized absorptive epithelial state involved in luminal pH sensing, bicarbonate secretion, and guanylin/uroguanylin hormone production. Evidence: • Core ionocyte markers: BEST4, OTOP2, OTOP3, CA4, CA7 and ADCY5 are hallmark genes of BEST4⁺ colonic enterocytes that sense extracellular pH and regulate electrolyte flux. • Guanylin pathway: GUCA2A and GUCA2B, encoding guanylin and uroguanylin, are signature hormones secreted by this enterocyte subset. • Additional epithelial / absorptive features: SLC2A5 (fructose transporter), LYPD8 (antimicrobial peptide produced by colon epithelium), CA4/CA7 (carbonic anhydrases), CTSE (protease expressed in gut epithelium) and CCNYL1 (Cyclin Y-like protein enriched in intestinal epithelium). • Transcriptional regulators linked to intestinal epithelium differentiation: HES4 (Notch target in secretory vs absorptive fate decisions) and MEIS1 (homeobox factor enriched in distal gut). • Absence of negatively loaded intestinal stem or Paneth cell genes supports a mature absorptive epithelial identity rather than a progenitor or secretory program. Inconsistencies: • CEACAM3 (granulocyte receptor), SPIB (M-cell / plasmacytoid DC TF), MYOM1 (muscle structural protein), LINGO1 and KCNIP4 (neuronal-associated) are atypical for enterocytes and may reflect low-level noise, ambient RNA, or secondary functions unrelated to the dominant intestinal ionocyte program.

program_10.description: The gene set reflects a metabolically-active, growth-factor–stimulated cell state characterized by high mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and elevated protein synthesis—an “OXPHOS/translation activation” program that is frequently seen in proliferating or recently activated somatic or immune cells rather than being specific to a single differentiated lineage. Evidence: • Oxidative phosphorylation/ETC genes (NDUFC1, NDUFA2, NDUFS6, UQCRB, HIGD2A, CISD3) and mitochondrial ribosomal protein MRPL41 indicate increased mitochondrial respiration and biogenesis. • Translation and co-translational targeting genes (EIF3K, SRP14, OST4, TMA7, PFDN5) point to globally up-regulated protein synthesis. • Growth-signal mediators LAMTOR5 (Ragulator component that activates mTORC1 on lysosomes) and MAP2K2 (MEK2) are consistent with nutrient-sensing and proliferation cues that drive both OXPHOS and translation. • ER/secretory-stress helpers SERP1 and chaperone/cytoskeletal folding factors TBCA, DSTN support an active proteostasis environment. • Negative loading of SH3GLB2 (Endophilin-B2, pro-autophagy) fits with mTORC1-high states, where autophagy is suppressed. Inconsistencies: • Actin/cytoskeletal organizers PDLIM1 and DSTN, lipid carrier SCP2, and transcriptional modulator EDF1 are not core OXPHOS/translation genes; however, they can accompany growth and metabolic activation, so their presence is not strongly contradictory.

program_11.description: The gene set represents a neuroendocrine-secretory program, characteristic of endocrine or neuroendocrine‐like epithelial cells that package and release peptide hormones/neuromodulators (e.g. mature pancreatic β-cells, intestinal enteroendocrine cells, or tumor cells that have adopted a neuroendocrine phenotype). Evidence: • Secretory-granule/peptidergic markers – CHGB and SCG2 are canonical components of dense-core secretory vesicles in endocrine and neuroendocrine cells. • Neuropeptide hormone – UCN3 is a maturation marker of pancreatic β-cells and other peptide-secreting endocrine cells. • Vesicle exocytosis machinery – UNC13A (Munc13-1), SCN2A (Nav1.2), KCNK9 (TASK-3 K⁺ channel) and TUBA1A support regulated membrane excitability and vesicle release typical of neuroendocrine cells. • Guidance/neuronal differentiation factors – EPHB6, TCF4 and ST18 are all enriched in cells with neuronal or neuroendocrine lineage specification. • Additional secreted/secretory proteins – AZGP1, FST and VSTM2A are frequently co-expressed with endocrine secretory programs. Inconsistencies: • MYBPC1 (striated muscle protein), CLEC2B & LAT2 (immune lineage), AKR1C4 (hepatic enzyme) and CRYBA2 (lens protein) are peripheral to a neuroendocrine identity and may reflect noise, low-level contamination or broader stress-response expression.

program_12.description: The gene set represents a broad Type I interferon–stimulated gene (ISG) program, characteristic of cells that have sensed viral‐like nucleic-acid danger signals and entered an antiviral response state; this transcriptional module can be super-imposed on many innate and parenchymal cell types. Evidence: • Canonical ISGs – ISG15, IFIT1/2/3, IFI27, IFI44/IFI44L, MX1/MX2, OAS2, RSAD2 (Viperin), CMPK2, IFI6 – are classical targets of the STAT1/STAT2–IRF9 complex downstream of Type I IFN signalling. • Antiviral effector/ubiquitin-like modifiers – HERC5, TRIM22, ISG15 – encode E3 ligases that conjugate ISGylation or ubiquitination during viral restriction. • Immune activation and maturation markers – EPSTI1 (IFN-induced adaptor in macrophages/DCs), LAMP3 (up-regulated in mature dendritic cells and IFN-treated epithelial cells), XAF1 (pro-apoptotic ISG) – further indicate a stimulated, antiviral defence state. Inconsistencies: • No genes in the list clearly contradict an interferon-stimulated antiviral program; the module is internally consistent.

program_13.description: The program reflects a cohesive, adherens- and desmosome-rich epithelial cell state typical of polarized intestinal/colonic epithelial cells, including proliferative progenitors. Evidence: • Desmosome / adherens-junction core: DSG2, CDH1 (E-cadherin), DSP, PTPRF and LPP encode structural or signaling components of epithelial cell–cell junctions. • Intestinal/colon epithelial identity: SATB2 (colon epithelium transcription factor) and KLF5 (drives intestinal progenitor proliferation) are hallmark markers of gut epithelium. • Polarized epithelial membrane maintenance: ATP8B1 (phospholipid flippase enriched in gut epithelium) and CLTC (clathrin-mediated trafficking) support apical–basal polarity. • Cytoskeletal anchoring of junctions: MYH9 and MARCKS participate in actin–myosin and membrane–cytoskeleton linkage needed for tight epithelial sheets. • General epithelial metabolism/regulation: MLXIP and NRIP1 coordinate nutrient-responsive transcription; APLP2/APP, RBM47, FAM120A, FRYL provide broad epithelial or junctional support functions. Inconsistencies: • APP, APLP2 and MYH9 are broadly expressed and not restricted to epithelium, but their presence does not contradict an epithelial adhesion program.

program_14.description: The program reflects an epithelial cell-cell junction/adhesion state characteristic of differentiated intestinal or other simple glandular epithelia, marked by strong expression of cadherins, desmosomal proteins and associated cytoskeletal components that stabilize adherens and tight junctions. Evidence: • Adherens junction cadherins – CDH1 (E-cadherin) and CDH17 (intestinal cadherin) are canonical epithelial adhesion molecules. • Desmosomal complex – DSG2, DSP and JUP encode core desmosome proteins, while ACTN4 and SPTBN1 provide cortical actin–spectrin support. • Junction-associated signaling/scaffolding – DLG1 (MAGUK scaffold) and ERBB3 (epithelial receptor tyrosine kinase often co-expressed with E-cadherin) reinforce an epithelial signaling context. • Epithelial serine protease and secretory machinery – ST14 (matriptase) and RRBP1 (ER ribosome receptor) are enriched in secretory/absorptive epithelia, especially intestine. • Additional epithelial/secretory genes – VMP1 (apical membrane protein), APP/APLP2 (type I membrane proteins up-regulated in polarized epithelia) align with a mature epithelial phenotype. Inconsistencies: • TAPBP (antigen-processing chaperone) and ZBTB7A (ubiquitous transcription factor) are not epithelial-specific but are broadly expressed; their presence does not contradict the overall epithelial junction program.

program_15.description: The program is characteristic of differentiated absorptive enterocytes/colonocytes of the distal large-intestinal epithelium, enriched for ion, water and bicarbonate transport functions typical of mature colon epithelial cells responding to luminal fluid and electrolyte balance. Evidence: • Ion and fluid transport genes typical of mature colonocytes – GUCA2A, GUCA2B (guanylin/uroguanylin peptides activating GC-C), SLC26A3 (DRA Cl⁻/HCO₃⁻ exchanger), CLCA4 (chloride channel accessory), CA4 (carbonic anhydrase 4) and AQP8 (water channel). • Colon/intestinal epithelium-restricted structural or adhesion genes – CEACAM7, MUC12, CLDN23, SDCBP2. • Barrier/efflux and metabolic genes enriched in differentiated enterocytes – ABCG2, EMP1, FTH1, TMPRSS2. • Low-level inflammatory/immune-responsive signal often seen in epithelial cells – IL32. Inconsistencies: No major contradictions; IL32 and ABCG2 can also be expressed in other cell types but are frequently detected in gut epithelium, so they do not strongly conflict with the colonocyte interpretation.

program_16.description: The program represents an interferon-γ–activated antigen-presenting cell state, characteristic of inflammatory dendritic cells / M1-like macrophages that are up-regulating MHC-II machinery and chemokines involved in T-cell recruitment. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: very high loading of MHC-II core genes CD74, HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1/5, HLA-DP(A1/B1), HLA-DQ(A1/B1), HLA-DMA/B – hallmark of professional APCs (DCs, macrophages) after activation. • IFN-γ response / inflammatory activation: IDO1, CXCL10, CXCL11 and GBP4 are classic IFN-γ–inducible genes enriched in inflammatory DCs and M1 macrophages, linking the program to a pro-inflammatory state. • Additional innate-immune / cytoskeletal support: NEXN (actin-binding protein up-regulated during macrophage activation) fits with a motile, activated APC phenotype. Inconsistencies: • GABRP is typically epithelial/neural; its presence is unusual in myeloid cells and could reflect low-level contamination or an alternative regulatory role. • NEXN is not specific to immune cells, so while compatible, it does not uniquely define the identified state.

program_17.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial-like cell program characterized by strong cell–cell / cell–matrix adhesion and cytoskeletal remodeling accompanied by globally elevated RNA-processing and translational activity, a profile typical of metabolically active or mildly proliferative epithelial cells (e.g., basal or regenerating epithelium). Evidence: • Adhesion / cytoskeleton: DSG2 (desmosomes), ITGB1 (integrin β1), SPTBN1 (spectrin), ACTN4, IQGAP1 and ROCK2 (Rho–actin regulators) together point to robust epithelial junctions and actin remodeling. • High biosynthetic load: EIF4G2 (translation initiation), CANX (ER folding), HNRNPK, PTBP3, SF3B1, NUFIP2 and ZNF207 (RNA-binding / spliceosome) indicate increased mRNA processing and protein synthesis. • Chromatin regulation enabling active transcription: ARID1B and ASH1L (SWI/SNF and histone methyltransferase) plus SMG1 (nonsense-mediated decay kinase) fit a transcriptionally active or lightly proliferative state. Inconsistencies: • PTBP3 is often enriched in hematopoietic cells, so its presence is not strictly epithelial-specific. • Canonical epithelial markers (EPCAM, KRTs) or definitive proliferation genes (MKI67, MCMs) are absent, leaving some ambiguity about exact lineage and proliferative intensity.

program_18.description: The gene set reflects a canonical Immediate-Early Gene (IEG) program that is rapidly induced when diverse cell types experience acute stimulation (e.g., growth factors, cytokines, mechanical or oxidative stress). It represents a transient “activated/stressed” cellular state rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • AP-1 transcription factors that define IEG responses: FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, ATF3 • Early response regulators: EGR1, IER2, IER3, NR4A1, BTG2 – classically up-regulated within minutes of stimulation across many cell types. • Stress-adaptive signaling and mRNA translation modulators: PPP1R15A (GADD34), TRIB1, RHOB, KLF6, MCL1 – genes induced to manage ER stress, cytoskeletal rearrangement, and survival immediately after activation. Inconsistencies: None apparent; all listed genes are characteristic components of the generic IEG/stress-activation program.

program_19.description: The gene set is characteristic of mature absorptive intestinal epithelial cells (colonocytes/enterocytes) in a homeostatic state, marked by high lipid-handling capacity, brush-border enzymes, and detoxifying metallothioneins. Evidence: • Intestinal/colon epithelium markers – LGALS4, PHGR1, C15orf48 and CA1/CA2 are highly enriched in differentiated colonocytes and small-intestinal enterocytes. • Lipid uptake & processing typical of mature enterocytes – FABP1 encodes the major cytosolic fatty-acid chaperone in intestine; MT2A, MT1H, MT1E and MT1M provide metal-binding/oxidative-stress protection during nutrient absorption. • Brush-border / ion-transport features – SLC26A2 (anion transporter) and carbonic anhydrases (CA1, CA2) support bicarbonate and sulfate exchange important for luminal ion balance. • General epithelial/absorptive cell metabolism – CKB (creatine kinase B) and ITM2C support high ATP buffering and membrane trafficking typical of differentiated epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • SLC26A2 is best known in chondrocytes, though low-level expression is reported in gut epithelium. • ITM2C is classically brain-enriched; its role in intestine is less documented, suggesting either broader expression or low-level noise in the program.

program_20.description: The program reflects a high‐mitochondrial (oxidative phosphorylation) transcriptional state that is classically observed in cells undergoing metabolic stress, apoptosis, or other conditions that lead to leakage of mitochondrial RNA and an over-representation of mitochondrial reads in single-cell libraries, rather than pointing to a specific differentiated cell type. Evidence: • MT-ND1/2/3/4/4L/5/6 (Complex I), MT-CYB (Complex III), MT-CO1/2/3 (Complex IV) and MT-ATP6 (Complex V) together represent almost the entire set of mitochondrial genome–encoded electron-transport chain genes, indicating globally elevated mitochondrial transcription. • Such concerted up-regulation of mitochondrial transcripts is a well-documented marker of stressed or dying cells in scRNA-seq datasets, where compromised membranes allow preferential capture of abundant, polyadenylated mitochondrial mRNAs. Inconsistencies: • No nuclear genes characteristic of specific cell lineages or cell-cycle phases are present; the signature is exclusively mitochondrial, consistent with a stress/apoptotic artifact and not contradictory to the interpretation above.

program_21.description: The gene constellation points to an actin-cytoskeleton remodelling and membrane-trafficking program that is typically up-regulated in highly motile, mesenchymal-like cells (e.g. migrating fibroblasts or epithelial cells undergoing an EMT-like state) and in immune cells that rely on rapid lamellipodia formation and vesicle turnover. Evidence: • Actin nucleation/branching: ARPC2 (Arp2/3 complex core), ABI1 (WAVE complex), TPM4 (tropomyosin) – hallmark drivers of lamellipodia and stress-fiber assembly. • Rho-family and associated signalling: RHOA (stress-fiber contractility), PTP4A2 (PRL phosphatase that enhances RHO signalling), YWHAZ (14-3-3 adaptor that binds phosphorylated RHO regulators), CSNK1A1 (phosphorylates cytoskeletal targets). • Membrane and vesicle dynamics that couple to actin: ARF1 (Golgi/vesicle budding; required for cell migration), TAX1BP1 and LRRFIP1 (link endosomal/autophagy machinery to actin). Collectively these genes form a well-described “cell motility / cytoskeletal remodelling” module observed when cells adopt a migratory, mesenchymal-like state. Inconsistencies: • The set lacks classical lineage markers; without ECM genes (e.g. FN1, COL1A1) or canonical EMT transcription factors (SNAI1/2, TWIST1), the program represents a generic motility module rather than a full EMT signature.

program_22.description: The gene set most consistently reflects a high biosynthetic, proliferation-linked program characterized by enhanced RNA splicing, chromatin remodeling and translational initiation—features typically up-regulated in actively cycling (S-phase) cells, irrespective of lineage. Evidence: • RNA splicing machinery – PRPF40A, SF3B1, SCAF11, BCLAF1 and PRRC2C encode core or auxiliary U2/U5 spliceosome components, a hallmark of cells ramping up mRNA processing during cell-cycle progression. • Translation initiation – EIF3A is the largest subunit of the eIF3 complex and is frequently elevated in proliferating or transformed cells to sustain protein synthesis. • Chromatin organization / DNA replication support – ATRX (SWI/SNF-like remodeler) and NIPBL (cohesin loader) are required for S-phase chromatin architecture and replication fork stability. • Transcriptional co-regulators – ANKRD11 and BCLAF1 further indicate heightened transcriptional activity needed for cell growth. • Organelle expansion – GOLGA4 marks Golgi enlargement that accompanies increased secretory and membrane-trafficking demand in dividing cells. Inconsistencies: • Classical cell-cycle markers (MKI67, PCNA, MCMs, TOP2A, etc.) are absent, so the program may capture the biosynthetic arm of proliferation rather than full canonical cell-cycle gene expression.

program_23.description: The gene set represents a generic “endoplasmic-reticulum chaperone / unfolded-protein-response (UPR)” program, seen in cells that are either highly secretory or undergoing ER stress rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • HSPA5 (BiP/GRP78), CALR and SEC61A1 – core UPR genes encoding the luminal chaperone BiP, calreticulin and the protein-translocation channel, all strongly induced during ER stress. • PDIA3, PDIA4, PDIA6, P4HB – protein-disulfide isomerases that catalyze oxidative folding of nascent proteins in the ER; canonical markers of an active UPR. • RPN2, LMAN2, TMED9 – components of the oligosaccharyltransferase complex and ER–Golgi trafficking (ERGIC/p24 family) that are up-regulated when secretory flux is high. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently participate in ER protein folding and trafficking.

program_24.description: The gene combination most closely fits an “inflammatory / adventitial fibroblast” program—i.e. stromal fibroblasts that secrete large amounts of extracellular matrix and complement components during tissue remodeling or early fibrotic responses. Evidence: • Core ECM-remodeling markers VCAN, THBS2 and SPOCK2 are canonical for VCAN⁺/THBS2⁺ adventitial (inflammatory) fibroblasts reported in lung, skin and other tissues. • CRABP2 is a retinoic-acid–responsive gene highly expressed in activated fibroblasts and up-regulated during wound repair. • SLC7A2 (CAT2) and CFP (properdin) denote fibroblasts engaged in inflammatory crosstalk, producing nitric-oxide–related metabolites and complement factors. • AQP5 has been detected in activated dermal and pulmonary fibroblasts and is linked to enhanced fibroblast motility, consistent with a remodeling phenotype. • HOMER2 and PON3, although not fibroblast-specific, are documented in subsets of stromal cells and secretory fibroblasts, supporting a secretory, signaling-competent state. Inconsistencies: • AQP5 is better known as an epithelial (alveolar type I, glandular) water channel, and HOMER2 is classically neuronal; their presence suggests either mixed cell contamination or broader expression of these genes in this fibroblast subset.

program_25.description: The gene set best matches a lung alveolar type-II (AT2) epithelial program, i.e. a secretory surfactant-producing state of distal airway epithelium, with some evidence of mild injury/repair signalling (EREG, CXCL14). Evidence: • Core AT2 identity: NKX2-1 (master lung epithelial TF), SFTPB and SFTA3 (surfactant proteins), SLC22A31 (AT2-enriched organic-ion transporter). • Secretory/ER machinery needed for surfactant export: ERP27 (ER protein-disulfide isomerase family), KIF25 (microtubule motor supporting vesicle traffic). • Repair/growth chemokines: EREG (EGF-family ligand induced during epithelial repair) and CXCL14 (chemokine released by lung epithelium, up-regulated after injury), consistent with an activated/homeostatic AT2 state rather than a quiescent one. Inconsistencies: • TNNC2 is a skeletal muscle troponin, not typically expressed in lung epithelium, suggesting low-level contamination or cross-loading. • CXCL14 and EREG can also be produced by other epithelial or stromal cells, but are documented in AT2 cells during regeneration, so only partly discordant.

program_26.description: The program represents a strong activation of the sterol/mevalonate-cholesterol biosynthesis pathway, a metabolic state typically driven by SREBP-2 signaling and observed in cells demanding new membrane production—e.g., rapidly proliferating cells, lipogenic hepatocytes, or myelinating oligodendrocytes. Evidence: • Core mevalonate-cholesterol enzymes: HMGCR, HMGCS1, MVD, IDI1, FDFT1, SQLE, MSMO1, DHCR24 collectively span every step from acetyl-CoA to cholesterol, a canonical SREBP-2‐induced cassette. • Regulatory component: INSIG1 is an ER anchor that modulates SREBP activation, itself transcriptionally up-regulated when the pathway is on, reinforcing pathway specificity. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all detected genes coherently belong to the same sterol biosynthetic module.

program_27.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial cell–junction/cytoskeletal organization program, typical of differentiated, polarity-established epithelial cells engaging desmosome and adherens-junction assembly. Evidence: • Desmosome/adherens-junction components – DSP (desmoplakin) and CTNND1 (p120-catenin) are core structural proteins of epithelial desmosomes and adherens junctions, respectively. • Cytoskeletal anchoring and remodeling – ACTR2 (Arp2/3 complex), DYNC1H1 (cytoplasmic dynein heavy chain) and AKAP9 (centrosome/Golgi scaffold) support actin nucleation, microtubule-based transport and centrosomal integrity required for epithelial polarity. • Membrane/ER support for secretory epithelia – RRBP1 (rough-ER ribosome receptor) and VMP1 (autophagy/ER-membrane protein) are highly expressed in secretory or highly biosynthetic epithelial cells. • Epithelial growth factor signalling – ERBB3 is a receptor tyrosine kinase preferentially expressed in many epithelial lineages and activated during epithelial maintenance and repair. • Genome maintenance during active proliferation – REV1 provides translesion DNA synthesis capacity, often up-regulated in cycling epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: No major contradictions; all listed genes are compatible with an epithelial junction/cytoskeletal maintenance program.

program_28.description: The gene set is most consistent with the “KRT8-high injury-induced transitional epithelium” program that emerges in simple epithelia (best described in the lung as damage-associated transitional progenitors, DATPs/ADI cells) when cells exit their steady state and engage wound-repair, migration and extracellular protease–modulating functions. Evidence: • Core cytokeratins of simple/transitional epithelium – KRT8, KRT19 – define the KRT8^high intermediate that appears after epithelial injury and before full differentiation. • Stress / migration complex – ANXA2 together with its binding partner S100A10, plus S100A6 and LGALS3, are canonical components of the annexin–galectin membrane–cytoskeleton complex enriched in DATPs and other repair-activated epithelia. • PI3 (elafin) is a secreted serine-protease inhibitor strongly induced in airway and other mucosal epithelia during inflammation and wound repair, matching the injury context of the program. • ACTB (β-actin) supports the cytoskeletal remodeling theme typical of motile, transitional epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes; ACTB is a ubiquitous housekeeping gene but is often highly scored in cytoskeleton-focused programs.

program_29.description: The gene set reflects a generic cellular program of heightened intracellular trafficking and actin–cytoskeleton remodeling that typically accompanies motile or phagocytic activity (e.g., in activated macrophages, dendritic cells or other cells engaged in vigorous endocytosis), rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • Vesicle/lysosome compartment – LAMP1 (lysosomal membrane), RNF7 (SCF-type E3 ligase that targets proteins for lysosomal/proteasomal turnover). • Actin nucleation & remodeling – ARPC4 (Arp2/3 complex), CORO1B (coronin family actin regulator). • Membrane-associated signaling/trafficking – GNB2 (G-protein β-subunit mediating receptor-regulated vesicle dynamics), LYPLA2 (acyl-protein thioesterase recycling palmitoylated membrane proteins). • Energy supply for the above processes – MRPL14 (mitochondrial ribosome) and NDUFA2 (Complex I subunit) indicate increased mitochondrial translation and respiration to meet ATP demand. Inconsistencies: • No strong lineage-specific markers (e.g., CD14, ITGAM for myeloid cells), so the program appears housekeeping/activation-related rather than defining a distinct cell type.

program_30.description: The gene set most consistently fits a WNT-high intestinal crypt base columnar (CBC) stem-cell program, reflecting cells that actively sense and dampen WNT signaling within the small-/large-intestinal epithelium. Evidence: • Classic WNT target / feedback inhibitors that typify CBC stem cells: NOTUM, APCDD1, NKD1, TNFRSF19 (TROY) – all are strongly and selectively induced in LGR5⁺ intestinal stem cells and act to tune the high WNT tone of the crypt base. • Coordinated presence of several such regulators in the same program argues for a WNT-responsive epithelial stem-cell state rather than generic WNT pathway activity elsewhere. • ASPSCR1 is broadly expressed in proliferative epithelial cells and does not conflict with an intestinal stem-cell identity. Inconsistencies: • Cartilage-associated matrix genes COL9A3 and COLGALT2 are atypical for intestinal epithelium and suggest minor contamination or cross-loading from chondrocyte / mesenchymal transcripts. • SERPINI1 is mainly neuronal and does not align with intestinal stem cells, pointing to possible ambient RNA or technical noise in the matrix.

program_31.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial cell population that has activated a fibroblast-like, extracellular-matrix-remodelling program—i.e. a partial epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (pEMT) often seen in invasive pancreatic or other gastrointestinal carcinomas. Cells retain epithelial traits (KRT7, TM4SF4) but up-regulate classic cancer-associated-fibroblast genes (FAP, COL7A1) together with a small neuroendocrine/secretory component (GCG, SYNGR4), collectively pointing to malignant epithelial cells that have adopted a stromal-remodelling, invasive state. Evidence: • Fibroblast/ECM-remodelling genes: FAP and COL7A1 are hallmark markers of activated fibroblasts and CAFs driving matrix degradation and deposition. • Additional mesenchymal-leaning gene: CRIP2 is enriched in smooth-muscle–like and fibroblast lineages and is up-regulated during EMT. • Retained epithelial identity: KRT7 (simple-epithelial keratin) and TM4SF4 (tetraspanin enriched in ductal/intestinal epithelia) indicate the cells have not fully lost epithelial features, fitting a partial rather than full EMT. • Secretory/neuroendocrine hints: GCG (pro-glucagon) and SYNGR4 (synaptic-vesicle protein) are sporadically induced in gastrointestinal and pancreatic tumour cells with mixed epithelial–neuroendocrine phenotypes, supporting a heterogeneous, malignant state rather than pure fibroblasts. Inconsistencies: • Classical endocrine markers (e.g., CHGA, PAX6) are absent despite the presence of GCG/SYNGR4, suggesting those two genes may stem from a minor sub-program or contaminating endocrine cells. • Full EMT markers such as VIM, FN1 or SNAI1 are not listed, indicating the transition is partial and may vary across cells.

program_32.description: The gene set is most consistent with a small-intestinal Paneth-like secretory epithelial program, i.e. mature crypt-base cells specialized for antimicrobial peptide release and other secretory functions. Evidence: • Strong Paneth markers – DEFA5 and DEFA6 encode α-defensins that are virtually restricted to small-intestinal Paneth cells. • Secretory peptide-processing machinery – PCSK1 (pro-hormone convertase) and KLK12 (secreted serine protease) fit the high secretory, proteolytic activity of Paneth/secretory epithelial cells. • Secretory support genes – CACNA2D2 (voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channel subunit) and CALD1 (caldesmon, actomyosin regulator) facilitate Ca²⁺-dependent vesicle exocytosis typical of Paneth cells. • Chemokine/defense milieu – Paneth cells can secrete chemokines; CXCL12 aligns with this immune-modulatory role. • No negatively loaded genes oppose a Paneth/secretory identity. Inconsistencies: • CXCL12 is more classically stromal, and SERPINA7 (thyroxine-binding globulin) is mainly hepatic; their presence may reflect ambient RNA or a broader secretory signature rather than strict Paneth specificity.

program_33.description: The expression pattern is most consistent with proliferative/growth-plate chondrocytes (immature cartilage-forming cells engaged in extracellular-matrix production and longitudinal bone growth). Evidence: • Cartilage matrix genes – COL2A1 and COL11A2 are hallmark fibrillar collagens of hyaline cartilage and growth-plate chondrocytes. • Chondrocyte-secreted factors – MIA (CD-RAP) and CTHRC1 are both highly expressed by proliferating/early hypertrophic chondrocytes and promote cartilage matrix remodeling. • Developmental growth factor – IGF2 is abundant in fetal cartilage, driving chondrocyte proliferation and matrix synthesis. • Additional supportive markers – GABRA4 transcripts are detected in growth-plate chondrocytes where GABA signaling modulates proliferation; CAPN6 is expressed in mesenchymal derivatives including developing cartilage. Inconsistencies: • CLDN2 is classically an epithelial tight-junction protein and is not a routine chondrocyte marker. • CAPN6 and GABRA4, while reported in developing cartilage, are more broadly expressed and thus provide weaker, non-specific support.

program_34.description: The gene set is most consistent with hepatocytes engaged in a metabolic-detoxification and oxidative-stress response state, characterized by high metallothionein expression and phase I/II xenobiotic enzymes. Evidence: • Metallothioneins MT1G, MT1M, MT1X, MT2A – classic liver-enriched stress proteins induced by heavy metals and reactive oxygen species. • ADH1C – class I alcohol dehydrogenase γ-chain, strongly expressed in mature hepatocytes for ethanol and retinol metabolism. • UGT2B17 – UDP-glucuronosyltransferase family member mediating phase II conjugation of steroids and xenobiotics in liver. • HMGCS2 – mitochondrial HMG-CoA synthase driving hepatic ketogenesis during fasting and high-fat conditions. • CHP2 – calcium-binding protein enriched in hepatocytes and other high-metabolic epithelia, supporting Na⁺/H⁺ exchanger activity. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; the main limitation is the absence of canonical hepatocyte structural markers (e.g., ALB, APO genes, CYP3A4), but their absence in this short list does not conflict with a hepatocyte stress/metabolic program.

program_35.description: The gene set is most consistent with a biliary epithelial (cholangiocyte) program, reflecting a secretory, Notch-active epithelial state characteristic of intra-hepatic bile duct cells. Evidence: • Biliary transport/secretory machinery – ATP8B1 (apical phospholipid flippase mutated in cholestatic liver disease) and GOLM1/GP73 (highly expressed and secreted by hepatocytes and cholangiocytes during bile duct injury). • Notch signalling hallmark of cholangiocytes – strong expression of the ligand JAG1, required for bile-duct specification and maintenance. • Glycoprotein production typical of ductal epithelium – GALNT1 catalyses O-glycosylation of mucins secreted into bile. • Ion transport and vesicle acidification in duct cells – CLCN3 supports chloride conductance/acidification of secretory vesicles. • Cytoskeletal and adhesion genes supporting epithelial tube structure – MYH9 (non-muscle myosin II-A) and LPP promote actin-based contractility and cell–cell junction integrity seen in ductal epithelium. Inconsistencies: • NBL1 (BMP antagonist) is not specifically linked to cholangiocytes and is more broadly expressed in stromal or endothelial compartments. • MYH9 and LPP are ubiquitous cytoskeletal genes and do not on their own specify biliary identity, though they are compatible with an epithelial program.

program_36.description: The program typifies mature absorptive enterocytes of the distal small intestine/colon that specialize in ion, bile-acid and xenobiotic transport under homeostatic conditions. Evidence: • MS4A12 – colon-restricted calcium channel enriched at the brush border of absorptive colonocytes. • SLC51B (OSTβ) – basolateral bile-acid exporter characteristic of ileal/colonic enterocytes engaged in enterohepatic bile-acid recycling. • SLC9A3 (NHE3) – apical Na⁺/H⁺ antiporter driving salt and water absorption in small-intestinal and colonic epithelium. • TMIGD1 – adhesion/brush-border protein abundant in differentiated intestinal epithelial cells. • MALL – lipid-raft tetraspan protein enriched in polarized epithelial membranes, including gut enterocytes. • SULT1A2 – phase-II sulfotransferase expressed in intestinal epithelium for xenobiotic detoxification. • PKIB – cAMP-dependent kinase inhibitor with high expression in colon, consistent with enterocyte signaling regulation. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes conflict strongly with an intestinal absorptive epithelial identity; PKIB is less tissue-restricted but not contradictory.

program_37.description: The gene set represents a mitochondrial oxidative-metabolism program – high oxidative-phosphorylation and fatty-acid β-oxidation – typical of cells that rely on efficient ATP generation and lipid catabolism (e.g. memory/long-lived immune cells or other quiescent yet metabolically active cell types). Evidence: • NDUFB4 and SLC25A3 – core components of mitochondrial complex I and the phosphate carrier; hallmarks of an OxPhos-high state. • HADHB and ALDH2 – key enzymes of mitochondrial fatty-acid β-oxidation and aldehyde detoxification, respectively, indicating active lipid catabolism. • SCP2 – sterol/long-chain–fatty-acid carrier that shuttles lipids into peroxisomes/mitochondria, reinforcing a lipid-utilisation profile. • ARPC3 and CIB1 – actin-nucleating ARP2/3 subunit and Ca²⁺/integrin-binding protein that promote cytoskeletal remodeling, consistent with metabolically poised, migratory cells that maintain high mitochondrial activity. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes to contradict the interpretation; however, the cytoskeletal genes (ARPC3, CIB1) are not strictly metabolic and could also be expressed in various activated or motile cell types.

program_38.description: The gene set typifies activated, pro-inflammatory myeloid cells—most consistent with disease-associated / inflammatory microglia or closely related inflammatory monocyte-derived macrophages. Evidence: • TYROBP (DAP12), AIF1 (IBA1) and FCER1G form a core microglial/macrophage signaling module that is up-regulated in disease-associated microglia and other activated myeloid cells. • LST1 is a hallmark of monocytes, macrophages and microglia responding to inflammatory cues. • S100A8 (calgranulin A) is strongly induced in inflammatory monocytes and in neuroinflammatory or “DAM” microglial states. • BCL2A1 provides anti-apoptotic support in activated macrophages and neutrophils, fitting an activated, survival-enhanced myeloid program. • SLC2A3 (GLUT3) supplies high glucose uptake typical of metabolically re-programmed, pro-inflammatory macrophages/microglia. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies detected; all listed genes align with an activated inflammatory myeloid (microglial/monocytic) program.

program_39.description: The gene set represents a plasmablast / early plasma-cell program in B-lineage cells that are transitioning from activated/memory B cells to antibody-secreting cells. Evidence: • JCHAIN, MZB1, DERL3 – canonical components of the endoplasmic-reticulum machinery required for high-rate immunoglobulin assembly and secretion; strongly enriched in plasmablasts and plasma cells. • TNFRSF17 (BCMA) – survival receptor selectively up-regulated on plasmablasts and plasma cells. • CD27 – marker of activated and memory B cells that is retained and often further increased during plasmablast differentiation. • CD79A and POU2AF1 – B-cell receptor component and transcriptional co-activator sustaining B-cell identity; their persistence is typical of plasmablasts (lost only in fully mature bone-marrow plasma cells). Inconsistencies: • None prominent; the continued expression of CD79A and POU2AF1 suggests the cells are not terminal bone-marrow plasma cells but earlier plasmablasts, which is compatible with the overall program.

program_40.description: The program represents an inflamed mucosal epithelial cell state—typical of intestinal (and other barrier‐site) epithelial cells exposed to bacterial products or IFN-γ—characterized by reactive-oxygen/nitrogen production and secretion of antimicrobial peptides. Evidence: • DUOX2 & DUOXA2 – dual oxidase complex that generates H₂O₂ for host defence; strongly induced in gastrointestinal and airway epithelium during infection or IFN-γ exposure. • LCN2 (lipocalin-2) and PI3 (elafin) – secreted antimicrobial/antiprotease factors released by activated epithelial cells in gut, lung and skin. • PDZK1IP1 (MAP17) – scaffold protein highly expressed in intestinal and other transporting epithelia, up-regulated under inflammatory conditions. • NOS2 – inducible nitric-oxide synthase frequently induced in epithelial cells by IFN-γ/TNF to produce microbicidal NO. • TNIP3 – NF-κB-responsive negative regulator that dampens TNF-driven inflammation, expressed in activated epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • NOS2 and TNIP3 can also be expressed by activated macrophages, yet classical myeloid markers (e.g., LYZ, CSF1R, CD68) are absent, arguing against a myeloid identity.

program_41.description: The gene set most coherently reflects a general “nuclear RNA-processing / high-transcription” program that is typically up-regulated in highly metabolically active or proliferating cells (e.g., cycling epithelial or tumor cells) rather than marking a specific differentiated lineage. Evidence: • RNA splicing / processing machinery – PNISR, ARGLU1, N4BP2L2 and POLR2J3 are all core components or cofactors of the spliceosome or RNA-polymerase II complex, whose concerted up-regulation is a hallmark of cells with high transcriptional throughput. • Transcription-driving TF – ELF3 is a nucleus-resident ETS family factor that promotes epithelial gene expression programs and is frequently induced during epithelial proliferation or oncogenic transformation, consistent with heightened transcriptional demand. • Organelle trafficking linked to mitosis – HOOK2 participates in centrosome and microtubule organization, functions commonly up-regulated in dividing cells, aligning with a proliferative/high-biosynthetic state. Inconsistencies: • NKTR encodes a membrane receptor preferentially expressed by NK/T lymphocytes; its co-up-regulation is not readily explained by a generic transcription/splicing program and may reflect cell-type heterogeneity or technical noise.

program_42.description: The program represents a generic “oxidative phosphorylation”/high-mitochondrial-respiration state, seen in cell types or conditions that rely heavily on aerobic ATP production (e.g., metabolically active differentiated cells, quiescent memory lymphocytes, or cells undergoing mitochondrial biogenesis). Evidence: • Multiple cytochrome-c-oxidase (complex IV) subunits (COX4I1, COX5B, COX6A1, COX6B1, COX8A) collectively indicate enhanced complex IV assembly and activity, a hallmark of elevated oxidative phosphorylation. • NDUFB2 (complex I) and UQCR11 (complex III) further point to coordinated up-regulation across the electron-transport chain, typical of a high-respiration metabolic program. • Absence of glycolytic or cell-cycle genes supports interpretation as a metabolic, not proliferative, signature. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all genes coherently encode mitochondrial respiratory-chain components.

program_43.description: The program is most consistent with an endoplasmic reticulum (ER) protein-folding / secretory-pathway activation state, as seen when cells expand their ER and Golgi to cope with increased protein synthesis or mild unfolded-protein response (UPR). Evidence: • ER chaperone/quality-control machinery: CANX (calnexin), PDIA3 (ERp57) and MLEC (malectin) act together in the calnexin cycle to fold and retain N-glycosylated proteins. • ER structural expansion: CKAP4 (CLIMP-63) tethers rough ER sheets to microtubules, a hallmark of secretory ER enlargement. • Forward trafficking: COG2 is a core subunit of the conserved oligomeric Golgi complex that receives and sorts newly folded cargo from the ER. • Vesicle/exocytosis support: SYNGR2 localizes to secretory vesicles and promotes exocytic trafficking, downstream of ER-Golgi processing. Inconsistencies: • FOXP1 is a lymphoid transcription factor linked to B- and T-cell differentiation rather than ER stress; its up-loading may reflect the lineage of the cells exhibiting the secretory/UPR program rather than the program itself.

program_44.description: The gene set signifies mature absorptive enterocytes of the small-intestinal epithelium, characterized by brush-border formation and active lipid uptake/β-oxidation metabolism. Evidence: • VIL1 encodes Villin-1, a canonical marker of brush-border intestinal epithelial cells. • ACSL5 is highly enriched in small-intestinal enterocytes where it activates long-chain fatty acids for absorption and metabolism. • HADHA functions in mitochondrial β-oxidation, matching the high fatty-acid catabolic activity of enterocytes. • ACVR1B (ALK4) mediates Activin/TGF-β signals that drive intestinal epithelial differentiation. • PRKAR2A (PKA regulatory subunit) supports cAMP-PKA signaling that modulates enterocyte secretion and metabolism. • SERINC5, while more ubiquitous, shows appreciable expression in epithelial tissues and is not inconsistent with an enterocyte profile. Inconsistencies: No strong contradictions; PRKAR2A and SERINC5 are broadly expressed but do not conflict with an intestinal epithelial identity.

program_45.description: The program most plausibly reflects cells in an active Wnt/β-catenin signaling state accompanied by intensified membrane-trafficking and cytoskeletal-remodeling machinery, a combination often seen in proliferative or migratory epithelial progenitors (e.g., intestinal crypt, basal epidermal, or carcinoma cells initiating EMT-like behavior).
