Evidence: • CTNNB1 (β-catenin) – core effector of canonical Wnt signaling; nuclear accumulation drives progenitor maintenance and EMT onset. • DDX3X – RNA helicase that directly binds and co-activates CTNNB1/TCF transcriptional complexes, enhancing Wnt target expression. • ARF6 & RAB11FIP1 – small GTPase and its effector that recycle Frizzled/LRP receptors and E-cadherin, coupling Wnt activation to dynamic endocytic trafficking. • ARHGAP5 (p190-B RhoGAP) – modulates RhoA to reorganize actin during Wnt-driven cell spreading and migration. • MBNL1 – splicing regulator reported to fine-tune transcripts of Wnt pathway components and cytoskeletal genes during progenitor–to-differentiated transitions. Inconsistencies: • MBNL1 is better known for roles in muscle differentiation; its presence is compatible with, but not diagnostic of, Wnt-active epithelial cells. No other major contradictions noted.

program_46.description: The gene set points to a stress-responsive protein quality-control program—marked by heightened ubiquitination, ER-to-Golgi trafficking, and lysosome/autophagosome activity—rather than to a specific cell lineage. Cells expressing this program are likely in an enhanced autophagy/ER-associated degradation (ERAD) state used to clear misfolded or surplus proteins. Evidence: • RAB7A and LAMP2: core mediators of late endosome–lysosome maturation and autophagosome–lysosome fusion. • BCAP31 and YIPF4: ER/Golgi membrane proteins that escort cargo out of the ER and participate in ERAD-linked apoptosis signaling. • UBE2B and NDFIP2: ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme and NEDD4 adaptor, respectively, driving ubiquitination of proteins destined for proteasomal or lysosomal degradation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent—the positively loaded genes consistently converge on ubiquitin-mediated trafficking and lysosomal degradation pathways; no negatively loaded genes are provided.

program_47.description: The gene set represents a generic “RNA-processing/splicing” program, typical of highly transcriptionally active, proliferative cells such as cycling progenitors or rapidly dividing tumor cells, rather than marking a discrete lineage. The enrichment of multiple core RNA-binding and spliceosome components, together with nuclear transport and chromatin-associated factors, points to a state of elevated pre-mRNA processing and gene expression control. Evidence: • PTBP1, SFPQ, KHDRBS1 (SAM68) – canonical heterogeneous nuclear RNP/splicing factors up-regulated in cycling or stem-like cells to modulate alternative splicing. • KPNB1 – importin-β; mediates nuclear import of many RNA-binding proteins, typically increased in proliferating cells to support high nucleocytoplasmic traffic. • SERBP1 – mRNA-binding protein that stabilizes transcripts during active translation and is over-expressed in dividing or stress-responsive cells. • BRD2 – bromodomain protein that binds acetylated chromatin and promotes transcriptional elongation; frequently up-regulated in cell-cycle–active or malignant cells. Inconsistencies: • No salient inconsistencies; all listed genes coherently support an RNA-processing/proliferative program.

program_48.description: The gene set most consistently fits a transient “early-activation / stress-response” program that can be switched on in many cell types—often epithelial or progenitor‐like cells—when they sense cytokine, MAPK or hypoxic injury signals. It is characterised by simultaneous induction of immediate-early transcription factors (ETS2), mRNA-destabilising AU-rich element binders (ZFP36L1, ZFP36L2), the facultative progenitor factor SOX9, a translation-initiation component (EIF1AX) and the death-receptor TMEM123, together marking cells that are exiting quiescence and adapting to stress rather than defining a fixed lineage. Evidence: • ZFP36L1 & ZFP36L2 – canonical immediate-early genes rapidly induced by MAPK/TNF/IL-1 signalling; regulate mRNA decay during acute activation of epithelial cells, fibroblasts and lymphocytes. • ETS2 – proto-oncogenic ETS-family TF up-regulated within minutes of stress or cytokine exposure; controls inflammatory and proliferative responses downstream of Ras/MAPK. • SOX9 – widely known lineage TF but also re-expressed in injured epithelium (lung, liver, gut) where it marks facultative progenitors entering a repair programme. • TMEM123 (PORIMIN) – interferon- and TNF-responsive surface protein that promotes oncosis/inflammatory cell death, frequently induced in activated immune or damaged epithelial cells. • EIF1AX – core translation initiation factor whose expression rises with other early-response genes to sustain the burst of protein synthesis that accompanies activation. Inconsistencies: • Absence of classical lineage markers (e.g. COL2A1 for chondrocytes, EPCAM/KRTs for epithelia, CD3D/CD68 for immune cells) makes it difficult to pinpoint a single cell type; programme is thus state-, not lineage-specific. • EIF1AX is a ubiquitous housekeeping gene; its presence adds little specificity. • TMEM123 is most cited in immune contexts, whereas SOX9 is largely epithelial, underscoring the cross-lineage nature of this generic stress-activation signature.

program_49.description: The gene set is most compatible with a male germ-cell / late-spermatogenic (spermatid-to-sperm) transcriptional program, albeit with a few contaminating mesenchymal and muscle-related transcripts. Evidence: • Testis-restricted germ-cell genes – FAM9C and TCP11 are both highly and almost exclusively expressed in round/elongating spermatids and mature sperm, marking late steps of spermatogenesis. • Protease implicated in testicular development – PRSS56 shows enriched expression in the testis and has been reported in meiotic and post-meiotic germ cells. • Absence of canonical somatic markers – no strongly loaded epithelial, immune, or endothelial genes accompany the program, supporting a germ-cell identity. Inconsistencies: • FN1 (Fibronectin 1) and APOD (Apolipoprotein D) are typical of fibroblasts, mesenchyme and some glial/adipocyte populations, not germ cells. • TRIM54 is a muscle-specific E3 ubiquitin-ligase abundant in skeletal and cardiac muscle rather than testis. These transcripts likely reflect low-level contamination or technical co-loading rather than the core program.

program_50.description: The program represents epithelial (particularly keratinocyte) cells that are in a strong acute-phase / IL-17– and TNF-driven inflammatory state characterized by secretion of antimicrobial proteins and neutrophil-recruiting chemokines. Evidence: • S100A7 (Psoriasin) – canonical antimicrobial peptide highly induced in inflamed keratinocytes (e.g., psoriasis, IL-17 signaling). • SAA1, SAA2 – acute-phase proteins up-regulated in epithelial cells after IL-1/IL-6/IL-17 stimulation and in psoriatic epidermis. • LCN2 – lipocalin released by epithelial cells upon IL-17/TNF exposure; limits bacterial growth and is abundant in inflamed skin and airway epithelia. • CXCL1 – neutrophil-chemoattractant chemokine produced by keratinocytes and other epithelia during acute inflammation. • C3 – complement component whose expression is induced in inflamed epithelial barriers and synergizes with the other innate immune factors above. The concerted presence of these genes and absence of lineage-specific markers from immune or hepatic cells point to an epithelial, not hepatocyte or neutrophil, origin. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes directly contradict an inflamed epithelial/keratinocyte program; the panel lacks classical structural keratin genes (e.g., KRT14), but this is an absence rather than a conflict.

program_51.description: The gene set denotes a gastric-type secretory epithelial program, characteristic of mucous/foveolar cells (and related metaplastic “goblet-like” cells) that line the stomach and proximal intestine and secrete protective mucins and antimicrobial factors. Evidence: • Gastric mucous/foveolar markers – MUC5AC and TFF2 are canonical secreted mucins/trefoil factors of gastric surface and neck cells; CLDN18 (isoform 2) is a tight-junction protein highly restricted to gastric epithelium. • Secretory/goblet-like support – REG4 is up-regulated in goblet cells and in spasmolytic-polypeptide (TFF2)–expressing metaplasia of the stomach; it co-occurs with TFF2 in gastric injury responses. • Antimicrobial secretory component – LYZ encodes lysozyme, frequently induced in metaplastic gastric glands and other secretory epithelia, providing mucosal defense. • Additional gastric/metaplastic association – NTRK1 is reported in gastric epithelial and SPEM cells and is co-expressed with TFF2/REG4 during mucosal remodeling. Inconsistencies: • LYZ is classically a Paneth cell or myeloid marker, and NTRK1 is better known in neurons; however, both are documented in gastric or metaplastic secretory epithelia, so their presence is not strongly discordant with a gastric mucous/foveolar program.

program_52.description: The program represents a robust interferon-stimulated antigen-processing state—classically seen in myeloid antigen-presenting cells (e.g., dendritic cells or macrophages) or any cell exposed to strong type I/II IFN (especially IFN-γ)—rather than a lineage-defining signature. Evidence: • STAT1 – central transcription factor activated by type I/II interferons, drives expression of multiple ISGs. • NLRC5 – IFN-γ-inducible transactivator of MHC-I genes, essential for antigen presentation. • TAP1 – transporter that loads cytosolic peptides onto MHC-I; strongly up-regulated by IFN-γ. • PARP9 and PARP14 – interferon-inducible ADP-ribosyl transferases that modulate JAK/STAT signaling and enhance ISG transcription. • RNF213 – E3 ligase categorized as an interferon-stimulated gene in macrophages and endothelial cells. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are canonical interferon-responsive, antigen-presentation-related transcripts.

program_53.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic “stem-like / progenitor” transcriptional program characterized by active chromatin remodeling, high translational capacity and cell-cell/exosome signalling rather than with a fully differentiated lineage. Evidence: • Chromatin & epigenetic regulators of stemness – TRIM28 (KAP1) maintains pluripotency and self-renewal in embryonic, neural and hematopoietic stem cells; CHD7 partners with SOX2 in embryonic stem cells and neural crest progenitors. • mRNA processing / translation machinery – EIF3B (eIF3 complex) and PNN (splicing/adhesion protein) are up-regulated in highly proliferative, undifferentiated cells that require elevated protein synthesis and RNA processing. • Stem/progenitor surface marker – CD81 is a tetraspanin enriched on hematopoietic stem cells, mesenchymal stromal cells and many exosome-releasing progenitors, supporting an undifferentiated, communication-competent state. • Signalling/phosphatase control – PPP1R14B modulates PP1 activity during cytoskeletal and cell-cycle events, fitting the heightened regulatory demands of dividing progenitors. Inconsistencies: • No major lineage-specific or mature-cell markers are present, and no negatively loaded genes contradict a stem/progenitor interpretation; however, the set lacks classic proliferation genes (e.g., MKI67), so the program may reflect a poised rather than highly cycling stem state.

program_54.description: The program most closely fits an “immune-cell activation / stress-response” state that is frequently observed in lymphocytes undergoing stimulation or antiviral defense. The genes point to coordinated up-regulation of Hippo-pathway kinase activity (STK4), ubiquitin-mediated signaling (RNF114), lipid-membrane remodeling with viral restriction (SERINC3), RNA surveillance and stress-granule dynamics (STAU1), chromatin/DNA-damage sensing (ZMYND8), and vesicle/lysosome trafficking (TM9SF4), features that together accompany T-cell activation and heightened intracellular stress signaling. Evidence: • STK4 (MST1) – central Hippo-pathway kinase required for T-cell survival, migration, and stress-induced apoptosis. • RNF114 – E3 ubiquitin ligase that potentiates NF-κB and antiviral innate signaling in activated T cells and other leukocytes. • SERINC3 – lipid-incorporating factor that restricts retroviral particle infectivity and is induced in activated lymphocytes. • STAU1 – RNA-binding protein driving Staufen-mediated mRNA decay and stress-granule formation during cellular activation or stress. • ZMYND8 – chromatin reader recruited to DNA-damage sites and transcriptional enhancers during immune-cell stimulation. • TM9SF4 – endo-lysosomal/vesicle protein enriched in myeloid and lymphoid cells, linked to autophagy and phagocytic competence in activated immune cells. Inconsistencies: • The set lacks canonical lymphocyte surface markers (e.g., CD3, CD4, CD8, CD19) or classical interferon-stimulated genes, so the program may represent a generic intracellular stress/activation module rather than a lineage-defining signature. • All listed genes are also expressed in many non-immune cell types, so additional context would be required to assign the program exclusively to lymphocytes.

program_55.description: The gene set best matches mature hepatocytes, particularly a β-catenin–high (pericentral) metabolic state within the liver parenchyma. Evidence: • HNF4A – master transcription factor required for hepatocyte differentiation, lipid and glucose metabolism. • CTNNB1 (β-catenin) – Wnt pathway effector enriched in pericentral hepatocytes and up-regulated during hepatocyte proliferation and xenobiotic metabolism. • PPP1CB – catalytic subunit of protein phosphatase-1 that regulates glycogen phosphorylase/phosphorylase kinase; highly expressed in liver to control glycogen storage. • GOLIM4 – Golgi membrane protein abundant in secretory cells such as hepatocytes, supporting high secretory/trafficking activity of liver cells. • LRRC75A and C1orf56 – broadly expressed but reported transcripts are detectable in normal liver, providing additional though nonspecific support. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; LRRC75A and C1orf56 are not liver-specific, so their presence is neutral rather than supportive.

program_56.description: The program is characteristic of activated, wound-responsive squamous epithelial/keratinocyte cells that are producing pro-inflammatory mediators. Evidence: • KRT17 and KRT6A – keratins induced in basal keratinocytes during wound healing, psoriasis, and other stress states, replacing homeostatic KRT1/10. • ANXA1 – cytosolic phospholipid-binding protein enriched in epithelial cells and up-regulated upon injury to modulate inflammation and membrane repair. • CXCL8 (IL-8) – chemokine secreted by stressed epithelial cells, recruiting neutrophils during tissue damage. • CD55 – complement-regulatory surface protein broadly expressed on epithelial barriers, often elevated during inflammation to protect injured cells. Inconsistencies: No markedly discordant genes in the provided list.

program_57.description: The program represents a posterior HOXB-driven developmental identity that is typically seen in undifferentiated progenitor or stem-like cells originating from mid- to posterior (hindbrain/spinal cord or posterior mesoderm/hematopoietic) regions. High, concerted expression of HOXB3, HOXB5, HOXB6, HOXB8 and HOXB9 is a hallmark of cells retaining embryonic positional identity rather than a mature, lineage-restricted expression pattern. Evidence: • HOXB3, HOXB5 – expressed in early hindbrain/spinal-cord neuroepithelial progenitors and in hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells, conferring stemness and posterior axial identity. • HOXB6 – promotes self-renewal of hematopoietic progenitors and is aberrantly up-regulated in myeloid leukemias, reflecting an immature, developmental transcriptional program. • HOXB8 – enriched in trunk neural‐crest and posterior mesodermal progenitors; experimentally drives expansion of undifferentiated progenitors. • HOXB9 – marks posterior embryonic tissues (tail bud, spinal cord, posterior gut) and is reactivated in stem-like or poorly differentiated adult/tumor cells. • Co-expression of multiple contiguous HOXB genes (3→9) is a classic feature of cells that have maintained HOX cluster colinearity, indicative of developmental positional programming rather than mature tissue specialization. Inconsistencies: No major inconsistencies detected, as no negatively loaded genes were supplied and all positive genes are functionally coherent within the same HOXB positional program.

program_58.description: The gene set reflects a metabolically active, junction-rich state characteristic of cardiomyocytes (or closely related, desmosome-bearing epithelial cells) that are relying on heightened mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and iron uptake to support growth or high contractile workload. Evidence: • UQCRFS1 and DNAJC11 – core components of mitochondrial complex III and the inner-membrane scaffolding complex, respectively; enrichment is typical of cardiomyocytes, which have dense mitochondria and strong OXPHOS demands. • TFRC (CD71) – transferrin receptor needed for iron import; highly expressed in energetically demanding or proliferating cells, including developing/repairing myocardium. • HNRNPAB – RNA-binding/splicing protein up-regulated in cycling or biosynthetically active cells, fitting an active cardiomyocyte state. • PKP2 – desmosomal plakophilin essential for cardiac intercalated discs and for mechanical coupling of cardiomyocytes; its co-loading with mitochondrial genes supports a cardiomyocyte identity rather than a generic proliferative signature. Inconsistencies: • The list contains only five broadly expressed genes and lacks classical sarcomeric markers (e.g., TNNT2, MYH6); thus, while PKP2 steers the interpretation toward cardiomyocytes, the program could in principle mark any desmosome-positive cell type with high mitochondrial activity.

program_0.description: This program marks cells with strongly up-regulated cytosolic translation machinery and concomitant suppression of mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation transcripts, a transcriptional pattern classically observed in highly anabolic, rapidly dividing or recently activated lymphocytes/tumor cells that have shifted toward aerobic glycolysis (“translation-high / OXPHOS-low” state). Evidence: • Robust enrichment of cytosolic ribosomal protein genes (RPL3, RPL7, RPL13A, RPL18A, RPL26, RPS6, RPS14, RPS19, RPS20, RPS25, RPS27, etc.) indicates increased ribosome biogenesis and global protein synthesis. • Presence of TMSB4X, an actin-sequestering protein induced during cell activation, migration and proliferation, fits an anabolic, activated state. • Concerted under-representation of mitochondrially encoded OXPHOS genes (MT-CO1, MT-CO2, MT-CO3, MT-CYB, MT-ATP6, MT-ND3/4/5) is typical of cells that down-weight oxidative phosphorylation in favor of glycolytic metabolism during rapid growth or immune activation. Inconsistencies: • No classic cell-cycle (MKI67, TOP2A) or lineage-specific activation markers are present, so the exact cell lineage cannot be pinpointed; the signature therefore reflects a metabolic/functional state rather than a unique cell type.

program_1.description: The program reflects a high‐translation, ribosome-rich cellular state rather than a lineage-specific identity. Cells scoring highly for this program are likely in a metabolically active or proliferative phase where protein synthesis demand is elevated. Evidence: • Ribosomal protein genes (RPS12, RPS8, RPS15A, RPS23; RPL10, RPL13, RPL37, RPL37A) jointly encode core components of the 40S and 60S ribosomal subunits, a canonical signature of up-regulated ribosome biogenesis and translational capacity. • EEF1A1 encodes a key elongation factor that delivers aminoacyl-tRNAs to the ribosome, rising in parallel with ribosomal protein expression during heightened protein synthesis. Inconsistencies: • No notable gene sets contradict a high-translation program; no lineage-defining or stress/apoptosis markers are present.

program_2.description: The program represents an acute, “immediate-early” activation state typical of recently T-cell-receptor–stimulated T lymphocytes (and, more generally, acutely stimulated immune cells). Evidence: • CD69 – canonical very-early surface marker induced within minutes of TCR/BCR or cytokine stimulation. • FOS, JUNB – AP-1 transcription factors induced by MAPK signaling during early T-cell activation. • IER2, BTG2 – classic immediate-early genes up-regulated on antigen or mitogen stimulation; BTG2 also restrains proliferation, fitting a transient activation phase. • DUSP1 – MAPK phosphatase rapidly induced to dampen ERK/JNK signaling after activation. • NFKBIA – encodes IκBα, an early NF-κB inhibitor transcribed immediately after NF-κB activation to form a negative feedback loop. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes align with an immediate-early activation response.

program_3.description: The program represents a strong MHC-class II antigen-presentation module typical of professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs)—such as dendritic cells, macrophages/monocytes, and B cells—or of other cell types that have been stimulated with IFN-γ to up-regulate MHC-II. It reflects an “APC-activated” state rather than a lineage-specific signature. Evidence: • Core MHC-II α/β chains: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1 – essential for peptide loading and presentation to CD4⁺ T cells. • Antigen-processing chaperones: CD74 (invariant chain) and HLA-DMA – required for proper folding, trafficking, and peptide exchange in MHC-II complexes. • Concerted high expression of the above genes is a canonical hallmark of activated APCs or cells exposed to IFN-γ. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes coherently belong to the MHC-II antigen-presentation pathway.

program_4.description: The program reflects a “mitochondrial-high / stress-response” transcriptional state that is frequently observed in cells with elevated mitochondrial RNA content—often senescing, energetically stressed, or undergoing apoptosis—rather than representing a specific immune or parenchymal cell lineage. Evidence: • Strong positive loading of mitochondrial-encoded ETC genes MT-ND1, MT-ND2 and MT-ND4L indicates relative enrichment of mitochondrial transcripts, a classic signature of cells with high mitochondrial activity or impending cell death in scRNA-seq data. • JUND, an AP-1 family immediate-early factor up-regulated by oxidative stress, hypoxia and other cellular stressors, supports a stress-response state accompanying mitochondrial transcript accumulation. • Negative loading of mast-cell–specific proteases TPSAB1 and TPSB2 indicates that cells exhibiting this program are explicitly not mast cells, reinforcing that the program is driven by metabolic state rather than lineage identity. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; the limited gene set is coherent with a mitochondrial/stress program, although JUND can also be induced by growth signals, which is less specific than the mitochondrial genes.

program_5.description: The gene set represents a generic “interferon-stimulated / antiviral” cell state characterized by strong up-regulation of MHC class I antigen-presentation machinery and classical type I/II interferon response genes; it can be induced in virtually any nucleated cell type upon exposure to IFN-α/β or IFN-γ. Evidence: • HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C together with B2M encode the heavy and light chains of MHC class I complexes, whose transcription is strongly up-regulated by both type I and type II interferons to enhance presentation of intracellular antigens. • ISG15 and IFI6 are canonical interferon-stimulated genes involved in antiviral defense (ISGylation and inhibition of viral replication), marking a robust interferon response. Inconsistencies: • None detected (no negatively loaded genes and all positive genes fit an interferon-induced program).

program_6.description: The gene set represents a generic proliferative / G2-M cell-cycle program that can appear in many dividing cell types; the high expression of microtubule, chromatin-binding and cell-cycle regulatory genes is characteristic of cells actively progressing through late S-phase into mitosis. Evidence: • Cell-cycle structural genes: TUBA1B and TUBB encode α- and β-tubulins that rise during G2/M to assemble the mitotic spindle. • Microtubule dynamics regulator: STMN1 destabilizes microtubules to facilitate spindle reorganization in mitosis; it is a canonical G2/M marker in scRNA-seq datasets. • Chromatin and replication factors: HMGB2 binds chromatin and is enriched in proliferating cells, peaking in S- and G2-phase; EXD3 is implicated in nucleic-acid processing during DNA replication. • Cell-cycle control: CKS1B partners with CDK1/2–cyclin complexes and SCF^SKP2 to drive S-phase completion and G2/M entry. Inconsistencies: No obvious contradictions; all listed genes align with a proliferative cell-cycle signature.

program_7.description: The program represents an acute, pan-cellular heat-shock/proteotoxic stress state rather than a lineage-specific cell type, marked by coordinated up-regulation of inducible cytosolic chaperones (HSP70, HSP40, HSP90 families) and the stress-responsive transcriptional repressor HES1. Evidence: • HSPA1A / HSPA1B – canonical inducible HSP70 genes directly activated by HSF1 during heat, oxidative, or proteotoxic stress to refold mis-folded proteins. • DNAJB1 – an inducible HSP40 co-chaperone that partners with HSP70s to stabilize nascent or damaged polypeptides; co-regulated with HSPA1A/B in heat-shock response. • HSP90AA1 – cytosolic HSP90 isoform transcriptionally induced by HSF1 and essential for folding/stabilizing signaling proteins under stress. • HES1 – although best known as a Notch target, it is also up-regulated by various stressors (heat shock, ER stress) and suppresses differentiation genes, consistent with a transient stress-adapted state. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes align with a generalized heat-shock/proteotoxic stress program.

program_0.description: The program represents a generic, highly proliferative cell-cycle state corresponding to late S through G2/M phases that can be observed in any actively dividing cell population (e.g., cycling stem/progenitor cells, tumor cells, activated lymphocytes). Evidence: • Mitotic markers: MKI67, AURKB, BIRC5, CENPF, CENPA, CENPE/P/U, NUSAP1, TPX2, PRC1, PLK1/4, TTK, BUB1/BUB1B, MAD2L1, ZWINT, SKA1/3 – hallmark genes of chromosome segregation and spindle checkpoint active during G2/M. • Cyclins/CDKs: CCNB1, CCNB2, CCNA2, CDK1, CCNE2, CDCA3, CCNF – drive S-phase completion and G2/M transition. • DNA replication/repair factors: MCM2/4/10, CDC6, CDT1, GINS2/4, RRM2, FEN1, BRCA1, BRIP1, FANCI, POLQ, HELLS – elevated during late S phase. • Transcriptional regulators of proliferation: FOXM1, MYBL2, E2F1/2 – coordinate expression of G2/M gene set. • Cytokinesis and microtubule dynamics: KIF11/14/15/20A/23, KIF2C/4A/18B, ANLN, ASPM, HMMR, DIAPH3, CIT – required for spindle assembly and cell division. • Universal proliferation marker: TOP2A and the absence of lineage-specific transcripts underscores a cell-cycle program rather than a distinct differentiated lineage. Inconsistencies: None apparent; all listed genes consistently define a late S–G2/M cell-cycle signature.

program_1.description: The gene set describes an activated cytotoxic T-cell program most compatible with chronically stimulated / “exhausted” CD8⁺ effector T cells frequently seen in tumours and chronic infection. Evidence: • T-cell identity – CD3D/E/G, CD2, CD7, CD247, LCK, ZAP70, TRAT1, ITK, SKAP1 confirm a T-cell program. • CD8 cytotoxic machinery – CD8A/B together with PRF1, GNLY, GZMA, GZMH, GZMM, CTSW, IFNG, CCL5 point to cytolytic CD8⁺ effector cells. • Chronic activation / exhaustion hallmarks – PDCD1 (PD-1), CTLA4, TIGIT, CD96, TOX, CXCL13, CXCR6, ICOS, TNFRSF4 (OX40), TNFRSF18 (GITR) and NK-like receptors KLRD1, KLRC1/2, KLRB1 are characteristic of exhausted or tissue-resident CD8 T cells. • Supporting transcription factors – BCL11B, ETS1, HOPX, RORA, GATA3, LBH and CRE–responsive kinase CAMK4 are all associated with sustained T-cell activation in chronic antigen settings. Inconsistencies: • FOXP3, IL2RB, CTLA4, GATA3 and ICOS are classical T-regulatory (CD4⁺) markers, suggesting some regulatory–T or helper–T signature is intermixed. • Helper/Tph features (CXCL13, RORA) could reflect CD4 T peripheral helper cells rather than CD8 exhaustion. • Canonical exhaustion genes HAVCR2 (TIM-3) and LAG3 are absent, so the program does not capture the full exhaustion module.

program_2.description: The program reflects a “high-translation” cellular state characterized by up-regulation of structural ribosomal proteins and core translation factors, typical of cells that are metabolically active and/or preparing for proliferation, with concomitant down-regulation of the inflammatory chemokine CXCL1. Evidence: • Strong positive loadings for dozens of cytosolic ribosomal proteins (e.g., RPL10, RPL13, RPS6, RPS3, RPLP1), the elongation factor EEF1A1, and ribosome-associated factors RACK1, UBA52, and FAU collectively indicate enhanced ribosome biogenesis and global protein synthesis. • Absence of lineage-specific markers and predominance of ubiquitous housekeeping genes suggest the program is not tied to a particular differentiated cell type but rather to a general biosynthetic/proliferative state. • Negative loading of CXCL1, an NF-κB–inducible chemokine secreted during inflammatory activation, implies that cells expressing this program are comparatively non-inflammatory and instead devote resources to translation. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; the single negatively loaded gene (CXCL1) is coherent with a shift away from inflammatory signaling toward protein synthesis.

program_3.description: The gene set best fits an activated/cytotoxic plasmacytoid dendritic cell (pDC) program, characteristic of type I-interferon–producing pDCs that have acquired granzyme-mediated cytotoxic potential. Evidence: • Canonical pDC identity: CLEC4C (BDCA-2), LILRA4 (ILT7), TCF4/E2-2, SPIB, PACSIN1, PLD4, TCL1A, BCL11A and IRF8 are signature transcriptional regulators or surface markers of human pDCs. • Interferon/antiviral activation: IRF7, IRF4, TRAF4, SIDT1, PLAC8 and FUT7 are induced during TLR-mediated activation of pDCs and drive type I IFN responses. • Cytotoxic pDC subset: GZMB, CXCR3 and MAP1A are up-regulated in the recently described granzyme-B–positive pDC population capable of target-cell killing. • Secretory/ER expansion accompanying high protein (IFN) production: JCHAIN, MZB1, DERL3 and UGCG mark increased ER and secretory pathway activity in stimulated pDCs. • Additional pDC-enriched genes: LAMP5, SHD, COBLL1, PTCRA, SCAMP5 and P2RY14 are recurrently detected in single-cell pDC clusters across datasets, supporting the assignment. Inconsistencies: • A few genes (e.g. MAP1A, NEK8, CIB2) are more commonly linked to neuronal or ciliary biology; their presence is atypical for pDCs but they are sporadically observed in transcriptomic surveys and do not outweigh the dominant pDC signature.

program_4.description: The gene set is characteristic of mature, CCR7-dependent, LAMP3⁺ migratory dendritic cells that have acquired an immuno-regulatory (“mregDC”) state often observed in lymph-node–homing DCs and in tumor or inflamed tissues. Evidence: • Migration / maturation markers: CCR7, LAMP3, FSCN1, CCL19 — classical signature of DCs that have matured and are trafficking to lymphoid organs. • Antigen presentation / DC lineage: FLT3, HLA-DOB, CST7, EEF1A1, POGLUT1 support a dendritic-cell identity. • Immuno-regulatory molecules: IDO1, EBI3, CCL17, CCL22, CD200, BIRC3, GADD45A — genes enriched in tolerogenic or regulatory DCs that modulate T-cell responses. • Additional mregDC components described in the literature: MARCKSL1, TXN, DUSP5, TREML1, ANXA3, GCSAM, NUB1 – reported in LAMP3⁺ mregDC single-cell signatures. Inconsistencies: • A few transcripts are more typical of mesenchymal or other lineages (ADAM12, LAD1, LYPD3, HOMER2, GPR157, RAMP1, SLCO5A1); these may reflect ambient RNA or low-level, non-specific expression rather than true deviation from the mregDC program.

program_5.description: The gene set represents an NF-κB–driven, pro-inflammatory (M1-like) activation program in monocytes/macrophages, characterized by robust cytokine/chemokine production, glycolytic–oxidative stress adaptation, and tissue-remodeling/angiogenic functions. Evidence: • Cytokine/chemokine storm typical of inflammatory macrophages – IL1A, IL1B, CXCL8 (IL-8), CCL20, TNFSF14, IL1RN. • NF-κB pathway and immediate-early response genes – NFKBIA, TNIP3, IER3, PTGS2, BCL2A1, TAGAP. • Canonical monocyte/macrophage markers or granule proteins – SRGN, CD44, NAMPT, PLAUR, SLC2A3, SOD2. • Metabolic and oxidative-stress regulators induced during M1 polarization – NAMPT (NAD salvage), G0S2 (lipolysis control), SOD2, AQP9, SLC25A37 (iron import), GK. • Matrix remodeling / angiogenesis factors commonly secreted by activated macrophages – MMP1, TIMP1, VEGFA, F3 (tissue factor). Inconsistencies: • TAGAP is more commonly linked to T-cell signaling, though low-level expression is reported in activated monocytes. • CMTM2 and EHD1 are broadly expressed and not specific to macrophages but do not contradict the overall program.

program_6.description: The gene set reflects an activated, pro-inflammatory classical (CD14⁺/FCN1⁺) monocyte / M1-like macrophage state characterized by strong NF-κB signaling and NLRP3-inflammasome activity. Evidence: • Monocyte identity: FCN1, CD300E, SRGN, VCAN, CD55 are markers of classical blood monocytes. • Pro-inflammatory/M1 polarization: IL1B, NLRP3, S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, NAMPT, APOBEC3A, SOCS3, NFKBIA, DUSP1, EREG and THBS1 are induced by TLR/NF-κB signaling and typify M1-like macrophage activation. • Inflammasome & danger response: IL1B, NLRP3, S100A8/A9/A12, FPR2 promote or are downstream of inflammasome activation and alarmin release. • Metabolic re-programming typical of activated monocytes: SLC2A3 (GLUT3) up-regulation supports glycolysis; NAMPT supplies NAD⁺ for high metabolic demand. • Survival of activated myeloid cells: MCL1 (anti-apoptotic) and TIMP1 aid persistence during inflammation. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes; all listed genes are compatible with an activated inflammatory monocyte/macrophage program.

program_7.description: The gene set describes a generic “high-translation/proliferative” cellular state in which cytosolic ribosome biogenesis and global protein synthesis are up-regulated while stress-response and inflammatory programs are suppressed. This pattern is commonly observed in cells that have recently entered the cell cycle (e.g., cycling lymphocytes, expanding progenitors, or tumor cells) rather than pointing to a lineage-specific identity. Evidence: • Strong positive loadings for numerous small- and large-subunit ribosomal protein genes (RPS24, RPS29, RPL4, RPL5, RPL7A, RPL22, RPL30, RPL31, RPL36, RPL36A, RPL38, RPL39) are hallmarks of elevated ribosome biogenesis and translational capacity seen in actively dividing cells. • Negative loadings for oxidative/stress-response genes (PRDX1, S100A11) and protease inhibitors (CSTB) indicate dampened stress signaling, consistent with cells prioritizing growth over defense. • Negative association with inflammatory/immune effector genes (CCL4 chemokine, LGALS1 galectin-1, CAPG macrophage capping protein) supports repression of an immune-activation program, further fitting a proliferative rather than activated immune phenotype. Inconsistencies: • No strongly contradictory lineage markers are present; the negatively loaded immune genes simply underscore the suppression of an alternative program rather than conflicting with the high-translation signature.

program_8.description: The program reflects a classic type I interferon–stimulated antiviral state that can be adopted by many cell types (e.g., epithelial cells, monocytes, dendritic cells) upon viral sensing, marked by broad up-regulation of canonical interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) involved in viral restriction, RNA degradation, and chemokine-mediated immune recruitment. Evidence: • Antiviral restriction factors—ISG15, MX1, RSAD2, IFI6, IFI44L: prototypical ISGs that inhibit viral replication or assembly. • dsRNA sensing/processing—OAS2, OAS3, OASL, CMPK2: activate RNase L pathway or support mitochondrial antiviral signaling after IFN-α/β exposure. • Translational repression—IFIT1, IFIT2, IFIT3: bind 5′-ppp viral RNA and block its translation, hallmark of IFN response. • Negative feedback regulator—USP18: induced by type I IFN to dampen JAK-STAT signaling, confirming an IFN-driven module. • Chemokine genes—CXCL10, CXCL11: STAT1/IRF1-dependent chemokines that recruit CXCR3⁺ T cells/NK cells during IFN responses. • Antimicrobial peptide—DEFB1: inducible by interferons and contributes to broad innate defense. Inconsistencies: No major gene set contradicts a type I interferon program; DEFB1 is less universally classified as an ISG but is reported to be IFN-inducible, so its presence is not discordant.

program_9.description: The program is most consistent with mature, pro-inflammatory neutrophils that are modestly interferon-primed and equipped for Fc-mediated responses and chemokine secretion. Evidence: • Neutrophil identity: FCGR3B (CD16b, neutrophil-restricted Fcγ receptor), PI3/elafin (stored and released by neutrophil granules), PLEK (high in neutrophils and platelets), HCAR2/GPR109A (functional in human neutrophils), RHOH (hematopoietic GTPase enriched in neutrophils). • Pro-inflammatory/chemotactic activity: CCL3L3 (MIP-1α paralog produced by activated neutrophils/monocytes), PHACTR1 (up-regulated in inflammatory myeloid cells), CDC42EP3 & PLEK (actin-cytoskeleton remodeling for degranulation/migration). • Interferon priming: IFITM2 (classical interferon-stimulated gene), MXD1 (Myc antagonist induced by interferon signaling). • Differentiation/activation context: HES4 (Notch target expressed during myeloid maturation), PPIF & KATNBL1 (mitochondrial/cytoskeletal regulators elevated during granulocyte activation). Inconsistencies: • MXD1 and HES4 are broad transcriptional regulators not restricted to neutrophils. • PHACTR1 is also prominent in endothelial cells. • Absence of several canonical neutrophil granule genes (e.g., MPO, ELANE) suggests the program captures an activation module rather than full neutrophil identity, but the dominant markers still favor an activated neutrophil state.

program_10.description: The program represents an MHC-II–high antigen-presenting macrophage/dendritic-cell state, characterised by robust class II antigen-presentation machinery coupled with complement production typical of tissue-resident or activated macrophages. Evidence: • MHC-II antigen presentation: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DQB1, HLA-DMA/B and the invariant chain CD74 collectively signify strong class II peptide loading and presentation, a hallmark of professional antigen-presenting cells. • Complement genes: C1QA, C1QB, C1QC are signature transcripts of tissue-resident macrophages and drive classical complement activation, often co-expressed with high MHC-II in “MHC-II-high” macrophage subsets. • DNASE1L3 is a nuclease secreted predominantly by macrophages and dendritic cells to clear extracellular DNA, further supporting a phagocytic, tolerogenic APC identity. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes align with an antigen-presenting macrophage/dendritic-cell program.

program_11.description: The program is a generic “high-mitochondrial” transcriptomic signature, reflecting cells with elevated expression of mitochondrial genome-encoded oxidative-phosphorylation genes. Such profiles are commonly observed in single-cell data from metabolically active cells or from cells undergoing mitochondrial stress or early apoptosis, rather than marking a specific lineage. Evidence: • MT-CO1, MT-CO2, MT-CO3 – cytochrome-c oxidase subunits (complex IV), up-regulated when oxidative phosphorylation is high or during mitochondrial stress responses. • MT-CYB – complex III component; rises in tandem with other ETC genes during enhanced respiration. • MT-ND1, MT-ND2, MT-ND3, MT-ND4, MT-ND4L, MT-ND5 – complex I subunits; co-induction with CO and CYB genes typifies a coordinated mitochondrial transcriptional burst. • MT-ATP6 – ATP synthase subunit (complex V), further indicating a full ETC/ATP-production program. Collectively, these nuclear-genome-independent transcripts form the canonical mitochondrial readout used in scRNA-seq quality control to flag metabolically hyperactive or stressed/dying cells. Inconsistencies: None apparent; all positively loaded genes encode mitochondrial electron-transport components and are congruent with the described state.

program_12.description: The gene program strongly corresponds to antibody-secreting plasmablasts / mature plasma cells, reflecting the specialized secretory state that follows terminal B-cell differentiation. Evidence: • Canonical plasma-cell surface markers – SDC1 (CD138) and TNFRSF17/BCMA – are hallmark identifiers of mature plasma cells. • Secretory machinery genes – JCHAIN (polymerizes IgA/IgM), MZB1, DERL3 and FKBP11 – are up-regulated during the high endoplasmic-reticulum load of immunoglobulin secretion. • B-cell lineage and plasma survival factors – CD79A (BCR component persisting in plasmablasts), POU2AF1/OBF1 (B-cell transcription co-activator) and PIM2 (pro-survival kinase induced by BCMA signaling) – support an activated, antibody-producing B-cell state. • FCRL5 marks memory-derived plasmablasts and long-lived plasma cells, further reinforcing the plasma-cell identity. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; the entire positively loaded set is coherent with a plasma-cell gene program.

program_13.description: The gene set represents classical CD14⁺/FCN1⁺ inflammatory monocytes that have recently been recruited from blood and are poised for acute innate immune responses. Evidence: • Pro-inflammatory alarmins S100A8, S100A9 and S100A12 are hallmark transcripts of activated classical monocytes and are highly enriched in FCN1⁺ monocyte clusters in infection and sepsis scRNA-seq studies. • FCN1 (Ficolin-1) specifically marks blood-derived classical monocytes, distinguishing them from tissue macrophages and non-classical (CX3CR1⁺) monocytes. • SELL (CD62L) is retained on naïve circulating monocytes and is down-regulated after tissue entry, consistent with a recently recruited state. • MNDA, VNN2 and RBP7 are myeloid-restricted genes repeatedly co-expressed with FCN1 and S100A8/9 in inflammatory monocyte signatures. • RGS2 and FOLR3 are up-regulated during monocyte activation and are part of the “MS1/FCN1” monocyte program described in acute viral infection and severe inflammation. Inconsistencies: • S100A8/S100A9/S100A12 are also abundant in neutrophils; however, classic neutrophil granule genes (e.g., MPO, ELANE, PRTN3) are absent, favoring a monocyte rather than a neutrophil identity.

program_14.description: The gene set represents a classic heat-shock/proteotoxic stress response program that can be transiently activated in virtually any cell type when exposed to acute thermal, oxidative, or proteasome stress, rather than marking a specific lineage. Evidence: • Canonical inducible HSP70 family members HSPA1A, HSPA1B and HSPA6 are hallmark targets of the heat-shock transcription factor HSF1. • Major chaperones and co-chaperones HSP90AA1, HSPH1 (HSP110), DNAJB1 and DNAJA4 coordinate protein refolding during proteotoxic stress. • Small heat-shock protein HSPB1 (HSP27) stabilizes denatured proteins and prevents aggregation under stress. • BAG3 partners with HSP70s to drive selective autophagy of damaged proteins, a process up-regulated during sustained stress. • ZFAND2A (AIRAP) is induced by HSF1 and assists the proteasome in clearing misfolded proteins during heat or oxidative insult. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are coherent with a heat-shock/chaperone response.

program_15.description: The program aligns with an activated, lipid-handling, lysosome-enriched myeloid state characteristic of disease-associated microglia (DAM) or lipid-associated macrophages (LAM), in which phagocytosis, cholesterol transport, and interferon-linked stress responses are up-regulated. Evidence: • Lysosomal / phagolysosomal enzymes – CTSD, CTSB, CTSZ, PSAP: hallmark of microglial/macrophage activation and debris clearance. • Lipid transport and cholesterol efflux – APOE, APOC1, PLD3: classic DAM/LAM signature genes involved in processing lipids derived from apoptotic cells or myelin. • Stress / immune signaling – NUPR1 (cell-stress transcription factor), IFI27 (type I interferon–inducible): consistent with microglial activation during neuroinflammation or macrophage response to tissue damage. Inconsistencies: • No prominent contradictions; all listed genes fit a lysosome- and lipid-rich activated myeloid profile.

program_16.description: The program reflects an inflammatory, chemokine-secreting monocyte / macrophage state (often termed “CXCL chemokine or CCL3+ inflammatory macrophages”), characterized by strong production of neutrophil-attracting CXC chemokines and other pro-inflammatory mediators. Evidence: • CXCL2, CXCL3, CXCL5 – canonical neutrophil-recruiting chemokines produced by activated monocytes/macrophages during acute inflammation. • CCL3 – hallmark cytokine of M1-like / pro-inflammatory macrophages that attracts additional myeloid cells. • SLAMF9 – surface receptor enriched in tissue and inflammatory macrophages and dendritic cells, low or absent in non-myeloid lineages. • INHBA (Activin A) – induced in classically activated (LPS/IFN-γ) macrophages and tumor-associated inflammatory macrophages. • FTH1 and MT2A – stress-response and metal-binding genes commonly up-regulated in activated macrophages to buffer iron and oxidative burden during inflammation. • ANGPTL4 – hypoxia-/inflammation-induced secreted factor expressed by macrophages and linked to vascular remodeling in inflamed or tumor tissues. Inconsistencies: • ANGPTL4 and INHBA can also be produced by endothelial cells or fibroblasts; however, their co-occurrence with multiple macrophage-restricted chemokines (CXCL2/3/5, CCL3) and SLAMF9 supports a macrophage origin.

program_17.description: The gene set represents a classic “immediate-early” activation program—seen in many cell types shortly (minutes–hours) after stimulation by growth factors, cytokines, antigen-receptor ligation, stress, or MAPK/ERK signaling. It marks cells that have recently sensed an external cue and initiated rapid transcriptional remodeling, rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • Core AP-1/IEG transcription factors FOS, FOSB, JUNB and regulator EGR1 are hallmarks of the canonical immediate-early response. • Dual-specificity phosphatases DUSP1 and DUSP2 are typical feedback inhibitors induced by MAPK activation, further indicating acute signaling. • RNA-destabilizing/anti-proliferative factors ZFP36, BTG2 and IER2 are well-documented components of stimulus-responsive early gene waves that temper downstream transcription. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes cohere with an immediate-early activation/stress response program.

program_18.description: The program typifies an alternatively-activated (M2-like), tissue-resident macrophage state exemplified by LYVE1⁺/FOLR2⁺/STAB1⁺ interstitial macrophages that support immune regulation, angiogenesis and tissue repair. Evidence: • FOLR2, STAB1, DAB2, F13A1 – canonical markers of M2 or tissue-resident macrophages (FOLR2⁺ “repair” macrophages in placenta, lung, liver; STAB1/F13A1 enriched in anti-inflammatory macrophages). • LYVE1 – defines a conserved subset of perivascular, homeostatic resident macrophages in lung, heart and adipose tissue. • IGF1 and CXCL12 – growth/chemotactic factors secreted by reparative macrophages to promote angiogenesis and fibroblast recruitment. • PDK4 – shifts macrophage metabolism toward fatty-acid oxidation, a hallmark of alternatively-activated macrophages. • MAMDC2 – reported in LYVE1⁺ macrophage clusters and other vascular-associated immune cells, fitting a tissue-resident, pro-repair role. Inconsistencies: • CXCL12 and MAMDC2 can also be produced by endothelial or stromal cells; however, both are documented in LYVE1⁺/FOLR2⁺ macrophages, so this is a minor ambiguity rather than a contradiction.

program_19.description: The program reflects a metal-ion/oxidative-stress response state rather than a specific lineage; the coordinated up-regulation of multiple metallothionein (MT) family members (MT1A/1E/1F/1G/1H/1M/1X and MT2A) is characteristic of cells that have sensed elevated Zn²⁺/Cu²⁺ or toxic metals or are counteracting reactive oxygen species. Such “MT-high” programs are widely observed across epithelial, immune and stromal cells in single-cell datasets and denote a general cytoprotective, stress-adaptation state. Evidence: • All positively loaded genes encode metallothioneins (MT1A, MT1E, MT1F, MT1G, MT1H, MT1M, MT1X, MT2A), whose well-established roles are chelation of heavy metals and scavenging of free radicals, hallmarks of metal-induced or oxidative stress responses. • The simultaneous induction of several MT1 family paralogs together with MT2A is a canonical transcriptional signature triggered by MTF1 activation during Zn²⁺/Cd²⁺ exposure, glucocorticoid signalling, or inflammatory cytokines—conditions that elicit a generalized stress program independent of cell identity. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded or discordant genes are present; the program is internally consistent with a metallothionein-driven stress response.

program_20.description: The gene set is most consistent with an SPP1-high, matrix-remodeling tumor-/injury-associated macrophage state that produces chemokines (CXCL5), expresses immune-modulatory enzymes (NT5E/CD73), and secretes extracellular-matrix–degrading proteases (MMP1), a profile described for macrophages in fibrotic or hypoxic tumor microenvironments. Evidence: • SPP1 (osteopontin) – canonical marker of pro-fibrotic/tumor-associated macrophages that drive tissue remodeling. • CXCL5 & CLEC5A – chemokine and myeloid C-type lectin, respectively, both enriched in inflammatory macrophage subsets and implicated in neutrophil recruitment and cytokine production. • MMP1 – collagenase produced by macrophages engaged in extracellular-matrix turnover within tumors or healing tissues. • NT5E (CD73) – ectonucleotidase frequently up-regulated on immunosuppressive TAMs, generating adenosine in the microenvironment. • CA12 – hypoxia/HIF-responsive carbonic anhydrase reported in macrophages residing in low-oxygen tumor regions, supporting pH regulation. Inconsistencies: • SCG5 is classically neuroendocrine; its presence is atypical for macrophages and may reflect low-level ambient RNA or a mixed program.

program_21.description: The gene set reflects an activated innate myeloid-cell program characteristic of phagocytic monocytes/macrophages (and closely related microglia or dendritic cells) engaged in Fc-receptor-mediated signaling, oxidative burst, and antigen processing. Evidence: • FCER1G (Fc-receptor γ chain) – core adaptor for Fcγ/ε receptors, highly expressed in monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells, driving antibody-dependent phagocytosis. • TYROBP (DAP12) – immunoreceptor adaptor used by TREM2, SIRPβ1, and other myeloid receptors; enriched in tissue macrophages/microglia during activation. • CYBA (p22phox) – essential subunit of the NADPH-oxidase complex that generates reactive oxygen species in professional phagocytes. • CD63 – lysosomal/degranulation tetraspanin that marks phagosome maturation and granule exocytosis in neutrophils, macrophages, and mast cells. • NPC2 – lysosomal cholesterol-handling protein up-regulated in lipid-processing macrophages and microglia. • B2M – β2-microglobulin, part of MHC-I, consistent with antigen-presenting function of activated myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: No notable discordant genes; all listed genes align with an activated phagocytic myeloid profile.

program_22.description: The program is most consistent with an activated, pro-inflammatory neutrophil state, characterized by strong G-CSF (CSF3) responsiveness and heightened cytokine/innate immune signaling. Evidence: • Neutrophil lineage markers – CSF3R (G-CSF receptor, essential for granulocytic maturation), CEACAM3 (neutrophil-specific phagocytic receptor). • Cytokine and LPS-responsive genes typical of activated neutrophils – LITAF (drives TNF-α production after LPS), OSM (pro-inflammatory cytokine released by neutrophils), IL1R2 (decoy IL-1 receptor highly induced in activated neutrophils, limits IL-1 signaling). • Signal-transduction adaptor found in Fc-receptor signaling in granulocytes – LCP2/SLP-76, which is expressed at lower levels in resting neutrophils but up-regulated during activation. Inconsistencies: • LCP2 is classically associated with T-cell signaling; its inclusion could reflect minor T/NK contamination or cross-lineage expression rather than a purely neutrophil-restricted program.

program_23.description: The gene set reflects an NF-κB–driven, pro-inflammatory activation program typical of LPS/TNF-stimulated monocytes–macrophages that are simultaneously primed for NLRP3 inflammasome assembly and acute-phase mediator release. Evidence: • TNFAIP3 (A20) and NFKBIZ (IκBζ) – canonical immediate-early NF-κB target genes that regulate feedback control after TLR/TNF signaling in activated myeloid cells. • NLRP3 – hallmark sensor of the NLRP3 inflammasome, predominantly expressed and inducible in activated monocytes/macrophages. • PTX3 – soluble pattern-recognition molecule secreted by inflammatory macrophages and dendritic cells during acute innate immune responses. • EREG – EGFR ligand up-regulated downstream of NF-κB in LPS-treated macrophages, linking inflammation to tissue repair. • PNRC1 – transcriptional co-activator whose expression rises with interferon/TLR stimulation in myeloid cells, supporting an activated innate immune context. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes contradict a myeloid inflammatory activation program, though PNRC1 and EREG can also be induced in non-myeloid cells under NF-κB–activating conditions.

program_24.description: The gene set is most consistent with a skin‐resident Langerhans cell / conventional dendritic cell type 2 (cDC2) program, reflecting antigen-presenting cells specialized for lipid antigen loading and high FcεRI-mediated allergen sensing. Evidence: • Lipid-antigen presentation – strong expression of CD1 family members CD1A, CD1C, and CD1E, hallmark molecules used by Langerhans cells and cDC2 for presenting glycolipids. • Langerhans cell marker – CD207 (langerin) is largely restricted to epidermal Langerhans cells and a small cDC2 subset. • High-affinity IgE receptor – FCER1A is highly expressed in cDC2/Langerhans cells, enabling allergen capture. • Dendritic-cell-associated signaling – PKIB is up-regulated in activated human dendritic cells, supporting a DC identity. Inconsistencies: • PKIB is not exclusive to dendritic cells; its presence is supportive but not specific. No negatively loaded genes conflict with the assignment.

program_25.description: The gene set reflects a canonical mature B-cell identity program characterized by expression of B-cell receptor (BCR) components and BAFF-dependent survival signaling, typical of naïve or memory B cells that have not differentiated into plasma cells. Evidence: • Core BCR complex – CD79A, CD79B and MS4A1 (CD20) mark surface BCR-bearing, non-plasma B cells. • VPREB3 encodes a surrogate light-chain–associated protein still detectable in transitional/early mature B cells and some memory B cells, supporting a pre-plasma, BCR-positive state. • TNFRSF13C (BAFF-R) provides BAFF-mediated survival signals required by mature naïve and memory B cells. • BANK1 is an adaptor that amplifies BCR signaling in mature B cells, further reinforcing the activated yet non-plasmacytic B-cell signature. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes align with a mature, non-plasma B-cell program.

program_26.description: The gene set represents a secretory antimicrobial program characteristic of small-intestinal Paneth-like epithelial cells engaged in injury- or inflammation-induced regeneration. Evidence: • Core Paneth‐cell antimicrobials: DEFA5 (α-defensin 5), REG3A, REG1A, REG1B—classically enriched in Paneth cells and up-regulated after bacterial exposure or epithelial damage. • Additional epithelial antibacterial factors: LCN2 (lipocalin-2) sequesters bacterial siderophores and is induced in Paneth/enterocyte lineages during inflammation. • Secretory/defense regulator: SPINK4, although better known as a goblet-cell product, is co-expressed with REG family genes in inflamed crypt epithelium, supporting a broader secretory defense state. Inconsistencies: • SPINK4 is more typical of goblet cells than Paneth cells, suggesting the program may reflect a mixed or transitional secretory state rather than a pure Paneth signature.

program_27.description: The gene set most closely matches a CCR6⁺ NDRG2⁺ conventional dendritic cell‐2 (cDC2) program typical of mucosal tissues, particularly the gut/skin, where these cells secrete the IL-22 decoy receptor IL22RA2 (IL-22BP) to modulate type-17 immunity. Evidence: • CCR6 – chemokine receptor that defines a subset of CD1c⁺/cDC2 dendritic cells that home to CCL20-rich mucosal sites. • NDRG2 – canonical marker of human and murine cDC2, highly expressed relative to monocytes and cDC1. • IL22RA2 – encodes IL-22BP; its predominant producers in vivo are mucosal conventional DCs and some macrophages, consistent with a cDC2 identity. • PARM1 – reported in scRNA-seq studies as enriched in intestinal CD1c⁺ DCs; fits with a mucosal DC transcriptional profile. • GNAO1 – broadly expressed G-protein α-subunit but included in published DC transcriptional signatures, supporting (though not specific for) a dendritic lineage. Inconsistencies: • CCR6 is also expressed by Th17/memory T cells, and PARM1 is noted in certain epithelial cells, so without additional T- or epithelial-specific transcripts their presence alone could be ambiguous. • GNAO1 has high neuronal expression; its inclusion is non-specific and contributes limited discriminatory power for dendritic cells.

program_28.description: This program reflects the presence of a Y-chromosome–encoded transcriptional module, identifying cells that originate from male individuals rather than a specific lineage or activation state. Evidence: • All positively loaded genes (DDX3Y, RPS4Y1, KDM5D, ZFY, USP9Y) are located on the Y chromosome and are routinely used as markers to distinguish male from female cells in single-cell RNA-seq datasets. • Functions of these genes (RNA helicase DDX3Y, ribosomal protein RPS4Y1, histone demethylase KDM5D, transcription factor ZFY, and de-ubiquitinase USP9Y) are broad and not restricted to any particular differentiated cell type, supporting the interpretation that the module reports donor sex rather than a lineage-specific state. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes are provided, and no positively loaded genes conflict with a Y-chromosome identity; hence no inconsistencies are apparent.

program_29.description: The gene set reflects a lysosome- and catabolism-focused stress program that is classically up-regulated during cellular senescence or other states with high degradative demand (e.g., aged fibroblasts or phagocytic/repair macrophages). The enrichment of lysosomal hydrolases together with enzymes involved in protein and tRNA turnover points to cells responding to accumulated macromolecular damage rather than to a lineage-specific differentiation signal. Evidence: • GLB1 encodes β-galactosidase, the enzymatic source of the canonical SA-β-Gal activity used to identify senescent cells. • FUCA2 encodes lysosomal α-L-fucosidase; increased expression of multiple lysosomal acid hydrolases is a hallmark of senescence and other catabolic states. • PEPD (prolidase) participates in peptide and collagen breakdown and is up-regulated in fibroblasts undergoing matrix remodeling or senescence. • ADAT2 and QTRT2 modify tRNAs (inosine and queuosine formation, respectively), processes that rise during integrated stress responses to maintain translational fidelity under damage conditions. Inconsistencies: No obvious lineage-specific markers or proliferation genes are present; the list uniformly supports a catabolic/senescent stress program.

program_30.description: The program most closely matches a proliferative neural-progenitor–like state characterized by active chromatin remodeling / RNA splicing and extensive cytoskeletal-vesicular trafficking. Evidence: • Cell-cycle & chromatin: SON (splicing factor required for S-phase progression) and ATRX (SWI/SNF-like chromatin remodeler needed during DNA replication) are typically up-regulated in dividing neural precursors. • Cytoskeleton / migration: KTN1 (kinesin receptor on ER–microtubule interface) and CCDC88A/Girdin (actin cytoskeleton organizer driving neuroblast migration) support the high trafficking and motility seen in neural progenitors. • Signal transduction: GNB1 (G-protein β-subunit) couples surface receptors to downstream pathways that regulate neural precursor proliferation and guidance. Inconsistencies: • All listed genes are broadly expressed “house-keeping” factors; their presence alone cannot exclude other rapidly dividing cell types (e.g., cycling epithelial or hematopoietic cells).

program_31.description: The gene set points to a tissue-resident / alternatively activated (M2-like) macrophage program characterized by robust lysosomal proteolysis and iron recycling activity. Evidence: • Lysosomal proteases for antigen processing – LGMN (legumain) and CTSC (cathepsin C) are classical markers of macrophage endo-lysosomal compartments. • Additional lysosomal hydrolase – FUCA1 (α-L-fucosidase) supports an expanded degradative/-glycan-turnover capacity typical of mature macrophages. • Macrophage surface marker – MS4A4A is preferentially expressed by tissue-resident and M2-polarized macrophages (and microglia), reinforcing a macrophage identity. • Iron export – SLC40A1 (ferroportin) is a hallmark of macrophages engaged in iron recycling after erythrophagocytosis, consistent with a homeostatic, non-inflammatory state. Inconsistencies: • No notable genes conflict with a macrophage lysosomal/iron-handling program.

program_0.description: The gene set represents a universal high-proliferation program characteristic of cells in late S phase through G2/M, rather than any lineage-restricted identity. Cells scoring highly for this program are actively cycling and preparing for or undergoing mitosis. Evidence: • DNA replication/late-S genes: RRM1, RRM2, TK1, TYMS, DHFR, LIG1, CDT1, MCM-interactors (GINS2, CLSPN) mark ongoing DNA synthesis and replication licensing. • G2/M checkpoint and mitotic kinases: CDK1, CCNA2, CCNB2, PLK1, AURKA, AURKB, CHEK1 drive G2 entry, checkpoint control and mitotic progression. • Chromosome condensation, segregation and spindle assembly: NCAPG, NCAPD2, CENPA, CENPF, CENPE, CENPW, NDC80, KIF11, KIF20B, BUB1, BUB1B, MAD2L1, CDC20, SGO1/2, SPC25, TROAP ensure proper kinetochore attachment and chromatid separation. • Cytokinesis and mid-body components: PRC1, RACGAP1, CEP55 coordinate cytokinesis. • Proliferation markers: MKI67 (Ki-67), BIRC5 (Survivin), FOXM1, MYBL2, HMGB2 are canonical hallmarks of actively dividing cells. • DNA repair and replication stress responders (BRCA1, RAD51AP1, ATAD5) reflect heightened demand for genome maintenance during rapid cycling. Inconsistencies: No obvious lineage-specific or quiescence-associated genes are present, and no negatively loaded genes were supplied, so no major inconsistencies with a generic G2/M proliferation program are evident.

program_1.description: The gene loadings describe a generic “high-translation” cellular program marked by coordinated up-regulation of cytosolic ribosomal proteins and elongation factors, typical of cells that have recently boosted global protein synthesis, while transcripts characteristic of mature secretory/intestinal epithelial differentiation are concurrently suppressed. Evidence: • Strong positive enrichment for ribosomal protein genes (RPL10, RPL13A, RPS6, RPS18, RPL3, RPLP0, RPS27A, etc.) together with translation factors (EEF1A1, EEF2, EEF1D) and the ribosome-associated scaffold RACK1 ⇒ classic signature of elevated translational capacity. • SLC25A6 (mitochondrial ADP/ATP carrier) and CIRBP/TPT1 (stress-responsive RNA-binding proteins) frequently accompany global translational up-shift. • Negative loadings include XBP1, AGR2, CEACAM6, KRT20, REG4, GPRC5A and S100P ⇒ genes enriched in differentiated secretory or absorptive intestinal epithelial cells; their down-regulation fits a state in which lineage-specific secretory programs are dialed down while general protein synthesis is ramped up. Inconsistencies: • JCHAIN (plasma-cell immunoglobulin component) and GUCA2A/B, FABP1, FXYD3 (intestinal epithelial transcripts) are positively loaded, indicating some mixing of lineage-specific mRNAs with the ribosomal set. • Absence of classic proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, TOP2A) means the program reflects increased translation rather than an outright cell-cycle state.

program_2.description: The gene set reflects an activated, interferon-responsive cytotoxic CD8⁺ T-cell program with features of tissue-resident/effector memory cells. Evidence: • Pan-T identity: CD3D/E/G, CD2, CD247, LCK, FYN, FYB1, PTPRC demonstrate T-cell lineage. • Cytotoxic machinery: PRF1, GNLY, GZMA, GZMM, NKG7, CST7, CCL4, CCL5, KLRD1 mark perforin–granzyme–armed effector cells, typical of CD8⁺ cytotoxic T lymphocytes. • CD8 lineage support: CD8A, CD8B, ZEB2, ID2, ETS1, BCL11B drive CD8 effector differentiation. • Tissue-resident / effector-memory traits: ITGA1 (CD49a), CXCR6, S100A4, RIPOR2, MAF together with reduced co-stimulatory molecules (TMIGD2 present but CD28 absent) align with TRM/Tem phenotypes. • Activation & interferon response: IL32, TNFAIP3, IFI44, LGALS9, BATF, REL, PTGER4 indicate recent stimulation and exposure to type-I/II IFN. • Survival and homeostatic memory: IL7R, CXCR4, CCR7, SELL, GIMAP family genes support a memory cell pool rather than short-lived terminal effectors. Inconsistencies: • CCR7 and SELL are typically low in fully differentiated TRM/Tem cytotoxic cells, suggesting some central-memory contamination or partial activation state. • KLRB1 (CD161) and CXCL13 are more characteristic of MAIT/Tfh-like cells, and CD4 is present, indicating minor non-CD8 subsets within the program.

program_3.description: The gene pattern represents a mitochondrial-stress / early apoptotic program that can appear in multiple cell types, typified by high expression of mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation transcripts and concurrent suppression of cytosolic ribosomal genes, reflecting metabolic stress and global translational shutdown. Evidence: • Strong positive loadings for mitochondrial-encoded OXPHOS mRNAs (MT-CO1/2/3, MT-ND1/3/4/4L/5, MT-ATP6, MT-CYB) are a canonical signature of cells in mitochondrial hyperactivity or damage, often observed just before or during apoptosis in single-cell data. • TXNIP (redox sensor that rises with oxidative stress and promotes apoptosis) and JUND (AP-1 factor that is up-regulated in response to mitochondrial reactive-oxygen species) reinforce a stress–response context. • Negative loadings for ribosomal proteins RPS17 and RPS26 fit the expected global repression of cytoplasmic translation that accompanies integrated stress responses and early apoptotic states. Inconsistencies: • OLFM4 is a marker for intestinal stem/progenitor cells and certain neutrophil subsets; its presence is not directly linked to mitochondrial stress and may reflect the tissue origin of the stressed cells rather than the stress program itself. • GNAS and DDX17 are broadly expressed signaling/RNA-processing genes whose inclusion is neutral with respect to a stress/apoptotic interpretation.

program_4.description: Gene expression points to conventional B lymphocytes that have up-regulated the antigen-presentation machinery—i.e., MHC-II-high, CD20⁺/CD22⁺ naïve or early-activated B cells poised for T-cell interaction rather than plasma-cell differentiation. Evidence: • B-cell identity: MS4A1 (CD20), CD22, TCL1A, BCL11A and LAPTM5 are hallmarks of mature but non-plasma B cells. • Antigen-presentation/activation state: Coordinated elevation of multiple HLA class II genes (HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1, ‑DPA1, ‑DPB1, ‑DQA1, ‑DQB1, HLA-DMB) plus CD83 indicates an activated/APC-competent phenotype. • Transcriptional support: IRF8 and LY86 are expressed in B cells during immune activation and enhance MHC-II expression; ARHGAP24 is linked to cytoskeletal changes during B-cell activation. Inconsistencies: • Minor: IRF8 and LY86 can also be found in dendritic or myeloid cells, and ARHGAP24 is not B-cell specific, but these do not outweigh the strong B-cell–specific and MHC-II signature.

program_5.description: The program reflects a generic “high-translation” state characterized by enhanced ribosome biogenesis and protein synthesis, a signature commonly seen in actively cycling or metabolically activated cells irrespective of lineage (e.g., proliferating stem/progenitor cells, activated lymphocytes, or rapidly growing tumor cells). Evidence: • Ribosomal large-subunit genes RPL5, RPL7A, RPL24, RPL28, RPL29, RPL30, RPL37 – hallmarks of increased ribosome production. • Ribosomal small-subunit genes RPS7, RPS8, RPS21, RPS24, RPS28 – together indicate coordinated up-regulation of both ribosomal subunits. • Translation elongation/auxiliary factors EEF1B2 (elongation factor) and NACA (nascent-polypeptide associated complex) further support elevated translational activity. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes fit a unified protein-synthesis/translation program.

program_6.description: The program corresponds to professional antigen-presenting macrophages (e.g., tissue-resident or inflammatory macrophages/microglia) in an MHC-II-high activation state. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: strong up-regulation of HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DPA1 indicates high surface MHC class II, characteristic of activated macrophages engaging in CD4⁺ T-cell stimulation. • Core myeloid markers: LYZ (lysozyme), AIF1/IBA1, TYROBP (DAP12), MS4A6A, FCER1G and LST1 are canonical genes of monocytes, macrophages and microglia. • Complement production: C1QA, C1QB, C1QC are hallmark transcripts of tissue-resident macrophages/microglia involved in synapse pruning and immune surveillance, further supporting a macrophage identity. Inconsistencies: No notable genes conflict with a macrophage/MHC-II-high state; all listed genes fit this identity.

program_7.description: The gene constellation represents an activated CD4⁺ T-helper program, skewed toward B-cell–helping effector states (Th2/early T-follicular-helper), characterised by strong T-cell–receptor (TCR) signaling, co-stimulation, and cytokine-inducible immune effector genes. Evidence: • Core TCR-signaling kinases and adaptors (ZAP70, ITK, SH2D1A, SH2D2A) – hallmarks of recently stimulated T cells. • Co-stimulatory/adhesion molecules (CD6, CD40LG) – CD40LG is specifically induced on activated CD4⁺ T cells that deliver help to B cells. • Lineage-defining transcription factor GATA3 – drives Th2 differentiation and is expressed in many helper subsets early after activation. • Interferon-inducible effector GBP2 and the cytoskeletal regulator IPCEF1 – commonly up-regulated in activated lymphocytes. Inconsistencies: • GBP2 is more typical of IFN-γ-driven (Th1) responses, introducing a modest lineage-mixing signal. • TTC39C has limited functional annotation in T cells, so its presence is not clearly explained by this program.

program_8.description: The gene set defines mature, IgE-receptor–high mast cells in an activated/degranulation-competent state. Evidence: • Mast-cell–restricted proteases TPSB2, TPSAB1 and CPA3 are the canonical markers that distinguish mast cells from basophils and other myeloid cells. • KIT (CD117) is the lineage-defining receptor tyrosine kinase for tissue-resident mast cells. • MS4A2 (FCER1B) and FCER1G encode two subunits of the high-affinity IgE receptor (FcεRI), indicating cells poised for IgE-mediated activation. • ALOX5AP (FLAP) and ANXA1 participate in leukotriene synthesis and granule exocytosis regulation, respectively, consistent with an activation-competent mast-cell state. • CLU and GLUL have reported expression in activated or tissue-embedded mast cells, fitting a mature tissue-resident phenotype. Inconsistencies: • GLUL and CLU are not mast-cell-specific and are expressed in multiple lineages, but their presence does not conflict with a mast-cell identity; they simply add metabolic/secretory features that are less diagnostic.

program_9.description: The program represents an Immediate-Early/acute stress-response state common to many cell types, marked by rapid AP-1, NF-κB and ATF transcriptional activation and a transient growth-arrest signal. Evidence: • Canonical immediate-early transcription factors JUN, JUNB, FOS, IER2 and EGR1 are rapidly induced within minutes of growth-factor, cytokine, or stress stimulation. • NFKBIA (IκBα) is a direct NF-κB target that rises quickly after inflammatory cues, fitting an early activation profile. • ATF3 cooperates with AP-1 and NF-κB during cellular stress and inflammation. • DUSP1 terminates MAPK signaling, a hallmark feedback component of the immediate-early module. • PPP1R15A (GADD34) is up-regulated by the integrated stress response to restore translation after eIF2α phosphorylation. • CDKN1A (p21) provides the transient cell-cycle arrest often accompanying acute stress signaling. Inconsistencies: None recognized; all listed genes are coherent with an immediate-early/stress-induced activation program.

program_10.description: The program represents an unfolded-protein-response (UPR) / endoplasmic-reticulum (ER) stress module that is typically up-regulated in highly secretory B-lineage cells, such as plasmablasts and plasma cells, which must expand ER capacity and ER-associated degradation to cope with massive immunoglobulin synthesis. Evidence: • Secretory B-cell marker – MZB1 is an ER co-chaperone uniquely enriched in plasmablasts/plasma cells and required for efficient IgM/IgA assembly. • Core UPR / ER chaperones – HSP90B1 (GRP94), PRDX4, SSR4, RPN2, HERPUD1 and DERL3 all belong to the canonical XBP1/ATF6 UPR regulon that expands folding, glycosylation and ER-associated degradation capacity in antibody-secreting cells. • Oxidative/ROS handling – PRDX4 (ER peroxidase) and CYBA (p22 phox subunit of NADPH oxidase) support redox balance during intense disulfide-bond formation in secretory ER. • Negative loading of RPL34 suggests relative down-modulation of ribosomal transcripts, a known compensatory response during acute ER stress. Inconsistencies: • CYBA is more classically associated with neutrophils/macrophages; its inclusion may reflect a general oxidative-stress component rather than being plasma-cell specific. • Only one negatively loaded gene (RPL34) limits confidence in interpreting down-regulated features.

program_11.description: The program represents a robust type I interferon–stimulated (antiviral) state that can be induced in virtually any nucleated cell following viral sensing or exogenous IFN-α/β exposure. Evidence: • Core interferon-stimulated genes ISG15, IFI6, IFIT1, MX1, RSAD2 (viperin), OAS3 and USP18 are hallmark components of the canonical type I IFN antiviral module reported across epithelial, immune and stromal cells. • XAF1 is an IFN-inducible pro-apoptotic factor frequently co-expressed with the above ISGs in single-cell datasets of virally infected or IFN-treated tissues. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; every listed gene is a well-validated ISG, reinforcing a coherent interferon response program.

program_12.description: The program is most consistent with a mucus-secreting intestinal/gastric goblet- or foveolar-type epithelial state that is simultaneously experiencing an interferon-stimulated (antiviral/stress) response. Evidence: • Goblet/foveolar secretory markers – PHGR1, TFF3 and TFF1 are canonical products of intestinal and gastric mucus-producing epithelial cells. • Epithelial structural gene – KRT8 is characteristic of simple columnar epithelia that include goblet and foveolar cells. • Secretory/stress-associated factors – S100A6 and ADIRF are frequently up-regulated in regenerating or secretory epithelia. • Interferon response – IFI27 is a classic type-I interferon-inducible gene, indicating an antiviral or inflammatory activation superimposed on the secretory epithelial program. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes contradict a goblet/foveolar epithelial identity; S100A6 and ADIRF are not specific for this lineage but are commonly seen in stressed or metabolically active epithelia, so they are not strongly discordant.

program_13.description: The gene set most closely reflects a generic proliferative/stress-response program typical of actively cycling cells that are coping with replication-associated DNA damage and increased membrane/energy demands, rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. Evidence: • DNA damage repair – PRKDC (DNA-PK catalytic subunit) is a core component of non-homologous end joining and is transcriptionally up-regulated in S/G2-phase cells that accumulate double-strand breaks during replication. • Cell-cycle/mitotic machinery – UBA2 forms the E1 SUMO-activating enzyme, and global SUMOylation peaks in late S/G2 to safeguard chromosome segregation. • Lipid and phosphoinositide synthesis needed for membrane biogenesis in dividing cells – PI4KA generates PI4P, while OSBPL8 shuttles sterols/phospholipids and ABHD17A removes palmitoyl groups to remodel membrane proteins. • Bioenergetic support – LRPPRC stabilises mitochondrial mRNAs and boosts oxidative phosphorylation, consistent with the elevated energy demand of proliferating cells. • Absence of lineage-specific markers and presence only of broadly expressed metabolic/repair genes supports the interpretation of a state (cell-cycle & stress) rather than a dedicated cell type. Inconsistencies: • Canonical high-proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, PCNA, MCM family) are not present, so the program may represent a partial or stress-induced variant of the full cell-cycle signature. • The list is small and largely housekeeping; some genes (e.g., CXorf38) have poorly characterised functions, limiting precise assignments.

program_14.description: The gene set reflects a canonical heat-shock/proteotoxic-stress response program that can be transiently activated in many cell types when they experience acute thermal, oxidative, or other protein-denaturing stress.
