Evidence: • Strong induction of classical inducible HSP70 isoforms (HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSPA6) that are hallmark markers of the heat-shock response controlled by HSF1. • Presence of ATP-dependent chaperones and co-chaperones HSP90AA1, DNAJB1 (HSP40 family), HSPE1 (HSP10) and the small heat-shock protein HSPB1, all of which function cooperatively to refold or triage damaged proteins during proteotoxic stress. • Absence of lineage-restricted markers supports a stress program rather than a specific differentiated cell identity. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are classical members of the heat-shock chaperone network and align with a unified cellular stress response.

program_15.description: The program reflects an IFN-γ–producing cytotoxic T-cell state (activated CD8⁺ or tissue-resident/effector memory T cells) characterized by granzyme-mediated killing and NKG2D-dependent activation. Evidence: • GZMB encodes granzyme-B, a canonical effector molecule of cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells and NK cells. • IFNG is the hallmark Th1/cytotoxic cytokine produced by activated CD8⁺ T cells and tissue-resident memory (Trm) T cells. • HCST (DNAX accessory molecule-1–related protein, the signaling adaptor for NKG2D) is enriched in activated CD8⁺ T and NK cells, supporting an NKG2D-driven cytotoxic program. • HOPX is repeatedly reported in long-lived effector and Trm CD8⁺/Th1 cells, marking durable cytotoxic memory. • SH3BGRL3 is up-regulated after T-cell receptor stimulation and in effector/memory T cells, consistent with activation. • ALOX5AP, although classically studied in myeloid cells, is induced upon T-cell activation and can contribute to leukotriene-mediated autocrine signaling in cytotoxic T cells. Inconsistencies: • ALOX5AP is more typical of monocytes/neutrophils; its presence may indicate either mixed leukocyte activation or paracrine crosstalk. • SH3BGRL3 is not exclusive to T cells and can be broadly expressed, so it provides weaker specificity for the assigned state.

program_16.description: The gene set is most consistent with a T-cell–specific signalling/priming programme typical of resting-to-early-activated memory/effector-precursor T lymphocytes that are poised to respond to IL-2. Evidence: • GRAP2 (GADS) and CBLB – canonical adaptor/ubiquitin ligase pair that fine-tune T-cell-receptor (TCR) signalling; both are highly enriched in CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T cells. • IL2RB (CD122) – β-chain of the IL-2/IL-15 receptor; strongly expressed on memory/effector-precursor T cells and required for IL-2-driven expansion. • LBH – Wnt-responsive transcriptional co-factor up-regulated in naïve-to-memory transition of T cells. • TSPAN14 and ARHGEF3 – modulators of NOTCH/ADAM10 and Rho-GTPase pathways, respectively, both reported to support lymphocyte activation and cytoskeletal rearrangement downstream of the TCR. Inconsistencies: • ARHGEF3 is also expressed in megakaryocyte/platelet lineages, but its presence in T cells during activation has been documented and does not contradict the overall T-cell signature.

program_17.description: The gene set most strongly fits a generic “high biosynthetic/proliferative” program often seen in actively cycling stem-like or cancer cells, marked by concerted up-regulation of chromatin remodeling (KDM1A), ribosome biogenesis (UTP14A), RNA-binding/splicing factors (HNRNPUL2, RBM42), and genome-maintenance proteins (SLX4IP), together with a lipid-signaling protein (PITPNA) that supports membrane production during growth. Evidence: • KDM1A (LSD1) – histone demethylase that sustains self-renewal and proliferation in embryonic stem cells and diverse cancers. • UTP14A – U3 snoRNP component essential for 18S rRNA processing; elevated in proliferating/tumor cells to boost ribosome output. • HNRNPUL2 and RBM42 – RNA-binding/splicing factors that increase global mRNA processing capacity in dividing cells. • SLX4IP – DNA-repair/telomere-maintenance protein up-regulated during replicative stress, supporting genome integrity in rapidly cycling cells. • PITPNA – phosphatidylinositol transfer protein that facilitates membrane trafficking and phosphoinositide signaling required for cell growth. Inconsistencies: • Lack of canonical cell-cycle markers (e.g., MKI67, PCNA, TOP2A) means the program captures biosynthetic readiness rather than the full mitotic signature. • PITPNA is broadly expressed and sometimes neuron-enriched, so its presence is less specific to proliferation.

program_18.description: The program most consistently fits an early neurogenic state—neural stem / progenitor cells that have begun to acquire neuronal features but still maintain REST-mediated repression of the full mature-neuron transcriptome. Evidence: • REST – highly expressed in neural stem and progenitor cells and down-regulated in fully differentiated neurons; its presence points to an undifferentiated or early-differentiating neural state. • NECAB3 – neuron-enriched Ca²⁺-binding protein whose transcription is initiated early in neuronal differentiation, supporting an incipient neuronal identity. • PGAP2 – GPI-anchor–remodeling enzyme with highest expression in developing brain; required for proper surface display of many neuronal proteins. • DHRS4 – retinol/retinoic-acid–metabolizing enzyme implicated in neurodevelopmental signaling pathways. • DDX50 – nucleolar RNA helicase elevated in proliferative, metabolically active progenitors, consistent with the biosynthetic demands of early neurogenesis. Inconsistencies: • Co-expression of REST (a suppressor of neuronal genes) with a mature-neuron marker such as NECAB3 is uncommon in fully differentiated neurons, underscoring that the program likely represents a transitional rather than a terminal neuronal state. No other major conflicts are evident within this limited gene set.

program_19.description: The gene set best fits a generic “metabolic-proliferative” program seen in cycling progenitor or recently activated cells that have up-regulated mitochondrial function and nucleotide biosynthesis to support DNA replication. Evidence: • DTYMK – catalytic step of dTTP synthesis; strongly induced during S-phase and in highly proliferative cells. • ATAD3A & HADH – mitochondrial inner-membrane ATPase and β-oxidation enzyme, respectively; co-up-regulation signals increased mitochondrial biogenesis/oxidative metabolism typical of dividing or activated cells. • CBR1 – NADPH-dependent oxidoreductase elevated in cells with high redox turnover, consistent with heightened metabolic activity accompanying proliferation. Inconsistencies: • ARMC6 has unclear functional annotation and is not classically linked to proliferation or mitochondrial metabolism, so its inclusion is not strongly explanatory but does not contradict the overall program.

program_20.description: The program most closely fits a T-cell signaling/activation module, characterized by expression of the T-cell adaptor PAG1 together with genes that modulate MAPK signaling (RPS6KA3), lipid-raft glycosphingolipid synthesis (UGCG), and transcript turnover (CNOT6), consistent with a state of T-cell receptor (TCR) engagement and downstream signaling regulation. Evidence: • PAG1 – membrane adaptor that recruits CSK to the TCR complex; highly enriched in T cells and NK cells and up-regulated on TCR stimulation. • RPS6KA3 (RSK2) – ERK-activated kinase functioning immediately downstream of TCR/MAPK signaling, supporting cytokine production and proliferation. • UGCG – catalyzes glucosylceramide production, required for sphingolipid-rich lipid rafts that cluster the TCR; its up-regulation accompanies activated T cells. • Concomitant presence of general signaling/mRNA-processing components (CNOT6, TMEM181) is typical of activated lymphocytes that increase translational and post-transcriptional control. Inconsistencies: • CNOT6 and TMEM181 are broadly expressed housekeeping genes and do not specifically mark T cells; their inclusion weakens cell-type specificity but does not contradict a T-cell activation program.

program_21.description: The program most strongly reflects a generic “biosynthetic/proliferation” state, characterized by up-regulated ribosome biogenesis, mRNA processing/export, tRNA-synthetase complex activity and de-novo purine synthesis—molecular hallmarks of cells preparing for or engaged in rapid growth and division; no markers point to a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • RPL26L1 – ribosomal protein paralog; increased expression mirrors global ribosome biogenesis in proliferating cells. • AIMP2 – scaffold of the multi-amino-acyl-tRNA synthetase complex; up-regulation accompanies high translation demand. • THOC3 – component of the TREX mRNA export complex; boosted mRNA nuclear export is typical during high transcriptional output. • ADSL – catalyzes steps in de-novo purine biosynthesis; elevated nucleotide synthesis supports DNA/RNA replication in dividing cells. • PAGR1 (negatively loaded) – chromatin-associated DNA-damage/replication factor; its relative repression is compatible with prioritizing translational over chromatin-modifying programs in rapidly cycling cells. Inconsistencies: • No major lineage-specific or cell-cycle phase-defining genes are present; the interpretation therefore remains a broad “high biosynthetic activity” program rather than a precise cell subtype/state.

program_22.description: The gene set points to activated/regenerative skeletal muscle satellite cells (early myogenic program) characterized by ECM remodeling, membrane-fusion competence and mTOR-regulated differentiation. Evidence: • AMPD1 – canonical skeletal-muscle isoform of AMP-deaminase; highly enriched in myofibres and up-regulated in regenerating muscle. • CD9 – tetraspanin used as a surface marker of quiescent/activated satellite cells and required for myoblast fusion. • TIMP1 – secreted by satellite cells and myoblasts to inhibit MMPs during ECM remodeling in muscle repair. • DEPTOR – negative regulator of mTORC1/2 that modulates myogenic differentiation and muscle mass. • Combined presence of ECM modulator (TIMP1), fusion marker (CD9), metabolic enzyme specific to muscle (AMPD1) and mTOR regulator (DEPTOR) fits the transcriptional program of satellite cells transitioning from quiescence to activation. Inconsistencies: • TTLL7 is better known as a neuron-enriched tubulin-modifying enzyme and is not classically associated with muscle, suggesting possible low-level expression or minor contamination from neuronal cells.

program_23.description: The program represents a “Y-chromosome signature” that marks cells derived from a genetic male (XY) individual rather than a specific lineage or activation state; it reflects broad, housekeeping-level expression of Y-linked genes that are routinely transcribed across most male somatic and germ-line cell types. Evidence: • RPS4Y1, EIF1AY – ribosomal protein and translation initiation factor encoded on the Y chromosome, ubiquitously expressed in male cells. • DDX3Y – Y-linked RNA helicase expressed in many tissues, routinely used to distinguish male from female cells in scRNA-seq datasets. • KDM5D, UTY – Y-linked histone demethylases that exhibit widespread, constitutive expression in male cells and are standard male sex markers in transcriptomic studies. Inconsistencies: • None detected; all detected transcripts are canonical Y-chromosome genes and coherently support a male-specific expression program.

program_0.description: The gene set reflects a quiescent, PI16⁺ perivascular/adventitial fibroblast program characterized by robust extracellular-matrix production, complement and chemokine secretion, and immune-modulatory factors—features typical of the CXCL12-abundant reticular (CAR) or “vascular adventitial” fibroblasts found around blood vessels in many organs. Evidence: • Fibroblast/ECM identity – abundant matrix genes DCN, LUM, FBN1, FBLN1/2, TNXB, COL6A2, MFAP4/5, PCOLCE2, PRELP, HAPLN1, SERPINF1, TIMP3. • Adventitial (PI16⁺) fibroblast markers – PI16, CXCL12, RSPO3, IGF1, CCL2, SCARA5, SFRP1/2, IGFBP6, ABI3BP, DPT, CCDC80; this combination is characteristic of vessel-associated fibroblasts across tissues. • Immune-modulatory/reticular cell traits – complement genes C1R, C1S, C3, CFD, CFH; cytokine/chemokine IL18, PLA2G2A, ADAMDEC1, RARRES2; serpins SERPINE2, SLPI; consistent with CAR cells that orchestrate leukocyte trafficking. • Low proliferation signature – only negatively loaded PTMA (a proliferation/translation factor) implies a differentiated, non-cycling state, matching quiescent stromal cells. Inconsistencies: • CTSK and OMD are more typical of osteogenic lineages; KRT24 is an epithelial keratin—these few genes are atypical for fibroblasts and may reflect minor contamination or shared mesenchymal gene usage rather than a different cell identity.

program_1.description: The program reflects a cell state with globally elevated cytosolic protein-synthesis capacity (ribosome biogenesis/translation module) coupled to suppressed mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation gene expression, a pattern typical of highly proliferative or recently activated cells across many lineages rather than of a specific differentiated cell type. Evidence: • Strong positive loading of virtually every small- and large-subunit ribosomal protein gene (e.g., RPL10, RPL13A, RPS6, RPS18) plus translation factors EEF1A1, RACK1/GNB2L1, FAU, NACA and TMSB4X → hallmark of active ribosome production and high translational throughput. • Negative loading of multiple mitochondrial-encoded OXPHOS genes (MT-ATP6, MT-CO2/3, MT-CYB, MT-ND3/4L/5, MT-ATP8) → relative reduction in oxidative phosphorylation transcripts, consistent with a metabolic shift often accompanying rapid growth. Inconsistencies: • Down-weighted CD81 (tetraspanin) and JUND (AP-1 transcription factor) are not directly related to mitochondrial function; their negative association may reflect lineage-specific regulation rather than the core translation/mitochondrial antagonism captured by the program.

program_2.description: The gene set represents a canonical G2/M-phase cell-cycle program, marking actively dividing cells (e.g., cycling progenitors, malignant cells, or any population undergoing mitosis). Evidence: • Core mitotic regulators: CCNB1, CCNB2, CDK1, AURKB, PRC1, MAD2L1, CENPE/P/K/M/W/N, ZWINT and SPC25 drive chromosome alignment, spindle checkpoint, and cytokinesis. • Proliferation markers: MKI67, TOP2A, BIRC5 (survivin) and PCLAF are classical indicators of high proliferative activity. • Spindle assembly/centrosome components: NUSAP1, TPX2, ASPM, DLGAP5, GTSE1 orchestrate spindle formation and stability. • DNA replication / repair genes up-regulated in late S–G2: RRM2, TYMS, DHFR, FEN1, BRCA2, FANCI, RAD51AP1 ensure DNA synthesis and damage repair before mitosis. • Cell-cycle transcriptional drivers: FOXM1 and MYBL2 activate the G2/M gene network. • Cytokinesis/abscission factors: CEP55, ANLN, UBE2C/T coordinate contractile ring formation and mid-body abscission. Inconsistencies: No major inconsistencies; all listed genes are coherent with a G2/M cell-cycle state.

program_3.description: The gene set is most consistent with a PDGFRA⁺ mesenchymal-stromal / fibroblast program in a “signalling-competent” or progenitor-like state, typical of dermal, perivascular or other tissue-resident fibroblasts that secrete developmental morphogens (WNTs, BMPs, NRG1) and matrix components (COL4A5/6, EMILIN1, POSTN) while lacking myofibroblast or immune signatures. Evidence: • Core fibroblast / stromal markers: PDGFRA, PDPN, POSTN, COL4A5, COL4A6, EMILIN1, EMID1, F3, PLAT, TSPAN33 indicate mesenchymal extracellular-matrix–producing cells. • Developmental morphogen secretion typical of “signalling” fibroblasts: WNT4, WNT5A, WNT5B, BMP4, BMP5, PTCH1, NRG1, SEMA3A, SEMA4D, CXCL14, TSLP. • Progenitor-associated genes: PROM1 (CD133), SOX6, INSC, VSTM2A, GADD45G support a less-differentiated fibroblast state. • Absence of pericyte (PDGFRB, RGS5), myofibroblast (ACTA2, TAGLN) or immune (PTPRC, CD68) genes further aligns with a non-contractile, non-hematopoietic stromal identity. Inconsistencies: • TMEM119 (classically microglia) and TRPA1 (sensory neuron/epithelial) are atypical for fibroblasts but can show low stromal expression. • EDNRB is more characteristic of neural-crest derivatives (melanocytes, pericytes); its presence may reflect mixed lineage signalling. • AGT and PCSK6 are liver/adipocyte-enriched secreted factors but are occasionally produced by fibroblasts in paracrine contexts.

program_4.description: The program is characteristic of activated/angiogenic micro- and post-capillary endothelial cells that have been stimulated by interferon-γ, leading to simultaneous up-regulation of classical endothelial markers, angiogenic regulators, and both MHC-class I and MHC-class II antigen-presentation machinery (“antigen-presenting endothelial cells”). Evidence: • Core endothelial identity – VWF, CLDN5, PLVAP, ENG (CD105), PTPRB, EMCN, CD93, JAM2, CLEC14A, ADGRL4 (ELTD1), RAMP2/3, S1PR1, RNASE1, RBP7 and CA4 are all well-established markers of blood endothelial cells. • Angiogenic / remodeling state – EGFL7, PLVAP, ENG, ENPP2, CLEC14A, ADGRL4 and PTPRB are induced during endothelial sprouting, permeability and vessel maturation. • Interferon-γ activation and antigen presentation – Strong co-expression of MHC-II genes (HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1, ‑DPA1, ‑DMA) together with CD74, alongside ubiquitous MHC-I genes (HLA-A, ‑B, ‑C, ‑E, B2M) and IFN-stimulated gene IFI27, is typical of IFN-γ–licensed endothelial cells capable of presenting antigen to T cells. • Additional activation/metabolic genes – TXNIP, FABP5, CD36 and ENPP2 reflect oxidative and lipid-handling changes often seen in activated endothelium. Inconsistencies: • SRGN is classically hematopoietic but has been reported in activated endothelial cells; its presence is therefore not strongly contradictory. • No other notable genes clearly conflict with an activated endothelial phenotype, and the absence of hematopoietic lineage-specific markers (e.g., PTPRC/CD45) supports endothelial assignment.

program_5.description: The gene set represents a mature, contractile vascular smooth-muscle / mural-cell program, typical of arterial smooth-muscle cells or pericytes that have adopted a fully differentiated, force-generating state. Evidence: • Core contractile apparatus: MYH11, ACTA2, MYL9, ACTG2, TPM2, TAGLN, CNN1, LMOD1 – canonical markers of differentiated contractile smooth-muscle cells. • Cytoskeletal & adhesion components that stabilize the contractile phenotype: FLNA, CAP2, CSRP1/2, ITGA7, DSTN. • Regulators of Ca²⁺-dependent contraction: MYLK, PLN, PPP1R14A (CPI-17), SPEG, NET1; together they tune myosin light-chain phosphorylation. • Ion-channel genes typical of vascular SMCs: KCNA5, KCNAB1, KCNMB1 provide K⁺ currents that shape membrane potential and tone. • Mural-cell signalling markers: NOTCH3 (arteriolar SMC/pericyte), RCAN2 (calcineurin signalling), RRAD and RERGL (Ras-like GTPases active in SMC). • Stress-protective muscle proteins: CRYAB, HSPB7, DMPK support cytoskeletal integrity during contraction. Inconsistencies: • NTRK2, ADIRF, NRIP2, MT1M, GADD45B are not classical smooth-muscle markers; they may reflect context-specific signalling or stress responses rather than the core contractile phenotype.

program_6.description: The program best fits a differentiated vascular mural cell (pericyte / vascular smooth-muscle) state that is both contractile and secretes extracellular-matrix and vaso-modulatory factors, typical of cells that line and stabilize small blood vessels within neurovascular or other microvascular beds. Evidence: • Contractile smooth-muscle machinery – MYOCD (master regulator), DES, TPM1, SYNPO2, LPP, SORBS1/2 support a muscle-type cytoskeleton. • Pericyte / adventitial fibroblast secretome – FRZB, LPL, SOD3, C1QTNF1, NPNT, CPM and OLFML2B are well-described markers of perivascular mesenchyme that regulate WNT, lipid and redox signalling around vessels. • Ion handling and Ca2+ signalling for contraction – KCNMA1 (BK channel), HRC, ATP1A2, ATP1B2, PIP5K1B enable rapid membrane repolarisation and Ca2+ storage typical of mural cells. • Genes mediating neurovascular interactions – NFASC, LGI4, NTRK3, RASGRP2 and SLC6A1 are enriched in pericytes that interface with axons and glia, consistent with a neurovascular niche. • Additional smooth-muscle / vessel regulators – TBX2, TSC22D1 and STEAP4 participate in vascular development, stress responses and metabolism, again aligning with mural cell biology. Inconsistencies: • SNCG and the neurotransmitter transporter SLC6A1 are more neuron-biased; their presence may reflect low-level neuronal contamination or shared neurovascular signalling. • STEAP4 is also expressed in adipocytes/macrophages, though it is reported in some perivascular cells.

program_7.description: The gene set represents a vascular mural-cell (pericyte / vascular smooth-muscle-like) program that is transcriptionally adapted to low-oxygen microenvironments. High expression of canonical pericyte markers (PDGFRB, RGS5, CSPG4, NOTCH3), ion-channel regulators of contractility (KCNJ8, ABCC9, ANO1), and hypoxia-induced mitochondrial modifiers (NDUFA4L2, COX4I2, HIGD1B) together indicate a microvascular pericyte state engaged in oxygen sensing and vessel stabilization. Evidence: • Core mural-cell identity: RGS5, PDGFRB, NOTCH3, CSPG4 (NG2), THY1, COL5A3 and ENPEP are well-established markers of pericytes and vascular smooth-muscle lineage. • Contractility / ion-handling typical of pericytes: KCNJ8 + ABCC9 (Kir6.1/SUR2 ATP-sensitive K⁺ channel), ANO1 (Ca²⁺-activated Cl⁻ channel), GJA4 and GJC1 (connexins) support a contractile mural phenotype. • Hypoxia / oxygen-sensing signature common in capillary pericytes: NDUFA4L2, COX4I2, HIGD1B, FAM162B, FOXS1 are classical HIF-responsive genes that tune mitochondrial respiration under low O₂. • Vascular guidance and ECM interaction: PLXDC1, SEMA5B, ITGA4, EGFLAM and COL5A3 participate in endothelial–pericyte crosstalk and matrix adhesion, reinforcing a vessel-associated state. Inconsistencies: • OR51E1 (olfactory receptor) and LINGO1 (axon guidance protein) are atypical for mural cells but have been sporadically reported in vascular or mesenchymal contexts; their presence is therefore minor and does not outweigh the dominant pericyte signature.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with a vascular endothelial-cell transcriptional program, enriched for factors that control endothelial identity, nitric-oxide signalling, vascular guidance and cytoskeletal remodelling typically seen in resting to mildly angiogenic blood-vessel endothelium. Evidence: • Endothelial identity / transcriptional regulators – ERG, TEK (TIE2), ROBO4, SCARF1, CCM2L, FGD5, ARHGEF15 and RHOJ are all well-validated, endothelial-selective genes required for vessel stability or angiogenesis. • Endothelial function – NOS3 (eNOS) mediates endothelial nitric-oxide production; ABO encodes blood-group glycotransferase expressed on vascular endothelium; PXN, ARHGEF3, ARHGAP31, PLEKHG5 and LRRC8C support focal adhesion and Rho-GTPase–dependent cytoskeletal dynamics in endothelial cells. • Angiogenic / guidance cues – SEMA6B, ROBO4, FGD5, RHOJ and ARHGEF15 participate in tip-cell guidance, lumen formation and sprouting. • Signal transduction and trafficking typical of endothelium – PRKCH, PDE2A, IPO11, SCARF1, MGAT4A, AGFG2 contribute to PKC, cAMP, import and membrane trafficking pathways active in vascular endothelium. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal-biased genes (CPLX1, FGF12) and immune-associated GIMAP6, ULBP2, plus broadly expressed NR5A2 and CARD6, are not classically endothelial and may reflect low-level background expression or mixed cell barcodes.

program_9.description: The gene set reflects an activated, pro-inflammatory, matrix-remodeling fibroblast program—classically described for wound-healing or inflammatory cancer-associated fibroblasts (iCAFs)—characterised by abundant chemokine/cytokine secretion and extracellular-matrix turnover. Evidence: • Fibroblast/CAF identity – PDPN, WNT5A, MME (CD10), INHBA, IL11 are canonical markers of activated dermal and tumour-associated fibroblasts. • Matrix remodelling – High expression of MMP1, MMP3, COL7A1 and COL12A1 indicates active degradation and re-synthesis of extracellular matrix. • Inflammatory/chemokine output – CXCL1, CXCL5, CXCL6, CXCL8, CCL20 and IL24 together typify the chemokine-rich “iCAF” phenotype that recruits neutrophils and other leukocytes. • Secreted wound-response factors – TNFAIP6, CHI3L1 and IL11 are released by fibroblasts during tissue injury and promote inflammation and fibrosis. • Stress-adaptation/metabolic reprogramming – FTH1, SOD2, MT2A and GK reflect oxidative-stress buffering and altered metabolism frequently seen in activated fibroblasts. • Transcriptional support – POU2F2 has been reported in some stromal cells and may contribute to cytokine-rich programmes. Inconsistencies: • POU2F2 is predominantly a B-cell transcription factor and is uncommon in fibroblasts. • IL7R is typically lymphoid; its presence may reflect paracrine receptor expression or mixed cell signal. • CA12 is more typical of hypoxic epithelial/tumour cells than fibroblasts.

program_10.description: The gene set most closely matches peripheral-nerve Schwann cells, particularly a myelinating/late-immature Schwann-cell program. Evidence: • Core peripheral‐myelin genes: MPZ, PMP22, PLP1, PRNP – hallmark constituents of compact myelin produced by Schwann cells. • Schwann-lineage and precursor markers: ERBB3, CDH19, LGI4, GPM6B, S100B – expressed from the neural-crest/immature stage through maturation. • Axon-glia interaction/adhesion genes typical of Schwann cells: NRXN1, ANK3, CADM1, SCN7A. • Additional Schwann-cell or peripheral-nerve ECM genes: MATN2, SEMA3B, XKR4. • Stress/chaperone gene CRYAB, often up-regulated in active myelination or repair contexts. Inconsistencies: • MYOT (muscle structural protein) and FXYD1 (cardiac/fast muscle regulator) are more characteristic of muscle. • SPP1 (osteopontin) is common in immune cells and reactive glia rather than baseline Schwann cells. • RASSF4 and GPR155 are broadly expressed signaling genes not specific to Schwann lineage.

program_11.description: The gene set represents an activated, extracellular-matrix-producing fibroblast program characteristic of myofibroblasts / cancer-associated fibroblasts (COL11A1⁺ “myCAF” state) engaged in tissue remodeling. Evidence: • Canonical fibrillar collagen genes (COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1, COL5A2, COL12A1) define fibroblasts and sharply increase upon myofibroblast activation. • COL11A1, COL10A1, INHBA, ADAM12, POSTN and CTHRC1 are repeatedly reported as the core signature of activated wound-healing fibroblasts and myCAFs across multiple tumor scRNA-seq studies. • Matrix-associated factors (POSTN, ADAM12, CTHRC1) and gap-junction component GJB2 support cell–cell communication and matrix remodeling typical of CAFs. • BHLHE41 is induced by hypoxia/TGF-β in mesenchymal cells, aligning with the pro-fibrotic, activated fibroblast milieu. Inconsistencies: • GJB2 (classically epithelial) and PLPP4 are not fibroblast-specific, and BHLHE41 has broader circadian roles; however, none contradict the overarching activated‐fibroblast interpretation.

program_12.description: The program most closely reflects an inflammation-activated, venular/post-capillary endothelial cell state specialized for recruiting circulating leukocytes. Evidence: • Endothelial/vascular markers – ACKR1 (canonical marker of venular endothelial cells), SELP (P-selectin stored in Weibel-Palade bodies of activated ECs), MMRN1 (EC/platelet extracellular matrix protein), ADGRG6 (broadly expressed in vascular endothelium). • Leukocyte-recruitment & chemokine milieu – ACKR1 scavenges and presents chemokines; CCL14 and CCL23 are chemoattractants; SELP supports rolling adhesion. • Complement & innate immune activation – C7 denotes local complement production typical of inflamed endothelium. • IFN-γ–responsive antigen-presentation signature – CD74 (MHC-II invariant chain) is induced in endothelial cells under inflammatory cytokines, consistent with an activated state. • Vesicular/secretory and stress-response genes (NPC2, CPE, DUSP23) are frequently up-regulated in activated ECs handling high secretory traffic. Inconsistencies: • CCL14, CCL23 and CD74 are classically associated with myeloid/lymphoid cells, and CPE with endocrine tissues, but all can be inducibly expressed in endothelial cells during inflammation. • ZNF385D has limited functional annotation, so its relevance to endothelium is unclear.

program_13.description: The program is characteristic of PDGFRA-positive mesenchymal stromal/fibroblast cells in an extracellular-matrix-producing (activated/wound-healing) state. Evidence: • Fibroblast/mesenchymal identity – PDGFRA, COL6A1, COL6A3, VCAN, SPON2, PCOLCE are canonical markers of tissue fibroblasts and mesenchymal stromal cells that synthesize and remodel collagen-rich matrix. • Matrix production/activation – High expression of COL6A1/COL6A3, VCAN, PCOLCE and SPON2 denotes active secretion and organization of structural ECM proteins typical of activated or wound-healing fibroblasts. • Stromal growth factors – CLEC11A (stem cell growth factor) and BMP4 (bone morphogenetic protein 4) are secreted morphogens produced by mesenchymal progenitors during tissue repair and development. • Pro-coagulant, inflammatory interface – F3 (tissue factor) is often induced in activated fibroblasts at injury sites, linking coagulation and repair. • Lipid/oxidative stress response – APOD is frequently expressed in fibroblasts undergoing metabolic or stress-related activation. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes; all listed genes are compatible with an activated mesenchymal stromal/fibroblast program, though F3 and APOD are not strictly fibroblast-specific and can appear in other contexts (endothelial/immune cells for F3, lipid-metabolic cells for APOD).

program_14.description: Gene expression profile is most consistent with an “inflammatory/chemokine-secreting fibroblast” state—i.e., stromal cells that retain core extracellular-matrix functions while up-regulating eosinophil/monocyte-attracting chemokines and other inflammatory mediators, a phenotype described in allergic airways, atopic skin, and fibrotic tissues. Evidence: • Chemokine arm – strong induction of CCL11 (eotaxin-1), CCL13 (MCP-4) and CCL8 (MCP-2) that are classically produced by activated fibroblasts and drive Th2-type eosinophil/monocyte recruitment; CXCL14 likewise marks chemokine-high fibroblasts in skin and lung. • Stromal/ECM identity – EMILIN1, EDIL3 (DEL1) and TFPI2 encode matrix or matrix-associated proteins abundantly secreted by fibroblasts, indicating a mesenchymal rather than immune or epithelial lineage. • Growth-factor signaling typical of fibroblasts – FGFR4 and PTGER4 are expressed in subsets of activated fibroblasts and mediate FGF or prostaglandin responses linked to wound repair and fibrosis. • Coordinated expression of multiple chemokines together with ECM genes matches published “inflammatory fibroblast” programs (e.g., Habermann et al., 2020; Tsukui et al., 2020). Inconsistencies: • STMN2 is best known as a neuronal microtubule regulator; its presence is atypical for fibroblasts and may reflect ambient RNA or a mixed program. • No genes are negatively loaded to contradict the assignment, but absence of canonical fibroblast markers (e.g., COL1A1, PDGFRA) could limit confidence.

program_15.description: The program is characteristic of vascular endothelial cells, with transcriptional features most consistent with capillary/tip-like endothelial cells engaged in angiogenesis. Evidence: • Canonical endothelial markers – CDH5 (VE-cadherin), FLT1 (VEGFR1), NOTCH4 and PODXL are hallmark genes of blood-vessel endothelium. • Endothelial progenitor/tip-cell signatures – CD34 and FLT1 are enriched in sprouting or immature endothelial cells that lead new vessel growth; NOTCH4 modulates tip/stalk decisions during angiogenesis. • Shear/activation response – RGCC and F2RL3 are induced by flow and thrombin, respectively, reflecting an activated vascular endothelium. • Basement-membrane/extracellular-matrix components – HSPG2 (perlecan) and VWA1 support vessel basement-membrane assembly typical of microvasculature undergoing remodeling. • Metabolic/insulin responsiveness – INSR is appreciably expressed in endothelial cells and up-regulated during angiogenic activation. Inconsistencies: No major conflicting genes are present in the current list.

program_16.description: The program reflects an S-phase cell-cycle state in actively proliferating cells, marked by coordinated activation of DNA replication, replication-coupled chromatin assembly, and genome maintenance pathways. Evidence: • DNA replication licensing/fork progression – MCM4 (MCM helicase), GINS2 (GINS complex), CLSPN (replication-checkpoint mediator) • S-phase transcriptional control – E2F1 drives expression of replication genes; ATAD2 is an E2F-responsive co-activator in proliferating cells • Chromatin assembly/epigenetic maintenance during replication – CHAF1A (chromatin assembly factor 1), UHRF1 (maintenance DNA methylation), HELLS (chromatin remodeler) • DNA damage surveillance/repair active in S phase – BRCA1 (homologous recombination repair) • Additional replication-associated factor – WDR76 associates with replisome components Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes coherently support an S-phase proliferation program.

program_17.description: The program strongly matches endothelial cells in an arterial/angiogenic state characterized by active Notch signalling and guidance-cue expression. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – ICAM2 (vascular adhesion molecule), TM4SF1 (endothelial/tip-cell marker), ANXA3 (endothelium-enriched phospholipid-binding protein). • Arterial specification – GJA5/Connexin-40 and HEY1 are canonical Notch-responsive arterial genes; SEMA3G is selectively produced by arterial endothelium and modulates vessel guidance. • Angiogenic remodeling – TM4SF1 and SEMA3G are up-regulated in sprouting/tip endothelial cells; PCSK5 processes extracellular proteins involved in vascular morphogenesis. • General endothelial support – SRP14 and ARL15 provide housekeeping/vesicular functions typical of metabolically active endothelial cells. Inconsistencies: • ANXA3 is also detected in some venous or lymphatic endothelia, and ARL15 is not endothelial-specific, but neither contradicts an overall arterial/angiogenic endothelial program.

program_18.description: The program represents a robust type I interferon (IFN-α/β) response that can be induced in many immune and non-immune cell types during viral sensing or exposure to exogenous IFN; the coordinated up-regulation of canonical interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) indicates cells in an antiviral, interferon-activated state rather than a distinct lineage. Evidence: • Classical ISGs—ISG15, MX1, RSAD2 (viperin), OASL, IFI6, CMPK2—encode antiviral effectors directly induced by STAT1/STAT2/IRF9 signaling downstream of type I IFN. • IFI44L, IFIT1, and IFIT3 are hallmark transcripts of the “core” interferon response module identified across diverse scRNA-seq datasets and viral infections. • Absence of lineage-defining markers and exclusive presence of ISGs argue for a transient activation state rather than a specific cell type identity. Inconsistencies: • None detected; all listed genes consistently participate in the interferon-stimulated antiviral program.

program_19.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, post-capillary venous endothelial-cell program characterized by up-regulation of leukocyte-recruitment molecules and vesicle/secretory machinery, typical of endothelium responding to inflammatory or angiogenic cues. Evidence: • ACKR1 (DARC) – canonical marker of venous/post-capillary endothelial cells that scavenges chemokines and mediates leukocyte trafficking. • SELP (P-selectin) – stored in Weibel-Palade bodies of endothelial cells; rapidly exposed on the surface during activation to capture leukocytes. • ADGRG6 (GPR126), TLL1, LRRC1 – broadly expressed in vascular endothelium and required for angiogenic sprouting and vessel integrity. • RAB3C, SYT15 – small GTPase and synaptotagmin involved in regulated exocytosis, fitting the need for Weibel-Palade body/secretory granule release in activated endothelial cells. • ADAM23 – disintegrin-metalloprotease implicated in endothelial migration and remodeling, supporting an activation/angiogenic state. Inconsistencies: • ZNF385D and ADAM23 are better known for roles in neural tissues; their presence may reflect low-level or context-specific endothelial expression rather than a core vascular signature.

program_20.description: The program represents a stimulus-induced “immediate early gene” (IEG) response, a transient activation state that can occur in virtually any cell type shortly after exposure to growth factors, cytokines, mechanical stress or dissociation. It is characterized by rapid, AP-1–driven transcription of FOS/JUN family members together with other prototypical IEGs. Evidence: • AP-1 transcription factors: FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB form the canonical AP-1 complex that is rapidly induced within minutes of diverse extracellular stimuli. • Early response regulators: IER2, EGR1, BTG2, ZFP36, and GADD45B are classic IEGs co-activated with AP-1 during acute signaling and regulate downstream mRNA turnover, cell-cycle checkpoints, and stress responses. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded or lineage-restricted markers are present; the gene set is internally consistent with a generic IEG activation state.

program_21.description: The gene set is most consistent with an adventitial / perivascular COL14A1⁺ fibroblast program—i.e., a quiescent, extracellular-matrix-secreting stromal cell state frequently observed around blood vessels in lung, skin and other tissues. Evidence: • Fibroblast-restricted collagens and matrisome genes: COL14A1, ANGPTL1 and CHRDL1 are canonical markers of adventitial fibroblasts that deposit specialized interstitial matrix. • Additional secreted ECM-associated factors enriched in COL14A1⁺ fibroblasts: SRPX, IGSF10. • Metabolic/enzymatic genes typical of stromal fibroblasts: AOX1 and AKR1C1 are highly expressed in mesenchymal cells involved in xenobiotic and steroid metabolism. • DCLK1 has documented, albeit lower, expression in COL14A1⁺ fibroblast clusters in single-cell atlases (e.g., human lung), supporting a fibroblast rather than epithelial program. Inconsistencies: • DCLK1 is better known as a tuft-cell marker, so its presence may indicate low-level tuft-cell contamination or a broader expression pattern. • No obvious endothelial or immune markers are present, but SRPX can also be found in endothelial cells.

program_22.description: The gene set most strongly reflects a lymphatic endothelial cell (LEC) program, characteristic of capillary/afferent lymphatic vessels that actively engage in immune-cell trafficking and extracellular matrix interactions. Evidence: • Canonical LEC identity genes – LYVE1 (hyaluronan receptor specific to lymphatic capillaries), PROX1 (master TF for LEC fate), and CCL21 (chemokine secreted by afferent lymphatics to attract CCR7⁺ dendritic and T cells). • Vascular/ECM components typical of lymphatic endothelium – MMRN1 (multimerin-1, stored in endothelial cells), AKAP12 (barrier-regulating scaffold in endothelial junctions), and KBTBD11 (enriched in endothelial gene signatures). • Metabolic/secretory markers reported in specialized LEC subsets – FABP4 (fatty-acid-handling protein detected in adipose and lung LECs) and TFF3 (secreted peptide up-regulated in reparative, mucosal, and lymphatic endothelial contexts). Inconsistencies: • FABP4 and TFF3 are more commonly noted in blood capillary endothelium or epithelial cells, respectively, and are not universal LEC markers; their presence suggests a tissue-specialized or metabolically active LEC subset rather than all lymphatic endothelial cells.

program_23.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated effector/memory T-cell program, characterised by T-cell–specific GIMAP family members, the T-cell surface tetraspanin TSPAN7, and expression of cytotoxic/apoptosis-inducing ligand TNFSF10, together with inducible MHC class II (HLA-DPB1) that appears on strongly activated human T cells. Evidence: • T-cell identity and survival: GIMAP7 and GIMAP4 are GTPases selectively enriched in mature and memory T lymphocytes and support their survival. • T-cell surface marker: TSPAN7 is expressed on naïve and memory T cells and up-regulated upon activation. • Cytotoxic/effector function: TNFSF10 (TRAIL) is produced by activated CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T cells and NK cells to induce apoptosis in target cells. • Activation-induced MHC-II: HLA-DPB1 is classically myeloid/B-cell, but is inducibly expressed on highly activated human T cells, indicating an activated state. • Cytokine responsiveness: LIFR is up-regulated on activated lymphocytes and mediates signaling of the IL-6/LIF family, fitting an activation program. Inconsistencies: • FAM107A and LIFR are not canonical T-cell markers and are more broadly expressed; their presence may reflect a broader stress/cytokine response rather than T-cell specificity. • Constitutive HLA-DPB1 is typical of professional antigen-presenting cells; if expression is high at baseline it could indicate contaminating APCs rather than activated T cells.

program_24.description: The program is most consistent with an angiogenic / remodeling endothelial-cell state characterized by active basement-membrane production and tip-cell–like activation. Evidence: • ESM1 (endocan) – selectively expressed by tip endothelial cells during sprouting angiogenesis and up-regulated by VEGF signaling. • COL4A1, COL4A2, HSPG2 (perlecan) – major basement-membrane collagens and proteoglycan synthesized by endothelial cells and pericytes during new vessel formation. • SPARC – matricellular protein secreted by activated endothelium that modulates collagen deposition and angiogenic signaling. • CDH13 (T-cadherin) – endothelial-enriched adhesion molecule that supports vascular remodeling and endothelial migration. • SOX11 – transcription factor induced in immature or angiogenic endothelial and perivascular mesenchymal cells, marking an actively remodeling rather than quiescent vasculature. Inconsistencies: • SOX11 is also expressed in neuronal progenitors, but its reported induction in angiogenic endothelium fits the overall vascular program; no other strong neuronal genes are present, so this is a minor concern.

program_25.description: The gene set is most consistent with a vascular smooth-muscle / pericyte lineage that has shifted from a purely contractile state toward a synthetic, extracellular-matrix–producing (fibro-/chondro-genic) phenotype often seen in vessel wall remodeling or atherosclerotic lesions. Evidence: • EDNRA and CALD1 – canonical markers of contractile vascular smooth-muscle cells and pericytes that respond to endothelin and rely on caldesmon-regulated actomyosin contraction. • ACAN – major cartilage proteoglycan whose induction in vascular smooth-muscle cells signals a chondrogenic, matrix-secretory “synthetic” state during vessel wall repair or calcification. • FHL5 – LIM-domain protein reported in smooth-muscle–rich tissues and up-regulated during their phenotypic modulation. • INPP4B – broadly expressed phosphatase induced during PI3K-mediated phenotype switching of smooth-muscle cells. • CNNM2 – magnesium transporter detected in perivascular cells and up-regulated during vascular remodeling. Inconsistencies: • CNNM2 is more characteristically renal/neuronal, and FHL5 is highly enriched in testis, so their presence may reflect broader stress-response or off-target expression rather than classic smooth-muscle biology. • Absence of negative-loading (down-regulated) contractile genes such as ACTA2 or MYH11 limits resolution of contractile-to-synthetic transition.

program_26.description: The gene set is most consistent with a Notch-active gastrointestinal surface epithelial/enterocyte-progenitor program that combines epithelial transport/lipid-handling functions with an IFN-γ–inducible, immune-modulatory state. Evidence: • Epithelial identity/transport – SLC14A1 (UT-B) is highly expressed on colonic, gastric and bladder epithelia to shuttle urea. – TM4SF18 is a tetraspanin enriched in stomach, colon and pancreatic duct/acinar epithelium. – TMEM88 is an apical membrane protein in intestinal epithelium that modulates Wnt signaling. • Notch-driven progenitor state – HES1 is the canonical Notch target that maintains intestinal crypt/early absorptive progenitors and suppresses secretory differentiation. • Metabolic support for absorption – MGLL governs monoacylglycerol hydrolysis in enterocytes to release free fatty acids for uptake. • Immune tolerance/IFN response – IDO1 is robustly induced in intestinal epithelial cells by IFN-γ and limits mucosal T-cell activation via tryptophan catabolism. Inconsistencies: • IDO1 and MGLL can also mark myeloid or tumor cells under inflammatory conditions. • SLC14A1 is abundant in erythrocytes and bladder epithelium, so its presence is not wholly specific to gut epithelium.

program_27.description: The gene set most closely matches a microvascular endothelial‐cell identity program, highlighting cells that maintain vascular barrier integrity and respond to sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) and cAMP signalling. Evidence: • ECSCR (Endothelial Cell-Specific Chemotaxis Regulator) – highly restricted to capillary and venous endothelial cells, regulates VEGF-induced migration. • S1PR1 – canonical S1P receptor that sustains endothelial barrier function and angiogenic sprouting. • B3GNT5 and GFOD2 – enriched in microvascular endothelium and implicated in glycocalyx/glycosylation processes that affect vessel permeability. • ADCY4 – adenylate cyclase isoform activated by GPCRs (including S1PR1) to produce cAMP, a key second messenger in endothelial barrier regulation. Inconsistencies: • CARD8 is best known as an inflammasome modulator in myeloid cells; while low-level expression occurs in endothelium, its prominence here is less typical.

program_28.description: The program is most consistent with a neuronal (likely cortical/hippocampal) state enriched for calcium-dependent signaling and actin-based vesicle trafficking, features typical of mature excitatory neurons engaged in synaptic activity. Evidence: • RASGRF2 – neuron-specific Ras-GEF activated by NMDA receptors, required for synaptic plasticity. • SLC24A1 (NCKX1) and ITPR3 – core components of neuronal Ca²⁺ homeostasis; NCKX1 extrudes Ca²⁺ after action potentials, while ITPR3 releases ER Ca²⁺ during synaptic transmission. • MYO5A – actin-based motor that transports vesicles/organelles in axons and dendrites, essential for neurotransmitter release and spine maturation. • ADGRG1 (GPR56) – adhesion GPCR enriched in developing and adult forebrain neurons, guides neuronal migration and cortical layering. • ZDHHC13 – palmitoyl-transferase that modifies multiple synaptic proteins (e.g., huntingtin, PSD95), supporting synapse stability. Inconsistencies: • MYO5A and ADGRG1 are also expressed in melanocytes, and ITPR3 is found in some non-neuronal epithelia, but the collective, concordant neuronal function of all six genes outweighs these broader expression profiles.

program_29.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial-to-mesenchymal–like (EMT-like) invasive state often seen in proliferating carcinoma or other highly migratory cells, characterized by re-wiring of cytoskeletal dynamics and RNA-processing to support motility and growth. Evidence: • Actin-cytoskeleton / motility regulators – BAIAP2L1 (IRTKS, actin bundling, membrane protrusions), FGD6 (CDC42 GEF essential for cell migration and angiogenic sprouting), NUDCD1 (regulates dynein–microtubule interactions, enhances invasion in cancers). • EMT-promoting transcription / signaling – NFE2L3 (NRF3) drives proteasome and EMT programs, fostering invasiveness in colorectal and breast cancers. • Alternative-splicing and RNA-binding factors that remodel gene expression during EMT – RBMS2 (stabilises cell-cycle/EMT mRNAs), PTBP3 (ROD1, hematopoietic/epithelial splicing factor that induces ZEB1 and EMT). • Absence of lineage-restricted markers supports the view that the program represents a cell-state (invasion/EMT) rather than a specific differentiated cell type. Inconsistencies: • Classic canonical EMT markers (e.g., VIM, FN1, SNAI1) are not present, so the program may represent a partial or early EMT rather than a full mesenchymal conversion.

program_30.description: The gene combination is most consistent with a WNT2⁺ mesenchymal stromal / fibroblast program seen in several tissues (e.g., gut sub-epithelial telocytes, lung alveolar fibroblasts, cancer-associated fibroblasts) that provide paracrine WNT signals and can acquire an osteogenic/RANKL-producing state. Evidence: • WNT2 and BICC1 – canonical markers of the WNT2⁺ fibroblast subset that supports nearby epithelium in intestine, lung and tumors. • DIO2 – thyroid-hormone–activating enzyme enriched in the same WNT2⁺ fibroblasts and in osteogenic mesenchyme, indicating a metabolically active stromal cell. • TNFSF11 (RANKL) – produced by osteogenic stromal cells and by synovial/cancer-associated fibroblasts to influence osteoclasts or immune cells, fitting an activated mesenchymal state. • TMEM200A – broadly expressed in fibro-adipogenic progenitors and tissue fibroblasts, reinforcing a stromal identity. • Lack of epithelial, endothelial, or immune lineage markers supports assignment to a fibroblast/mesenchymal program. Inconsistencies: • F2RL2 (PAR3) is better known in platelets/megakaryocytes; although it can be detected in some stromal cells, its presence is less typical of fibroblasts.

program_31.description: The gene set is characteristic of mature intestinal epithelial cells—predominantly absorptive enterocytes with some secretory features—reflecting a differentiated mucosal epithelium program typical of small intestine/colonic lining. Evidence: • PHGR1, FABP1 – highly expressed in differentiated enterocytes; FABP1 supports fatty-acid uptake characteristic of absorptive epithelium. • FXYD3 – membrane protein enriched in gastrointestinal epithelial cells, marking mature intestinal/colonic epithelium. • PIGR – receptor mediating trans-epithelial transport of secretory IgA, a hallmark function of gut epithelial cells. • GUCA2A (guanylin) & GUCA2B (uroguanylin) – paracrine peptides produced by intestinal epithelial cells that regulate electrolyte and fluid secretion via GC-C, typical of differentiated small intestine and colonic cells. Inconsistencies: No notable inconsistencies; all listed genes align with a mature intestinal epithelial program.

program_32.description: The gene set is most consistent with an inflammatory/activated endothelial-cell program, typical of vascular endothelium exposed to cytokines such as TNF-α or IL-1β, which up-regulates leukocyte-adhesion molecules, secretes myeloid growth factors and modifies lipid handling. Evidence: • SELE (E-selectin) and SELP (P-selectin) – canonical adhesion molecules rapidly induced in activated endothelial cells to recruit leukocytes. • LIPG – endothelial lipase, strongly enriched in vascular endothelium and further induced by inflammatory stimuli. • CSF3 (G-CSF) – produced by cytokine-stimulated endothelial cells to promote neutrophil mobilization. • CSF2RB – shared β-chain of GM-CSF/IL-3/IL-5 receptor; endothelial cells up-regulate this subunit under stress to respond to hematopoietic cytokines. • LAMP3 – up-regulated in hypoxic or TNF-activated endothelial cells and marks their lysosomal/endosomal remodeling during inflammation. Inconsistencies: • LAMP3 is also a hallmark of mature migratory dendritic cells, and CSF2RB is classically hematopoietic; their presence could reflect minor dendritic/immune contamination or endothelial–immune cross-talk rather than pure endothelial origin.

program_33.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated mononuclear-phagocyte program—typical of peripheral macrophages or CNS microglia engaged in membrane repair, cytoskeletal remodeling and purinergic (UDP) inflammatory signaling. Evidence: • DYSF encodes dysferlin, highly expressed in macrophages and microglia where it supports membrane repair and phagocytic vesicle trafficking. • P2RY6 is a UDP-sensing purinergic receptor that drives pro-inflammatory responses in macrophages and microglia. • PLEK2 (pleckstrin-2) is enriched in hematopoietic myeloid cells and promotes actin reorganization during phagocytosis and cell spreading. • RASGRP3 is a DAG-activated Ras/Rap1 GEF expressed in innate immune cells, linking receptor stimulation to oxidative burst and cytokine production. • ACOT7 regulates intracellular acyl-CoA levels; its induction in macrophages supports lipid remodeling during activation. Inconsistencies: • ACOT7 is also well known in neurons; if neuronal clusters are absent in the dataset, its presence could reflect cross-contamination or broader metabolic activation rather than a strictly myeloid signature.

program_34.description: The gene set is most consistent with an “activated vascular endothelial/vascular wall remodeling” program, i.e. endothelial cells (and closely related vascular wall cells) that are responding to pro-inflammatory or mechanical cues and are gearing up for extracellular-matrix turnover and vesicle/lysosome-dependent secretion. Evidence: • TSPAN18 – endothelial and platelet-enriched tetraspanin required for ORAI1-mediated Ca²⁺ influx and von Willebrand factor release during endothelial activation. • ADAMTS7 – secreted metalloprotease induced in endothelial and vascular smooth-muscle cells; degrades matrix proteins during vascular remodeling and atherogenesis. • PPM1F – Ca²⁺/calmodulin-regulated phosphatase that de-phosphorylates cytoskeletal regulators (e.g., RhoA) in migrating/activated endothelial cells. • LIMD1 – scaffold that links cytoskeleton and hypoxia-inducible signaling; up-regulated by shear stress in endothelial cells. • ATP13A2 – lysosomal P5-type ATPase that supports vesicle/lysosome function, consistent with increased secretory/turnover demand during endothelial activation. Inconsistencies: • ATP13A2 is best known for neuronal lysosome biology; its presence in this program is supportive of high vesicular activity but is not strictly endothelial-specific.

program_35.description: The program resembles a generic “high metabolic/house-keeping” state seen in cells that are actively synthesising macromolecules and shuttling material through endo-lysosomal and nuclear-pore pathways, rather than a lineage-restricted signature. It is therefore most consistent with a broad, metabolically up-regulated cellular state that can accompany proliferation or activation across multiple cell types. Evidence: • ATP6V1A – V-ATPase catalytic subunit; up-regulated when endo-lysosomal acidification and autophagy are high, a common feature of metabolically active or activated cells. • PFAS – rate-limiting enzyme in de-novo purine synthesis; elevated nucleotide demand accompanies cell growth/proliferation. • YEATS2 – scaffold of the ATAC histone-acetyltransferase complex; increased chromatin remodelling during transcriptional up-shift. • POM121C – nucleoporin that expands nuclear-pore number/throughput during heightened mRNA export. • Collectively, these genes define enhanced macromolecular biosynthesis, trafficking and acidification typical of a “house-keeping/high-activity” program. Inconsistencies: • CD2AP is best known for roles in immune synapse formation (T/B cells) and podocyte slit-diaphragm maintenance; its enrichment is not a prototypical marker of a generic metabolic program and could indicate concurrent cytoskeletal remodelling in a subset of immune or epithelial cells.

program_36.description: The program represents a sex-chromosome signature that marks male (XY) cells; it is not tied to any particular lineage or activation state but instead reflects ubiquitous expression of housekeeping genes encoded on the Y chromosome. Evidence: - RPS4Y1, DDX3Y, EIF1AY: Y-linked ribosomal or translation-related genes broadly expressed in all viable male cells. - ZFY: Y-linked zinc-finger transcription factor expressed across many male tissues. - KDM5D: Y-linked histone lysine demethylase constitutively transcribed in male cells and frequently used to distinguish male from female samples. Inconsistencies: - None detected; all positively loaded genes are canonical Y-chromosome markers, and no negatively loaded genes are provided.

program_37.description: The gene set most consistently points to a cellular program characterized by heightened post-translational protein processing—ubiquitination/SUMO-regulation and O-glycosylation—typically up-regulated in activated lymphocytes and other immune cells preparing for effector functions. Evidence: • Ubiquitin/SUMO control – RC3H2 (Roquin-2): RING-type E3 ubiquitin ligase that fine-tunes mRNA stability during T-cell and B-cell activation. – OTUD6B: Cytoplasmic de-ubiquitinase that dampens innate-immune signaling and is induced in activated lymphocytes. – SENP6: SUMO-specific protease required for proliferating hematopoietic and B‐cell populations; promotes turnover of SUMO-modified proteins during immune activation. • Glycosylation/secretory pathway – GALNT7: O-GalNAc transferase enriched in cells with high secretory load—including stimulated lymphocytes—and required for rapid proliferation. – GXYLT1: Xylosyl-transferase that modifies Notch and other EGF-like repeat–containing proteins; Notch signaling is a key pathway during T- and B-cell activation and differentiation. Together these genes describe a coordinated increase in protein quality-control and processing machinery, a hallmark of immune cells transitioning from quiescence to an activated, biosynthetically active state. Inconsistencies: • Classical activation markers (e.g., CD69, IL2RA, IRF4, immunoglobulin chains) and generic cell-cycle genes (MKI67, TOP2A) are absent, so the program may represent only the proteostasis facet of activation and could, in principle, be engaged by other highly secretory cell types.

program_38.description: The gene set represents a nuclear, chromatin-modifying / transcriptional-repression program that is typically enriched in pluripotent or highly plastic progenitor cells rather than in a lineage-committed mature cell type. The coordinated up-regulation of multiple epigenetic regulators and co-repressors (SPEN, MBD2, NACC1, KLF16) together with the nonsense-mediated decay factor SMG7 points to a state in which the cell is tightening control over transcription and mRNA quality—features commonly observed in embryonic stem cells and other rapidly cycling, undifferentiated populations preparing for fate decisions. Evidence: • Chromatin repression: SPEN (Notch and Xist co-repressor), MBD2 (methyl-CpG–binding NuRD component) and KLF16 (GC-box binding KLF family member) cooperate in transcriptional silencing and chromatin remodeling. • Pluripotency / progenitor links: NACC1 is highly expressed in embryonic stem cells and cancers, supporting self-renewal and proliferation; MBD2 and SPEN are likewise enriched during early developmental stages. • mRNA surveillance component: SMG7 enforces nonsense-mediated decay, complementing the above repressors by limiting aberrant transcripts—a quality-control mechanism accentuated in stem and progenitor compartments. Inconsistencies: No strong lineage-specific markers appear in either direction; the program lacks obvious contradictions but is also not highly specific, so it should be interpreted as a general epigenetic control state rather than a definitive cell-lineage signature.

program_39.description: The program most closely matches a tuft/solitary chemosensory epithelial cell state, a rare secretory cell type found in the airway and intestine that specializes in sensing luminal stimuli and producing cysteinyl-leukotrienes. Evidence: • LTC4S – hallmark enzyme of cysteinyl-leukotriene synthesis that is strongly and selectively expressed in intestinal and airway tuft cells. • KCTD12 & SSTR1 – GPCR-associated signalling components; tuft cells are enriched for neuronal-like GPCR and G-protein modulators involved in chemosensation. • TMEM100 – reported in Notch/BMP-regulated epithelial lineages and included in published tuft-cell gene sets from gut and trachea. • CLU – secreted chaperone up-regulated in multiple secretory epithelial subsets, including published tuft-cell profiles, consistent with the secretory nature of these cells. Inconsistencies: • CLU is broadly expressed in many stressed or secretory cells, so it is not exclusively tuft-specific. • Classical immune leukotriene-producing cells (mast cells, eosinophils) would co-express KIT, TPSAB1, CPA3, PRG2, etc., which are absent here, arguing against an immune origin but worth noting as a potential alternative explanation for LTC4S expression.

program_0.description: The gene set represents a generic G2/M-phase cell-cycle program characteristic of any actively dividing cell, rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. High expression of mitotic regulators (cyclins, kinases, spindle and centromere proteins) together with the proliferation marker MKI67 indicates cells that are in late S, G2, or mitosis. Evidence: • Core mitotic cyclins and CDKs: CCNB1, CCNB2, CCNA2, CDK1, CDC25C – drive G2/M transition. • Chromosome condensation/segregation: TOP2A, NCAPG, CENPA, CENPE, CENPF, CENPW, SGO1, HJURP, NUF2 – required for chromatid cohesion and kinetochore function. • Spindle assembly & motor proteins: KIF11, KIF14, KIF18A/B, KIF20A, KIF23, KIF2C, KIFC1, AURKB, PLK1, TTK, TPX2, NUSAP1 – assemble and regulate the mitotic spindle. • Cytokinesis/scaffold proteins: ANLN, PRC1, CEP55, RACGAP1, CIT – coordinate contractile ring formation and abscission. • Proliferation markers: MKI67, BIRC5 (survivin), UBE2C, GTSE1, FOXM1 – classical markers of dividing cells. • Absence of lineage-specific transcripts and the uniformly positive loadings support a shared proliferative state rather than a specialized differentiation program. Inconsistencies: No substantial inconsistencies; occasional genes with broader functions (e.g., SMTN, MTFR2) are reported to rise during division or cytoskeletal remodeling and do not contradict a mitotic program.

program_1.description: The program represents a “high‐translation” state characterized by coordinated up-regulation of cytosolic ribosomal proteins and other components of the protein-synthesis machinery. Such a signature is broadly seen in proliferating or recently activated cells (e.g., cycling progenitors, stimulated lymphocytes, many tumor cells) that require elevated protein production, rather than being specific to a single lineage. Evidence: • Ribosomal protein surge – virtually every small- (RPS) and large-subunit (RPL) gene is strongly loaded (e.g., RPL10, RPL13A, RPLP1/2, RPS3, RPS6, RPS18), a classic hallmark of increased ribosome biogenesis and translation. • Translation factors – EEF1A1 (elongation), RACK1 (ribosome-associated scaffold), TPT1, UBA52 and FAU (ubiquitin–ribosomal fusion proteins) further denote active protein synthesis and growth signaling. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes contribute to ribosome structure or translational control, supporting a coherent high-translation program without clear lineage-specific markers.

program_2.description: The gene set represents a highly cytotoxic, NK-receptor-expressing effector lymphocyte program typical of activated NK cells and/or NK-like cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells (including tissue-resident/innate-like subsets). Evidence: • Cytolytic machinery – GZMA, PRF1, GNLY, NKG7, CTSW encode granzymes, perforin, granulysin and granule-associated proteins that mediate target-cell killing. • NK receptors & signalling adapters – KLRD1 (CD94), KLRC1 (NKG2A), KLRC2 (NKG2C) together with TYROBP (DAP12), FCER1G and HCST (DAP10) are canonical components of NK-cell activation pathways and are also found in NK-like CD8⁺ T_RM/MAIT cells. • Chemokine/effector markers of activated cytotoxic lymphocytes – CCL5 (RANTES) and XCL2 are secreted by activated NK and cytotoxic T cells to recruit additional immune cells. • T-cell identity & effector differentiation – CD7 and HOPX are expressed in mature effector/memory CD8⁺ T cells, supporting a T-lineage component. • Negative loading of LTB (lymphotoxin-β), a gene enriched in naïve/central-memory T cells, is consistent with a terminally differentiated cytotoxic state. Inconsistencies: • No strong inconsistencies; however, the presence of multiple NK-specific signalling adapters (TYROBP, FCER1G) suggests a heavier NK bias than seen in conventional CD8⁺ T cells, while the absence of classical CD8A/B genes in the loadings could reflect dataset-specific variability rather than true absence.

program_3.description: The program is characteristic of resting, mature (primarily naïve / non–germinal-center) B lymphocytes displaying an intact B-cell receptor (BCR) signaling apparatus and dependence on BAFF-R–mediated survival signals. Evidence: • Core B-cell surface molecules: CD19, CD22, MS4A1 (CD20), CD79A collectively define mature B cells. • BCR signaling scaffold/kinases: BANK1 and BLK are classic BCR–proximal signaling components enriched in naïve B cells. • Transcriptional regulators of naïve B identity: BCL11A, MEF2C, POU2AF1 (OBF-1) and TCF4 maintain mature, non-activated B-cell programs and are down-regulated upon plasma-cell or germinal-center transition. • BAFF-R pathway: TNFRSF13C (BAFF-R) is required for peripheral B-cell survival and marks mature naïve and marginal-zone B cells. • Additional B-lineage/pre-B genes: VPREB3 and LY86 are frequently retained at low levels in resting peripheral B cells, reinforcing lineage identity. Inconsistencies: • ARHGAP24 and BASP1 are not B-cell–specific; however, both are expressed in lymphoid cells and do not contradict a mature B-cell state.

program_4.description: The gene set represents leukocytes (PTPRC⁺) that are undergoing a mitochondrial-stress or pre-apoptotic state characterized by heightened transcription of mitochondrial genome–encoded oxidative-phosphorylation genes and concurrent suppression of ribosomal/house-keeping transcripts. Evidence: • Mitochondrial stress signature – strong positive loading of multiple mtDNA genes (MT-ATP6, MT-CO2/3, MT-CYB, MT-ND1/3/4/5) is a well-recognized hallmark of cells with high mitochondrial RNA content seen during oxidative stress or early apoptosis. • Global translation down-regulation – negative loading of ribosomal protein genes (RPL31, RPS17, RPS26) and actin-binding housekeeping genes (PFN1, TMSB4X) is typical when protein synthesis is reduced under cellular stress. • Stress-activated transcription factors – JUND (AP-1 component) and ETS1 are induced by reactive oxygen species and mitochondrial dysfunction, reinforcing a stress/apoptotic program. • Leukocyte identity – PTPRC (CD45) confirms the program operates in immune cells rather than in parenchymal tissues. Inconsistencies: • No major conflicts; lineage-specific markers beyond PTPRC are absent, so the exact leukocyte subset (e.g., T vs. B vs. myeloid) cannot be resolved.

program_5.description: The program most closely represents an activated / signaling-competent natural killer (NK) cell state driven by immunoreceptor adaptor pathways (FcεRI-γ, DAP12/TYROBP, LAT2) and NK-specific receptors (KIR2DL4), accompanied by downstream tyrosine-kinase signaling (FGR, FES) and the NK-secreted chemokine XCL2. Evidence: • NK-restricted receptors / adaptors – KIR2DL4, FCER1G, TYROBP (DAP12), SH2D1B (EAT-2) and LAT2 are core components of activating SLAM-, Fc- and KIR-mediated signaling in NK cells. • NK/ILC chemokine – XCL2 is classically produced by activated NK and cytotoxic T cells. • Innate-immune GPCR – ADGRG3 (GPR97) is enriched in granulocytes and NK/innate lymphoid cells. • Signal-propagating kinases – FGR and FES are Src-family/non-receptor tyrosine kinases induced during Fc-receptor signaling in NK and myeloid cells, consistent with an activated signaling program. • Modulators of receptor/RTK pathways – SPRY2 and CXXC5 are induced after growth-factor or cytokine stimulation, fitting an activation context rather than a resting state. Inconsistencies: • KRT81 (hair keratin) and COL23A1 (epithelial collagen) are epithelial/keratinocyte genes not typically expressed in NK cells, suggesting low-level contamination or ambient RNA. • CCNJL and B3GNT7 are ubiquitous cell-cycle / glycosylation genes without clear NK specificity.

program_6.description: The gene loadings depict a “high-translation/low-immune” cellular program typical of metabolically active, non-immune (e.g., epithelial or stromal) cells that are ramping up protein synthesis while simultaneously down-regulating antigen-presentation and cytotoxic T-cell genes; this pattern is often seen in proliferating tumor or regenerating somatic cells that are not engaged in immune functions. Evidence: • Up-regulated ribosome/elongation machinery (EEF1B2, RPL4, RPLP0, RPL7A, RPL36A, RPL23, RPS24) ⇒ heightened global protein synthesis characteristic of proliferating or highly metabolically active somatic cells. • FOS, an immediate-early gene induced by growth-factor or stress signaling, commonly accompanies entry into proliferation and increased biosynthetic demand. • Concurrent down-regulation of classical MHC-I complex genes (HLA-A, HLA-B, B2M) ⇒ loss or reduction of antigen-presentation typical of non-immune or immune-evasive cells. • Reduced IL32 and GZMK, markers of activated/cytotoxic T cells, supports absence of T-cell effector identity and further separates this program from immune activation. • Net pattern therefore fits a state of non-immune cells focused on biosynthesis rather than immune interaction. Inconsistencies: • MT-CO1 (mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation gene) being negatively loaded suggests slightly lower mitochondrial transcript abundance, which is not uniformly associated with hyper-translation but could reflect technical variation or a shift toward glycolytic metabolism.

program_7.description: The program represents an early T-cell receptor (TCR) activation signature, typical of recently stimulated CD4⁺ (and some CD8⁺) T cells that still express the homeostatic receptor IL-7R. Evidence: • Immediate-early response/AP-1 complex: FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, EGR1, BTG2, DUSP1 – rapidly induced within minutes of TCR engagement. • NF-κB pathway modulation: NFKBIA (IκBα) and TNFAIP3 (A20) are classic feedback inhibitors transcribed after TCR-triggered NF-κB activation. • Early surface activation marker: CD69 is one of the first proteins up-regulated after T-cell stimulation. • Cytokine/chemokine receptors associated with resting–memory or lymphoid-homing T cells: IL7R (CD127) and CXCR4, consistent with non-terminally differentiated, recently activated cells. • Glucocorticoid-induced leucine zipper TSC22D3 (GILZ) and transcription factor KLF6 are both up-regulated downstream of TCR signaling and modulate activation thresholds. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes were provided, and all positively loaded genes coherently fit an early T-cell activation program; thus no major inconsistencies are apparent.

program_8.description: The gene set points to a highly activated, cytotoxic T-cell state (HLA-DR^hi GZMB^+ “effector”/“peripheral helper–like” T cells) that has up-regulated MHC class II genes under strong IFN-γ stimulation, a phenotype reported for chronically stimulated CD8⁺ and CD4⁺ T cells in infection and cancer. Evidence: • Cytotoxic/effector molecules: GZMB, GZMH and IFNG mark classical cytolytic T-cell activity. • Activation-induced chemokines: CCL3, CCL4 and CXCL13 are secreted by strongly activated T cells to recruit additional immune cells; CXCL13 is characteristic of peripheral helper/T_FH-like CD4⁺ T cells found in inflamed tissues. • HLA class II machinery: HLA-DRB1, HLA-DRA, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQA1 and CD74 collectively indicate HLA-DR^hi status; although typical of professional APCs, these genes are induced in T cells after sustained IFN-γ signalling and mark intensely activated or chronically stimulated effector T cells. Inconsistencies: • Robust MHC-II expression is more canonical for APCs; its presence requires IFN-γ–mediated induction in T cells. • Lack of explicit CD8A/B or CD4 transcripts in the provided list prevents assignment to a precise T-cell subset.

program_9.description: The program most closely reflects an activated / effector regulatory T-cell (Treg) state. Evidence: • Core Treg identity – FOXP3 (lineage-defining transcription factor) and IL2RA/CD25 are indispensable markers of regulatory T cells. • Activated/effector Treg features – TNFRSF4/OX40 and BATF are highly induced upon T-cell receptor stimulation in suppressive, tissue-migratory Tregs; LTB and IL1R2 are likewise up-regulated in activated Tregs and contribute to immunomodulatory functions. • Survival / suppressive support – RTKN2 promotes NF-κB–dependent survival of resting and activated Tregs. • Lack of negative loading genes eliminates counter-signatures (e.g., cytotoxic, naive, or non-T lineages) that might oppose a Treg interpretation. Inconsistencies: • CD177 is classically a neutrophil surface protein and is uncommon in T cells. • FANK1 (testis-associated) and SAT1 (ubiquitous polyamine metabolism) are not specifically linked to Treg biology and may reflect broader activation or technical noise.

program_10.description: The program reflects a generic actin-cytoskeleton/housekeeping signature that is prominent in most non-lymphoid or activated immune cells and is specifically low in naïve, recirculating T cells. Evidence: • Cytoskeleton and actin-remodeling genes are positively loaded ─ ACTB (β-actin), CFL1 (cofilin 1), ARPC2 (ARP2/3 complex), MYL6 (myosin light chain) and SH3BGRL3 (interacts with actin) — indicating enhanced actin dynamics and cell motility. • Metabolic housekeeping gene GAPDH is also positively loaded, fitting a high baseline metabolic program. • Naïve T-cell trafficking factors are negatively loaded ─ IL7R, CCR7 and the transcription factor KLF2 (drives CCR7/S1PR1) — showing the program is suppressed in naïve, lymph-node-homing T cells and therefore marks other cell types or more activated T-cell states. Inconsistencies: • None of the positively loaded genes are lineage-restricted, so the program lacks markers that pinpoint a single differentiated cell type; it instead captures a broad cellular state (high cytoskeletal activity) common to many lineages.

program_11.description: The program reflects a canonical heat-shock / proteotoxic-stress response that can be transiently activated in virtually any cell type when cytosolic protein folding capacity is challenged; it is driven by HSF1 and characterized by coordinated induction of multiple chaperones and co-chaperones. Evidence: • Core inducible HSP70 family members HSPA1A, HSPA1B and HSPA6 are prototypical HSF1 targets up-regulated during heat shock and other proteotoxic stresses. • HSP90AA1, HSPE1 (HSP10), HSPH1 (HSP105) and HSPB1 (HSP27) compose the major cytosolic chaperone network mobilized to refold or triage mis-folded proteins. • DNAJB1 (HSP40) acts as a co-chaperone that stimulates HSP70 ATPase activity, a hallmark of the heat-shock response module. • JUN is an immediate-early transcription factor frequently co-induced by cellular stress and functions downstream of MAPK pathways activated during heat shock. Inconsistencies: No clear inconsistencies—every listed gene is a well-described component or companion effector of the heat-shock response.

program_12.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature, highly cytotoxic CD16⁺ natural killer (NK)–cell program (closely related to terminally differentiated effector CD8⁺ T/NK cells), characterized by strong Fc-receptor signaling, killer lectin receptors, and tissue-egress capacity. Evidence: • FGFBP2 – canonical marker of late-stage cytotoxic NK and CD8⁺ T cells with high perforin/granzyme content. • FCGR3A (CD16) – defines mature CD56^dim CD16⁺ NK cells that mediate antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity. • KLRF1 – NK‐associated activating receptor (NKp80) enriched in cytotoxic NK/T subsets. • S1PR5 – sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor driving bone-marrow egress of mature NK cells. • PLAC8 and SPON2 – up-regulated in activated, tissue-infiltrating innate lymphocytes (NK/T) and augment cytotoxic or migratory functions, fitting an activated effector state. Inconsistencies: • IGFBP7 and AKR1C3 are more typical of stromal or myeloid populations; their co-expression suggests either contaminating transcripts or a specialized NK subset acquiring tissue-remodeling/oxidoreductive functions.

program_13.description: The gene set reflects an acutely activated, pro-inflammatory myeloid program characteristic of circulating inflammatory monocytes or newly recruited neutrophil-like cells producing IL-1β and CXCL8 in response to TLR/LPS stimulation. Evidence: • CXCL8 (IL-8) – canonical chemokine released by activated monocytes/neutrophils to recruit additional granulocytes. • IL1B and IL1RN – hallmark genes of TLR-activated monocytes; IL-1β synthesis together with its natural antagonist defines an IL-1–driven inflammatory response. • S100A8 and S100A9 – calcium-binding alarmins abundantly expressed in inflammatory monocytes and neutrophils; form the heterodimer calprotectin released during acute inflammation. • G0S2 – induced by NF-κB signaling in activated monocytes; linked to early cell-cycle exit and cytokine production. • FTH1 – ferritin heavy chain up-regulated in myeloid cells under inflammatory/oxidative stress to sequester iron during infection. • C15orf48 (NMES1) – enriched in inflammatory macrophages/monocytes and up-regulated after LPS stimulation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently map to an acute inflammatory myeloid activation program.

program_14.description: The gene set defines a canonical S-phase cell-cycle program, marking cells that are actively synthesizing DNA and preparing for mitosis rather than a specific differentiated lineage. Evidence: • TYMS and RRM2 encode key enzymes for de-novo dTTP and dNTP synthesis, a classic requirement of S-phase. • PCLAF (KIAA0101) and CKS1B bind PCNA or CDKs, respectively, promoting DNA polymerase processivity and G1/S transition. • ZWINT participates in kinetochore assembly, up-regulated from late S through G2/M in dividing cells. • HMGN2 is enriched in rapidly cycling cells, facilitating chromatin remodeling during replication. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes and no lineage-restricted markers are present; the program is coherent with a generic proliferative (S-phase) state.

program_15.description: The gene set represents an activated human T-helper 17 (Th17) effector program, characterized by robust IL-17 cytokine production and associated chemokine/enzymatic mediators of inflammation and tissue remodeling.
