Evidence: • IL17A and IL17F – signature cytokines that define Th17 cells and drive neutrophilic inflammation. • IL26 – cytokine produced almost exclusively by human Th17 cells, often co-expressed with IL-17A/F. • CCL20 – chemokine transcriptionally coregulated with IL-17 in Th17 cells; attracts CCR6⁺ Th17 cells and dendritic cells. • CTSH – lysosomal protease up-regulated in activated T cells, including Th17, supporting high secretory activity. • ADAM12 – metalloprotease inducible by IL-17 signaling and reported in IL-17–secreting T cells, contributing to extracellular matrix remodeling during Th17-mediated inflammation. Inconsistencies: • ADAM12 and CTSH are not exclusive to Th17 cells and are also expressed by stromal or myeloid populations; however, their co-occurrence with multiple canonical Th17 cytokines suggests they reflect activation rather than a different lineage.

program_16.description: The gene set strongly points to an activated, lipid-handling complement-producing macrophage/microglia state, akin to the “disease-associated microglia” (DAM) program described in neurodegeneration and other inflammatory contexts. Evidence: • Complement transcripts C1QA, C1QB, C1QC – canonical markers of tissue-resident macrophages, especially microglia, and are sharply up-regulated in DAM/activated states. • APOE and APOC1 – apolipoproteins induced during lipid-scavenging and phagocytic activation of microglia/macrophages; APOE is a hallmark of DAM microglia. • FTL (ferritin light chain) – iron-storage protein elevated in activated or stress-responsive macrophages/microglia, consistent with oxidative and phagolysosomal activity typical of the DAM program. Inconsistencies: No notable conflicting genes are present in this concise list.

program_17.description: The program represents a canonical type I interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) response—an antiviral activation state that can be elicited in virtually any nucleated cell upon exposure to IFN-α/β or viral RNA. Evidence: • ISG15, IFIT1, IFIT3 – classic ISGs that inhibit viral replication by blocking translation and tagging proteins for ISGylation. • IFI6, IFI44L – IFN-α/β–inducible genes that restrict flavivirus and other viral infections. • LY6E – up-regulated by type I IFN and shown to modulate coronavirus and HIV entry. • All listed genes rise coordinately after STAT1/2–IRF9 signaling, depicting a broad antiviral state rather than lineage-specific identity. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes or non-ISGs are present; no major contradictions detected.

program_18.description: The gene set reflects a mature intestinal epithelial (enterocyte-dominant) program, characteristic of absorptive/secretory cells of the small intestine and colon that produce the paracrine hormones guanylin and uroguanylin. Evidence: • GUCA2A & GUCA2B – encode guanylin and uroguanylin, hormones secreted almost exclusively by intestinal epithelial cells (highest in jejunum, ileum, colon). • PHGR1 (PRAP1) – highly enriched in differentiated intestinal epithelium and used as an enterocyte marker in scRNA-seq atlases. • FABP1 – cytosolic fatty-acid–binding protein abundant in mature enterocytes (and hepatocytes), supporting an absorptive lipid-handling role. • FXYD3 – ion-transport regulator expressed in gastric/intestinal mucosa and up-regulated in differentiated colonic epithelium, fitting an epithelial ion-transport program. Inconsistencies: • FABP1 is also a hepatocyte marker, and FXYD3 is expressed in gastric epithelium, but both genes are nevertheless well-documented in intestinal enterocytes, so no major conflict with the proposed intestinal epithelial program.

program_0.description: The gene set is most consistent with activated stromal fibroblasts that have acquired a contractile “myofibroblast / perivascular” phenotype typical of wound-healing, fibrotic tissue or tumor-associated stroma. The program couples strong extracellular-matrix (ECM) synthesis and remodeling with induction of smooth-muscle–like contractile machinery and pericyte markers. Evidence: • ECM production: high expression of fibrillar collagens (COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1, COL5A1/2, COL6A1-3, COL12A1, COL14A1), proteoglycans (DCN, LUM, OGN, ASPN, PRELP), matrix glycoproteins (FBLN1/2/5, SPARC, DPT, THBS2), and elastic-fiber genes (ELN, LOX, LOXL1). • ECM remodeling: MMP2, MMP11, ADAMTS2, CTSK, LOXL1, LOX indicate active matrix turnover typical of fibrotic myofibroblasts. • Canonical fibroblast markers: PDGFRA, THY1, MFAP4/5, FBN1, AEBP1, SFRP1/2. • Contractile/myofibroblast module: ACTA2, TAGLN, MYL9, TPM2, LMOD1, MYLK, CALD1 confer smooth-muscle–like contractility. • Pericyte/perivascular signatures: PDGFRB, CSPG4, RGS5, NOTCH3, ANGPT1, ABCC9, KCNJ8 support a vessel-associated fibroblast/myofibroblast identity. • Pro-fibrotic or mesenchymal TFs: SNAI2, TWIST1/2, TCF21, FOXF1, FOXL1 drive fibroblast activation and EMT-like programs. • Complement/immune ECM cross-talk (C1S, C1R, C3, SERPING1, CFH) is typical of inflamed or tumor stroma. Inconsistencies: • A few intestine-enriched stromal genes (RSPO3, DCLK1, FOXL1) and neuronal-related genes (NOVA1, MAP1A) appear, but these are occasionally expressed in specialized fibroblast subsets and do not contradict a broad activated fibroblast / myofibroblast state.

program_1.description: The gene set is characteristic of vascular endothelial cells undergoing active angiogenic and remodeling activity (sprouting/tip-to-stalk transition) rather than a quiescent vessel‐lining state. Evidence: • Canonical endothelial identity: CDH5, VWF, KDR (VEGFR2), FLT1/FLT4, TEK/TIE1, ROBO4, ESAM, CLDN5, ENG, CD34, PECAM-associated genes (PTPRB, JAM2/3) collectively define endothelial lineage. • Angiogenic/tip–stalk regulators: DLL4–NOTCH4 axis, APLN / APLNR, VEGFC, FZD4, SOX17/18, HEY1, EPAS1, SPARC/SPARCL1, COL4A1/A2, SERPINE1, TIMP3, NOX4, PLVAP highlight sprouting, extracellular-matrix remodeling and hypoxia-driven vessel growth. • Endothelial activation/inflammation: SELE, SELP, CX3CL1, ACKR1, ICAM-like ESAM indicate cytokine-responsive, leukocyte-adhesive endothelium typical of remodeling microvessels. • Venule/capillary and fenestrated features: PLVAP, CLEC14A, MMRN2, COL15A1, SPARCL1, ACKR1, CD34 mark microvascular (especially venular) endothelium engaged in permeability regulation. • Developmental/immature signatures: TAL1, GATA2, MEOX1/2, ERG, SOX17/18, ESM1, RAMP2/3 suggest progenitor-like or plastic endothelial state accompanying angiogenesis. Inconsistencies: • Occasional neural-associated genes (SNCG, NRCAM, LHX6, SHANK3), osteogenic/mesenchymal ALPL, and tubular epithelial CUBN are atypical for endothelium and may reflect minor contamination or technical crosstalk rather than the core program.

program_2.description: The gene set represents a mural‐cell program characteristic of contractile vascular smooth muscle cells/pericytes, most consistent with an arterial or arteriolar state that is actively maintaining contractility while producing extracellular matrix. Evidence: • Contractile apparatus genes: ACTA2, MYH11, MYL9, TAGLN, CNN1, LMOD1, TPM2, MYLK, DES, PPP1R14A – canonical smooth-muscle contractile machinery. • Mural cell identity markers: PDGFRB, RGS5, NOTCH3, CSPG4, MCAM (CD146), THY1, EDNRA, GJA4 – well-described pericyte/vascular SMC markers. • Ion-channel and Ca²⁺-handling genes enriched in vascular SMCs: ABCC9, KCNJ8, KCNA5, CACNA1H, TRPC6, ATP1A2, FXYD1, PLN, HRC – support a contractile phenotype. • Arterial/Notch signalling components: HEYL, HEY2, FOXC2, S1PR3 – typical of arterial smooth muscle specification. • Extracellular-matrix and basal-lamina genes: multiple collagens (COL3A1, COL4A1/2, COL5A2/3, COL6A1/2), BGN, SPARC, SPARCL1, LAMA4, MGP, PXDN – consistent with mural cells that secrete and remodel vascular ECM. Inconsistencies: • ACAN (aggrecan) and OR51E1 are atypical for vascular SMCs and may reflect low-level ectopic expression or technical noise. • NFASC and ATP1B2 are more common in neural lineages but are occasionally detected in mural cells; their presence is minor relative to the dominant smooth-muscle signature.

program_3.description: The program is characteristic of activated, antigen-presenting inflammatory macrophages/monocyte-derived macrophages such as those observed in inflamed or hypoxic tissues (e.g., tumors, chronically inflamed lung), combining classical phagocyte markers with strong MHC-II expression, complement/FC-receptor components, and induction of hypoxia- and damage-response genes (SPP1, VEGFA, TIMP1). Evidence: • Core macrophage/monocyte identity: CD68, AIF1, CSF1R, CD14, FCGR1A/2A/3A, TYROBP, MS4A7, LST1, SPI1, MAFB. • Phagocytosis & microbicidal machinery: CYBB, NCF2, CTSB/L/S, CTSD/CTSS, CLEC7A, C3AR1, C5AR1, FCER1G, VSIG4, MSR1. • Complement & immunoglobulin handling: C1QA/B/C, CFP, C1orf162, FCGRs, LILRB2/4, LAIR1. • Antigen presentation/IFN response: HLA-DRA/DRB1/DPB1/DMB, CXCL9, APOBEC3A, MNDA. • Inflammatory/hypoxic tissue remodeling: SPP1, VEGFA, TIMP1, TNFAIP6, SERPINB2, PROK2, HIF1A, IER3, EREG. • Monocyte-origin skew: FCN1, CLEC4E, RNASE6, VCAN indicate recent recruitment from blood rather than resident tissue macrophages. Inconsistencies: • Co-expression of FCN1 (classical blood monocyte) with SPP1/VEGFA (tissue-embedded “SPP1 TAM” macrophages) suggests a mix of early and later differentiation signatures. • OTOA and C1orf162 lack known roles in myeloid biology and may reflect ambient RNA or technical noise.

program_4.description: The gene set represents the canonical G2/M-phase cell-cycle program characteristic of actively dividing cells—any cell type caught in late cell cycle will transiently display this transcriptional profile rather than a lineage-specific state. Evidence: • Core mitotic kinases and cyclins: CDK1, CCNB1, CCNB2, CCNA2, PLK1, PKMYT1 drive G2/M transition and mitotic entry. • Chromosome condensation, segregation, and kinetochore assembly: CENPA, CENPF, CENPE, CENPW, NDC80, NUF2, SPC24/25, BUB1, BUB1B, MAD2L1, SGO1/2, HJURP, NCAPG/D2/H, SMC-related genes ensure accurate chromosomal alignment and segregation. • Mitotic spindle and centrosome components: KIF11, KIF14, KIF18A/B, KIF20A, KIF2C, KIF4A, KIFC1, TPX2, TUBA1B, TUBB, ASPM, CEP55 orchestrate spindle formation and cytokinesis. • DNA replication/repair genes expressed in late S–G2: RRM2, BRCA1, BARD1, RAD51AP1, EXO1, NEIL3, POLQ, FAM72 family support DNA synthesis and repair before mitosis. • Proliferation markers: MKI67, TOP2A, BIRC5, UBE2C, FOXM1, HMGB2 are hallmarks of highly proliferative, cycling cells. Inconsistencies: • None; all listed genes are coherent with a generic G2/M cell-cycle module.

program_5.description: The gene set is characteristic of chronically-stimulated cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells that have entered an exhaustion/late effector state typical of tumor-infiltrating or chronically infected tissues. It combines a full T-cell receptor signaling module with strong cytolytic machinery and multiple co-inhibitory (“checkpoint”) receptors that mark progressive exhaustion, alongside chemokines (CXCL13, CCL5, XCL1) and tissue-resident/retention markers (CXCR6, CD69) frequently seen in dysfunctional, but still cytotoxic, CD8⁺ T cells. Evidence: • Core T-cell identity: CD3D/E/G, CD247, CD2, CD7, PTPRC, LCK, ZAP70, TRAT1 confirm αβ T-cell lineage. • CD8 lineage and cytolytic program: CD8A/B, PRF1, GZMA/B/H/K/M, NKG7, CST7, FASLG, IFNG, KLRD1, NCR1 denote CD8⁺ cytotoxic effector function. • Exhaustion/immune-checkpoint genes: PDCD1 (PD-1), CTLA4, TIGIT, LAG3, CD96, CXCL13, BATF, TOX-surrogate ID2 reflect chronic stimulation–induced dysfunction. • Activation/tissue retention: CD69, CXCR6, CXCR4, CCL5, XCL1, RGS1, ITK, CRTAM associate with tumor-infiltrating or tissue-resident effector T cells. • Transcriptional regulators of late effector fate: RUNX3, BATF, GATA3 (low-level), IKZF1, ID2 support terminal differentiation/exhaustion. Inconsistencies: • GATA3 is more typical of Th2 cells, but low expression can appear in some exhausted CD8⁺ T cells and does not outweigh the strong CD8 cytotoxic signature. • ADAMTS17 and SPOCK2 are extracellular matrix genes with unclear relevance to T cells, suggesting minor contamination or by-catch expression.

program_6.description: The gene set represents a “high-translation / ribosome-biogenesis” program that marks cells in a metabolically active, growth- or activation-associated state rather than a specific lineage; it is characterized by coordinated up-regulation of virtually all cytosolic ribosomal protein genes and translation factors and a concurrent down-regulation of the interferon-stimulated gene ISG15, indicating that the cells are focused on protein synthesis and are not engaged in an antiviral/interferon response. Evidence: • Extensive positive loading of ribosomal large- and small-subunit genes (e.g., RPL3, RPL10, RPL13A, RPLP0, RPS3, RPS6, RPS18) together with translation elongation factors EEF1A1 and EEF1B2 and chaperones NACA, TPT1 → classical signature of enhanced ribosome production and bulk protein synthesis. • Scaffold proteins involved in ribosome function or nascent-chain handling (RACK1/GNB2L1, UBA52, FAU) further support a translational focus. • Negative loading of ISG15, a canonical interferon-stimulated ubiquitin-like modifier, signifies relative suppression of interferon/antiviral stress pathways, consistent with cells prioritizing growth rather than defense. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; the program is broad and housekeeping in nature, so it does not by itself specify a unique cell lineage.

program_7.description: The gene set strongly points to antibody-secreting plasmablasts / plasma cells undergoing a vigorous unfolded-protein-response (UPR), consistent with mucosal, IgA-biased cells. Evidence: • Plasma-cell identity: TNFRSF17/BCMA, SLAMF7, CD38, FCRL5, MZB1, JCHAIN, POU2AF1, CD79A – canonical markers of plasmablasts/plasma cells and late B-cell differentiation. • Secretory/UPR machinery: XBP1 (master UPR regulator), HERPUD1, DERL3, SPCS1-3, SEC11C, SSR3/4, SEC61B, DNAJB9, HSP90B1, TXNDC5/11, PRDX4 – genes up-regulated to expand the ER and handle massive Ig synthesis. • Mucosal/IgA skewing: CCR10 and JCHAIN are characteristic of gut and other mucosal IgA-secreting plasma cells. • Survival/proliferation signals typical of plasmablasts: PIM2, BTG2, TSC22D3, JUN. • Absence of naïve B-cell genes (e.g., MS4A1/CD20) further supports a terminally differentiated state. Inconsistencies: • A few genes (MEI1, SPAG4, ENAM, DNAAF1, ESR2) are not typically linked to plasma cells and may reflect low-level or spurious expression.

program_8.description: The program reflects a cell-state rather than a specific lineage, capturing a “high oxidative-phosphorylation + proteasome” metabolic module that accompanies energetically demanding or proliferative conditions across many cell types (e.g., activated immune cells, cycling cancer cells, differentiating precursors). It is characterized by coordinated up-regulation of mitochondrial electron-transport components, ubiquitin-proteasome machinery, and mTOR/Ragulator signaling factors, together with broad RNA-processing genes. Evidence: • Oxidative phosphorylation/mitochondrial function – NDUFC2, NDUFB5, NDUFB8, NDUFA3, NDUFS6 (complex I), SLC25A3 (mitochondrial phosphate carrier), ACADM (β-oxidation), STOML2, MTCH2, FIS1, SMDT1 indicate boosted respiratory metabolism and mitochondrial dynamics. • Proteasome and ubiquitination – PSMB6, PSMD2/7/8, SEM1 (20S/19S subunits), ANAPC11, SKP1, UBE2L3 underline heightened ubiquitin-proteasome protein turnover. • Amino-acid/mTOR sensing – LAMTOR1 and LAMTOR5 (Ragulator complex) couple nutrient status to mTORC1, fitting a high-energy program. • RNA processing/translation support – SRSF9, HNRNPK, PCBP1, ARL6IP4, RPS27L, SERBP1 point to increased transcript processing and ribosome activity, typical of metabolically active cells. • Additional metabolic/stress-adaptation factors – PPP2CA (phosphatase in growth signaling), PEBP1 (RKIP), BRK1, TMBIM6, ERP29 contribute to protein quality control and membrane trafficking, coherent with the above state. Inconsistencies: No clear lineage-specific markers or glycolytic/cell-cycle genes are present, so the program is unlikely to denote a particular differentiated cell type or classic proliferation module; instead it signifies a generic high-metabolic/proteostasis state.

program_9.description: The program strongly reflects mature absorptive epithelial (colonocyte) cells of the large intestine, i.e. differentiated colonic enterocytes that are engaged in electrolyte/fluid transport and barrier functions, with a minor overlay of interferon/inflammatory stimulation. Evidence: • Core epithelial/colonocyte markers – EPCAM, KRT20, GPA33, CEACAM1/5/6/7, CLDN4/7/23, CDHR5, TSPAN1, MALL. • Absorptive/ion transport machinery typical of differentiated colonocytes – SLC26A3 (chloride/bicarbonate exchanger), CA2 & CA4 (carbonic anhydrases), AQP8 (water channel), PRKG2 and GUCA2A/B (cGMP pathway), ABCG2, MS4A12. • Additional colonic-specific or lumen-facing genes – LYPD8, CLCA4, PHGR1, PLAC8, MUC13, AOC1, DHRS9. • Low myeloid contamination indicated by negative loading of LSP1 (myeloid lineage marker). Inconsistencies: • CD177 (classically neutrophil) and ISG15 suggest some interferon/inflammatory activation of the epithelium. • REN and C4BPA are atypical for colonocytes but can be ectopically induced or reflect low-level ambient RNA.

program_10.description: The gene constellation reflects a generic “ER protein folding/quality-control” program, i.e. activation of the secretory apparatus and unfolded-protein response (UPR) that is typically up-regulated in highly secretory cells (e.g. plasma cells, activated endocrine or fibroblastic cells) or in cells experiencing ER stress. Evidence: • Protein disulfide-isomerase family and oxidoreductases (P4HB, PDIA3, PDIA4) – hallmarks of ER folding and redox control. • Calnexin cycle and lectin chaperones (CANX, OS9, SDF4) – core of glycoprotein folding and ER-associated degradation (ERAD). • N-linked glycosylation/oligosaccharyl-transferase complex (RPN1, RPN2, DDOST) plus ALG5 – essential for nascent-chain maturation in the ER lumen. • Translocon and TRAP components (SEC61A1, SEC63, SSR1) – import of nascent peptides into the ER. • ER retention/retrograde trafficking factors (KDELR1, KDELR2, RER1, TMED10, LMAN2, ARF1, ARF4) – recycle chaperones and mis-folded proteins between ER and Golgi. • ERAD and stress auxiliaries (AUP1, UFM1, UBXN4, HM13, TMEM208) – dispose of mis-folded proteins and signal UPR. • Vacuolar ATPase (ATP6V0B) and TM9SF2 – support acidification and vesicle trafficking within the secretory pathway. Collectively, these positively loaded genes form a coherent module dedicated to high-volume protein synthesis, folding, and quality control, aligning with classical UPR/secretory cell states. Inconsistencies: No strong outliers; IFNAR1, OXR1 and NDUFC2 are not core ER genes but are ubiquitously expressed and do not contradict a general ER stress/secretory program.

program_11.description: The program captures a strongly pro-inflammatory, TREM1⁺/S100A8-A9-high neutrophil (granulocytic) activation state, typical of low-density or “emergency”/immature neutrophils that appear during acute infection, sepsis or cytokine storm and are characterized by robust IL-1 signalling, NLRP3-inflammasome activity and enhanced antimicrobial/oxidative responses. Evidence: • Neutrophil/granulocyte lineage – FCGR3B (CD16B), CSF3R (G-CSF receptor), OLR1, FFAR2, FPR2, AQP9, PLEK: classical to immature/activated neutrophil markers. • S100-calgranulin inflammatory module typical of activated neutrophils and low-density granulocytes – S100A8, S100A9, S100A12. • Amplified IL-1 axis and NLRP3 inflammasome – IL1A, IL1B, IL1RN, NLRP3, PTGS2, PLAUR, OSM, CXCL8 (IL-8) drive autocrine and paracrine neutrophil activation. • TREM1 pathway and myeloid activation genes – TREM1, LITAF, CEBPB, BCL2A1, NAMPT, SOD2 underscore heightened inflammatory and survival signalling. • Metabolic/iron-handling changes seen in acutely activated neutrophils – SLC2A3 (GLUT3), SLC25A37 (mitoferrin-1), FTH1, SLC11A1, G0S2 reflect increased glycolysis and iron sequestration during emergency granulopoiesis. Inconsistencies: • CD44 and SLC11A1 are more typical of monocytes/macrophages, but can be up-regulated in immature or degranulating neutrophils. • Absence of classical neutrophil granule genes (e.g., MPO, ELANE) suggests this program focuses on the inflammatory signalling arm rather than core granule components, yet does not contradict a neutrophil activation identity.

program_12.description: The gene set indicates mature, MHC class II–high B lymphocytes (predominantly naïve/follicular B cells capable of antigen presentation and poised for germinal-center entry). Evidence: • Core B-cell identity genes: MS4A1 (CD20), CD19, CD79B, CD22, PAX5, BLK, BANK1, BCL11A, FCRLA/FCRL1, CR2 (CD21) – collectively define mature B cells. • Antigen-presentation machinery: abundant HLA-DRA/DRB1/DQA1/DQB1/DPA1/DPB1, HLA-DOB, and CD74, matching the high MHC-II expression of follicular/naïve B cells that present peptide to CD4⁺ T cells. • Follicular cues: CXCR5 (homing to B-cell follicles), FCER2 (CD23) and TNFRSF13C (BAFF-R) characteristic of naïve and early memory B cells; TLR10 and CNR2 further mark peripheral B cells. • Activation/germinal-center priming: IRF8, STAG3, AFF3 and LY86 are up-regulated as B cells transit toward the germinal center reaction, supporting an antigen-experienced yet still classical B-cell profile. Inconsistencies: • VPREB3 is typically higher in pre-B cells, and STAG3 is most enriched in germinal-center B cells, suggesting a mixture of maturation stages rather than a purely naïve pool. • COL19A1 is not commonly associated with B-cell biology and may reflect low-level, non-specific expression or stromal contamination.

program_13.description: The gene set is most consistent with a highly proliferative, transcriptionally-active cell state—typical of cycling progenitor or cancer cells—characterised by intense chromatin remodelling, RNA processing and an active DNA-damage/repair machinery rather than a lineage-specific phenotype. Evidence: • Chromatin remodelling/epigenetic control: SMARCC1, CHD4, BRD9, BAZ1B and SUPT16H are core subunits of BAF, NuRD, ISWI and FACT complexes that open or reposition chromatin during replication and transcription. • DNA-damage sensing/repair: PRKDC (DNA-PKcs) together with XRCC5 (Ku80) and TOP2B mark the non-homologous end-joining and topoisomerase pathways activated in S-phase and in rapidly dividing cells. • RNP biogenesis & splicing: Multiple heterogeneous nuclear RNPs (HNRNPD/K/C/PR, SYNCRIP, SERBP1, SFPQ), the splice-associated PRPF40A and RNA helicase DDX21 indicate heavy pre-mRNA processing. • Translation/stress granule assembly: EIF3A, G3BP1 and CCT2/5/7 (TRiC chaperonin) together with HSPA9 support high ribosome loading, nascent-polypeptide folding and stress-granule dynamics observed in fast-growing cells. • Nuclear transport & RNA regulation: KPNB1 (importin-β), CBX3 (HP1γ) and AGO2 highlight active nucleo-cytoplasmic trafficking and post-transcriptional control. Inconsistencies: • No major lineage-specific markers appear; SLC7A6 (amino-acid transporter) is the only gene not directly linked to the above processes but fits a general metabolic up-regulation seen in proliferating cells.

program_14.description: The gene set typifies a transcriptionally hyper-active, replication-stressed nuclear state that is commonly seen in rapidly growing or malignant cells rather than marking a specific lineage. High expression of numerous spliceosome components, chromatin remodelers and DNA-damage-repair factors suggests cells that are simultaneously producing, processing and protecting large amounts of nascent RNA and DNA—features characteristic of proliferating cells under replication stress. Evidence: • mRNA splicing / nuclear RNA processing – HNRNPD, HNRNPK, HNRNPC, RBM25, RBM39, SRRM1, SRRM2, PRPF40A, LUC7L3, SFPQ, SERBP1, EIF3A indicate an active spliceosome and translation initiation. • DNA double-strand break repair / replication-stress response – PRKDC (DNA-PKcs), XRCC5 (Ku80), ATRX, BOD1L1, SFPQ, TPR are core components of non-homologous end joining and replication-fork protection. • Chromatin remodelling / epigenetic regulation – KMT2A, KDM5A, ARID1B, BPTF, ATF7IP, ANKRD11, BOD1L1 support dynamic chromatin required for high transcription and repair. • General nuclear transport and transcription – KPNB1 (importin-β), GTF2I, TPR, UBXN4, MYCBP2, PRRC2C reflect elevated nucleocytoplasmic trafficking and transcription. Taken together, these modules are canonically enriched in cycling tumour cells experiencing replication stress and heavy RNA output. Inconsistencies: • NKTR encodes a surface receptor most studied in immune cells and does not directly relate to nuclear RNA-processing or DNA-repair pathways, though low-level expression is occasionally seen in other proliferative contexts.

program_15.description: The program reflects a generic but coordinated surge in actin-cytoskeleton remodeling and vesicle-trafficking activity, typical of cells that are actively migrating, spreading, or phagocytosing (e.g., motile immune cells, metastatic epithelial cells). Up-regulation of multiple ARP2/3-complex members, small GTPases (RAB, ARF, CDC42), heterotrimeric G-protein subunits, and SNARE/coat proteins together indicate enhanced lamellipodia formation, endocytosis, and exocytosis, whereas the sole negatively loaded gene (JTB) is not essential for these processes. Evidence: • Actin polymerization & depolymerization – ACTR2, ARPC4, BRK1 (ARP2/3 complex), CDC42, WDR1, CAP1, CAPZA1, TPM3 support dynamic filament turnover and protrusion formation. • Vesicle trafficking – RAB5C (early endosomes), RAB7A (late endosomes/lysosomes), ARF1 (COPI coat), SNAP23 (SNARE), TGOLN2 (trans-Golgi), RTN4 (ER/ER-Golgi), CAPZA1/SLC25A3 cooperation indicate an active endo-/exo-cytic cycle. • Signal transduction driving motility – GNB1, GNB2, GNG5 (GPCR βγ subunits), YWHAB (14-3-3), MOB1A (Hippo pathway), SKP1/RNF7 (SCF ubiquitin ligase) relay cues that trigger cytoskeletal change. • Transcriptional/translation machinery support – PCBP1, HNRNPK, MAX, MTPN, PPP4C suggest increased gene expression needed for remodeling. • Down-regulation of JTB, a mitochondrial/ER-associated protein not directly tied to motility, is consistent with a shift toward cytoskeletal rather than metabolic functions. Inconsistencies: No major cell-type–specific markers (e.g., immune- or epithelial-restricted genes) are present, so while the program denotes motile behavior, it does not conclusively assign a precise lineage.

program_16.description: The program strongly indicates mature, immunologically active mast cells—likely mucosal or connective-tissue mast cells primed for IgE-dependent degranulation and eicosanoid/histamine release. Evidence: • Classical mast-cell granule enzymes: CPA3, TPSAB1, TPSB2, TPSD1, CTSG. • High-affinity IgE receptor components and signaling adaptors: FCER1A, MS4A2, IL1RL1 (ST2). • Histamine and eicosanoid biosynthesis: HDC (histidine decarboxylase), LTC4S (cysteinyl-LT synthesis), HPGDS (PGD2 synthase). • Stem cell factor/Kit pathway and mast-cell transcription factors: KIT (CD117), GATA2. • Vesicular amine transport and secretory machinery: SLC18A2 (VMAT2), CLU, SVOPL. • Additional mast-cell–associated genes often enriched in mucosal subsets or nerve-associated mast cells: NTRK1 (NGF receptor), GFRA3, ADCYAP1, CNRIP1. Inconsistencies: • ITGA2B (platelet/megakaryocyte marker) and KRT1 (keratinocyte marker) are atypical for mast cells. • Neuronal markers CALB2, KCNH2, and AKAP12 are uncommon but have been reported at low levels in certain tissue-resident mast cells, so their presence may reflect tissue-specific cross-talk rather than a different cell identity.

program_17.description: The program represents a mature secretory/goblet cell state of the intestinal epithelium, characterized by high expression of mucin-producing and secretory-lineage transcriptional regulators that drive mucus biosynthesis, packaging, and release. Evidence: • Goblet-cell hallmark mucins and mucus-binding proteins: MUC2, FCGBP, TFF3, ZG16, FCGBP, B3GNT6, ST6GALNAC1, CLCA1, ITLN1, RETNLB. • Secretory lineage transcription factors: ATOH1 (master regulator of secretory fate) and SPDEF (goblet-cell maturation). • Genes linked to mucus granule formation/exocytosis: REP15, RAB26, CAPN9, LRRC26, BEST2. • Secreted protease inhibitors typical of intestinal goblet cells: SPINK4. Inconsistencies: • MB (myoglobin) is muscle-specific and not typical of intestinal epithelium. • Prostate-associated kallikrein genes (KLK1, KLK3, KLK12) and ANO7, HPN suggest low-level contamination or promiscuous expression not usually seen in gut goblet cells.

program_18.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial-progenitor program characterized by high membrane/lipid biosynthesis and active vesicle-trafficking, a state commonly seen in proliferative basal or early-secretory epithelial cells preparing for growth and communication rather than cells in mitotic division. Evidence: • Epithelial identity / adhesion – DSG2 (desmosomes), ATP1A1 and ATP2A2 (polarized epithelial ion pumps), CD9 (tetraspanin enriched in basal and secretory epithelia), KLF5 (transcription factor driving intestinal and skin basal-cell programs). • Vesicle and exosome biogenesis – CLTC (clathrin heavy chain), TM9SF3 (Golgi/vesicle acidification), APP & APLP2, CD9, DSG2 (all abundant in exosomes), TFRC (endocytic receptor), PIGN (GPI-anchor synthesis) support intense membrane trafficking. • Lipid / glycan synthesis for new membranes – CERS6 (ceramide synthesis), FAR1 (fatty-alcohol production), GALNT1 (O-glycosylation of secreted proteins). • ER/secretory stress buffering – CCDC47, ATP2A2 (ER Ca²⁺ pump) and MGST2 (microsomal glutathione transferase) indicate expanded ER function. • Growth and metabolic support – HDGF, CTBP2, IRF2BP2 (growth-associated regulators) together with CS, IARS2, ALDH2 signal enhanced mitochondrial metabolism typical of actively growing, yet not mitotic, cells. Inconsistencies: • Absence of canonical epithelial keratins (e.g., KRT8/18/19) reduces lineage specificity. • Lack of classic S/G2/M cell-cycle genes (MKI67, MCMs, TOP2A) suggests the program reflects biosynthetic preparation rather than overt proliferation. • Most listed genes are ubiquitous “house-keeping” factors, so additional markers would be needed to pinpoint a specific epithelial tissue of origin.

program_19.description: The gene set reflects a generic “oxidative phosphorylation / high-mitochondrial-activity” program, commonly seen in cells that up-regulate respiratory chain biogenesis (e.g., metabolically active, proliferating, or differentiated cells relying on aerobic metabolism) rather than marking a particular lineage. Evidence: • Mitochondrial complex I subunits – NDUFS6, NDUFS7, NDUFA2/6/11/13, NDUFB1/2/3/7/11 – hallmark of electron-transport-chain assembly. • Other respiratory chain components – UQCRFS1 (complex III), CYC1 (cytochrome c), HIGD2A (complex IV chaperone). • Mitochondrial protein import / ribosome – TIMM13 (TIM-complex), MRPL23 (mitochondrial large-ribosomal subunit) – indicate mitochondrial biogenesis. • Redox or mitochondrial maintenance factors – TXNDC17 (thioredoxin), AURKAIP1, EDF1, UBL5 – support heightened mitochondrial function. • General translation / transcription support – EIF3K, POLR2L, NAA38 – often co-expressed with OXPHOS genes in metabolically active cells. Inconsistencies: • Few overt contradictions; genes such as GNG5 (G-protein γ5), DDT, or DYNLL1 are not classical OXPHOS genes but are frequently co-regulated with metabolic or proliferative states, so their presence is not strongly discordant.

program_20.description: The program is characteristic of germinal-center (GC) B cells engaged in class-switch recombination and somatic hypermutation—i.e., actively cycling, affinity-maturing centroblasts/centrocytes—rather than naïve or plasmablast B cells. Evidence: • GC-defining activation and DNA-editing genes: AICDA (essential for SHM/CSR), SERPINA9 (centerin), NEIL1 (DNA repair in SHM), RGS13 and DTX1 (GC-enriched regulators), HRK (pro-apoptotic gene elevated in GC selection). • Core B-cell identity genes: PAX5, MS4A1 (CD20), CD79B, CD22, TNFRSF13C (BAFF-R), FCRLA, BCL7A. • Follicular homing/GC retention genes: CXCR5 and MME (CD10) mark GC and follicular B cells. • Transcriptional regulators restraining plasma differentiation and supporting GC fate: BACH2, GCSAM, BASP1. • Additional GC-associated or centroblast-biased genes: STAG3, AFF2, SNX22, VNN2. Inconsistencies: • TCL1A is typically high in naïve B cells and down-regulated in mature GC cells; its strong loading suggests either an early/transition GC stage or admixture with naïve B cells. • CAMP and HTR3A are not canonical B-cell genes; their presence may reflect low-level, off-target expression or technical noise.

program_21.description: The program most consistently reflects a cell that is actively remodeling its plasma membrane and actin cytoskeleton—i.e. a “membrane-trafficking / adhesion-turnover” state frequently seen in motile or mechanically stimulated epithelial or mesenchymal cells rather than a lineage-specific signature. Evidence: • Clathrin-mediated endocytosis & vesicle trafficking – CLTC, PICALM, APLP2, TGOLN2, FURIN, SPPL2A support heavy coated-vesicle formation and Golgi/TGN sorting. • Integrin recycling / focal-adhesion dynamics – ITGB1 together with ACAP2, LASP1, WDR1, ACTR2, IQGAP1, TMOD3 and EFHD2 mark actin-linked adhesion turnover needed for cell migration. • Adherens-junction remodeling – CTNND1 (p120-catenin) and CTNNA1 (α-catenin) indicate modulation of cadherin complexes during junction disassembly/reassembly. • Signalling scaffolds regulating these events – GNAQ, GNB1 (GPCR), CAB39 (LKB1-AMPK), TAB2 (TAK1/NF-κB) and SHOC2 (RAS–RAF) provide upstream control of cytoskeletal and endocytic machinery. • Calcium-dependent membrane reshaping – ATP2A2 (SERCA2) and CAST (calpastatin) supply Ca²⁺ handling/protease inhibition necessary for rapid cytoskeletal remodeling. Inconsistencies: No strongly lineage-restricted markers are present (e.g. immune, neuronal, fibroblast-specific genes), reinforcing that the program describes a generic, process-oriented state rather than a specific cell type.

program_22.description: This program most strongly reflects a generic “secretory/vesicle-trafficking” state that can be super-imposed on many cell types when they are actively moving cargo through the ER-Golgi–endosome network. The coordinated up-regulation of coatomer (COPI) subunits, clathrin, Golgi and dynein components, together with the ER Ca²⁺ pump SERCA2, indicates heightened membrane trafficking and protein export rather than a lineage-specific identity. Evidence: • Vesicle coat machinery – COPA, COPB1 (COPI complex) and CLTC (clathrin) mark formation of coated vesicles for ER↔Golgi and endocytic transport. • Golgi/ER structural proteins – TGOLN2 (TGN46), GOLGB1 (giantin) and TM9SF2/3 are hallmarks of an expanded trans-Golgi and endosomal system seen in secretory cells. • Motor and tethering factors – DYNC1H1 (cytoplasmic dynein), IQGAP1 and GNB1 support long-range vesicle movement and membrane fusion. • Calcium handling for secretion – ATP2A2 (SERCA2) loads Ca²⁺ into the ER, a prerequisite for high-level protein folding and export. • Transcriptional/RNA-processing co-factors – YY1, PTBP3, ZNF638 and others likely coordinate the transcriptional and post-transcriptional demand that accompanies increased secretion. Inconsistencies: • Nuclear chromatin regulators (BPTF, KDM5A, SETD2, NIPBL, SPEN, IRF2BP2) are not classical trafficking genes; their co-loading suggests a broader activation state or cycling cells but does not conflict with, nor specifically point to, any distinct lineage.

program_23.description: The gene set defines a generic “nuclear RNA-processing / spliceosome” program that is typically up-regulated in highly transcriptionally active or proliferating cells (e.g., cycling progenitors or tumor cells) rather than marking a lineage-restricted cell type. It reflects coordinated elevation of heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoproteins, core spliceosomal components, nucleolar RNA-binding proteins and chromatin/DNA-repair factors that support brisk pre-mRNA splicing, ribonucleoprotein assembly and genome maintenance during rapid growth. Evidence: • Pre-mRNA splicing core: SNRPB, SNRPF, SRRM1, SRSF2, SRSF7, SF1 – canonical spliceosome constituents. • Broad hnRNP surge: HNRNPK, HNRNPC, HNRNPD, HNRNPM, HNRNPF, HNRNPR, HNRNPA3 – typical of nuclei engaged in intense RNA processing. • Nucleolar / RNA-binding proteins: NCL (nucleolin), SERBP1 – support rRNA maturation and mRNA stability in active cells. • Nuclear transport & chromatin: KPNB1 (importin-β), CBX3 (HP1γ), SET – required for import of RNPs and chromatin remodeling during replication. • Genome maintenance / replication stress: XRCC5 (Ku80), NUCKS1 – often co-induced in proliferating cells to safeguard DNA. Inconsistencies: • No classical S- or M-phase markers (MCMs, PCNA, MKI67) appear, so the program captures the RNA-processing arm of proliferation rather than the full cell-cycle signature.

program_24.description: The gene set is most consistent with quiescent perivascular fibroblasts / adventitial fibroblasts that line blood vessels and meninges (often termed vascular-associated or leptomeningeal fibroblasts). These cells synthesize basement-membrane collagens, secrete morphogens (BMPs) and vasoactive molecules (AGT, EDNRB, F3, PLAT) that modulate endothelial and immune activity, and express mesenchymal transcription factors such as FOXF2 and SOX6. Evidence: • Mesenchymal / fibroblast identity – FOXF2, SOX6, BMP4, BMP5, PLEKHH2, EMID1, ECM1, COL4A5, COL4A6. • Perivascular / adventitial specialization – AGT (renin-angiotensin system), EDNRB (endothelin signaling), F3 (tissue factor), PLAT (t-PA), COL4A5/6 (vascular basement membrane). • Secretory, immuno-modulatory profile – CXCL14, TSLP, ALDH1A3, ENHO, SCUBE2, BMP4/5 provide chemokine, cytokine and morphogen outputs typical of vessel-associated fibroblasts that orchestrate local immune and angiogenic responses. • Neurovascular coupling genes often seen in leptomeningeal fibroblasts – TRPA1, ADGRL3, NSG1 support a niche at the neurovascular interface. Inconsistencies: • TMEM119 (canonical microglial marker) and NSG1 (neuronal vesicle protein) are atypical for fibroblasts and may reflect low-level contamination or ambient RNA.

program_25.description: The gene set reflects a generic “high biosynthetic/proliferative” cellular state rather than a lineage-specific cell type. It captures cells that are simultaneously ramping up ribosome biogenesis, nucleocytoplasmic transport, chaperone-mediated protein folding and glycolytic/PPP metabolism—features typically seen in actively cycling cancer cells, germinal-center B cells, embryonic stem cells or other rapidly dividing populations. Evidence: • Ribosome biogenesis / RNA processing – DDX21, PDCD11, EXOSC6, KHSRP, SYNCRIP, CAPRIN1, UBAP2L all participate in rRNA transcription, processing or mRNA stability, hallmarks of nucleolar activation during proliferation. • Nucleocytoplasmic transport – KPNB1, IPO7, POM121C, LRRC58 facilitate elevated nuclear import/export and pore formation required for brisk transcription–translation coupling. • Protein homeostasis / chaperones – CCT2, HSPA9, PHB2, MLEC promote folding of nascent proteins in cytosol, mitochondria and ER, matching the increased translational load. • Metabolic support – GPI (glycolysis) and TKT (pentose-phosphate pathway) channel glucose toward ATP and ribose generation needed for nucleotide and biomass synthesis. • Genome maintenance & proliferation regulators – PRKDC (DNA-PK), TRIM28 and IRF2BP2 link to DNA repair and chromatin control during S/G2, consistent with cycling cells. Inconsistencies: • PPP1R14B is best known as a smooth-muscle contractility regulator but is also up-regulated in several cancers; its presence is not strictly required for a generic proliferative program yet is not contradictory.

program_26.description: The gene set is most consistent with mature, mucus-secreting intestinal goblet cells undergoing an active secretory program. Evidence: • Core goblet-cell mucins and co-secreted factors: MUC2, FCGBP, ZG16, TFF3, TFF1 – canonical markers of intestinal goblet cells and their mucus granules. • Secretory lectins and receptors typical of goblet cells: ITLN1 (intelectin-1) and FFAR4, both enriched in colonic goblet epithelium. • Goblet-cell/intestinal-epithelium enzymes and structural proteins: CAPN9, BEST2, SCEL, TSPAN1, REP15, and RAB3B support a secretory epithelial phenotype. • Additional goblet-cell–associated or secretory‐pathway genes: SYTL5, FER1L6, GPR153, FAM177B, MINPP1 contribute to vesicle trafficking and mucin release, fitting an activated secretory state. Inconsistencies: • TPSG1 (tryptase γ) is typically mast-cell-restricted and atypical for epithelial cells. • BCAS1 and TBX10 are not classically linked to goblet cells; their presence may reflect low-level expression or technical noise.

program_27.description: The gene set strongly matches the canonical transcriptional program of epithelial tuft (brush) cells—a rare, chemosensory secretory cell type found in airway and intestinal epithelia that relies on taste-receptor signaling and POU2F3-driven lineage commitment. Evidence: • Lineage-defining TFs: POU2F3 and GFI1B are established master regulators required for tuft-cell specification. • Taste/chemosensory machinery: TRPM5, TAS1R3, HTR3E, and GNG13 encode components of gustatory GPCR signaling that characterize tuft cells. • Cytoskeletal/structural tuft markers: AVIL (advillin) and CORO2B are enriched in tuft cells and associated with their long microvilli. • Tuft-cell cytokine/receptor axis: IL17RB is the receptor for IL-25 produced by tuft cells and is routinely co-expressed in this lineage. • Eicosanoid synthesis enzymes typical of tuft cells: PTGS1 (COX-1) and HPGDS support prostaglandin and leukotriene production reported in tuft cells. • Additional reported tuft-cell genes: AZGP1 (secreted glycoprotein) and SH2D6/7, BMX, OGDHL are found in published tuft-cell single-cell RNA-seq signatures. Inconsistencies: • HCK (myeloid-associated kinase), NCMAP (myelin protein), and PAK3 (neuronal kinase) are not classical tuft-cell markers and may indicate low-level contamination or broader epithelial/immune signaling overlap.

program_28.description: The gene set reflects a generic “adhesion-and-vesicle-trafficking” program typical of cells that are actively remodeling their plasma membrane and secretory/endo-membrane systems—features seen in migratory mesenchymal or stromal cells such as fibroblasts rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • Cell–matrix / cell–cell adhesion: ITGB1, CTNND1 (p120-catenin), LPP, APP & APLP2 (membrane adhesion/interaction proteins) are up-regulated when cells form or remodel focal adhesions and adherens junctions. • Vesicle trafficking & secretory pathway: CLTC (clathrin heavy chain), TGOLN2 (trans-Golgi protein), TM9SF3 (endolysosomal trafficking), ATP2A2 (SERCA-mediated Ca²⁺ loading required for ER/Golgi function) and CAST (calpastatin; regulates membrane-associated calpains) point to heightened endocytosis/exocytosis. • Signalling and transcriptional regulators that drive or respond to adhesion/trafficking cues: RPS6KA3 (RSK2), NFAT5, ZBTB7A, MED13, SMG1, RC3H1, NUFIP2, PTBP3 can coordinate gene expression changes accompanying motility and stress associated with membrane turnover. • Absence of lineage-defining markers (e.g., immune, neuronal, epithelial-specific genes) supports a generic mesenchymal/stromal rather than specialized cell-type program. Inconsistencies: No strongly contradictory genes; all listed genes participate broadly in adhesion, trafficking, or associated regulatory processes, consistent with the proposed state.

program_29.description: The gene set depicts a motile, adhesion-remodeling state typical of mesenchymal-like or actively migrating cells rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Coordinated up-regulation of actin polymerization/contractility factors, focal-adhesion components and clathrin-mediated trafficking genes suggests a program that equips cells to reorganize their cytoskeleton, cycle integrins through endocytosis, and respond to G-protein–coupled cues during migration or invasion. Evidence: • Actin cytoskeleton remodeling – ACTR2 (Arp2/3 complex), WDR1 (cofilin co-factor), TPM3, PPP1R12A (MYPT1), MTPN and PAK2 collectively drive filament assembly, myosin regulation and contractility required for cell movement. • Adhesion / focal-adhesion turnover – ITGB1 (β1-integrin), IQGAP1 (Rac/Cdc42 scaffold), CSNK1A1 (focal-adhesion kinase regulator) support dynamic cell–matrix interactions. • Vesicle and membrane trafficking – CLTC (clathrin), TGOLN2 (trans-Golgi), RTN4 (ER/vesicle curvature), KPNB1 (nuclear import), DNAJB14 (ER chaperone) indicate heightened endocytosis and membrane flow that accompany focal-adhesion recycling. • Signal reception – GNB1 and GNG5 (G-protein β/γ subunits) couple extracellular signals to cytoskeletal changes, reinforcing a migratory phenotype. • Increased biosynthetic capacity – EIF4G2, BZW1 and ATAD2B enhance translation and chromatin accessibility, supporting rapid protein turnover during motility. Inconsistencies: • The module lacks classical EMT transcription factors (e.g., SNAI1, ZEB1) or extracellular-matrix genes (COL1A1, FN1); therefore it represents a generic migration/adhesion program rather than full EMT. • Inclusion of general translation (EIF4G2, BZW1) and nuclear-transport genes could also reflect heightened proliferation, though most genes point principally to motility.

program_30.description: The gene set is characteristic of mature, migratory dendritic cells—often termed LAMP3⁺/CCR7⁺ “mreg-DCs.” These cells have completed antigen uptake, up-regulated costimulatory and chemotactic programs (CCR7, CCL19/17/22) that guide them to lymph-node T-cell zones, and express immunoregulatory molecules such as IDO1 and EBI3. Evidence: • Maturation/migration markers: LAMP3 (DC-LAMP), FSCN1 (actin-bundling protein induced during DC maturation), CCR7 and its ligand CCL19, plus FLT3 and CSF2RA—classical conventional DC genes. • Chemokine repertoire typical of mature DCs: CCL17 and CCL22 (attract CCR4⁺ T cells), CCL19 (attracts CCR7⁺ T cells), supportive of T-cell-zone trafficking. • Immunoregulatory signature: IDO1 (tryptophan-catabolizing, tolerogenic), EBI3 (IL-27/IL-35 subunit)—both enriched in “mreg-DCs.” • Additional myeloid/DC-associated genes: TREML1, NCCRP1, HMSD and SLCO5A1 reported in LAMP3⁺ DC clusters across tissues and tumors. Inconsistencies: • TREML1 is also expressed in platelets, and GPR157 or SLCO5A1 have limited DC literature, but these do not outweigh the strong, concordant DC maturation signature.

program_31.description: The program reflects cells undergoing mitochondrial‐high, ribosome‐low stress/death— a canonical “high-mito” signature frequently seen in low-quality or apoptotic single-cell RNA-seq profiles rather than a differentiated, healthy cell type. Evidence: • Strong positive loadings for nearly every mitochondrially encoded OXPHOS gene (MT-CO2/3, MT-CYB, MT-ND1-6, MT-ATP6/8, MT-ND4L) — hallmark of cells in which mitochondrial transcripts dominate the library, typically because cytoplasmic RNA is degraded during cell stress or apoptosis. • Negative loadings for multiple ribosomal protein genes (RPS17, RPS20, RPL4, RPL17) and the RNA-binding protein HNRNPA1, consistent with loss of cytoplasmic mRNA and reduced translation that accompanies cellular stress and impending death. Inconsistencies: • TMEM238 has no clear connection to mitochondrial enrichment or cell death; its presence is not readily explained by the dominant stress/apoptosis program.

program_32.description: The gene set most consistently reflects an activated, cytotoxic, tissue-resident memory–like CD8⁺ T/NK cell program (CD161⁺/NKG2A/C⁺ “innate-like” T or NK cells), characterised by strong cytotoxic effector genes, multiple NK-cell receptors and the memory/T-resident transcription factor HOPX. Evidence: • Cytotoxic effector molecules – GNLY, XCL2, CD160, CLIC3 support a granule-mediated killing program typical of cytotoxic T and NK cells. • NK/T-cell receptors – KLRC1 (NKG2A), KLRC2 (NKG2C), KIR2DL4, KLRB1 (CD161) and TMIGD2 (CD28H) are hallmark surface molecules of innate-like NK and CD8⁺ T cells. • Memory/tissue-resident signatures – HOPX (core Trm transcription factor), ALOX5AP and CKLF (lipid/chemokine genes up-regulated in long-lived memory T cells), together with TMSB4X (actin remodelling during T-cell activation), point to a resident-memory or chronically stimulated state. Inconsistencies: • KRT81 and KRT86 are hair-follicle keratins and are atypical for immune cells, suggesting ambient RNA or epithelial doublets rather than a true component of this immune program.

program_33.description: The gene set most closely matches a neuroendocrine/peptidergic neuronal program—typical of hypothalamic or brain-stem peptide-secreting neurons (and analogous peripheral neuroendocrine cells)—that couples secretory-granule biogenesis with high electrical excitability and vesicle exocytosis. Evidence: • Secretory granule / neuroendocrine markers: CHGB (chromogranin B), VSTM2A, UCN3 (urocortin-3 neuropeptide) • Neuronal excitability components: SCN2A (Nav1.2), KCNK9 (K2P9.1), UNC13A (synaptic vesicle priming), RUNDC3A, ASPHD1 • Stem/forebrain neuroepithelial factor: SOX2 (maintained in many hypothalamic neuroendocrine cells) • Receptor/axonal guidance typical of neuroendocrine neurons: EPHB6 • Additional secreted proteins often co-expressed in neuroendocrine epithelia: AZGP1, AQP5 Inconsistencies: • MYBPC1 (slow-twitch muscle), AKR1C4 (hepatic enzyme), CRYBA2 (lens crystallin) are atypical for neuroendocrine neurons, suggesting low-level contamination or technical noise.

program_34.description: The gene set represents a generic “membrane trafficking / clathrin-mediated endocytosis and adhesion” program that is typically up-regulated in cells undergoing active receptor internalisation, lysosomal turnover and cytoskeletal remodelling (e.g. migratory or growth-factor–stimulated stromal or immune cells), rather than defining a single lineage. Evidence: • Clathrin-mediated endocytosis: CLTC (clathrin heavy chain), PICALM (clathrin assembly), APLP2 (clathrin-adaptor interactor) • Endosome–lysosome–ER trafficking: SCARB2 (LIMP-2, late endosome/lysosome), RTN4 (ER shaping), ATP2A2 (SERCA2, ER Ca²⁺ pump), SERINC1 (membrane lipid incorporation) • Cytoskeleton/adhesion for vesicle movement: ITGB1 (integrin β1), CTNNA1 (α-catenin), CYFIP1 (WAVE complex, actin polymerisation), RHOB (endosomal GTPase) • Signal reception driving internalisation: GNAQ (G-protein αq), TNFRSF1A (TNF receptor) • Transcriptional/co-regulatory support: KLF10 (TGF-β–responsive zinc-finger factor), ZFAND5, LEPROT (trafficking regulator for cytokine receptors) Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; however KLF10 (TGF-β–induced transcriptional repressor) is more broadly associated with differentiation and may not be directly tied to vesicle transport.

program_35.description: The gene set best matches an “activated/matrix-remodeling fibroblast” program, typified in many solid tumours as COL11A1⁺ cancer-associated fibroblasts (myCAF). These fibroblasts up-regulate collagens and other extracellular-matrix (ECM) components, WNT and heparan-sulfate modulators, and the fibroblast lineage TF PRRX1, collectively driving desmoplastic stroma formation and tumour-promoting signalling. Evidence: • ECM/collagen core – COL11A1, COL10A1, COL7A1, MFAP2, SPOCK1, PODNL1, FNDC1: hallmark of desmoplastic, matrix-depositing fibroblasts; COL11A1⁺/COL10A1⁺ signatures repeatedly define myCAF populations in pancreatic, breast, ovarian and colorectal cancers. • Fibroblast lineage/activation markers – PRRX1 (mesenchymal TF crucial for fibroblast identity), ITGA11 (fibroblast-restricted collagen receptor up-regulated during myofibroblast activation). • Matrix-modifying & pro-tumour signals – WNT2 (paracrine WNT ligand secreted by CAFs), SULF1 (heparan-sulfate 6-O-endosulfatase that shapes WNT/TGF-β gradients), SPOCK1 and MFAP2 (ECM glycoproteins promoting invasion). • Additional stromal or cartilage-related ECM genes (DIO2, PRR16, PLPP4) are often co-expressed in COL11A1⁺ CAF clusters in single-cell studies, reinforcing a specialized, highly remodelled stroma profile. Inconsistencies: • NTM (neurotrimin) is classically neuronal, and DIO2 is thyroid hormone-related; while both have reported stromal expression in some tumours, they are less canonical fibroblast markers. Overall, however, they do not outweigh the dominant myCAF signature.

program_36.description: This program reflects a generic “secretory/ER-Golgi expansion” state seen in many highly secretory cells (e.g., plasma cells, activated fibroblasts, endocrine cells) rather than a lineage-restricted signature. The coordinated up-regulation of ER chaperones and retrieval receptors, Golgi structural proteins, and vesicle-trafficking GTPases indicates an enlarged secretory apparatus, while chromatin- and spliceosome-associated factors point to the transcriptional and post-transcriptional up-scaling that typically accompanies robust protein production. Evidence: • Rough ER and protein translocation – RRBP1, HDLBP, CANX, KDELR1 all encode ER-resident proteins required for co-translational import and folding of secreted peptides. • Golgi structure/vesicle trafficking – TM9SF2, TM9SF3, ARF1, GOLGA4, GOLGB1, AKAP9, TTC3 are core components of Golgi membranes or coat-protein/ARF-dependent transport, supporting high anterograde flux. • Global transcriptional up-scaling – SRRM2 (splicing scaffold), KAT6B and ASH1L (histone acetyl- and methyl-transferases) facilitate increased mRNA synthesis/processing that typically accompanies secretory activation. • Additional membrane or secretory-associated factors – JTB (type I membrane protein) further fits a membrane-rich, secretion-oriented profile. Inconsistencies: No prominent contradictions; all listed genes are compatible with an augmented ER-Golgi/secretory program, and no negatively loaded genes were provided.

program_37.description: The gene set is most consistent with an extracellular-matrix–remodeling, perivascular (adventitial) fibroblast state that secretes anti-coagulant/anti-angiogenic factors and the eosinophil-recruiting chemokine CCL11, a profile described for HAPLN1⁺/WNT2B⁺ stromal fibroblasts in lung, gut and synovium. Evidence: • ECM organisation & inhibition of matrix proteases – HAPLN1, TIMP3, TFPI2, EDIL3 all encode secreted ECM components or inhibitors typical of fibroblasts engaged in tissue remodeling. • Anti-coagulant / vascular niche molecules – TFPI and TFPI2 (tissue factor pathway inhibitors) and PLPP3 (endothelial/fibroblast lipid-phosphatase up-regulated in vessel wall) mark perivascular fibroblasts that modulate haemostasis. • Fibroblast identity & Wnt signaling – WNT2B and FHL1 are signature transcripts of mesenchymal stromal/fibroblast subsets; WNT2B⁺ fibroblasts have been reported in several organs. • Chemokine secretion – CCL11 (eotaxin) is produced by activated fibroblasts and recruits eosinophils, fitting an inflammatory stromal program. • Additional mesenchymal or senescence-associated genes – GNG11 (senescent fibroblasts), EDIL3 and EPHA7 (vessel-associated mesenchyme) further support a stromal, not epithelial or immune, identity. Inconsistencies: • Neuron-associated transcripts MAPK10, NEGR1 and EPHA7/TRIL are atypical for fibroblasts but are variably expressed in developmental or inflammatory stromal cells, so their presence is not strongly contradictory.

program_38.description: The program reflects a tetraspanin-integrin–driven membrane remodeling and vesicle-trafficking state that supports cell adhesion, motility and exosome production rather than marking a specific lineage; it is a generic “adhesion/vesicle-secretion” module that can be activated in many epithelial, stromal or immune cells when they become migratory or communicate via extracellular vesicles. Evidence: • CD9 and CD151 – canonical tetraspanins that cluster integrins and are hallmarks of exosome membranes. • ITGB1 together with RAC1 and CAPNS1 – core components of integrin signaling and actin/cytoskeletal rearrangement required for cell spreading and motility. • APP and APLP2 – physically interact with β1-integrin complexes and promote adhesion/migration; both are repeatedly detected in exosome proteomes. • TM9SF3, DYNC1I2 and PACS2 – proteins involved in endo-lysosomal acidification, dynein-based vesicle transport and cargo sorting, consistent with active vesicular trafficking. • TSPO – mitochondrial outer-membrane channel up-regulated in metabolically or stress-activated cells that demand high energy for motility/vesicle biogenesis. Inconsistencies: • LMNA (nuclear lamina) and SERPINB6 (cytosolic protease inhibitor) are housekeeping or stress-protection genes whose presence is not specifically tied to adhesion/vesicle programs, but they do not conflict with the overall theme.

program_39.description: The gene set represents a conventional dendritic-cell antigen-presentation program, most closely matching human CD1C⁺/CLEC10A⁺ conventional dendritic cells (cDC2) and skin-derived Langerhans-like DCs that are actively expressing MHC class II machinery. Evidence: • Professional antigen presentation: HLA-DPA1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DQB1 together with the invariant chain CD74 indicate high cell-surface MHC-II processing typical of dendritic cells. • cDC2 identity: CD1C (BDCA-1), CLEC10A (CD301), FCER1A and CD1E are canonical markers of CD1C⁺ conventional DCs. • Lipid-antigen presentation / skin DC features: CD1A and CD207 (langerin) are characteristic of epidermal or dermal dendritic cells that present lipid antigens. • Additional DC-enriched transcripts: PLD4 and IL22RA2 are both reported to be preferentially expressed in myeloid dendritic cells, reinforcing a dendritic-cell activation signature. Inconsistencies: • CD207 (langerin) is largely restricted to Langerhans cells and a subset of dermal DCs, whereas many cDC2 outside skin lack this marker; its presence suggests either a skin-derived DC subset or a mixed DC program rather than a pure blood cDC2 signature.

program_40.description: The gene set represents a generic “nuclear housekeeping / RNA-processing” program that is typically up-regulated in highly transcriptionally active or proliferating cells, independent of a specific lineage. Evidence: • Pre-mRNA splicing / RNA binding – HNRNPC, HNRNPD, HNRNPA3, HNRNPDL, SRSF11, SON, SFPQ, PCBP2 all encode core heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoproteins or splicing factors that rise in cells with heavy mRNA biogenesis. • Coupling to transcription, chromatin and genome maintenance – ARID4B (chromatin remodeling), XPC (nucleotide-excision DNA repair) and MTDH (links transcription, mRNA export and oncogenic proliferation) are commonly co-induced with high transcriptional throughput. • Protein turnover – PSMB1 (proteasome β-subunit) supports brisk proteostasis seen in cycling cells. Inconsistencies: No major lineage-specific markers are present; the program lacks genes that would contradict a generic high-activity nuclear state.

program_41.description: This gene set reflects a generic “organelle-maintenance / high-metabolic-activity” program rather than a lineage-defining signature. Coordinated up-regulation of mitochondrial biogenesis and respiratory-chain components together with ER/Golgi trafficking and proteasome subunits is typical of cells that have increased oxidative phosphorylation and protein-turnover demands—for example proliferating or metabolically activated cells (e.g., activated lymphocytes, cycling progenitors, or stressed epithelial cells). Evidence: • Mitochondrial biogenesis & OXPHOS – MRPL23 (mitochondrial ribosome), NDUFS2 (complex I core), GHITM (mitochondrial morphology), TMEM14C (inner-membrane heme transporter required for cytochrome synthesis). • Organelle protein quality control – PSMD11 (26S proteasome regulator, elevated in highly proteostatic cells), RNF7 (SCF E3 ligase component), PPP4C (phosphatase involved in DNA-damage/ER-stress recovery). • ER/Golgi trafficking – RTN3 (ER tubule shaping), RER1 (ER retention receptor), TM9SF3 (Golgi/lysosome membrane protein) support enhanced secretory-pathway activity. • Stress/apoptosis modulators – PDCD6 (Ca²⁺-dependent cell-death regulator) aligns with heightened organelle stress signalling. Inconsistencies: • TMEM14C is best known for erythroid heme synthesis, which is not reinforced by other erythroid markers in this list. • GNB2 (heterotrimeric G-protein β-subunit) is a ubiquitous signalling factor and does not specifically point to oxidative or proteostatic states, but its inclusion is not incompatible with a general metabolic-activation program.

program_42.description: The program matches the transcriptional signature of intestinal BEST4⁺/OTOP2⁺ “ionocyte-like” enterocytes—an epithelial sub-type in human small and large intestine specialized for pH and electrolyte sensing/secretion and occasionally showing immune-sensing features. Evidence: • Canonical markers of BEST4⁺ enterocytes: BEST4, OTOP2, OTOP3; these genes define this rare epithelial lineage in single-cell atlases of human gut. • Ion and pH homeostasis machinery: CA7 (carbonic anhydrase), ADCY5 (cAMP production), SRI (calcium-binding protein), KCNIP4 (potassium channel regulator) support an ion-transport/secretion role. • SPIB is reported in BEST4⁺ cells and related M-cell–like epithelial subsets, indicating potential immune-sampling capacity. • MT1G (metallothionein) reflects oxidative-stress handling common to gut surface epithelium. Inconsistencies: • CEACAM3 (classically neutrophil receptor), MYOM1 (muscle structural protein), and partial neuronal gene KCNIP4 are unusual for gut epithelium and may represent low-level ambient RNA or cross-loading noise rather than true expression in this program.

program_43.description: The program represents a canonical type I interferon (IFN-α/β)–induced antiviral state that can be activated in virtually any nucleated cell upon viral sensing. Evidence: • Classical ISGs: ISG15, IFIT1, IFIT3, IFI44, IFI44L, MX1, OAS2, OAS3 and CMPK2 are prototypical genes up-regulated after type I IFN signaling and mediate antiviral restriction. • Viral RNA-sensing/IFN-amplifying genes: IFIH1 (MDA5) and XAF1 enhance detection of viral double-stranded RNA and apoptosis in an IFN-dependent manner. • IFN-regulated immune modulators: PARP9 (DTX3L-PARP9 complex) and XAF1 further confirm an activated interferon transcriptional program. Inconsistencies: • None noted; all listed genes align with a type I interferon response signature.

program_44.description: The gene set reflects a TREM2⁺ APOE⁺ GPNMB⁺ macrophage state classically termed “disease-/lipid-associated macrophages” (DAM/LAM) that arises under chronic tissue stress (neurodegeneration, obesity, atherosclerosis) and is characterized by enhanced lipid handling, lysosomal activity and tissue-remodeling functions. Evidence: • Lipid metabolism & uptake – APOE, TREM2, SLCO2B1 support cholesterol/oxidized-lipid sensing that defines DAM/LAM. • Lysosomal/phagocytic enzymes – CTSZ, PLD3, ACP5, MMP12, GRN denote up-regulated lysosome and protease machinery typical of lipid-laden, debris-clearing macrophages. • Canonical DAM/LAM markers – GPNMB, APOE, TREM2, PLD3 repeatedly reported in single-cell studies of neurodegenerative microglia and adipose or atherosclerotic LAM. • Alternative-activation/remodeling cues – CAPG (actin-capping for phagocytosis) and M2-associated chemokine CCL18 are characteristic of reparative, lipid-rich macrophages. Inconsistencies: • ACP5 is classically an osteoclast marker and CCL18 is abundant in lung/tumor macrophages; their presence suggests some tissue-specific variation within the broader DAM/LAM program but does not contradict a lipid-associated macrophage identity.

program_45.description: The program reflects an activated CD4⁺ helper T-cell state with a strong bias toward the T-follicular-helper (Tfh) lineage, characterised by costimulatory molecules that mediate B-cell help and transcription factors typical of mature T cells. Evidence: • T-cell activation/core lineage: BCL11B (T-cell lineage–defining TF), CD5, CD28, ETS1 support a bona-fide T-cell identity. • Tfh-associated costimulation and B-cell help: ICOS, CD40LG (CD154) and SH2D1A (SAP) are canonical markers required for germinal-centre Tfh function and interaction with B cells. • Additional supportive regulators: RORA and ZNF831 participate in helper-T differentiation and have been reported to be up-regulated in Tfh/activated CD4⁺ states. • Absence of negative loadings underscores a uniformly positive association of these genes with the program. Inconsistencies: • RORA is more widely linked to Th17/ILC2 differentiation, and ZNF831 has been implicated in multiple immune lineages, so their presence is not exclusive to Tfh cells. Otherwise, the gene set is largely coherent with an activated CD4⁺ T/Tfh program.

program_46.description: The gene set is most consistent with mature intestinal absorptive epithelial cells (enterocytes), likely of the distal small intestine/colon, displaying a barrier-defence program that includes IgA transcytosis and metallothionein-mediated stress protection. Evidence: • Enterocyte / intestinal epithelium markers – FABP1 (liver-type FABP highly expressed in enterocytes), LGALS4 (galectin-4, characteristic of apical membranes of intestinal epithelium), CA1 (abundant in colonic epithelium), TMEM54 and SLC26A2 (reported in gut epithelium). • Mucosal immune interface – PIGR mediates polymeric IgA/IgM transcytosis across gut epithelium; LGALS3 (galectin-3) binds glycoproteins and microbes at mucosal surfaces. • Stress / metal-handling typical of gut lining – MT1M, MT1H and MT2A (metallothioneins induced in enterocytes by dietary metals and oxidative stress). • Coordinated expression of the above genes is a well-described transcriptional signature of differentiated absorptive enterocytes in single-cell atlases of human and mouse intestine. Inconsistencies: • CA1 is also found in erythrocytes, but the absence of hemoglobin genes argues against a red-cell program. • SLC26A2 is classically associated with chondrocytes; however, low-level expression in intestinal epithelium has been reported, so this is only a minor mismatch.

program_47.description: The gene set points to an activated, extracellular-matrix-remodeling fibroblast program (often termed SFRP4+/CLEC3B+ or “activated/vascular” fibroblasts seen in many tissues), characterized by high matrix components, WNT antagonism and PDGF-related signaling, consistent with fibroblast activation in wound repair, fibrosis or cancer-associated stroma. Evidence: • Fibroblast/ECM genes – OMD, CLEC3B (Tetranectin), PDGFRL, SFRP4, CRABP2, FAM180A and OSR1 are repeatedly reported as enriched in tissue fibroblasts or stromal cells undergoing matrix deposition and remodeling. • Activation / remodeling markers – ADAM33 (metalloproteinase linked to airway and fibrotic remodeling), GFPT2 (hexosamine pathway enzyme enriched in cancer-associated fibroblasts), SFRP4 (WNT antagonist up-regulated during fibroblast activation) together typify an activated rather than quiescent fibroblast state. • ECM-linked keratin – although most keratins are epithelial, KRT24 has been noted in transitional or EMT-like states and appears in subsets of activated stromal cells in single-cell atlases, fitting a fibroblast that has adopted partial epithelial gene expression during activation. Inconsistencies: • KRT24 is primarily an epithelial keratin and is atypical for canonical fibroblasts, suggesting either a minor EMT-like feature or contaminating epithelial expression.

program_48.description: Gene expression pattern typifies an M1-like, pro-inflammatory myeloid cell (activated monocyte / macrophage) that is secreting a broad panel of neutrophil-recruiting chemokines and cytokines. Evidence: • Neutrophil-attracting ELR+ CXC chemokines (CXCL1, CXCL2, CXCL3, CXCL5) are classical products of activated macrophages and drive acute inflammation. • CCR1/CCR5 ligand CCL3 and CCR6 ligand CCL20 are hallmarks of M1-polarized macrophages and amplify leukocyte recruitment. • IL6 is a signature cytokine of classically activated macrophages exposed to TLR/IL-1/IFN-γ stimuli. • CLEC5A (MDL-1) is a surface receptor restricted to monocytes, macrophages and neutrophils, up-regulated by inflammatory cues. • INHBA (Activin-A) is induced in LPS/IFN-γ–stimulated macrophages and contributes to tissue remodeling during inflammation. • Coordinated induction of multiple chemokines together with IL6 and INHBA fits the “chemokine storm” program described for M1 macrophages in scRNA-seq studies. Inconsistencies: • PPBP (CXCL7) is classically a platelet/megakaryocyte granule protein, though it can be detected in neutrophils and occasionally in activated macrophages; its presence may reflect platelet RNA contamination or uptake.

program_49.description: The gene set typifies an activated/effector regulatory T-cell (Treg) program, such as those found in inflamed tissues or tumors, marked by FOXP3-driven suppressive identity together with costimulatory TNFRSF family receptors that rise upon T-cell activation. Evidence: • FOXP3 – lineage-defining transcription factor for Tregs. • TNFRSF18 (GITR), TNFRSF4 (OX40), TNFRSF9 (4-1BB) – TNF-receptor super-family members selectively up-regulated on activated/effector Tregs and enhance their survival and suppressive function. • IL2RG – common γ-chain of the high-affinity IL-2 receptor; Tregs depend on IL-2 signaling. • LAIR2 – soluble inhibitory receptor enriched in peripheral and tumor-infiltrating Tregs. • ZBED2 – transcription factor reported to mark effector tumor-infiltrating Tregs. • DUSP4 – phosphatase induced during T-cell anergy/tolerance and in FOXP3⁺ cells. • B2M, HLA-A – housekeeping MHC-I components consistent with activated lymphoid cells. Inconsistencies: • No classical T-cell receptor or CD25 (IL2RA) reads listed, and the presence of broadly expressed B2M/HLA-A provides little specificity; however, these do not contradict a Treg identity and may reflect dataset sparsity rather than a true biological mismatch.

program_50.description: The gene set best fits a generic proteostasis-stress program, reflecting cells that have up-regulated RNA binding/processing factors, translation-initiation machinery and molecular chaperones to cope with increased protein-folding demand or early stress-induced apoptosis; it is not specific to a single lineage but rather marks a transient “high translation & protein quality-control” state that can be seen in many proliferating or stressed cells. Evidence: • Protein-folding chaperones – HSPA9 (mitochondrial HSP70), PFDN2 (prefoldin), and the Hsc70 co-chaperone CLNS1A are classic markers of heightened proteostasis demand. • Translational up-shift – EIF2S3 is a core subunit of eIF2 that drives initiation of bulk protein synthesis during growth or recovery from stress. • Post-transcriptional RNA control – SERBP1, HNRNPD (AUF1) and NONO are multifunctional RNA-binding proteins that stabilize/translate specific mRNAs during cellular stress. • Stress-linked apoptotic modulators – PDCD6 (ALG-2) and TMEM123 (Stannin) rise during Ca²⁺/oxidative stress and can trigger apoptosis, fitting a stress-response context. • ANGEL2 participates in RNA tail processing and mitochondrial RNA metabolism, further supporting an RNA/translation quality-control module. Inconsistencies: • No strong contradictions; however, classical ER-UPR markers such as HSPA5, ATF4 or XBP1 are absent, implying a more general proteostasis or mitochondrial stress rather than a full unfolded-protein response.

program_51.description: The gene set is characteristic of cells engaged in high‐level protein and membrane production/processing – a “secretory–ER/ Golgi trafficking” program most often seen in metabolically active epithelial cells such as hepatocytes or cholangiocytes, but also inducible in other secretory cell types under ER-stress or unfolded-protein-response conditions. Evidence: • ER/Golgi trafficking and vesicle formation – CLTC (clathrin heavy chain), ERGIC1 (ER-Golgi intermediate compartment), TM9SF3 (endolysosomal/secretory vesicles). • ER quality control / ER-associated degradation – EDEM3 (ERAD mannosidase), FAM120A (stress-granule and ER-stress adapter). • Lipid-flipping and membrane asymmetry required for secretion – ATP8B1 (aminophospholipid flippase; liver-enriched, mutated in cholestasis). • Glycosylation and hexosamine pathway – GFPT1 (rate-limiting for N- and O-linked glycosylation). • Phosphatidylcholine/choline supply for membrane synthesis – SLC44A1 (choline transporter). • mRNA handling for abundant secretory transcripts – RBM47 (RNA-binding/editing). These coordinated functions are hallmarks of secretory epithelial programs, particularly pronounced in hepatocytes that continuously export bile acids and serum proteins. Inconsistencies: • The module lacks classic liver-specific products (e.g., ALB, APOA1), so it may represent a generic secretory/ER-stress state rather than a liver-exclusive signature. • No negatively loaded genes were provided to further refine or contradict the interpretation.

program_52.description: The gene set most closely matches a generic “house-keeping / basal transcription-regulation” program rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity; it is typically seen in diverse, quiescent cells that are maintaining membrane integrity, lipid homeostasis and broad transcriptional control without strong activation of lineage-defining or stress pathways. Evidence: • Multiple ubiquitous transcriptional co-regulators or DNA-binding factors – IRF2BP2, CTBP2, GTF2I, SMAD5 and RFX3 – are broadly expressed in many cell types and control basal or context-dependent gene expression. • House-keeping metabolic or membrane components – TM9SF3 (Golgi/lysosomal trafficking), HSD17B12 (fatty-acid elongation), SERINC3 (phospholipid/serine incorporation) – support routine cellular maintenance. • CD46, a complement-regulatory surface molecule present on virtually all nucleated cells, fits a non-restricted, steady-state profile. • Absence of either strongly lineage-specific markers (e.g., CD3E, EPCAM, PECAM1) or stress/proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, IFI genes) argues that the program reflects a basal, quiescent state rather than a specialized activation signature. Inconsistencies: • No clear inconsistencies; the listed genes all fall within widely expressed, maintenance-oriented categories, reinforcing the interpretation of a pan-cellular housekeeping program.

program_53.description: The program reflects a generic, calcium-dependent actin-cytoskeleton remodeling and signal-transduction module typical of metabolically active, motile cells (e.g., cells undergoing migration or shape change) rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • Actin filament dynamics: WDR1 (cofilin-mediated actin severing) and TPM3 (tropomyosin, stabilizes F-actin) are both up-regulated during cytoskeletal reorganization required for cell movement. • Calcium signalling hub: CALM1, CALM3 (calmodulins) and CIB1 (calcium- and integrin-binding protein) provide Ca²⁺-sensitive control of myosin light-chain kinase and integrin outside-in signalling, key steps in motility. • G-protein/second-messenger input: GNG5 couples surface receptors to downstream pathways that trigger cytoskeletal rearrangement. • Energetic and proteostatic support: VDAC1 (mitochondrial metabolite exchange), SEM1 (proteasome subunit), PPP4C (phosphatase regulating microtubules and stress responses) and BLOC1S1 (vesicle/lysosome trafficking) supply ATP, protein turnover and membrane trafficking needed for dynamic shape changes. Inconsistencies: • No strong inconsistencies; however, all listed genes are broadly expressed “housekeeping” factors, so the program lacks definitive lineage markers and could be active in many cell types that transiently engage in migration or structural remodeling.

program_54.description: The gene set reflects an actin-cytoskeleton remodeling program characteristic of actively migrating myeloid leukocytes (e.g., monocytes / neutrophils) preparing for chemotaxis or diapedesis. Evidence: • Core actin pool and polymerization factors – ACTB, PFN1, TMSB4X, ARPC2, ARPC1B, CFL1, COTL1 – encode β-actin and multiple nucleation/branching or severing proteins that drive rapid actin tread-milling during cell movement. • Contractility component – MYL12A (myosin light-chain) supports acto-myosin contractile force required for transendothelial migration. • Leukocyte-restricted regulators of Rho family GTPases – ARHGDIB (RhoGDI-β, predominantly hematopoietic) and SH3BGRL3 (up-regulated in monocytes/macrophages) modulate Rac/Rho signaling that orchestrates lamellipodia and podosome formation in myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes are present; all listed genes participate in cytoskeletal dynamics or are commonly enriched in hematopoietic lineages, supporting the assigned migratory myeloid state.

program_55.description: The gene set is most consistent with an endothelial program associated with sprouting/angiogenic remodeling, i.e. capillary-tip or developmentally activated endothelial cells. Evidence: • ADGRA2 (GPR124) – endothelial-specific adhesion GPCR indispensable for CNS and tip-cell angiogenesis. • TMEM47 – tight-junction tetraspanin enriched in endothelial and epithelial junctions, up-regulated during barrier maturation. • ARHGEF25 (p63RhoGEF) – RhoA GEF promoting actin remodeling and migration of endothelial cells during VEGF-driven sprouting. • RBMS3, ECM2, CHRD – secreted/ECM-binding factors induced in endothelial cells during vessel morphogenesis and extracellular matrix remodeling. • MEIS3, PYGO1 – Wnt/HOX co-factors implicated in vascular development and endothelial lineage specification. • VSTM4 – transmembrane immunomodulator detected in vascular endothelium, proposed to temper leukocyte adhesion in newly forming vessels. Inconsistencies: • Several genes (RBMS3, ECM2, CHRD, MEIS3, PYGO1) are also expressed in mesenchymal fibroblasts; their presence suggests potential contribution from perivascular stromal cells or endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition, but does not contradict an overall angiogenic endothelial program.

program_56.description: The program is characteristic of activated, pro-inflammatory extracellular-matrix–remodeling fibroblasts such as the WNT5A⁺/PDPN⁺ cancer-associated fibroblast (CAF) or wound-activated stromal fibroblast state.
