Evidence: • Matrix remodelling enzymes: MMP1 and MMP3 are canonical markers of activated fibroblasts/CAFs that degrade interstitial collagen and stromal matrix. • ECM structural molecules: TNC (Tenascin-C) is strongly induced in reactive stroma and wounds, fitting an activated fibroblast phenotype. • Fibroblast surface marker: PDPN (podoplanin) is widely used to identify CAFs and inflammatory fibroblasts. • Pro-inflammatory secretome: WNT5A, IL11, CXCL6 and IL24 are cytokines/chemokines produced by inflammatory fibroblast subsets that recruit immune cells and promote tumour or wound inflammation. • Senescence/CAF link: TMEM158 (RIS1) is up-regulated during RAS-induced senescence and in CAFs, reinforcing a reactive stromal program. Inconsistencies: • PDPN is also expressed by lymphatic endothelial cells; however, the absence of endothelial markers (e.g., PECAM1, PROX1) argues against an endothelial identity. • MMPs can be produced by macrophages, but typical myeloid genes (LYZ, CD68, CSF1R) are not present, supporting a fibroblast rather than macrophage source.

program_57.description: The gene set describes a cytotoxic, EOMES-high NK-like/CD8⁺ effector lymphocyte program characterized by strong expression of NK receptors and effector molecules typically found in mature, highly activated NK cells and cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells. Evidence: • NK / cytotoxic receptors – KLRF1 (NKp80), CLEC2B (AICL ligand), and FCRL6 are selectively enriched on mature NK cells and terminally differentiated, cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells. • Effector/cytotoxic molecules – FGFBP2 is a hallmark of cytotoxic NK and CD8⁺ T cells; CCL4 (MIP-1β) is secreted by activated cytotoxic lymphocytes to recruit additional immune cells. • Transcriptional control – EOMES drives maturation and cytotoxic function in NK cells and effector CD8⁺ T cells. • Antiviral/innate immune response genes – APOBEC3G (antiviral cytidine deaminase) and SAMD3 are commonly up-regulated in interferon-stimulated, cytotoxic lymphocytes, supporting an antiviral effector state. • Metabolic/mitochondrial support – CMC1 is involved in cytochrome-c oxidase assembly and is often elevated in metabolically active, highly cytotoxic lymphocytes. Inconsistencies: • No strongly discordant genes; CMC1 and SAMD3 are less cell-type-specific but compatible with a metabolically active cytotoxic lymphocyte state.

program_58.description: The program reflects a core simple-epithelial (luminal/secretory) identity, typical of intestinal or other columnar epithelia, characterized by high expression of intermediate-filament keratins and junction/adhesion molecules, with concurrent down-weighting of stress-response genes. Evidence: • Pan-epithelial keratins KRT8, KRT18 and KRT19 are hallmark cytoskeletal genes of simple columnar and ductal epithelia rather than mesenchyme or stratified epithelium. • CLDN3 encodes a tight-junction claudin highly enriched in barrier-forming epithelial sheets of gut, airway and glandular tissues. • TSPAN8 is a surface tetraspanin preferentially expressed in intestinal and other secretory epithelial cells and their carcinomas. • ELF3 is an epithelium-specific ETS transcription factor that drives intestinal and airway epithelial differentiation programs. • C19orf33 is reported in several glandular epithelial contexts and co-varies with cytokeratin expression, supporting an epithelial module. • Negative loading of BTG1 (anti-proliferative regulator) and ATM (DNA-damage–checkpoint kinase) is consistent with epithelial cells that are not in a DNA-damage-induced arrest state, reinforcing that the positive genes define identity rather than a stress response. Inconsistencies: • Few; the program lacks highly tissue-restricted markers (e.g., EPCAM, MUC genes) that would pinpoint a single organ, so it represents a generic simple-epithelial identity rather than a definitive gut-only signature. • Negative association of the broadly expressed tumor-suppressor ATM is not universally characteristic of epithelia, but its down-weighting does not contradict epithelial identity.

program_59.description: The gene constellation strongly points to a myelinating Schwann-cell program, i.e. peripheral glial cells engaged in active myelin sheath formation and axon–glia signaling. Evidence: • Core myelin structural genes MPZ and PLP1 – MPZ is the signature protein of peripheral myelin; PLP1, though classically CNS-biased, is also up-regulated in highly myelinating Schwann cells. • Schwann-cell–restricted adhesion/recognition factors CDH19 and LGI4 drive peripheral axon–glia interaction and radial sorting. • SCN7A, a sodium channel enriched in non-neuronal Schwann cells, and COL28A1, a collagen deposited in peripheral nerve basal lamina, mark mature myelinating Schwann cells. • CRYAB (α-B-crystallin) and GPM6B are stress-protective and membrane-modulating proteins up-regulated during active myelin compaction or repair. • Absence of neuronal or immune lineage markers and the coherent enrichment of multiple peripheral myelin genes support a specialized Schwann-cell myelination state rather than oligodendrocyte or other glial identities. Inconsistencies: • PLP1 and GPM6B are more abundant in CNS oligodendrocytes than in Schwann cells, but their documented expression in highly myelinating or stressed Schwann cells makes this only a minor conflict.

program_60.description: The gene set represents a classic “immediate-early response” program—an acute, transient transcriptional state that is rapidly induced in many cell types after stimulation (e.g., cytokines, growth factors, mechanical stress). It reflects recent cell activation rather than a specific lineage identity. Evidence: • FOS, FOSB, ATF3 – AP-1 family transcription factors induced within minutes of diverse stimuli and hallmark components of immediate-early gene (IEG) responses. • EGR1, IER2, NR4A1 – prototypical IEG transcription factors rapidly up-regulated during cellular activation, stress, or depolarization. • PPP1R15A (GADD34) – stress-inducible phosphatase regulator downstream of PERK/eIF2α signaling, commonly co-expressed with IEGs. • MYADM, CCNL1 – broadly expressed genes that often rise with general transcriptional up-shifts accompanying early activation. Inconsistencies: • No overt contradictions; however, the list lacks lineage-defining markers, so the program cannot specify a particular cell type—only the activated/stimulated state.

program_61.description: The program is most consistent with an epithelial cell state characterized by strong adherens-junction assembly and active Rho-GTPase–mediated cytoskeletal remodeling, i.e., a homeostatic, non-mesenchymal epithelium maintaining tight cell–cell adhesion rather than undergoing epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). Evidence: • CDH1 (E-cadherin) – canonical adherens-junction component and defining marker of epithelial identity. • CD2AP – scaffolding adaptor that binds E-cadherin and F-actin, stabilizing adherens junctions. • ROCK2 and ARHGAP5 – Rho kinase and Rho-GAP that modulate actin contractility and junction maturation, supporting an epithelial remodeling program. • TM9SF3 and DYNC1LI2 – membrane trafficking/vesicular transport proteins implicated in delivery of junctional components and polarity factors. • XIAP – anti-apoptotic factor often up-regulated in intact, survival-competent epithelia. • MED13, FMR1 – transcriptional/RNA-binding regulators that, while not epithelial-specific, are expressed in many epithelia and can support the extensive gene regulation needed for junction maintenance. Inconsistencies: • No strong contradictions; genes such as FMR1, MED13, and XIAP are ubiquitously expressed and provide limited epithelial specificity but do not conflict with the overall adherens-junction epithelial program.

program_62.description: The gene constellation most strongly reflects a ubiquitous “cellular housekeeping / mild stress-response” program rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. It highlights core components of membrane trafficking, integrin-mediated adhesion and general proteotoxic/oxidative stress buffering that can be transiently up-regulated in many cell types when they increase vesicle turnover or experience modest environmental stress. Evidence: • Membrane trafficking/endocytosis – CLTA (clathrin light chain), VPS35 (retromer core), ITGB1 (integrin β1 that couples to clathrin-mediated internalisation) support heightened vesicle cycling and adhesion remodeling. • Stress and proteostasis – HSBP1 (heat-shock factor modulator), MGST2 (ER-associated glutathione-dependent detoxification), ATF7 (ATF/CREB family stress-activated TF) point to oxidative/heat or unfolded-protein stress. • Signal integration / scaffolding – YWHAG (14-3-3γ) and YBX3 (Y-box RNA/DNA-binding protein) are classic, broadly expressed adaptors that stabilise phosphorylated clients or stress-regulated mRNAs. • Lack of lineage-defining markers and the predominance of widely expressed genes indicate a program that can be overlaid on many cell types rather than defining one. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; the list is simply too generic to ascribe to a specific differentiated lineage, though the absence of prominent chaperones such as HSPA1A/HSP90 suggests a mild rather than acute stress state.

program_63.description: The program most plausibly reflects a polarized, metabolically-active epithelial cell state—typical of intestinal, renal or other glandular epithelia—in which vesicle/recycling endosome trafficking and mitochondrial activity are up-regulated. Evidence: • RAB25 – hallmark small GTPase of apical recycling endosomes in gut, kidney and other columnar epithelia; rarely expressed outside epithelial lineages. • PCBD1 – co-factor for HNF1A-driven gene networks that pattern intestinal and renal epithelial cells. • TM9SF3 and SYNGR2 – transmembrane/vesicle-associated proteins enriched in secretory or absorptive epithelia, consistent with heightened membrane trafficking. • MRPL23, MLF2 – mitochondrial ribosome and nuclear/ER protein up-regulation, pointing to increased biosynthetic/energetic demands typical of actively transporting epithelia. • PDCD6 and RNF114 – Ca²⁺-dependent apoptotic/ubiquitin-ligase factors often induced during epithelial stress or remodeling, fitting a dynamic epithelial state rather than a mesenchymal or immune identity. • Absence of immune (e.g., CD3E), stromal (e.g., COL1A1) or neuronal (e.g., SNAP25) markers supports an epithelial assignment. Inconsistencies: • RNF114 is also reported in keratinocytes and some immune cells, and SYNGR2 can appear in hematopoietic lineages, so a small contribution from non-epithelial cells cannot be ruled out.

program_64.description: The gene set represents a metabolic program characterized by elevated mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and fatty-acid β-oxidation, a state commonly seen in highly oxidative cell types or cells that have shifted from glycolysis to an oxidative, quiescent or long-lived state (e.g., memory lymphocytes, mature neurons, cardiomyocytes). Evidence: • OXPHOS electron-transport chain – SDHC (complex II) and UQCRC2 (complex III) are core subunits of the respiratory chain, marking enhanced oxidative phosphorylation. • Tricarboxylic-acid cycle – MDH2 encodes mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase, supporting increased TCA cycle flux. • Fatty-acid oxidation – HADHA (trifunctional protein α) and ACSF3 (malonyl-/methyl-malonyl-CoA ligase) denote active long-chain fatty-acid β-oxidation, a hallmark of oxidative, energy-efficient cells. • Mitochondrial/translation support – SERBP1 (mitochondrial RNA-binding protein) and JTB have documented roles in mitochondrial mRNA handling and protein import, supporting heightened mitochondrial biogenesis. • Signaling/co-factor proteins – CSNK2B (casein-kinase II β) and PDCD6 (Ca²⁺-binding apoptotic regulator) frequently accompany increased mitochondrial activity and stress-response signaling. Inconsistencies: • PDCD6 and CSNK2B are not strictly metabolic; their presence may reflect parallel stress or survival signaling rather than pure oxidative metabolism.

program_65.description: The program reflects a proteostasis-oriented cellular state characterized by enhanced ubiquitin–proteasome activity together with active endocytic and endo-lysosomal trafficking; such a transcriptional pattern is commonly seen in metabolically active or recently stimulated cells (e.g., activated immune or proliferating cells) rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • Proteasome up-regulation – PSMD8 and PSMC5 encode 19S regulatory subunits of the 26S proteasome, marking increased protein degradation capacity. • Endocytosis/early endosome components – AP2M1 (AP-2 adaptor complex), RAB5C (early endosome GTPase) and ACTR1A (dynactin complex) cooperate in clathrin-mediated internalisation and vesicle transport. • Lysosome/mTOR coupling – LAMTOR1 anchors the Ragulator complex on late endosomes/lysosomes, linking amino-acid sensing to mTORC1 and autophagy regulation. • Metabolic and redox support – TALDO1 (non-oxidative pentose-phosphate pathway) supplies NADPH and ribose sugars needed for biosynthesis and stress defence; RNH1 protects against ribonuclease-mediated stress. • Collectively, these genes form a coherent proteostasis and vesicular-trafficking module typical of cells experiencing increased protein turnover or receptor recycling during activation. Inconsistencies: No strongly conflicting genes; TMEM50A and RNH1 are broadly expressed housekeeping genes that neither contradict nor uniquely specify the program.

program_66.description: The gene set is most consistent with an NRF2-driven antioxidant / cytoprotective stress-response program that can be activated in many epithelial and parenchymal cell types when they encounter oxidative or electrophilic stress. Evidence: • Glutathione metabolism – GCLC (rate-limiting enzyme for glutathione synthesis) and MGST2 (microsomal glutathione S-transferase) are canonical NRF2 targets that expand glutathione stores and conjugation capacity. • NADPH regeneration – IDH1 supplies cytosolic NADPH required to keep glutathione reduced and is frequently co-induced with NRF2 signaling. • Barrier / protease control – SPINT2 (HAI-2) is an epithelial Kunitz-type protease inhibitor up-regulated during stress to limit extracellular protease activity. • Secretory-pathway homeostasis – ATP2C1 (Golgi Ca2+/Mn2+ ATPase) and APLP2 are NRF2-responsive genes that help preserve ER/Golgi function under stress. • Transcriptional and RNA-processing modulators – RBM47 and IRF2BP2 are reported NRF2 co-regulated genes that modulate post-transcriptional handling of stress-response mRNAs. • Histamine catabolism – HNMT can also be NRF2-inducible and provides additional detoxification of reactive amines. Inconsistencies: • IRF2BP2 is better known for roles in macrophage polarization, and HNMT/RBM47 are not classical NRF2 targets; however, all three have documented induction under oxidative stress, so they do not strongly contradict the assignment.

program_67.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated fibroblast / myofibroblast program characteristic of fibrotic tissue or tumor-associated stroma, marked by high collagen production, extracellular-matrix (ECM) remodeling, and cytoskeletal re-organization. Evidence: • Collagen synthesis & maturation – SERPINH1 (HSP47, collagen-specific chaperone) and LOXL2 (collagen cross-linking enzyme) are canonical markers of collagen-secreting, matrix-remodeling fibroblasts/myofibroblasts. • Cytoskeletal / focal-adhesion remodeling – DLC1 (RhoGAP regulating actin stress fibers), KANK2 (focal-adhesion adaptor), and TMSB15A (actin-binding thymosin) support a contractile, motile myofibroblast phenotype. • Paracrine immunomodulation – IL34 (CSF1R ligand secreted by stromal fibroblasts to sustain macrophages) and TDO2 (tryptophan catabolism, immune-suppressive in stromal cells) fit stromal fibroblast functions in chronic inflammation or tumors. • Stress adaptation – MSRB3 counters oxidative/ER stress that accompanies high secretory activity in ECM-producing fibroblasts. Inconsistencies: • IL34 can also be produced by microglia/keratinocytes, and TDO2 is classically hepatic; however, both are reported in activated fibroblasts within inflamed or neoplastic tissues, so their presence is not strongly discordant.

program_68.description: The program is characteristic of alternatively-activated (M2-like), tissue-resident macrophages that display scavenger, anti-inflammatory and antigen-presenting functions. Evidence: • Scavenger/clearance receptors typical of M2 macrophages – STAB1, CD163L1, CD209 (DC-SIGN) and DNASE1L3 support a phagocytic, debris-clearing phenotype. • Anti-inflammatory/tolerogenic markers – FOLR2 and DAB2 are canonical genes enriched in M2 or immunoregulatory macrophages found in tissues and tumors. • Inhibitory immune receptors – LILRB5 is expressed on myeloid cells with dampened activation, fitting an immunosuppressive macrophage state. • GFRA2, although less commonly cited, has been reported in certain tissue macrophage subsets and aligns with a tissue-resident, differentiation-associated transcriptional profile. Inconsistencies: • GFRA2 is better known as a neurotrophic co-receptor and is not universally expressed in macrophages, so its presence may reflect a tissue-specific subset or mixed cell signal rather than a core macrophage marker.

program_69.description: The program most consistently reflects a generic “house-keeping / mild proliferative” state that accompanies many actively cycling cells rather than a lineage-restricted identity. The coordinated up-regulation of genes for nucleocytoplasmic transport (KPNB1), global transcriptional regulation (YY1, PURA), DNA damage surveillance (RAD23A), mitochondrial fitness (PHB2), and actin remodeling (WASF2, RALBP1) points to cells preparing for or progressing through the cell cycle while maintaining intracellular trafficking and energy production. Evidence: • KPNB1 and RALBP1 – importin-β1 and RLIP76 drive nucleocytoplasmic transport and vesicle/endocytotic trafficking, processes that rise with cell growth and division. • YY1 and PURA – broad chromatin/transcription regulators required for DNA replication and gene expression in proliferating cells. • RAD23A – nucleotide-excision repair and ubiquitin-shuttling protein, typically elevated when DNA synthesis and repair are active. • PHB2 – mitochondrial inner-membrane chaperone essential for mitochondrial biogenesis and mitophagy, supporting the higher energetic demand of dividing cells. • WASF2 – WAVE2 promotes actin polymerization, aiding cytokinesis and membrane dynamics during cell cycle progression. Inconsistencies: • NPHP3 encodes a ciliary/basal-body protein best known in kidney epithelia; its presence is not a canonical marker of proliferation and may reflect tissue-specific expression rather than the core program.

program_70.description: The gene set represents a universal S-phase cell-cycle program seen in proliferating cells of any lineage; it highlights DNA replication licensing, nucleotide synthesis, and chromatin/DNA-damage checkpoint functions that are maximally active as cells transition through G1/S into S phase. Evidence: • DNA replication licensing/checkpoint: CLSPN (S-phase checkpoint mediator), MCM10 and DTL (origins firing and replisome stability). • G1/S cyclin: CCNE2 drives entry into S phase. • Nucleotide biosynthesis for DNA synthesis: TYMS supplies dTMP for replicating DNA. • Maintenance of epigenetic marks during replication: UHRF1 and HELLS coordinate DNA methylation and chromatin remodeling in dividing cells. • Additional S/G2 cell-cycle gene: ZNF367 peaks in S/G2 and supports chromosome segregation. Inconsistencies: None apparent—every listed gene is tightly linked to S-phase cell-cycle activity.

program_71.description: The program represents a phagolysosomal/antigen-handling state typical of tissue-resident or activated macrophages (and closely related dendritic cells), characterized by high expression of Fc-receptor-mediated IgG uptake, vesicle trafficking, and lysosomal acidification genes. Evidence: • FCGRT (neonatal Fc receptor) – mediates IgG salvage and immune-complex uptake in macrophages and DCs. • SKAP2, MARCKS – cytoskeletal adaptors that promote integrin signaling, phagocytosis, and reactive oxygen burst in myeloid cells. • RAB32, RTN4 – small GTPase and ER/vesicle membrane protein involved in phagosome–lysosome fusion and antimicrobial activity in macrophages. • ATP6V0D1 – v-ATPase subunit required for lysosomal acidification during pathogen killing and antigen processing. • LGALS9 – immunomodulatory galectin enriched in alternatively activated and tissue-resident macrophages. • NCOA4 – ferritinophagy receptor; iron recycling is up-regulated in macrophages engaged in erythrophagocytosis or general autophagy. Inconsistencies: • No major outliers; RTN4 is better known for neuronal roles but is documented in macrophage ER where it regulates phagosome maturation, so it is not strongly contradictory.

program_72.description: The program reflects a nucleolar-enriched “ribosome-biogenesis/translation” state that is typically up-regulated in highly proliferative or metabolically active cells (e.g., cycling progenitors or rapidly dividing tumor cells). Evidence: • Nucleolar rRNA transcription / processing: DDX21, WDR43, PDCD11 are core components of 18S/28S rRNA maturation and nucleolar organization. • Translation initiation and ribosome assembly: EIF3B, BZW2, CCT6A (CCT/TRiC chaperonin) and SYNCRIP promote initiation-complex formation, folding of nascent polypeptides, and mRNA handling, all hallmarks of increased protein synthesis demand. • Coupling to DNA repair in cycling cells: PRKDC (DNA-PKcs) is activated during replication to repair double-strand breaks, commonly co-expressed with ribosome-biogenesis genes in proliferating cells. Inconsistencies: No clear inconsistencies; all positively loaded genes converge on nucleolar function, translation, or proliferation support.

program_73.description: The program most closely reflects a neuronal cell-adhesion / synaptic-maturation state, characterized by coordinated up-regulation of junctional, cytoskeletal-linker and integrin-associated genes that stabilize neuron–neuron and neuron–matrix contacts. Evidence: • CTNNA1 (α-catenin) – core adherens-junction component that links cadherins to the actin cytoskeleton in neurons and is required for synapse stabilization. • APP – highly expressed in neurons; its extracellular domain and intracellular tail promote neurite outgrowth and interact with ITGB1 to modulate synaptic adhesion. • ITGB1 – β1-integrin subunit essential for axon guidance, dendritic spine maintenance and neuronal ECM interactions. • PDLIM5 – PDZ/LIM scaffold enriched in postsynaptic densities; anchors actin and signaling proteins during synapse maturation. • NECTIN2 (PVRL2) – immunoglobulin-like adhesion molecule that forms nectin–afadin complexes at puncta adherentia junctions in neurons. • FRMD8 – FERM-domain adaptor that stabilizes membrane proteins (e.g., ADAM17), supporting receptor shedding and synaptic remodeling. • CYB5R3 – neuronal flavoprotein that regulates redox state and membrane lipid desaturation, processes important during high synaptic activity. • PTTG1IP – nuclear envelope protein up-regulated in differentiating neurons, linked to chromatin changes that accompany maturation. Inconsistencies: No strongly contradictory genes are present; the gene set lacks negative loaders, and all listed genes can be reconciled with a neuron-centric adhesion / maturation program, although CYB5R3 and PTTG1IP are more general housekeeping or cell-cycle related and provide weaker, but not conflicting, support.

program_74.description: The gene set represents a metabolic program of heightened mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS), typical of cells in an energetically demanding, highly respiring state rather than a lineage-specific signature. Evidence: • Multiple cytochrome-c oxidase (complex IV) subunits up-regulated (COX5A, COX5B, COX6A1, COX6C, COX7B, COX8A) – hallmark of increased complex IV assembly and activity. • UQCRQ (complex III) and NDUFA1 (complex I) co-induction indicates coordinated up-regulation of the entire electron-transport chain, a canonical OXPHOS module. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently fit an OXPHOS program.

program_75.description: The gene set represents a generic “RNA processing / transcriptional machinery” program rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity; it marks cells with heightened RNA polymerase II–driven transcription and extensive co-transcriptional splicing activity, a state often seen in metabolically active or rapidly responding cells across diverse tissues. Evidence: • Core DEAD-box RNA helicases DDX5 and DDX17 are central components of the spliceosome and transcriptional co-activators, hallmarking increased pre-mRNA processing. • PNISR, RSRP1 and ARGLU1 are serine/arginine-rich splicing regulators that scaffold or modulate spliceosome assembly, reinforcing an RNA-splicing-focused program. • POLR2J3 encodes a small subunit of RNA polymerase II, directly linking the program to elevated transcription. • KANSL1 is part of the NSL histone-acetyltransferase complex that promotes open chromatin and supports high transcriptional output. • N4BP2L2 has been reported to interact with ubiquitin and RNA-binding proteins, and co-varies with spliceosome components in expression datasets, fitting the same functional theme. Inconsistencies: No clear contradictory genes are present; all listed genes participate in, or associate with, RNA polymerase II–mediated transcription or RNA splicing.

program_76.description: The program most closely matches tissue-resident memory (Trm) / innate-like cytotoxic T lymphocytes that maintain TCR signalling competence and NF-κB–modulated survival. Evidence: • ZNF683 (Hobit) – master transcription factor driving tissue residency of CD8⁺ Trm cells and ILC1. • LAT and PRKCH – core T-cell receptor signalling adaptors/kinases required for sustained T-cell activation and memory maintenance. • JAKMIP1 – cytoskeletal and JAK-STAT regulator enriched in cytotoxic T and NK cells. • TNIP3 – inducible NF-κB inhibitor up-regulated in activated/resident T cells to temper inflammatory signalling. Inconsistencies: • NELL2 and OXNAD1 are not T-cell-specific; their presence may reflect low-level background expression or technical noise rather than the defining biology of this program.

program_77.description: The program most plausibly reflects a generic “house-keeping / metabolic activation” state—cells that are gearing up transcription, translation, RNA processing, and signal-transduction pathways needed for growth or stress responses rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • RNA translation / ribosome control – EIF4G2 (DAP5) drives cap-dependent and cap-independent translation; BAZ2A (TIP5) organizes the nucleolus for rRNA transcription; together they typify cells with high protein-synthesis demand. • RNA processing / editing – ADAR catalyzes A-to-I editing and is induced when cells are metabolically or interferon activated, again marking heightened RNA turnover. • Core signaling & cytoskeleton – GNB1 (G-protein β), IQGAP1 (scaffold for MAPK/Actin), and PTP4A2 (PRL-2 phosphatase) all promote proliferation, migration, or survival signalling seen in many actively growing cells. • Stress- or activation-linked antigen pathway – TAPBP (tapasin) is an interferon-responsive chaperone for MHC-I peptide loading and is widely induced outside professional APCs during cellular activation, fitting a generalized “alert” state rather than a dedicated immune lineage program. Inconsistencies: • TAPBP is usually accompanied by other MHC-I machinery genes (HLA-A/B/C, B2M, TAP1/2); their absence means this is unlikely to represent a full antigen-presentation module, underscoring the program’s non-lineage-specific, partial activation character.

program_78.description: The program is characteristic of differentiated colonic/intestinal epithelial cells—predominantly absorptive enterocytes/colonocytes that contribute to mucin production and ion transport. Evidence: • MUC12 and GCNT3 – surface mucin (MUC12) and glycosyl-transferase (GCNT3) required for O-glycan branching on intestinal mucins, both enriched in mature colon epithelium. • SLC9A3 (NHE3) – brush-border Na⁺/H⁺ exchanger that mediates electroneutral Na⁺ absorption in differentiated enterocytes/colonocytes. • TMPRSS2 – serine protease highly expressed in luminal colon and small-intestinal epithelium. • TMIGD1 – adhesion molecule confined to mature intestinal epithelial cells, particularly colonocytes, and induced during differentiation. • TRIM31 – autophagy-related E3 ligase enriched in intestinal epithelium and linked to epithelial homeostasis. • C11orf86 – transcript with highest expression in colon tissue according to GTEx, supporting a colonic epithelial signature. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; all listed genes fit a mature intestinal epithelial/colonocyte program.

program_79.description: The gene set is most consistent with a small-intestinal Paneth-cell–like secretory program characterized by high production of α-defensins and an enhanced regulated-exocytosis machinery. Evidence: • DEFA5, DEFA6 – canonical α-defensins uniquely abundant in small-intestinal Paneth cells that mediate antimicrobial defense. • CADPS, CACNA2D2 – Ca²⁺-dependent secretory-granule priming and voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channel subunit, respectively; both enrich Paneth and other secretory epithelial cells with dense-core granules. • PCSK1 – prohormone convertase involved in peptide processing within regulated granules, supporting a secretory/peptidergic phenotype. • KLK12, ELOVL2 – enzymes expressed in intestinal gland epithelial cells, associated with mucosal barrier functions and lipid modifications found in Paneth‐cell secretory products. Inconsistencies: • PCSK1 is more typical of enteroendocrine cells than Paneth cells, suggesting some overlap with endocrine programs. • KLK12 and ELOVL2 are not Paneth-specific and are expressed in other epithelial contexts, indicating that the program may capture a broader secretory signature beyond pure Paneth identity.

program_80.description: The gene set strongly points to proliferating/early chondrocytes in developing cartilage (e.g., growth-plate or articular cartilage) undergoing matrix production and IGF-driven growth. Evidence: • Cartilage extracellular matrix genes – COL2A1 and COL11A2 encode type II and XI collagens that are canonical markers of chondrocytes and essential components of cartilaginous matrix. • Chondrocyte-associated secreted factor – MIA/CD-RAP is a well-established marker of differentiated chondrocytes and is highly expressed in cartilage. • Growth-promoting signal – IGF2 supports embryonic skeletal growth and stimulates chondrocyte proliferation and matrix synthesis in the growth plate. • Developmental cytoskeletal regulator – CAPN6 is enriched in mesenchymal tissues, including developing cartilage, and modulates cytoskeletal dynamics during chondrocyte maturation. Inconsistencies: • CLDN2 is classically a tight-junction protein of absorptive epithelia (intestine, kidney) rather than cartilage. • GABRA4 is a neuronal GABA-A receptor subunit; its presence is atypical for chondrocytes and may reflect low-level background expression or mixed cell populations.

program_81.description: The gene set is characteristic of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) in a basal/resting state, reflecting their canonical surface receptors and intracellular trafficking machinery. Evidence: • LILRA4 (ILT7) and CLEC4C (BDCA-2) – paired, pDC-specific inhibitory receptors universally used to immunophenotype human pDCs. • SCT (Secretin) – repeatedly identified in single-cell studies as a high-confidence pDC transcript despite limited expression elsewhere. • PTCRA – although classically a thymocyte gene, low-level expression is a known feature of lymphoid-related pDCs and appears in multiple pDC RNA-seq signatures. • PACSIN1 and SMPD3 – regulators of endocytosis and membrane lipid remodeling that are enriched in pDCs, fitting their potent endosomal TLR7/9 signaling capacity. • VASH2 – reported among interferon-competent pDC clusters and linked to angiostatic factor production by these cells. Inconsistencies: • PTCRA is more typical of early T-cell precursors, and VASH2 can be endothelial, but both have documented, albeit lower, expression in pDC transcriptomes; no gene strongly contradicts a pDC identity.

program_82.description: This gene program is characteristic of SPP1⁺, SLAMF9⁺ inflammatory macrophages engaged in extracellular-matrix remodelling and neutrophil recruitment, a state commonly observed in fibrotic or tumour-associated tissues. Evidence: • SPP1 (osteopontin) and SLAMF9 are co-markers of a well-described SPP1⁺ macrophage subset enriched in fibrotic liver, lung, and many cancers. • CTSL (lysosomal cathepsin) together with the matrix-degrading enzymes MMP9, MMP8 and MMP10 denotes macrophages with high proteolytic/ECM-remodelling activity. • CXCL5 is a neutrophil-attracting chemokine secreted by activated tissue macrophages, fitting the pro-inflammatory, recruitment role of this state. Inconsistencies: • MMP8 is classically abundant in neutrophils rather than macrophages, but has been reported in a subset of highly inflammatory macrophages, so the discordance is minor.

program_83.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated mesenchymal / fibroblast program characterized by focal-adhesion remodeling, actin-cytoskeleton reorganization and synthesis of extracellular matrix components—features typical of migratory, myofibroblast-like cells. Evidence: • Focal-adhesion & actin-cytoskeleton genes (cell motility): ACTN1 (actin cross-linking), PTPN12 and ASAP1 (focal-adhesion/ARF-GAP regulators). • Microtubule/actin coupling that promotes protrusive migration: DPYSL2 (CRMP2). • ECM and glycosaminoglycan biosynthesis: CHSY1 (chondroitin-sulfate synthase). • Signal-transduction components that drive motile mesenchymal behavior: GNB4 (G-protein β subunit) and SLCO3A1 (organic-anion transporter often up-regulated in migrating stromal cells). Inconsistencies: • DPYSL2 and GNB4 are better known for neuronal functions, introducing a neuronal flavor that is not typical for fibroblasts, but both proteins also participate in generic cytoskeletal and signaling pathways found in motile non-neuronal cells.

program_84.description: The gene set represents a generic “house-keeping / metabolic activity” program seen in many viable, metabolically active cells rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. High expression of translation initiation, co-translational N-glycosylation, nucleotide salvage, and mitochondrial electron-transport components points to cells that are maintaining robust protein synthesis and oxidative phosphorylation but do not show markers of a specific differentiated lineage or of overt cell cycle progression. Evidence: • Translation machinery – EIF3F (eIF3 subunit), BTF3 (nascent-chain–associated transcription/translation factor) support active protein synthesis. • Protein processing – OST4 is part of the oligosaccharyl-transferase complex that glycosylates nascent polypeptides, consistent with high secretory/processing activity. • Mitochondrial function – TOMM7 (protein import into mitochondria) and UQCRB (Complex III subunit) indicate enhanced oxidative phosphorylation capacity. • Nucleotide metabolism – APRT participates in the adenine salvage pathway, fitting a metabolically active, biosynthetic state. • C12orf57, although less characterized, is reported as constitutively expressed across tissues and fits a housekeeping profile. Inconsistencies: No strong lineage-specific or cell-cycle genes are present; the set is internally consistent with a generalized metabolic program.

program_85.description: The gene set is most consistent with an immune-cell activation program, typical of T lymphocytes (and other leukocytes) that are simultaneously responding to cytokine/JAK-STAT signals and engaging integrin-dependent adhesion and chemokine-guided motility. Evidence: • Cytokine signalling – JAK1 and STAT3 form the core of IL-6/IL-10-type JAK-STAT pathways that are rapidly induced in activated T cells and other leukocytes. • Chemokine/G-protein signalling – GNAI2 is the principal G-protein α-subunit used by CCR and CXCR chemokine receptors during T-cell trafficking. • Adhesion/migration machinery – TLN1 (talin-1) links activated integrins to the actin cytoskeleton, while WNK1 supports integrin-dependent volume and motility changes; both are required for immunological synapse formation and leukocyte transmigration. • Innate/activation co-factors – LRRFIP1 (modulator of TLR/NLR signalling) and the RNA helicase DDX3X (type-I-IFN sensor/co-activator) are up-regulated during immune activation and cooperate with STAT pathways. Inconsistencies: • No obvious conflicts; the list is small and all genes can be accommodated within a broad leukocyte activation/adhesion state, though the absence of classic effector genes (e.g., CD69, IFNG) limits more precise subtype assignment.

program_86.description: The program represents an SREBP2-driven cholesterol/mevalonate-biosynthetic state that can emerge in any cell type requiring rapid membrane synthesis or lipid homeostasis (e.g., proliferating, metabolically activated, or lipogenic cells). Evidence: • HMGCR, HMGCS1 and IDI1 – rate-limiting enzymes of the mevalonate pathway producing precursors for cholesterol and isoprenoids. • SQLE, MSMO1 and DHCR24 – successive enzymes converting squalene to lanosterol and then to cholesterol. • INSIG1 – ER anchor that regulates SREBP processing and transcriptionally feeds back on sterol biosynthetic genes, marking activation of the SREBP2 regulon. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes participate coherently in de novo cholesterol synthesis.

program_87.description: The gene set is most consistent with an IL-13–responsive, tissue-remodeling epithelial/fibroblast program often seen in airway or mucosal epithelium exposed to type-2 cytokines, where cells acquire extracellular-matrix–modifying and migratory features. Evidence: • IL13RA1 – obligate subunit of the IL-13/IL-4 receptor; strongly up-regulated in epithelial and stromal cells exposed to type-2 cytokines. • ADAM9 – metalloproteinase that degrades extracellular matrix and is induced during epithelial injury, repair and EMT; elevated in IL-13–treated airway epithelium. • PTPN12 and CYFIP1 – regulators of integrin signalling and actin dynamics, respectively, supporting increased cell motility typical of EMT/tissue-remodelling states. • ATP11A – phospholipid “flippase” enriched in barrier epithelia and required for membrane remodeling during cell migration. • ZFHX3 – transcription factor that promotes epithelial plasticity and has been implicated in EMT and airway epithelial differentiation. Inconsistencies: • PHC2 and several other listed genes (e.g., CYFIP1) are ubiquitously expressed housekeeping or chromatin-regulating factors and do not specifically mark IL-13–responsive epithelium; however, they do not contradict the program.

program_88.description: The gene set is most consistent with a neuronal program associated with active neurite/axon out-growth and cytoskeletal remodeling, a state typical of developing or regenerating CNS neurons rather than a specific mature neuronal subtype. Evidence: • DPYSL2 (CRMP2) – key mediator of microtubule assembly and growth-cone dynamics during axon extension. • MACF1 – microtubule/actin cross-linker required for neuronal migration and neurite elongation. • WNK1 – kinase that promotes axon lengthening and regulates ion fluxes in growing neurites. • TBC1D2B & HERC1 – Rab-GAP and E3-ubiquitin ligase involved in vesicle trafficking and protein turnover, processes heightened during neurite extension. • PRKAR1A – PKA regulatory subunit; cAMP–PKA signaling steers growth-cone guidance. • QKI – RNA-binding protein that stabilizes mRNAs encoding cytoskeletal regulators in developing neurons (also expressed in glia but up-regulated during neuronal process formation). Inconsistencies: • QKI is also a hallmark of oligodendrocyte lineage cells, and the set lacks classic neuron-specific synaptic markers (e.g., SNAP25, SYP); however, QKI’s documented role in early neuronal development lessens this concern. • Several genes (PRKAR1A, HERC1) are broadly expressed housekeeping/regulatory factors, offering limited cell-type specificity but are compatible with an active growth program.

program_89.description: The gene set denotes an activated, extracellular-matrix-remodeling fibroblast / myofibroblast program often seen in wound-healing, fibrotic, or tumor-associated stroma. Evidence: • POSTN and HAS2 – canonical markers of periostin-positive, TGF-β–responsive myofibroblasts that secrete collagen and hyaluronan during tissue repair and fibrosis. • BMPER – modulates BMP signaling in mesenchymal cells and is up-regulated in activated stromal fibroblasts. • PTGDS and APOD – lipid-modifying, secreted factors enriched in specific fibroblast subsets (lipofibroblasts, inflammatory CAFs) that accompany matrix remodeling. • FILIP1L – regulates actin cytoskeleton dynamics in motile mesenchymal cells, aligning with a migratory/contractile fibroblast phenotype. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes were supplied; no strong contradictions within the positively associated list.

program_90.description: The program is most consistent with activated bone-marrow mesenchymal/early osteoblastic stromal cells that secrete RANKL to drive osteoclastogenesis during bone remodeling. Evidence: • TNFSF11 (RANKL) – quintessential product of osteoblast-lineage and bone-marrow stromal cells that signals to osteoclast precursors. • ARHGAP28 – promotes actin remodeling and mechanotransduction in differentiating osteoblasts; up-regulated during osteogenic commitment. • IGDCC4 (neogenin-like Ig superfamily member) – highly expressed in osteogenic mesenchyme and supports BMP-driven osteoblast maturation. • NCAM1 – cell-adhesion molecule present on mesenchymal stromal cells and immature osteoblasts, facilitating osteoblast–osteoclast contact. • F2RL2 (PAR3) – protease-activated receptor detected in osteoblasts and marrow stromal cells, where thrombin signaling modulates bone turnover. • SGCD – although classically a muscle sarcoglycan, it is also detected in mesenchymal cells in marrow and calvaria and is implicated in bone matrix organization. Inconsistencies: • SGCD is best known for skeletal/cardiac muscle expression; its presence may reflect muscle contaminating transcripts or a myogenic bias of the mesenchymal population. • NCAM1 and IGDCC4 are also abundant in neural tissues, and F2RL2 in platelets/endothelium, so their co-expression could indicate a heterogeneous mesenchymal subset rather than a pure osteoblast population.

program_91.description: The gene set is most consistent with a skeletal‐muscle/myocyte program, reflecting cells that maintain the sarcolemmal dystrophin–glycoprotein complex and a muscle-specific stress-response machinery typical of mature or late-stage differentiating skeletal muscle fibers. Evidence: • SGCA encodes α-sarcoglycan, a core component of the dystrophin–glycoprotein complex restricted to skeletal and cardiac muscle membranes. • HSPB2 is a small heat-shock protein highly enriched in skeletal and cardiac myocytes where it associates with Z-lines and supports contractile protein folding during mechanical or metabolic stress. • RERGL shows preferential expression in heart and skeletal muscle, fitting a muscle-restricted transcriptional profile. • C1QTNF2 (CTRP2) is an adipokine but is also produced by metabolically active skeletal muscle, especially under exercise-like conditions, aligning with a muscle metabolic/stress program. Inconsistencies: • GPR20 and NRIP2 are better known for neuronal or broad tissue expression; their inclusion suggests either low-level, context-dependent expression in muscle or minor contamination from nearby cell types.

program_92.description: The gene set is most consistent with a homeostatic lung/alveolar fibroblast (lipofibroblast-like) program characterized by secretion of antioxidant and xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes together with extracellular-matrix/TGF-β–modulating proteins. Evidence: • GPX3 – secreted antioxidant peroxidase strongly enriched in alveolar/adventitial fibroblasts of human lung and found in their culture supernatants. • LTBP4 – ECM glycoprotein that binds latent TGF-β; a canonical fibroblast marker, highly expressed in pulmonary interstitial fibroblasts. • GPC3 – heparan-sulfate proteoglycan reported in “alveolar fibroblast / lipofibroblast” clusters in single-cell lung atlases. • CYP4B1 – cytochrome P450 isoform with highest expression in lung parenchyma; provides xenobiotic-metabolizing capacity to fibroblasts and other stromal cells. • CES1 – carboxylesterase involved in lipid and xenobiotic metabolism; expressed in mesenchymal stromal cells including lung/adipose fibroblasts. • PAMR1 – secreted serine protease expressed by skeletal muscle and lung fibroblasts, fitting a mesenchymal, ECM-related program. • Absence of negative (down-loaded) genes rules out opposing epithelial or immune signatures, further supporting a mesenchymal fibroblast identity. Inconsistencies: • CES1 and GPC3 are also abundant in hepatocytes, and GPX3 is strongly produced by kidney proximal tubules; thus the program shares some detoxification genes with other secretory organs, though their co-expression with LTBP4 and CYP4B1 is most parsimoniously explained by a lung fibroblast rather than hepatic or renal identity.

program_93.description: The gene set reflects an activated T-cell program characterized by proximal T-cell-receptor (TCR) signalling adaptors, cytoskeletal/adhesion regulators and an NF-κB–inducible negative-feedback component, consistent with recently stimulated, integrin-engaged T lymphocytes. Evidence: • TCR-signalling adaptors – FYB1 (ADAP), LCP2 (SLP-76) and SLA are core components of the proximal TCR signalosome, required for LAT/PLCγ recruitment and downstream activation. • Cytoskeletal and integrin coupling – FYB1 and LCP1 (L-plastin) promote actin re-arrangement and inside-out activation of LFA-1; ADGRE5 (CD97) is up-regulated on activated T cells and enhances adhesion/motility. • Immediate early activation marker – TNFAIP3 (A20) is rapidly induced by NF-κB after TCR or TNF stimulation, providing negative feedback to dampen inflammatory signalling, a hallmark of recent activation. Inconsistencies: • ADGRE5 and LCP1 are also expressed in myeloid cells, but their co-occurrence with multiple TCR-specific adaptors strongly favours an activated T-cell rather than myeloid program.

program_94.description: The program most closely matches an activated CD4⁺ T-cell state, enriched for IL-2/IL-2-receptor signaling and NF-κB–dependent gene expression typical of recently stimulated effector or regulatory T cells (Tregs). Evidence: • IL2RA (CD25) – high-affinity IL-2 receptor α-chain; classic marker of TCR-activated CD4⁺ T cells and constitutively high on Tregs. • RTKN2 – T-cell–restricted Rho effector that promotes NF-κB survival signaling in activated CD4⁺ T cells and is abundant in Tregs. • LTB – TNF-superfamily cytokine produced after T-cell activation, reinforcing lymphoid tissue signaling. • FANK1 together with CUL9 – genes linked to Fas-mediated apoptosis and p53 pathways, processes engaged during strong T-cell activation. • Absence of negatively loaded genes supports a focused, activation-driven transcriptional program rather than a mixed lineage signature. Inconsistencies: • FANK1 is better known for germ-cell expression, and GNG8 is usually neuronal; their presence may reflect broader stress/GPCR signaling not specific to T cells. • CUL9 is ubiquitous, offering limited lineage specificity.

program_95.description: The gene set reflects an interferon-induced MHC class I antigen-processing and presentation program, typical of cells (immune or parenchymal) that have been stimulated by IFN-γ and are preparing to display intracellular peptides to cytotoxic T lymphocytes. Evidence: • Classical MHC-I heavy chains HLA-B and HLA-C are strongly up-regulated, a hallmark of IFN-γ–driven antigen presentation. • Non-classical MHC-I genes HLA-E and HLA-F rise concurrently, a known feature of the same interferon response. • TAP1 (peptide transporter) and PSMB9 (immunoproteasome subunit β1i) are core components of the IFN-γ–inducible peptide-loading machinery required for optimal MHC-I presentation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently participate in the interferon-stimulated MHC class I pathway.

program_96.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, IL-23–responsive Th17 (IL-17–producing CD4⁺ T helper) program that has adopted a pathogenic/tissue-inflammatory phenotype often seen in autoimmune or barrier-site inflammation. Evidence: • IL17A – signature cytokine of Th17 cells. • IL23R – IL-23 receptor required for maintenance and pathogenicity of Th17 cells. • IL26 – cytokine co-secreted by human Th17 and Th1/17 cells in inflamed tissues. • SLC4A10 – bicarbonate transporter repeatedly reported as highly enriched in pathogenic or CNS-infiltrating Th17 cells. • S100A4 – calcium-binding protein up-regulated in activated/memory T cells and migratory effector Th17 cells. • NCR3 (NKp30) – NK receptor expressed on a subset of “pathogenic” or tissue Th17 cells that display cytotoxic potential, fully compatible with an inflammatory Th17 state. Inconsistencies: • NCR3 is classically an NK-cell marker; its presence suggests either a specialized NK-receptor⁺ Th17 subset or minor contamination by NK cells, but it has been documented on human Th17 cells. • Lack of canonical Th17 transcription factor RORC or chemokine receptor CCR6 in the provided list (possibly due to limited feature selection rather than true absence).

program_97.description: The gene combination most strongly points to an endosome/lysosome acidification and trafficking program that is typically up-regulated in phagocytic myeloid cells (e.g., macrophages or microglia) when they are actively internalising and processing cargo. Evidence: • RAB5C – key GTPase for early endosome formation and maturation, highly expressed during active phagocytosis in myeloid cells. • CHMP5 – ESCRT-III component required for multivesicular body (MVB) formation and receptor down-regulation, enriched in antigen-processing phagocytes. • ATP6V0B – V-ATPase V0 subunit essential for endosomal/lysosomal acidification; high levels mark lysosome-rich phagocytes. • NR1H2 (LXR-β) – nuclear receptor controlling cholesterol efflux and lipid handling; strongly induced in macrophages/microglia undergoing lipid processing after phagocytosis. • TMEM219 – plasma-membrane receptor that modulates IGFBP3-dependent apoptosis and is reported in macrophages, linking endocytic signalling to cell fate. Inconsistencies: • Lack of classical myeloid surface markers (e.g., CD68, CSF1R, AIF1) means the program is endosome-centric rather than definitively macrophage-specific. • C1orf43 has unclear function in endocytic biology and is broadly expressed.

program_98.description: The gene set represents a generic, proliferation-linked proteostasis program that supports cells preparing for or undergoing division, rather than marking a specific lineage. Elevated expression of chaperones and ubiquitin-like modifiers points to increased protein folding, post-translational modification, and microtubule assembly—core processes required during cell-cycle progression. Evidence: • SUMO2 and NEDD8 – ubiquitin-like modifiers whose conjugation peaks in S phase and mitosis to regulate cullin-ring ligases and chromosome segregation. • TBCA – tubulin-folding co-factor essential for assembling α/β-tubulin heterodimers and building the mitotic spindle. • PTGES3 (p23) – HSP90 co-chaperone that stabilizes many kinase and steroid-receptor clients, including several cell-cycle regulators. • ERH – nuclear protein that interacts with spliceosome components and is required for faithful DNA replication and sister-chromatid cohesion. • Collective absence of lineage-defining markers and presence of multiple housekeeping/stress-response genes are typical of a broad “cell-cycle/proteostasis” state seen across proliferating cells. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; the small set is internally consistent with a general proliferation/protein-quality-control program.

program_99.description: The program represents an S-phase DNA-replication module characteristic of actively cycling (proliferating) cells, irrespective of lineage. Evidence: • MCM3, MCM5, MCM7 – core components of the MCM2-7 helicase that licenses replication origins and operates during S phase. • GINS2 – part of the GINS complex that, together with MCM and CDC45, forms the CMG helicase driving replication-fork progression. • DNMT1 – maintenance DNA-methyltransferase recruited to replication forks to copy CpG methylation patterns during S phase. • MMS22L – replication-coupled DNA-repair factor that stabilizes stalled forks and supports genome integrity in S phase. Inconsistencies: • None obvious; all listed genes coherently support a DNA-replication/proliferation state.

program_100.description: The gene set denotes a cellular state characterized by activation of the unfolded-protein response (UPR)/endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress program, a condition commonly observed in highly secretory cells or in cells exposed to hypoxia or other stresses that increase protein-folding load. Evidence: • HSPA5 (BiP/GRP78) – master ER chaperone transcriptionally induced by all three UPR branches (ATF6, IRE1, PERK). • CALR – ER calcium-binding lectin chaperone up-regulated during UPR to assist glycoprotein folding. • PDIA4 and PDIA6 – ER-resident protein disulfide-isomerases whose expression rises during ER stress to catalyze disulfide bond formation. • PPIB – cyclophilin B, an ER peptidyl-prolyl isomerase co-regulated with other ER chaperones in UPR gene modules. • HYOU1 (ORP150) – hypoxia-up-regulated, ER-localized chaperone induced by ATF6 and PERK pathways, linking hypoxic stress with the UPR. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are canonical components of the ER stress/UPR machinery.

program_101.description: The gene set represents an endoplasmic-reticulum (ER) stress / unfolded-protein-response (UPR) program typical of highly secretory cells that are coping with increased protein-folding load. Up-regulation of ER quality-control (ERQC), ER-associated degradation (ERAD) and COPII vesicle–mediated ER-to-Golgi trafficking components suggests cells in an activated secretory state (e.g., plasma cells, pancreatic acinar, goblet, or hormone-producing endocrine cells) experiencing adaptive UPR rather than a lineage-specific signature. Evidence: • CCPG1 – ER-phagy receptor induced by UPR to remove damaged ER. • DNAJC3 (P58IPK) – HSP40 family co-chaperone transcriptionally up-regulated by PERK/ATF6 arms of the UPR to attenuate ER stress. • SEL1L – Core scaffold of the HRD1 ERAD complex; expression rises during UPR to clear mis-folded proteins. • SEC24D & SEC31A – COPII coat proteins required for ER-to-Golgi export; increased demand reflects heightened secretory throughput. • USO1 (p115) – Golgi tethering factor facilitating COPII vesicle docking, likewise elevated during secretory expansion. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all positively loaded genes participate in ERQC/secretory trafficking and align with an ER stress / UPR program rather than contradicting it.

program_102.description: The gene set best fits a CD27⁺ memory B-cell program, reflecting mature, antigen-experienced B cells with active SLAM-family signaling; the presence of the erythrocyte marker GYPC likely represents ambient RNA or occasional doublets rather than a defining feature of the state. Evidence: • CD27 – canonical surface marker of switched and unswitched memory B cells. • LY9 (SLAMF3/CD229) – SLAM-family receptor highly expressed on mature and memory B cells, involved in B-cell activation. • TMEM156 and CYTIP – both reported to be up-regulated in CD27⁺ memory B cells in human peripheral blood scRNA-seq datasets. • RIC3 – detectable in lymphoid populations and has been noted in memory B-cell transcriptional signatures. Inconsistencies: • GYPC – erythrocyte membrane glycoprotein; points to red-cell ambient RNA or doublet contamination rather than a lymphoid program.

program_103.description: The gene set is most consistent with a differentiated intestinal epithelial (colon/small-intestinal) enterocyte program characterized by active ketogenesis and steroid/ion-handling functions. Evidence: • HMGCS2 – mitochondrial HMG-CoA synthase, a hallmark of ketogenic metabolism in mature small-intestinal and colonic enterocytes. • HSD11B2 – converts cortisol to cortisone; highly expressed in colon and kidney epithelia that regulate sodium transport, fitting absorptive colonocytes. • VSIG2 – enriched in intestinal epithelial cells and reported as a surface marker of mucosal/goblet-lineage epithelium, supporting an intestinal origin. • CHP2 – calcium-binding regulator of Na⁺/H⁺ exchangers, abundant in intestinal epithelium where tight pH and ion homeostasis are required. • PRKACB & PDCD4 – broadly expressed signaling/tumor-suppressor genes that participate in cAMP-PKA and stress-response pathways; their inclusion is compatible with metabolically active, hormonally responsive epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • No strongly conflicting genes; PRKACB and PDCD4 are ubiquitous rather than intestine-specific but do not contradict an enterocyte state.

program_104.description: The program represents mucosal epithelial cells—most characteristically intestinal enterocytes—engaged in an acute innate-immune/antimicrobial response. Evidence: • DUOX2 & DUOXA2 – dual oxidase complex that generates H2O2 in intestinal and airway epithelia for microbicidal activity; strongly induced in inflamed gut mucosa (e.g., IBD). • LCN2 – lipocalin-2, a neutrophil-like antimicrobial protein also secreted by activated intestinal/airway epithelial cells to sequester bacterial siderophores. • PI3 (elafin) – epithelial serine-protease inhibitor with direct antimicrobial and anti-protease functions; highly expressed in inflamed gut and lung epithelia. • SAA1 – acute-phase apolipoprotein produced by epithelium during cytokine-driven inflammation and infection. • PDZK1IP1 (MAP17) – membrane protein enriched in absorptive enterocytes and renal/colonic epithelium; up-regulated by oxidative stress and inflammatory cues. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded or obviously discordant genes were supplied, so no clear inconsistencies with the proposed epithelial innate-immune activation state.

program_105.description: The gene set is most consistent with a malignant epithelial cell program characterized by cancer-testis antigen (CTA) expression together with an acute-phase/secretory response that is often seen in dedifferentiated gastrointestinal or pancreatic tumor cells exposed to inflammation. Evidence: • CTA module: MAGEA3 and MAGEA6 are classical cancer-testis antigens that are virtually absent from normal somatic epithelia but frequently re-expressed in a wide range of carcinomas, indicating a malignant, dedifferentiated state. • Acute-phase/secretory genes: ORM1 (α1-acid glycoprotein), REG3A (antimicrobial C-type lectin), and LCN15 (lipocalin family) are all secreted proteins that rise during epithelial inflammatory or injury responses and are up-regulated in inflamed or neoplastic intestinal/pancreatic epithelium. Their co-expression with CTAs supports an inflamed tumor cell phenotype. Inconsistencies: • HBA2 is an erythroid hemoglobin gene and is likely derived from ambient RNA or a red-blood-cell doublet rather than the epithelial tumor cell itself. • LCN15 expression is most documented in nasal/airway epithelium, so its presence here may reflect broader secretory activation or technical noise rather than lineage specificity.

program_106.description: The gene set denotes a surfactant-producing alveolar type II (AT2) pneumocyte program, reflecting mature lung epithelial cells specialized for phospholipid secretion and innate defense. Evidence: • NKX2-1 (TTF-1) – master transcription factor for lung epithelial lineage and required for AT2 identity. • SFTPB and SFTA3 – core components of pulmonary surfactant, selectively expressed in AT2 cells. • SLC22A31 – organic ion transporter highly enriched in AT2 cells and co-regulated with surfactant genes. • KIF25, ERP27 – genes involved in vesicle trafficking and ER protein folding, supporting the heavy secretory load typical of AT2 pneumocytes. Inconsistencies: • No strongly contradictory genes; KIF25 and ERP27 are more ubiquitous but are compatible with a secretory epithelial context.

program_107.description: The gene set represents a neuroendocrine secretory program most consistent with mature pancreatic β-cells (and closely related peptide-secreting endocrine cells). Evidence: • SCGN (Secretagogin) – Ca²⁺-binding protein abundant in insulin-secreting β-cells and other neuroendocrine cells; promotes regulated exocytosis. • SCG2 (Secretogranin II) – Core component of secretory granules in endocrine and neuroendocrine cells, including pancreatic islets. • UCN3 (Urocortin 3) – Neuropeptide highly enriched in mature β-cells and used as a late marker of β-cell maturation. • INSM1 – Transcription factor required for endocrine differentiation; persists in mature islet endocrine and other neuroendocrine lineages. • Coordinated up-regulation of multiple granule/peptide-hormone genes (SCGN, SCG2, UCN3) together with the endocrine transcription factor INSM1 typifies a β-cell/neuroendocrine secretory identity. Inconsistencies: • CRYBA2 – Canonically a lens crystallin; its sporadic expression in pancreatic islets has been reported but is not widespread. • MS4A8 – Described mainly in intestinal epithelium; limited evidence for a role in β-cells, so its presence may reflect cross-tissue expression or technical noise.

program_108.description: The gene set reflects an actin-cytoskeleton remodeling and contractility program typical of cells in a motile/mesenchymal-like state (e.g., epithelial or endothelial cells undergoing epithelial–mesenchymal transition or activated stromal cells preparing for migration). Evidence: • ACTN4 and MYH9 – core components of stress fibers; their up-regulation accompanies lamellipodia formation and enhanced cell motility seen during EMT and wound-healing migration. • LIMA1 (EPLIN) and SPTAN1 – actin-bundling and spectrin scaffold proteins that reorganize adherens–junction–associated actin into contractile cables during transition to a migratory phenotype. • STK24 (MST3) – STE20-family kinase that phosphorylates cytoskeletal regulators and promotes focal-adhesion turnover and cell movement. • FYCO1 – autophagosome adaptor that couples vesicle trafficking to microtubules/actin, supporting cytoskeletal turnover needed in migrating cells. Inconsistencies: • Classic EMT transcription factors (e.g., SNAI1, ZEB1) or extracellular matrix genes (e.g., COL1A1, FN1) are not present, so the program may represent a partial or generic motility module rather than a full mesenchymal conversion.

program_109.description: The program represents a generic cytosolic heat-shock/proteotoxic-stress response that can be transiently triggered in virtually any cell type rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • HSPA1A / HSPA1B (inducible HSP70), HSPH1 (HSP110) – classical Heat Shock Factor 1 (HSF1) targets up-regulated upon thermal or proteotoxic stress to refold denatured proteins. • DNAJB1 and DNAJA1 – HSP40 family co-chaperones that deliver unfolded substrates to HSP70, hallmark components of the heat-shock chaperone machinery. • BAG3 – nucleotide-exchange factor for HSP70 that couples chaperoning to autophagic clearance of irreparable protein aggregates, typically induced during sustained stress. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes and no lineage-specific markers appear; the set is coherently aligned with a generalized heat-shock response.

program_110.description: The gene set is most consistent with a neuronal program, typical of cortical excitatory neurons or radial-glia–derived immature neurons that show active NRG1–ERBB3 signaling and high mitochondrial/ceramide metabolism. Evidence: • Neuronal identity – ADNP (neuronal developmental regulator), CERS6 (enriched in glutamatergic cortical neurons), PCMTD2 (brain-enriched). • Neuregulin pathway – ERBB3 is the canonical NRG1/HER3 receptor, highly expressed in developing radial glia and differentiating excitatory neurons. • High metabolic/mitochondrial activity expected in neurons – AKAP1 and LRPPRC regulate mitochondrial structure, RNA stability and oxidative phosphorylation, fitting the energy demand of neurons. Inconsistencies: • No strongly contradictory genes present; several genes (AKAP1, LRPPRC) are broadly expressed housekeeping/mitochondrial factors rather than neuron-specific, but they do not conflict with a neuronal interpretation.

program_111.description: The gene set most closely fits a vesicle-trafficking/autophagy program that is typically up-regulated in phagocytic innate-immune cells (monocytes-macrophages) when they engage lysosomal degradation and mitochondrial fatty-acid oxidation—i.e., a “phagolysosomal/autophagy activation” state rather than a lineage-defining signature. Evidence: • TM9SF3 – transmembrane protein required for phagosome acidification and lysosome function in professional phagocytes. • SH3GLB2 (Endophilin-B2) – drives membrane curvature during autophagosome biogenesis and mitophagy. • HEBP2 – mitochondrial heme-binding protein that triggers apoptosis/autophagy under stress. • ECI1 – mitochondrial β-oxidation enzyme, indicating increased fatty-acid catabolism that often accompanies macrophage activation and autophagy. • PDLIM1 – actin-binding adaptor enriched in macrophages; modulates cytoskeleton and NF-κB, both important for phagocytosis. • MAP2K2 (MEK2) – central MAPK component activated during inflammatory or stress-induced autophagy signaling. Inconsistencies: • Absence of canonical macrophage markers (LYZ, CD68, CSF1R, etc.) means the program alone does not definitively specify myeloid lineage and could represent a more generic cellular stress/autophagy module shared across cell types.

program_112.description: The gene set represents a glycolytic metabolic program (high aerobic-glycolysis/“Warburg” state) characteristic of rapidly proliferating or hypoxia-adapted cells rather than a specific lineage. Evidence: • GAPDH, ENO1, TPI1, PGK1, PKM – core glycolytic enzymes catalyzing sequential steps from glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to pyruvate, collectively up-regulated when glycolysis is elevated. • LDHA – converts pyruvate to lactate, a hallmark of aerobic glycolysis seen in dividing cancer cells, activated lymphocytes, stem cells, and hypoxic tissues. • Coordinated positive loading of multiple rate-limiting glycolytic genes without lineage-restricted markers points to a metabolic state rather than a defined cell type. Inconsistencies: • No clear inconsistencies; the list is uniformly composed of glycolytic genes with no contradictory lineage or pathway markers.

program_113.description: The gene set is most consistent with a gastric-type secretory epithelial program, characteristic of gastric foveolar (surface mucous) cells or pyloric-type metaplastic epithelium that secretes MUC5AC-rich mucus and expresses the stomach-restricted tight-junction protein CLDN18. Evidence: • MUC5AC – canonical gel-forming mucin of gastric foveolar cells and gastric-type metaplasia. • CLDN18 – tight-junction claudin isoform highly restricted to gastric epithelium (CLDN18.2) and retained in gastric metaplasia and early gastric cancer. • REG4 – secretory/goblet-like factor up-regulated in gastric mucosa during injury and metaplasia, frequently co-expressed with MUC5AC and CLDN18. • Co-occurrence of several secretory genes (MUC5AC, REG4, CLDN18) without classical intestinal absorptive markers supports a gastric rather than intestinal lineage. Inconsistencies: • CCK – hallmark of enteroendocrine I-cells of the intestine; its presence suggests either a mixed epithelial program or low-level endocrine contamination. • MSMB – classically prostate-enriched; rarely reported in stomach, so may represent background expression or a minority contaminating population.

program_114.description: The gene set reflects squamous epithelial/epidermal keratinocytes that are in a stress- or wound-activated, late-differentiation (cornification) state, characterized by enhanced cornified-envelope formation and protease activity. Evidence: • Cornified-envelope components up-regulated (SPRR1B, SPRR2D, SPRR3) – hallmark of terminally differentiating keratinocytes forming the skin barrier. • KRT17 – keratin induced in activated/wound-edge basal keratinocytes and hyperproliferative epidermis, supporting a repair/stress program. • KLK10 – kallikrein protease enriched in stratified epithelium and involved in desquamation, consistent with late keratinocyte differentiation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent given the limited gene list; all listed genes fit a squamous/epidermal activation–cornification program.

program_115.description: This program reflects a Wnt-high intestinal epithelial stem/progenitor state, resembling Lgr5⁺ crypt base columnar cells that sit at the bottom of the intestinal crypt and display strong negative-feedback regulation of canonical Wnt signaling. Evidence: • NOTUM, NKD1, APCDD1 – canonical Wnt target genes whose products dampen Wnt signaling; all are transcriptionally enriched in Lgr5⁺ intestinal stem cells. • TNFRSF19 (TROY) – surface receptor highly expressed in crypt stem cells and frequently used as an alternative marker for Lgr5⁺ intestinal stem cells. • Concordant co-expression of multiple independent Wnt feedback inhibitors (NOTUM, NKD1, APCDD1) indicates a cell population experiencing high Wnt stimulation, characteristic of crypt base stem/progenitors rather than differentiated villus cells. • COLGALT2 – although not a classic stem-cell marker, is expressed in rapidly renewing epithelial compartments and supports collagen processing within the stem-cell niche, fitting a crypt environment. Inconsistencies: • COLGALT2 is also seen in fibroblasts and other mesenchymal cells, so its presence is less specific for intestinal stem cells and could reflect stromal contamination or general ECM-related expression.

program_116.description: The gene set most parsimoniously reflects an epithelial / cardiomyocyte-like program centered on desmosome assembly and cortical cytoskeleton organization, with possible engagement of stress- or apoptosis-related signaling. Evidence: • DSP (Desmoplakin) – core component of desmosomes; highly expressed in cardiomyocytes and stratified epithelia where strong cell–cell adhesion is required. • ADD3 (Adducin-γ) – spectrin–actin–membrane linker that stabilizes the cortical cytoskeleton and works with junctional complexes, complementing DSP-mediated adhesion. • PAWR (PAR-4) – stress-induced, pro-apoptotic regulator that is up-regulated in cardiomyocytes and epithelial cells during mechanical or oxidative stress, fitting a “junction + stress” state. • ZKSCAN1 – zinc-finger transcription factor implicated in regulation of cytoskeletal and junctional genes, supporting a transcriptional program that governs adhesion/structure. • LRBA – vesicle-trafficking protein involved in recycling of membrane receptors; coherent with the need to shuttle junctional proteins to and from the plasma membrane. Inconsistencies: • LRBA is best known for roles in immunocytes; its inclusion is compatible but not specific for epithelial or cardiomyocyte states. • Absence of canonical cardiomyocyte contractile genes (e.g., TNNT2, MYH6) or epithelial keratins leaves some ambiguity between cardiac and general epithelial junction programs.

program_117.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature alveolar type I (AT1) epithelial cell program, reflecting cells that have completed or are undergoing AT1 differentiation in the lung. Evidence: • EMP2 – well-validated surface marker of AT1 cells and a constituent of the canonical AGER/PDPN/EMP2 AT1 signature. • NFIA and NFIC – Nuclear Factor I family transcription factors that drive and maintain AT1 fate; loss of NFIA impairs AT1 differentiation in mouse lung. • BDH2 – mitochondrial dehydrogenase enriched in the highly oxidative AT1 compartment, fitting the metabolic shift that accompanies AT1 maturation. • BEX3 – although first described in neurons, single-cell lung atlases show its up-regulation in AT1 cells and in the AT2→AT1 transitional population, consistent with an AT1-associated program. Inconsistencies: • BEX3 has broader expression and strong neuronal annotation, so its presence is not uniquely AT1-specific and may signal some off-target or stress-related expression.

program_118.description: This gene program reflects a “male-cell signature” marking cells that carry a Y chromosome rather than any specific differentiated cell type or activation state. Evidence: • RPS4Y1, EIF1AY – Y-linked housekeeping ribosomal and translation-initiation factors broadly expressed in all male (XY) cells. • DDX3Y – Y-linked RNA helicase with ubiquitous expression in male somatic and germ cells. • UTY – Y-linked histone demethylase expressed across many male cell types. • USP9Y – Y-linked de-ubiquitinase transcribed in diverse male tissues. Collectively, concurrent high expression of multiple non-ampliconic Y-chromosome genes is a canonical indicator that the profiled cell originates from a male individual. Inconsistencies: • None detected; all listed genes are core housekeeping genes located on the Y chromosome and coherently support a male-cell identity.
